Modern miniature digital detectors present an opportunity to assess x-ray tube focal spots more conveniently and more quantitatively. Our lab has two pinhole apertures (30 and 75 microns; Fluke Biomedical) for focal spot imaging; and a Hamamatsu S11684-12 intra-oral dental detector with a 1000x1500 array of 20 micron elements. This element size is smaller than needed for recording patient images but it is perfect for recording in detail the x-ray tube focal spot emission pattern. This usage has been evaluated by a previous student who demonstrated that although the focal spot pinhole images are faint; their acquisition is possible using manual mode. Addition of exposures results in a focal spot intensity map. Building on this work; the intern will (i) configure a mounting system to align the detector; pinhole and x-ray tube to make a focal spot inspection camera; (ii) write scripts in Matlab for image summation; projections and other analysis; and (iii) the camera will be tested on two general radiology tubes and two C-arm tubes. The tradeoffs of using the 30 versus 75 micron pinholes will be investigated. Focal spot characteristics will be measured versus tube potential (50 to 120 kV) and current (50 to 300 mA).
Skills: Appropriate preparation for this project would be courses in modern physics and a senior physics laboratory; plus experience with programming; which optimally will include practical knowledge of Matlab. Programming will be in the Windows environment. In the lab; the intern will be expected to work with ionizing radiation. Although my lab’s interest is medical applications; the emphasis is on technology and prior life sciences courses are not expected. This project can provide an interesting mix of physics analysis; experiment; computation; and instrument mechanical design.

Name: Image-based soil organic matter characterization for sustainable management
Description: Soil organic matter (SOM) is considered as the backbone of soil health or soil quality and influences many physical; chemical and biological properties and processes. For example; SOM influences soil structure; affects water holding capacity; nutrient contributions; biological activity; water infiltration; air exchange; pesticide activity; soil compressibility; and shear strength. It is a critically important property that determines soil functionality and use. Proper characterization of SOM can help make informed management decisions for agro-environmental operations. The two most common methods of SOM estimation are Walkley Black acid digestion and weight loss on ignition. However; the requirement of specialized equipment's; trained professionals; time for analysis and sample preparation; cost; and labor pose challenges in measuring SOM on a large number of samples in order to characterize and map soils with high spatial variability. Spectroscopic characteristics measured using Vis-NIR or NIR sensors have shown promise in predicting SOM in laboratory ex-situ conditions or at the field in situ conditions. However; the high price and often the portability of these instruments restrict their common use. With the advancement of imaging techniques and the development of computing powers; computer vision-based image analysis techniques show promise to characterize soil properties including SOM as it contributes to the color of the soil. Along with good cameras and other advanced imaging techniques; cell phones became an increasingly popular device for photographs. The availability of cell phones with high processing power and image collection capability could provide us new ways to characterize soil. This project aims to develop a cell phone app to characterize SOM. In developing the app; reliable and robust image analysis algorithms need to be developed. So; the first part of the project is to develop an algorithm that can analyze images of various qualities and then develop an app for cell phones.
Skills: A strong background in cell phone app development; computer programming; and image processing is required with desirable knowledge on image collection or photography using different types of camera; taking the photographs of soil samples; collecting and processing soil samples in the laboratory and in the field; and setting up laboratory conditions to take images. Knowledge of coding (mainly in Matlab) to automatize the image processing algorithm and image collection system using a computer is required. Critical thinking and comprehending knowledge are also required in this project.
Student academic background: Agriculture; Computer Science; Earth Science; Electronic Systems; Engg-Biological; Engg-Chemical; Engg-Civil; Engg-Computer; Engg-Electrical; Engg-Enviromental; Engg-Enviromental; Engg-Geological; Engg-Mechanical; Engg-Mining; Engg-Software; Engg-Systems and Technology; Engineering; Environmental Studies; Geology; Geomatics; Land Information; Mathematics; Physics; Soil Science; Statistics

Name: Developing computer vision algorithms for characterizing soil properties
Description: Soil properties vary from location to location. Therefore; we need to measure a large number of soil samples In order to characterize soil properly. However; most of the soil properties are time-consuming; laborious; and expensive to measure which calls for new methods to overcome the issues. With the advancement of imaging techniques and the development of computing powers; computer vision-based image analysis techniques show promise to characterize soil properties. Developing reliable and robust image analysis algorithms can provide a large number of opportunities to characterize soil quickly and cheaply. Soil texture (percent sand silt and clay fractions in soil) is an important factor for the decision-making of a large number of agricultural management operations; civil engineering applications; and other industries. Similarly; soil organic matter is considered the backbone of soil health and quality. This project aims to develop a reliable and robust computer vision algorithm to characterize soil texture and organic matter. In general; soil texture and organic matter are affected by the presence of soil moisture. Previously some attempts have been made to characterize soil texture and soil organic matter using computer vision techniques. However; the challenge lies in the effectiveness of those algorithms as the image quality is often affected by soil moisture. A new algorithm to be developed or organized by combining several old algorithms to characterize soil properties. Examining the effect of soil moisture on the image quality and the performance of the newly developed algorithms on those images would provide a new way to characterize soil properties specifically soil texture and soil organic matter.
Skills: A background in computer programming and image processing is required with desirable knowledge on image collection or photography using different types of cameras; taking photographs of soil samples; collecting and processing soil samples in the laboratory and in the field; and setting up laboratory conditions to take images. Knowledge of coding (Matlab/R/Python) to automatize the image processing algorithm and image collection system using a computer is required. Critical thinking and comprehending knowledge are also required in this project.

Name: Revival of Viable But Non-Culturable Pathogens from Food and Environmental Samples
Description: Through research we have identified that pathogens can enter a Viable But Non-Culturable (VBNC) state whereby cells remain viable but cannot be cultured using standard plating techniques. Of significance; pathogens in the VBNC state can remain infectious and hence food safety risks frequently under-estimated. Previously; there have been attempts to enumerate VBNC through using viability staining coupled to molecular based methods. However; due to the cells being in a dormant state such approaches have limited success in differentiating between dormant and non-viable cells. The current project will develop novel approaches to detect or revive dormant cells thereby providing accurate data that can be applied for risk assessment. Once the method for recovering VBNC has been optimized this will be applied to assess the survival of pathogens in the inputs of CEA along with the final plants. The inactivation of VBNC relative to normal cells treated with biological; chemical or physical intervention methods will be assessed. The intervention methods will include protective cultures (probiotics); plasma-activated water; and a process based on gas-phase hydroxyl radical process. Of interest will be to assess if VBNC cells have enhanced resistance to treatments and retain viability. Here; the inputs into CEA will be inoculated with the test pathogen then the intervention measures optimized for microbial reduction without negatively affecting seed germination/plant development. The inactivation kinetics will be modeled then use to devise and provide a prediction of the optimal treatment parameters that will subsequently be verified
Skills: The project will suit someone with a background in food science or microbiology. The techniques to be applied will include pathogen handling; enumeration and characterization. Full training will be provided in other methods such as enzyme assays; plant propagation and sampling.

Name: Development of Solid-State Nanopores-based Single-Molecule Bionanotechnologies.
Description: Our lab is focused on developing a new type of low cost; portable; ultra-sensitive electronic biosensing system based on solid-state nanopore technology. Our goal is to develop a platform technology that can be deployed in a wide variety of health and diagnostics-related applications; including wearables; implantable sensors; low-cost sensors for developing countries; biodefense; and remote environmental monitoring. We have developed the only low-cost; scalable method of fabricating solid-state nanopores - nanometer sized holes in thin insulating membranes like silicon nitride. Nanopores are just large enough to allow biomolecules like DNA and RNA to pass through one at a time; with each translocation generating a unique electrical signal as the molecule temporarily blocks current flow through the pore. We are now focused on refining this nanoscale fabrication technology and integrating it with custom-designed molecular labels; and methods to manipulate biomolecules to accurately detect disease at the earliest possible stages; when there are just a few molecules present in a biological sample.
Skills: Specific skills and experience (this is a diverse list so we don't expect any students to possess all of these; you will acquire them during this project) • Experimentation: designing; conducting; and analyzing high quality; controlled experiments to understand an issue • Theory: applying theoretical understanding (thermodynamics; electrostatics; mechanics; surface chemistry etc.) to justify the best course of action (whether a design or experimental program) • Design: intuitive understanding of mechanical; electrical; and fluidic systems; and experience with CAD programs (SolidWorks; Inventor; etc.) • Hands-on prototyping experience: 3D printing; hand and power tools; wiring; soldering; hacking; building; gluing; fasteners; etc.
Student academic background: Biological Sciences; Chemistry; Engg-Biomedical; Engg-Biological; Engg-Electrical; Engg-Materials; Engg-Mechanical; Engineering; Molecular Biology; Physics

Name: High-speed optical 3D imaging: development and applications
Description: In general; the intern(s) will closely work with graduate students and postdoctoral fellows in LACI in developing novel BLIP systems [Opt. Express 30; 19824(2022); Photonics Res 8; 1808(2020); Opt Lett 45; 964(2020)] for applications in biomedicine and advanced manufacturing. Projects include the following four areas: 1. Assemble the optical imaging system The intern(s) will learn how to operate incoherent light sources (e.g; light emitting diode and superluminal diode) coherent light sources (e.g.; lasers); and light modulation devices (e.g.; digital micromirror device and electro-optic modulator). The intern(s) will also learn how to use various optical components and opto-mechanical components. Upon mastering this knowledge; the intern(s) will be assigned to build a module for an optical imaging instrument under construction. They will learn how to precisely align each optical component to achieve the optimized imaging quality. 2. Develop system control software The intern(s) will learn knowledge about system control; such as generating TTL and analog signals; signal characterization; and LabVIEW programming. Upon mastering these skills; the intern(s) will be assigned to develop system control software using the LabVIEW interface to synchronize the light source; the modulator; and the camera in an optical imaging system under development. 3. Write image reconstruction and processing scripts The intern(s) will learn various imaging reconstruction algorithms; such as back projection and compressed sensing. In addition; the intern(s) will learn various imaging calibration methods (e.g.; projective transformation). Upon mastering this knowledge; the intern(s) will be assigned to write scripts for processing acquired experimental data. 4. Analyze experimental data The intern(s) will learn data analysis methods; such as statistical comparison and curve fitting to evaluate experimental data. Specific tasks may include automated data selection; feature extraction; and statistical evaluation. Under auspicious scenarios; the intern(s) may summarize and disseminate the results; in either a conference proceeding or a journal paper.
Skills: Applicants should be enrolled in an undergraduate major in Electrical Engineering; Automation Control; Optical/Optoelectronic Engineering; Biomedical Engineering; Physics; Computer Science and Engineering; or a related field. Preferences will be given to candidates with a strong background in applied optics; physical optics; digital/analog electronics design; system automation and control (using LabVIEW interface); imaging reconstruction and processing (using Matlab and C++); biology; and/or acoustics. Previous internship experience in a research laboratory is highly desired. Proficiency in English (e.g.; TOEFL; IELTS and/or GRE scores) is a plus. Experience in optical design software (e.g.; Zemax or CodeV) is a plus; but not necessary.

Name: Ultrafast intelligent camera: Development and application
Description: In general; the intern(s) will closely work with graduate students and postdocs in LACI in learning and playing with compressed ultrafast photography (CUP) [Nat. Comm. 12; 6401 (2021); Laser&Photonnics Rev 14; 2000122; Photonics Res. 9; 2464 (2021); Opt. Lett. 44; 1387 (2019)]. Projects include the following four areas: 1. Simulation of CUP imaging concepts The intern(s) will learn about the forward and backward models of CUP. The interns will be asked to simulate the performance of different illumination schemes; (e.g.; chirped pulse or ultrafast pulse train generation). Then; they will be assigned to simulate these models using existing software frameworks; e.g.; TwIST; ADMM; and/or machine learning. They will analyze the reconstructed image quality using different criteria and optimize the performance of the image formation and image reconstruction in simulation. 2. Implement new image concepts in an actual CUP system Working with the graduate students and/or postdocs in my group; the intern(s) will learn how to operate the CUP system. They will learn the knowledge of different light sources (e.g; an ultrafast laser); and light modulation devices (e.g.; digital micromirror device and electro-optic modulator). The intern(s) will also learn how to use various optical components and opto-mechanical components. Upon mastering this knowledge; the intern(s) will learn how to implement the simulation results into the CUP system and make modifications if necessary. 4. Analyze and summarize experimental data The intern(s) will learn data analysis methods; such as statistical comparison and curve fitting to evaluate experimental data. Specific tasks may include automated data selection; feature extraction; and statistical evaluation. Under auspicious scenarios; the intern(s) may summarize and disseminate the results; in either a conference proceeding or a journal paper.
Skills: Applicants should be enrolled in an undergraduate major in Electrical Engineering; Automation Control; Optical/Optoelectronic Engineering; Biomedical Engineering; Physics; Computer Science and Engineering; or a related field. Preferences will be given to candidates with a strong background in applied optics; physical optics; digital/analog electronics design; system automation; and control (using LabVIEW interface); imaging reconstruction and processing (using Matlab and C++); biology; and/or acoustics. Previous internship experience in a research laboratory is highly desired. Proficiency in English (e.g.; TOEFL; IELTS; and/or GRE scores) is a plus. Experience in optical design software (e.g.; Zemax or CodeV) is a plus; but not necessary.
Student academic background: Engg-Biomedical; Engg-Electrical; Physics; Computer Science; Engg-Computer; Biological Sciences; Engg-Biological; Electronic Systems; Engg-Materials; Engg-Software; Engg-Systems and Technology; Engineering

Name: Satellite remote sensing of the Earth climate
Description: This project will use modeled and actual satellite data to study the co-variations of atmospheric state and radiation variables; to support the development of a new satellite for observing greenhouse gases; aerosols and clouds in extreme weather and climate change.
Skills: Having taken introductory courses in meteorology; atmospheric science and physics; ability to use Linux computers; data analysis skills with Matlab or Python.

Name: Ultrahigh-speed single-pixel camera: Development and application
Description: In general; the intern(s) will closely work with graduate students and postdocs in LACI in learning and playing with single-pixel imaging accelerated by swept aggregate patterns (SPI-ASAP) [Nat. Comm. 13; 7879 (2022); Opt. Express 28 (20); 29377 (2020)]. SPI-ASAP exhibits one of the fastest general-purpose single-pixel camera. Projects include the following three areas: 1. Simulation of SPI-ASAP imaging concepts The intern(s) will learn about the forward and backward models of SPI-ASAP. The interns will be asked to simulate the performance of different active and passive illumination schemes. Then; they will be assigned to simulate these models using existing software frameworks; e.g.; direct interpolation-and-inversion; TwIST; ADMM; and/or machine learning. They will analyze the reconstructed image quality using different criteria and optimize the performance of the image formation and image reconstruction in simulation. 2. Implement new image concepts in an actual SPI-ASAP system Working with the graduate students and/or postdocs in my group; the intern(s) will learn how to operate the SPI-ASAP system. They will learn the knowledge of different light sources (e.g; an ultrafast laser); light modulation devices (e.g.; digital micromirror device and electro-optic modulator); and detector (e.g.; SPAD). The intern(s) will also learn how to use various optical components and opto-mechanical components. Upon mastering this knowledge; the intern(s) will learn how to implement the simulation results into the CUP system and make modifications if necessary. 3. Analyze and summarize experimental data The intern(s) will learn data analysis methods; such as statistical comparison and curve fitting to evaluate experimental data. Specific tasks may include automated data selection; feature extraction; and statistical evaluation. Under auspicious scenarios; the intern(s) may summarize and disseminate the results; in either a conference proceeding or a journal paper.
Skills: Applicants should be enrolled in an undergraduate major in Electrical Engineering; Automation Control; Optical/Optoelectronic Engineering; Biomedical Engineering; Physics; Computer Science and Engineering; or a related field. Preferences will be given to candidates with a strong background in applied optics; physical optics; digital/analog electronics design; system automation; and control (using LabVIEW interface); imaging reconstruction and processing (using Matlab and C++); biology; and/or acoustics. Previous internship experience in a research laboratory is highly desired. Proficiency in English (e.g.; TOEFL; IELTS; and/or GRE scores) is a plus. Experience in optical design software (e.g.; Zemax or CodeV) is a plus; but not necessary.
Student academic background: Engg-Biomedical; Engg-Electrical; Physics; Computer Science; Engg-Computer; Biological Sciences; Engg-Biological; Electronic Systems; Engg-Materials; Engg-Software; Engg-Systems and Technology; Engineering

Name: Is Alzheimer's diseases caused by hidden viruses in our brain?
Description: Several aspects of AD pathophysiology remain unknown. Accumulation of misfolded protein in the cytoplasm; and amyloid plaques outside the neurons as well as inflammation are a few topics that are actively researched. We also know that many genes undergo expressional changes and many vital proteins are abnormally decreased or increased in the brain tissue of AD patients. However; the cause of these changes is still unknown. As he human life expectancy is increased; it is estimated that the number of patients with dementia and the cost of health care will increase significantly for the next two decades. Therefore; it is very important to find new treatments for dementia. In this project we will be looking at the nucleus of the nerve cells; as it contains the chromatin and controls all cellular functions. We and others have shown that the nuclear envelope on neurons shrinks in AD; and this causes changes in chromatin compaction and affects gene expression. Human DNA composed of large portion of non-human DNA including ancient retroviruses that are incorporated in our genome. We ask whether the pathology associated with AD can be caused by expression retroviral proteins that are awaken after nuclear envelope shrinkage. We have identified the molecular players that cause these changes; and plan to see if we can prevent these changes. The student assistants in this project will learn neuronal biology by working in the lab and assessing specific molecular signalling pathways. Student will learn neuronal culture; assessing changes in gene and protein after nuclear damage. Microscopy and image analysis and statistical analysis are other techniques that they will acquire during this internship. Senior students will closely tutor the student assistants to provide real contribution to the project in hand. Winnipeg's summers are very beautiful; making this internship very memorable time for the students.
Skills: -Students in all disciplines of Biology that have taken courses in Biochemistry; cell biology and molecular biology can apply for this position. Also students in Medicine and Dentistry will be considered. Hands on experience with animal cell culture is a bonus but not essential for this project. We will provide sufficient opportunity for the student to learn the techniques. Students will be pre-selected based on their transcripts and final selection will be based on an online interview. These projects require good learning capability as well as communication skills. Future graduate student positions are available for the students.

Name: A la découverte de la Fransaskoisie
Description: Parmi les communautés francophones du Canada; les "Fransaskois" sont parmi les moins connus. Vous aurez la chance découvrir cette communauté vibrante; grâce à un travail collaboratif avec la Société historique de la Saskatchewan. Vous devrez notamment numériser le journal communautaire "L'Eau vive" et indexer les articles de façon thématique. Vous aurez aussi à développer une liste des archives liées à la Fransaskoisie qui sont conservées un peu partout à travers la province (au sein d'institutions municipales; congrégations religieuses; collections privées). Votre contribution sera cruciale pour faire mieux connaître la communauté fransaskoise. Les résultats de vos recherche seront affichés sur un site internet; facilitant le travail d'autres chercheurs dans une variété de disciplines (histoire; sociologie; science politique; linguistique; communications; etc.).
Skills: maîtrise du français; intérêt pour le sujet; capacité de travailler de façon minutieuse

Name: Statistical challenges in individual participant data meta analysis
Description: In a typical meta analysis; estimates of the parameter of interest (e.g. odds ratio) are extracted from the literature or by contacting researchers and pooled together. In contrast; for IPD-MA line-by-line patient data are obtained from each study. IPD-MA data permit researchers to define exposures and outcomes consistently across studies; and to analyze the association of interest consistently (e.g. adjusting for the same confounders); which may minimize heterogeneity. IPD-MA are of particular value for synthesis of observational studies. In traditional MAs based on published data; it is difficult to investigate differences between study results; to adjust for differences in populations across studies and to pool effects that have been adjusted for other variables. IPD-MA have higher power than meta-regression to detect covariate-treatment interactions; and are preferable when the aim is to estimate interactions with patient-level covariates. IPD-MA are not prone to ecological bias; because patient-level data are not aggregated. While in some cases IPD-MA and aggregate data MA may give similar results; this is unlikely when evaluating treatment-covariate interactions; incorporating nonlinear relationships; when trials are small; and there is heterogeneity across trials; and particularly for pooling of non-randomized studies that may need to adjust for several confounders. For these reasons; IPD-MA are considered the gold-standard of MA; despite the complexity and cost of collecting the data; and are published with increasing frequency. The student and the supervisor will work together to determine a suitable project in this domain; considering the skills; abilities and interests of the student.
Skills: The ideal candidate is a student completing an undergraduate degree in Mathematics or Statistics. Students from other quantitative disciplines with some statistics classes will be considered. Programming skills; particularly in R; are an asset. Knowledge of epidemiology and/or health research experience is also an asset.

Name: Examining the role of Secretion Associated Ras-related GTPase-1B (SAR1B) in muscle nutrient sensing and metabolism
Description: Despite SAR1B expression being the highest in skeletal muscle as compared to other tissues; prior studies have only examined the role of SAR1B in the hepatocyte and enterocyte. Whether SAR1B mediate the metabolic effects of BCAA and BCKA in the skeletal muscle is yet to be explored. Hypothesis: Gain of SAR1B function would decrease activation of mTOR; potentiate insulin signaling; and counter metabolic and signaling actions of BCAA and BCKA. Methods: Student will examine whether exposure of skeletal and cardiac muscle cells to higher lipids and/or amino acids alters SAR1B expression and its GTPase activity. Ex vivo and in vitro; C2C12 (mouse myotubes) and H9C2 (rat cardiomyofibroblasts) cell lines will be incubated with high glucose; palmitate; BCAAs and BCKAs for 4; 8; 12 and 16 h; and SAR1B protein and mRNA expression will be measured by immunoblotting analysis and quantitative-PCR (qPCR); respectively. To recapitulate these findings in vivo; SAR1B protein and gene expression will be ascertained in adult mouse cardiomyocytes as well as soleus; gastrocnemius; tibialis and extensor digitorum longus (EDL) of both male and female C57BL6/J mice fed either chow or high-fat high sucrose diets for 4; 8; 12; weeks. Next student will determine if loss or gain of SAR1B function alters insulin signaling in the presence and absence of BCAA; BCKA and high palmitate. Differentiated C2C12 and H9C2 cells will be subjected to siRNA mediated silencing of SAR1B or adenoviral overexpression of SAR1B; followed by exposure to high glucose; palmitate; BCAA and BCKA for 4; 8; 12 and 16h. Cells will then be treated with 100 nM insulin before immunoblotting analysis to examine the expression of genes encoding markers of insulin signaling. Significance: Specifically; this research is expected to uncover the non-canonical role of Sar1B in muscle nutrient-sensing; insulin signaling and its linkages to cellular metabolism; and function.
Skills: Student must possess an undergraduate level background in cellular biochemistry or molecular biology or physiology or pharmacology. Student must have good grades and a reasonable understanding of laboratory research and work culture. Student must be willing to learn and work in a team of research staff ranging from graduate students; fellows and technicians. Recruited student will be expected to work with chemicals; biomaterials; and animals for which adequate training will be provided. At the end of the program student will be expected to publish the work with inputs from the supervisor.
Student academic background: Biochemistry; Biological Sciences; Biology; Medicine; Medical Sciences; Molecular Biology; Nutrition; Pharmacology; Pharmacy; Physiology; Pathology; Zoology

Name: Role of transcription factor EB in cardiac metabolism and function
Description: Rationale: miRNAs are a class of molecules that regulate intracellular gene expression and protein content. Indeed; miRNA-132/212; miRNA 29a; and miRNA30b reduce TFEB gene expression and protein content. During lipotoxicity; whether high palmitate increases the expression of microRNAs targeting TFEB remains to be examined. Hypothesis: Palmitate overload increases the expression of miRNA targeting TFEB to inactivate TFEB in the cardiomyocyte. Objectives: Aim i) To examine if lipid (palmitate) overload activates miRNAs inhibiting myocyte TFEB expression. qPCR expression analysis of miRNA targeting TFEB (miRNA29; miR30; miR132/212) will be performed in BSA or palmitate treated H9C2 rat cardio myofibroblasts; C2C12 mouse myotubes and adult mouse cardiomyocytes. miRNA profiling will also be conducted in cardiomyocytes from C57BL6J mice fed chow and 6 week high fat fed animals. By comparing miRNA profiles between cell lines; primary cells and cardiac tissue; we will characterize the specific miRNA that targets TFEB; setting the stage for subsequent antagomir (miRNA inhibitors) studies. Aim ii) To investigate if antagomir-mediated inhibition of miRNA targeting TFEB prevents TFEB decline during lipotoxicity rescuing metabolic dysfunction and cell injury during obesity and diabetes. H9C2; C2C12 cells and adult cardiomyocytes will be pre/co-treated with TFEB miRNA antagomirs and then subjected to BSA or palmitate overload. Readout for the proposed experiments will include the determination of lipid droplet size and number; TFEB expression; mitochondrial respiration; cell death and organelle (mitochondrial and lysosomal) function assays. Significance: miRNA antagomirs treatment will ensure that TFEB content is not declining during lipotoxicity; thereby attenuating cardiometabolic complications during obesity and diabetes. Since TFEB is indispensable for lysosomal function; characterizing miRNAs targeting TFEB in the cardiomyocyte would lead to a druggable target for obesity and diabetes-related cardiomyopathy.
Skills: Student must possess an undergraduate level background in cellular biochemistry or molecular biology or physiology or pharmacology. Student must have good grades and a reasonable understanding of laboratory research and work culture. Student must be willing to learn and work in a team of research staff ranging from graduate students; fellows and technicians. Recruited student will be expected to work with chemicals; biomaterials; and animals for which adequate training will be provided. At the end of the program student will be expected to publish the work with inputs from supervisor.

Name: Next-Generation Database Engines
Description: Data-intensive systems (in particular database systems) are a fundamental building block that powers today's digital infrastructure and applications such as machine learning; data mining and blockchains. The making of these systems is heavily shaped by computer hardware; which is going through radical changes and brings both challenges and opportunities. Prior designs; though still work; will not fully reap the benefits of new hardware such as persistent memory (e.g.; Intel Optane DC) that allows data to be persisted without high-overhead storage stack (e.g.; SSDs); manycore processors that feature hundreds of CPU cores; and new networking devices that allow users to run customized logics to achieve line-rate speeds. This research project aims to bridge this gap in software and hardware and devise a next-generating database systems in the context of modern hardware. The project will devise a series of techniques and system components touching upon topics like concurrency and parallelism; transactions; parallel programming and distributed systems. Specifically; we will focus on the making of database engines for persistent memory; next-generation solid state drives including computational SSDs; new interconnects such as CXL and fast RDMA networks. Based on these new components; a full system that fit the characteristics of and perform well on such new hardware will be built and evaluated against prior work.
Skills: - Solid C/C++ programming skills. - Experience in multi-threaded; concurrent programming. - Knowledge in characteristics of modern hardware features; e.g.; multicore processors; multi-socket (NUMA) architecture; modern storage devices (e.g.; PCIe SSDs; persistent memory). - Related core courses; e.g.; database systems; systems programming; distributed systems; operating systems; computer architecture/organization. - Relevant experience working in areas such as operating systems; database systems and distributed systems not mandatory but a plus.

Name: Visualization of for solving Very Large Scale problems in Physical Design
Description: In this research; we will first develop a game as a visualization tool for the design automation of digital circuits. An interactive visualization tool will be developed to solve real-world problems from the circuit design. The project will have these phases: The development of the visualization tool analyzes the solutions obtained from the tool; the development of algorithms for further improvement of the solution quality; and finally the application of game mechanics to the tool.
Skills: Programming in C++ or Java Good communication skills Team player Collaborative

Name: Advanced data analytics and machine learning tools for development for traffic systems with regards to sustainability and social justice
Description: The recent advancement in transportation systems such as autonomous vehicles along with the concerns related to the climate crisis will fundamentally transform our personal mobility and the design of our cities. The purpose of this research proposal is to improve and build upon a developed framework that simulates the integration of autonomous vehicles in city infrastructure. The framework will advance the complex and dynamic transportation infrastructure systems while supporting users and improving the mobility; environmental quality; equity; safety and security of urban areas. The focus is on the four emerging technological trends; namely sharing; automation; connectivity and electrification; which will be harnessed; managed and directed within the developed holistic framework to meet our sustainability and societal goals.
Skills: The student needs to be able to program in C++ or Python programming language. The student needs to have an open mind on learning new things and integrating ideas together.

Name: À la recherche des phéromones des limaces
Description: Slugs are formidable herbivores; but they seem vulnerable with their slow movement and lack of physical defence such as a shell. However; they manage to survive as they can be observed in large numbers in forests and gardens. The key to their success lies in their ability to produce mucus; a viscous liquid made up mainly of water; which serves as a lubricant for movement; a means of defence and an intraspecific recognition system. As a result of work done by my research group; molecules of the terpene family have been discovered in several slug species. At this time; the function of these molecules is unknown. The structure of the identified molecules bears a striking resemblance to onocerin; a molecule found in many plants. This similarity suggests that the slugs acquire onocerin and then transform it into the derivatives they need. This role could also be played by the animal's microbiota. In order to adequately study terpenes from slugs; it is necessary to isolate enough of them to perform a variety of experiments. Since capturing slugs in the forest is laborious; it would be appropriate to keep specimens in captivity and feed them to increase their biomass. However; we must ensure that the desired metabolites will not be diluted during captivity. The objective of this research project is therefore to evaluate the concentration of certain secondary metabolites in slugs during their maintenance in captivity. To do this; slugs will be captured in the forest and then kept in captivity by feeding them easily accessible food. Throughout their captivity; the mass of the specimens will be measured and the concentration of metabolites evaluated by LCMS.
Skills: The student must have skills in prototype design; electronics; programming and statistics. He/she should also have a basic knowledge of chemistry and/or biology in order to understand the objectives of the work. The student will have to demonstrate a high degree of autonomy since he/she will be joining a group of chemists with little experience in prototype design.

Name: Optimizing Federated-Learning in Wireless Networks usng Deep Reinforcement Learning
Description: The project proposes to explore Deep Reinforcement Learning (DRL) approaches to optimize the performance of wireless networks that are dedicated to asynchronous federated learning. Federated learning is an approach of distributed machine learning where data is kept locally on different devices or servers; while the model is trained cooperatively. The objective of this project is to explore DRL approaches to solve specific problems encountered in asynchronous federated learning. These issues include managing wireless resources; optimizing power consumption; reducing latency; and improving the transmission quality of service.
Skills: Wireless networking and wireless communications. Evaluation of algorithms complexity. Machine learning. Deep reinforcement learning. Wireless network simulations (ex.; Python).

Name: Using machine learning to identify noise aspects in log files
Description: Software systems in production generate data; services; and facilities for their users. But as it runs; it also needs to create other information about the system execution. The log files hold this information; which will be helpful to DevOps engineers; monitoring and observability systems; ensuring the good health of the system; preventing attacks; and even as a basis for investigating any system failures. What are the scenarios; settings; and data capable of generating noise in log files? What data characterize the information desired in the log files; and what information is unwanted? From a knowledge base about logs; one way to reach this objective is to apply Machine Learning (ML) techniques to analyze the lines of the log files to find the noises of these contained in them. In this project; we will research existing log libraries; interview system operators to understand the scenarios in which logs are used; and what information is desired and unwanted from these scenarios. Thus; we will build a Machine Learning (ML) model to evaluate the log files and their noise level from the collected responses. The project product will support students in the context of UQAC's bachelor with a major in software with knowledge in monitoring; logging; and machine learning.
Skills: The student’s required skills are Python and JavaScript programming languages as well as web technologies such as Node.js and concepts on databases such as SQL. Solving problem capability; communication curiosity and proactivity are desired for this project. The student has to be interested in text manipulation and Artificial Intelligence (AI) approaches like Machine Learning.

Name: Machine Learning techniques for improving the user-base station association in future cellular networks
Description: To tackle the mobility challenges in the next generation of cellular networks (5G and beyond); we aim to propose a centralised mobility-aware user-base station association strategy based on a learning method. As a model system; we propose a hybrid heterogeneous network with the co-existence of sub-6 GHz macro-cell base station; sub-6 GHz small-cell base stations and millimetre wave small-cell base stations. To reduce the need for frequent update of association between a user and a base station; we propose to make the macro-cell base station learn the best association by predicting the future position of mobile users. In other words; after learning and based on the predicted position of mobile users; the macro-cell base station will be able to determine for each user the base station he will be associated with. To perform prediction on the location of mobile users; we propose using a machine learning technique such as deep learning; support vector machine and reinforcement learning techniques. The objective of this internship is to determine the appropriate machine learning technique that minimises the number of user-base station association updates.
Skills: Wireless Networking and Wireless communications. Evaluation of Algorithms complexity. Machine learning. Deep reinforcement learning; Combinatorial optimisation; Wireless Network simulations.
Student academic background: Computer Science; Engg-Computer; Engg-Systems and Technology

Name: Micro & Nano Sensors
Description: Two classes of inertial sensors are currently under development: - MEMS & NEMS gas sensors - MEMS chemical sensors in water
Skills: - Design; handling; and post-processing of MEMS - Design; debug; and test derive and detection circuits and the corresponding PCBs - Micro-scale experimental (fabrication and / or characterization) techniques - Hands-on experience in the dynamics; vibrations; and / or control of electromechanical systems.

Name: Signal Processing and Machine Learning for Human Movement Recognition
Description: The ageing global population is putting increasing stress on the healthcare system; necessitating a shift towards proactive health monitoring and self-management. Although increases in various medical conditions are correlated with age; it is reduced muscle strength and balance that contribute to making falls the number-one cause of accidental injuries in elderly people. This research is part of a larger program focused on wearable and mobile technology solutions to help track the quality and quantity of physical activity of the elderly population. The specific focus of this project is to conduct experiments and to develop algorithms to quantify stability and mobility of a user using information collected from wearables; computer vision; pressure sensitive flooring; and other instrumented devices. This project is also focused on using machine learning approaches to develop analytics that allow the processing of human movement; behaviors; activities; health; and engagement. Specifically; this experience will offer a unique combination of technical and experimental training as part of a collaborative and multi-disciplinary team that will prepare the successful candidates for future graduate studies or work in industry.
Skills: Electrical and Computer Engineering/Biomedical Engineering/Computer Science Signal Processing Pattern Recognition/Machine Learning/AI Computer Vision and IoT (Sensors; BLE; App dev; etc.) Software Development (Python; MATLAB; C; C++; Java; etc.)
Student academic background: Computer Science; Engg-Biomedical; Engg-Electrical; Engg-Computer; Engg-Software; Engg-Systems and Technology; Engineering; Ergonomics; Industrial Design and Technology; Engg-Electrical

Name: Micro Actuators
Description: We are actively developing two class of micro actuators - electrostatic rigid and deformable micro-mirrors - electrostatic micro tweezers We are also investigating novel designs of optomechanical resonators.
Skills: - Design; handling; and post-processing of MEMS - Design; debug; and test of drive circuits and their PCB implementations - Micro-scale experimental (fabrication and / or characterization) techniques - Hands-on experience in the dynamics; vibrations; and / or control of electromechanical systems.

Name: Enhancing capacity to combat agri-food misinformation
Description: Online misinformation can hinder the adoption of inclusive and innovative agricultural practices; potentially reinforcing social inequalities. The spread of misinformation in our interconnected world can have profound effects; such as undermining democratic institutions; discrediting scientists; and polarizing society. Studies have shown that agricultural misinformation is produced and disseminated online; which can impede the adoption of sustainable agricultural practices. This misinformation can undermine the roles of science; participatory research; and evidence-based decision making; and is often amplified by a network of actors with vested interests. To combat this; our project aims to understand the dynamics of misinformation circulation and develop strategies based on literature reviews; interviews; and surveys with agri-food stakeholders such as farmers and agricultural advisors. We will also create a collaborative platform that integrates various knowledge mobilization strategies; including podcasts; conversations with scholars and practitioners; and a literature database of misinformation and networks of scholars.
Skills: The intern will need the following background and skills: - Knowledge about agricultural sciences; agricultural extension and advisory services and agri-food technology adoption - Skills to search and retrieve literature; news sources - Analytical writing skills - Intermediate to advanced computer skills (skills in a computer language to design; host and deploy websites and data visualization is an asset) - Intermediate to advanced graphics and digital media skills (e.g. production of animated video; infographic; social media skills etc.)
Student academic background: Agriculture; Anthropology; Biological Sciences; Communication; Comparative Development; Development Studies; Engg-Biological; Engg-Biomedical; Engg-Computer; Engg-Software; Environmental Studies; Geography; Information Studies; International Studies; Veterinary Science and Medicine; Soil Science; Science and Technology

Name: Design and Manufacturing of an Environmental Friendly Pumps for Carbon Capture
Description: Carbon dioxide (CO2) is the main greenhouse gas; remarkably contributing to global warming and climate change. Nonetheless; CO2 is an inevitable output of a vast variety of industries relying on fossil fuels for addressing the energy demand. On the other hand; CO2 is a valuable matter and can be used in many processes; for instance; CO2 plays a vital role in plant growth (i.e.; photosynthesis) and it is extensively consumed in greenhouses. Therefore; there exists an opportunity to develop and apply a technology that can not only capture CO2 but also directly integrate it into plant growth process in greenhouses. The main objective of this project is to design an airlift pump a CO2 capture device while dissolving it into water if operating by exhaust flue gases from heating processes. Using the new airlift pump technology can improve plant growth by 40-60% while creating a positive environmental impact. During the course of this project; this objective has been accomplished by designing and testing multiple units of these pumps in the field for potential commercialization for the greenhouse industry. Currently; a final product development and manufacturing process optimization to produce those pumps at commercial scale are needed before our technology is ready for the indoor farming market.
Skills: Student with strong background of mechanical engineering. Also; student with background on electrical systems; data processing and instrumentation will be as asset.

Name: Immune protection in infectious diseases
Description: We will use sterile inflammation; bacteria infection; or virus infection to induce skin diseases. Then; we will study how neutrophil migration is regulated upon Staphylococcus aureus infection. We will study how lymph nodes; particular the fibroblastic reticular cells supporting the lymph node cell migration are altered during the skin diseases. We will further explore airway infection during predisposed diseases.
Skills: We will use fixed samples and intravital time-lapse imaging to study neutrophil migration. We will use flow cytometry analysis to characterize different cell populations and other molecular biology tools to study the molecular pathways that can regulate the lymphatic function and neutrophil migration.

Name: Cancer immunotherapy targeting the tumor draining lymph node (1)
Description: The goal of this study is to address how anti-tumor immunity are activated in the tumor draining lymph node (TdLN). We will study how tumor antigen activate anti-tumor immunity during lymphatic metastasis. Next; ionizing radiation (IR) therapy is widely used to treat cancer patients. Recent studies show that the efficacy of radiation therapy depends on activating host CD8+ T cell responses. We will investigate if IR therapy boosts anti-cancer immunity by improving lymphatic function and boost anti-tumor CD8 T cell responses. In our preliminary studies; we found that during cancer lymph node metastasis; tumor antigen and tumor associated DCs enter TdLN and potentially trigger anti-tumor immunity. However; tumor antigen and DCs cannot enter TdLN efficienty in the established lymph node metastases. We will use multiphoton intravital microscopy (MP-IVM) to examine how TuDC entering lymph nodes and interact with CD8 T cells. We use B16F10 melanoma cells transfected with ovalbumin (OVA) and fluorescent protein YFP (B16F10-OVA-YFP) to highlight tumor cells and test antigen specific T cell response. We will use anti-CD11c and anti-CD169 to highlight DCs and macrophages repectively. Next; we will transfer CFSE labeled OTI cells (transgenic mouse with CD8 T cells specifically response to OVA) and test OTI cell proliferation and cytokine production. Finally; we will study if IR stimulates tumor antigen and TuDC to traffic to TuLN and activate CD8 T cell responses.
Skills: The student should have a strong background in molecular biology and immunology; and have a strong interest in cancer biology. Prior hand-on experience with molecular biology techniques is preferred. The student should have good English skills (both written and verbal communication skills) and an enthusiasm for research and learning.

Name: Assessing the impact of preimplantation genetic testing on blastocyst and trophoblast development
Description: The project will assess the impact of preimplantation genetic testing (PGT) on blastocyst and subsequent trophoblast and placental development. We will measure gene expression by digital droplet polymerase chain reaction (ddPCR) in genes previously linked to preeclampsia and placental development in mouse blastocysts that have undergone PGT. Gene expression in PGT mouse blastocysts will be compared to mouse blastocysts that have not undergone PGT protocols. We will also assess gene expression in these candidate genes in the media the mouse blastocysts are stored in. If the gene expression signature in the media matches the gene expression signature in the blastocysts; using the media may open a new avenue for non-invasive PGT in the future.
Skills: The ideal student for this project will have a solid background in genetics; genomics; and statistics.

Name: Validation de vidéos immersives pour supporter la réadaptation des personnes vivant avec la schizophrénie en psychiatrie légale
Description: Le projet de recherche vise à valider une série de vidéos immersives (vidéos 360) pour l'entraînement de la cognition sociale auprès des personnes vivant avec la schizophrénie en milieu carcéral et en psychiatrie légale. Les vidéos que nous avons créées visent à reproduire des situations de la vie quotidienne qui peuvent mener à des interprétations erronées ou bien biaisées chez cette population. L’objectif est d’intégrer de telles vidéos immersives au sein d’approches cognitivo-comportementales pour la schizophrénie. Il s’agit d’une application novatrice de cette technologie en psychiatrie. Dans les dernières années; nous avons tenté de développer des scénarios immersifs qui : 1) suscitent un sentiment de présence 2) sont jugés réalistes 3) peuvent être mal interprétés et; conséquemment; 4) générer des émotions proches de la colère. Le présent projet implique la validation de ces scénarios (vidéos immersives) auprès de patients vivant avec la schizophrénie et de membres de la communauté sans trouble de santé mentale (n=20).
Skills: Il est attendu que l'étudiante ou l'étudiant ait des compétences dans le domaine de la santé mentale ou de la psychologie. Des connaissances de base sur la schizophrénie; la réadaptation psychosociale ou l’usage des technologies immersives seront des atouts.

Name: Assessing variability in cell-free placental DNA
Description: The research project will use bioinformatics and computational biology approaches to assess variability in cell-free placental DNA across gestation and between different fetal sex. This project will assess total cell-free placental DNA; DNA methylation profiles; and genomics variants using data generated by performing cell-free methylated DNA immunoprecipitation sequencing (cfMeDIP-seq).
Skills: The ideal student for this work will have a strong genomics and epigenomics background; and have strong computational skills; ideally proficient in R; python and or command line scripts. Previous experience with genomic sequencing data is an asset.
Student academic background: Biochemistry; Biological Sciences; Biology; Computer Science; Genetics

Name: Soil health and regenerative agriculture
Description: Saskatchewan has a vibrant and growing horticulture industry; home to commercial and market production of cool-season vegetables (i.e.; cole crops; carrots; beets); potatoes; and fruit crops (i.e.; haskaps; saskatoonberries; sour cherries); and a budding greenhouse crop industry as well. Across the province; the horticultural industry is the foundation for many small businesses such as cideries; distilleries; agri-tourism sites; greenhouses; restaurants; etc. With this growing industry; there is a high demand from the prairie horticultural industry for information; resources; and tools to support increased yields; expand production; optimize efficiency for crop production—and especially a high demand for soil health resources and information. Increased knowledge translation and transfer to prairie horticulture growers will help to strengthen this growing industry; help to expand production; and contribute to a more diversified Saskatchewan agricultural landscape and revenue generation.The USask Hort Field Lab infrastructure presents an excellent opportunity for reinvigorating prairie horticulture research and extension; the best equipped on campus horticulture facility located at a Canadian university (2013 TransformUS report). We already have tree fruit orchards of varying ages; berry orchards; annual vegetable and potato production sites; shelterbelts; an all-American flower display garden; and an arboretum with over 900 specimens adapted to circumpolar climate. Further; we have key infrastructure including buildings; agri-photovolatic demonstration; high-tunnels; irrigation equipment; mechanical berry harvesters; etc. With key personnel to organize; coordinate; and lead the activities; we propose opening up the Field Lab directly to horticultural growers and industry by creating a space called the “Prairie Horticulture & Soil Health Interpretive Centre”. This Centre will focus on efforts to translate knowledge gained from prairie horticulture research activities to horticultural growers; and the MITACS student will help with these activities.
Skills: Required skills include: strong communication; ability to understand and apply research results; ability to translate research findings for public and end-users; strong social skills; professional conduct; solid outreach and extension skills. A strong background in soil science; horticulture; and/or agriculture is required.
Student academic background: Agriculture; Biology; Botany; Earth Science; Ecology; Environmental Studies

Name: How does Chinchillas do their rolling?
Description: Chinchillas are rodents native to the Andes mountains in South America. They are also cute fluffy pets that you can find in local pet stores. They have extremely soft fur and each hair follicle has about 60 very fine hairs (1 or 2 hairs per follicle for humans). One interesting behavior of a chinchilla is that they take bath in fine dust; not in water. To be more specific; they roll in volcano dust. It is said that the dust bath can keep them clean from being too greasy (check out the figure and Youtube videos below) However; do you have the same questions as I do? What’s wrong with being too greasy? Is this true that they clean the oil on fur using dust? If yes; how do they exactly do it? What if the sand is not fine enough; will that work too? Can we model this cute and bizarre behavior; and make something useful for humans?
Skills: curiosity; a strong background in physics (intuition; analysis; and experimental)

Name: splash free urinals
Description: How can men’s pants and restrooms stay away from splashing back body fluids? Half of the population on the earth have been suffering from this issue since urinals were invented over 100 years ago. We will solve the problem by learning from dessert moss; nautilus shells; and puppies. This is multi-disciplinary research connecting fluid dynamics and bio-inspired design and art.
Skills: Physics; engineering (mechanical); industrial design; installation art etc.

Name: Interfacial phenomena of droplet on fiber
Description: How do droplets move on a fibre in the wind and in the gravitational field of Earth? The answer to this question is the cornerstone of many industrial and natural processes. Examples include some chemical reactors in carbon engineering; fog harvesting facilities; and the cleaning process of spider webs. We want to attack the rich fundamental physics of droplet moving on fibre.
Skills: applied math; experimentation; and data processing.

Name: Towards a conceptualization of crime as occupation
Description: This project is a concept synthesis aimed to explicate crime as occupation and generate a critical account of illegal occupations grounded in extant explanations of crime. The literature has already been searched using index terms including; but not limited to; crime; criminal activity; criminal behaviour; and criminal act/action. We now seek to analyze the results using Hocking’s (2009) occupational parameters for describing the things people do. This project will position occupational science for disciplinary and theoretical integration within the field of criminology; supporting the integration of occupational theories and models with others applied to explanations of crime. This work will also support occupational therapists and occupation scientists who are increasingly working with populations with legal involvement.
Skills: It is expected that the student will have a background in the field of criminology; social work or psychology. The student is also expected to be able to read and translate into English one of the following languages: Russian; Spanish; Lithuanian; Croatian or Portuguese (as some of the literature is in these languages).

Name: Réforme de la gouvernance locale pour un Nouveau-Brunswick dynamique et durable : comprendre l’étape de la mise à l’agenda politique / Local Governance Reform for a Vibrant and Sustainable New Brunswick: Understanding the Public Policy Agenda Setting
Description: For several years now; the local governance (LG) model in New Brunswick has led to significant challenges; whether of a social; financial or structural nature. Local governance is defined as the processes; systems and institutions that deliver services to residents and through which they fulfill their obligations; rights and rights; and communicate their needs and interests (International Peace Institute; 2018). Considering the importance of the issues facing the local governance system; some stakeholders; including experts; researchers and community groups; have proposed various potential solutions to address these issues. Despite all these attempts to influence; few changes are made to the current model. However; major changes will be on the horizon in 2020; radically transforming the portrait of local governance in New Brunswick. Why; after so long? In 2018; during its first term in office; the Higgs government put forward its intention to proceed with the modernization of local governance framework. Following his re-election in 2020; coinciding with a second term; this time with a majority; the Higgs government will officially launch its Local Governance Reform. Knowing that the challenges arising from this file have existed for more than 60 years; our main research question is the following: How to explain that the Higgs government finally decided to take seriously in 2020 the grievances of the actors interested in the question of the local governance in New Brunswick; when the many social; financial and structural challenges caused by government inaction in this matter had been known and documented since the 1960s?
Skills: Intellectual maturity; natural curiosity; good attitude (respect; enthusiasm; honesty); analytical skills; skills in research methodology (research in scientific databases; preparation of literature review on specific themes; conducting research interviews; research data analysis; scientific writing); knowledge of both official languages of the province (French and English).
Student academic background: Public Policy and Administration; Canadian Studies; City/Regional Planning; Sociology; Political Science

Name: Ten years after the adoption of their Public Participation Policy: is there “more” democracy in this complex linguistic context? The case of Dieppe / La démocratie délibérative en tant qu’instrument d’action publique : le cas de Dieppe
Description: 10 ans après l’adoption de sa politique P2
Faculty supervisor: Adopted in 2014; the Public participation (P2) policy in Dieppe (New Brunswick; Canada) permitted to increase public participation in this complex linguistic context; where both official languages (French and English) are used. They organized two Participatory Budgeting Process (2015 and 2018) and designed a new digital democracy tool; a dedicated website where citizens can participate at different levels of engagement. But instead of designing and implementing a new policy and P2 tools; where are we now in terms of increasing democracy in Dieppe? Have we met the principles of P2? Do all those efforts change anything in the democracy portrait in Dieppe? Are citizens more involved? Are the staff members and decision makers in Dieppe think and do differently since 2014 regarding democracy (are we doing democracy differently since the introduction of the policy? If so; how (what are the facilitators in doing so)? If not; why (what are the challenges/obstacles?). This qualitative research will be based on other separate projects I’ve done in the past with the city of Dieppe (on the P2 policy; on the digital platform; on both evaluation of the 2015 and 2018 PBP) and on research interviews with key actors at the city.
Student academic background: Intellectual maturity; natural curiosity; good attitude (respect; enthusiasm; honesty); analytical skills; skills in research methodology (research in scientific databases; preparation of literature review on specific themes; conducting research interviews; research data analysis; scientific writing); knowledge of both official languages of the province (French and English).

Name: The RET kinase is a key therapeutic target in human cancer
Description: Tumour metastasis is the primary cause of cancer related death; worldwide. Our lab focuses on the regulation of the RET receptor; a cell surface molecule with roles in growth and metastatic spread of several clinically challenging human cancers including pancreatic; lung and breast tumours. While we know that RET is abnormally active in these cancers; we don’t fully understand how it escapes normal regulatory controls to contribute to the spread of these devastating diseases. Our goals are to characterize these regulatory processes and explore RET’s roles and potential as a therapeutic target in multiple human cancers. First; we will determine the localization of RET in the cell under various conditions and how that contributes to tumour invasion. We will use high throughput approaches; such as MaMTH or synthetic lethal screens; to identify RET interactions with regulatory molecules; and investigate their effects on RET functions and signals that allow RET to escape normal controls and contribute to cancer. The student will investigate the protein interactions that regulate RET expression and signaling at the cell surface and how these can promote cell invasion into surrounding tissues. Students will perform molecular analyses of protein expression and interactions in vitro (western blotting); and in vivo (confocal or immunofluorescence microscopy). We will explore effects of perturbing expression of RET and other invasion-associated signaling molecules (over expression or CRISPR knockout) on RET-mediated invasion in functional assays. We will identify processes that target RET to the cell invasive front to promote cell motility and explore RET’s roles in regulating the cell’s degradation of its surroundings which allows tumours to spread and metastasize to distant sites. We will explore therapeutic opportunities to block these processes by identifying novel molecular targets for controlling RET–mediated cell motility and invasion as approaches to limiting RET’s cancer-causing activities.
Skills: We are seeking a motivated student interested in developing skills and models for exploration of cancer therapies. They should have a background in some aspect of biological sciences or related field. Previous courses in biochemistry; molecular biology and protein or gene function or other relevant fields of study would be key to contributing to the project goals. Some molecular research experience; particularly mammalian cell culture would be an asset. Good English oral and written communication skills and experience with critical reading of scientific literature will optimize the student’s experience and provide opportunities for them to present/publish their research work.

Name: Production and characterization of a plant aldehyde dehydrogenase protein
Description: Aldehyde dehydrogenases (ALDHs) constitute a superfamily of enzymes present in nearly all taxa. They become highly induced in plants subjected to environmental stresses. Upon induction; these enzymes detoxify the cells from toxic aldehydes generated by stress. The aim of this study is to characterize the enzymatic activity of the succinate semialdehyde dehydrogenase enzyme in the presence of a potential inhibitor. The results will provide insights into the regulation of the activity of this enzyme within the plants subjected to environmental stresses.
Skills: The student should have a background in molecular biology; biochemistry; or plant biology.

Name: Isolation of aldehyde dehydrogenase mutants from the model plant Arabidopsis thaliana
Description: To test the hypothesis that plant enzymes aldehyde dehydrogenase (ALDH) protect proteins in plants under stress; the objectives of this course are 1) to identify two aldh-knockout mutants of two ALDH genes in the Arabidopsis thaliana plant; and 2) to examine the state of protein carbonylation in these mutants. This will allow us to better understand the biological function of these genes in the prevention of protein carbonylation in plants. This study will contribute to current knowledge of plant defense mechanisms against abiotic stress by providing new avenues for improving plant health through biotechnology.
Skills: The student should have a background in molecular biology; biochemistry; or plant biology.

Name: Cloning of an aldehyde dehydrogenase gene of the model plant Arabidopsis thaliana
Description: Aldehyde dehydrogenases (ALDHs) constitute a superfamily of enzymes in nearly all taxa. They become highly induced in plants subjected to environmental stresses. Upon induction; these enzymes detoxify the cells from toxic aldehydes generated by stress. The aim of this study is to clone an ALDH gene in a plant binary vector; which will is used to transform plants.
Skills: The student should have a background in molecular biology; biochemistry; or plant biology.
Student academic background: Biochemistry; Molecular Biology; Biology; Engg-Biological; Biological Sciences; Botany; Genetics; Science and Technology

Name: Cognitive Neurorobotics for Damage Recovery
Description: Spiking Neural Networks (SNN) will be employed to construct a decision-making neural circuit model of the human brain; including both connectome and functional perspectives; for sensorimotor activities. The SNN model will include a multisensory brain simulation including visual auditory; somatosensory; motor and interoceptive/ proprioceptive brain modules coordinated by secondary associative modules and further controlled by amodal higher “executive” centers with long-range neural connectivity. As a starting point; we will initially adopt a neurocognitive architecture based on a neural network implementation of the most established neurocognitive modeling architecture: Adaptive Control of Thought—Rational (ACT-R)36. We will materialize this framework; performing research on Neural Engineering Framework in combination with Vector Symbolic Architecture. The interaction of the brain model with a robotic system will be facilitated through the two-way translation of multimodal sensorimotor signals at the robot and stimulating spikes in the SNN to develop a simulation platform for brain-robot interaction. The SNN combines dopamine and Spike-Time-Dependent Plasticity (STDP) mechanisms to learn functionalities from an existing self-model of the robot. This self-model is also plastic as it is updated with experiential learning and is modified by simulation during the sleeping state (dreaming) and during wakefulness (imagination). We will also investigate curiosity-based learning methodologies to study the learning behaviour of the modelled brain-robot system.
Skills: Artificial Intelligence; Reinforcement Learning; Spiking Neural Networks; Robotics; Signal Processing.

Name: Muscle synergy feature extraction for applications in exoskeleton design
Description: The project is centered around the extraction of muscle synergies from high-density EMG data. Through wavelet decomposition; we differentiate muscle activation patterns across various frequency bands. Further; we apply matrix factorization techniques like nonnegative matrix factorization (NMF); and independent component analysis (ICA) to decompose the time-frequency representations into distinct components; interpreted as muscle synergies. Understanding the particular synergies that emerge during different physical activities allows us to gain insights into muscle group coordination and their synergistic adjustments to diverse physical demands. These insights will enhance our comprehension of human motor control and its implications for exoskeleton design and control. We anticipate that revealing and understanding these muscle synergies will allow us to design exoskeletons that align more closely with the user's natural movement patterns; leading to improved performance and user comfort.
Skills: The intern should have a strong background in biomedical or electrical engineering; particularly in signal processing and programming (MATLAB or Python). A thorough understanding of wavelet transform; linear algebra; calculus; and basic human physiology is critical. Experience with EMG data collection; preprocessing; and wavelet-based analysis would be beneficial.

Name: Physiological and cognitive responses in exoskeleton users under extreme thermal conditions
Description: This project delves into how extreme cold (-20°C) and heat (40°C) conditions affect the physiological and cognitive responses of exoskeleton users. Participants will perform tasks in a climate-controlled chamber that challenge both their physical capacity and cognitive abilities. We'll use a Polar H10 sensor to monitor heart rate; and calculate heart rate variability (HRV) in both time and frequency domains. These measures provide insights into cardiovascular and metabolic responses. Cognitive measures; including NASA Task Load Index (TLX) and specific tests assessing attention; memory; and problem-solving abilities; will also be employed. The ultimate goal is to integrate these findings into exoskeleton design; considering thermal constraints. Through the analysis of the collected data using signal processing and statistical techniques; we aim to improve the understanding of human responses under different thermal conditions and enhance exoskeleton design.
Skills: The ideal candidate should be pursuing or have completed a degree in Engineering; Physics; or a related field. They should have a strong understanding of thermodynamics; heat transfer; signal processing; and computer programming. Familiarity with cognitive science; exoskeleton technology; and experience in design considering human physiological measures will be advantageous.
Student academic background: Engg-Biomedical; Ergonomics; Medical Sciences; Physics; Physiology; Psychology; Neuroscience

Name: Development of soft robots for upper limb motion assessment and rehabilitation
Description: Clinical assessment plays a major role in medical decision making or in rehabilitation process after surgical treatment of hand and wrist. The objective of this project is to develop a wearable soft robot that not only would measure the hand and wrist motion; but also would assist in rehabilitative procedures. This project will be conducted in collaboration with the Faculty of Medicine and Dentistry and involves the bio-mechatronic hardware design; integrating the wearable sensors and actuators; and developing computer controllers for this biomedical device. The expected outcome is a biomedical device to be implemented in clinical research and practice. The student will acquire expertise in multibody dynamics; signal processing; biomedical instrumentation design and physiological measurement.
Skills: The student must be familiar with computer programming using MATLAB and engineering mechanics. Knowledge on mechatronics is an asset. Electrical; Biomedical; Mechanical; Computer Engineering students would typically have the required background. The student must be familiar or willing to learn data acquisition; physiological measurements; and data/signal processing; human motion biomechanics.

Name: Daily activity monitoring using wearable technologies for outcome evaluation of clinical treatments
Description: Human motion measurement during daily activities (such as walking) is like a fingerprint and can distinguish patients with neurological; psychological; or musculoskeletal conditions from able-bodied individuals. Although human motion can be measured in motion measurement labs; patients may not act as naturally as in their home. Wearable sensor technology is an ideal alternative to for human motion measurement out of laboratories. Although smartphones and watches can assess the step count and the general level of physical activity; they are not validated to be precise biomedical devices (imagine a fingerprint scanner) and cannot be used for medical decision-making. The objective of this project is to develop wearable technologies using off-the-shelf sensors such as inertial sensors and force sensors to precisely assess clinically relevant parameters describing typical activities during daily life. Examples of to-be-measured parameters are the ankle; knee; hip joint angles during walking; standing up or sitting down. The motion data will be collected and analyzed from both patients and able-bodied individual groups. Then the measurements will be compared between the two groups to investigate the efficiency of the developed wearable technology.
Skills: The student must be familiar with computer programming using MATLAB and engineering mechanics. Knowledge in mechatronics is an asset. Electrical; Biomedical; Mechanical; Computer Engineering students would typically have the required background. The student must be familiar or willing to learn data acquisition; physiological measurements; and data/signal processing; human motion biomechanics; and biomechatronics.
Student academic background: Computer Science; Electronic Systems; Engg-Biological; Engg-Biomedical; Engg-Computer; Engg-Electrical; Engg-Electrical; Engg-Mechanical; Engg-Software; Engg-Systems and Technology; Engineering; Computer Science; Management Information Systems; Physics; Physics; Rehabilitation Medicine;

Name: Novel wearable technologies for athletic performance assessment
Description: Athletic activities play a significant role in improving our physical and mental health and thus our quality of life. In addition; professional sports; athletic equipment design; protective equipment design; etc. create a major market and potential for R&D activities. Athletic performance evaluation for the purpose of improving the athletic performance as well as injury prevention is usually performed based on the coach’s observation. However; the coach’s observation is frequent subjective and cannot capture slight motion pattern changes. On the other hand; a majority of sportive activities cannot be performed in standard motion capture labs. Wearable technologies create a significant opportunity for sportive performance evaluation in the field and recording the actual and natural performance of the athletes. The objective of this project is to develop wearable technologies for athletic performance assessment in athletic fields such as ice hockey; volleyball; and track and field activities. These technologies will enable the coach and the training team to better assess the performance of the athletes and reduce the risk of injuries.
