This project will be completed in collaboration with physical education scientists and athletic teams at the University of Alberta. In our general plan; the developed wearable technology will be designed; validated in the lab; tested in the field; and delivered towards technology transfer.
Skills: The student must be familiar with computer programming using MATLAB and engineering mechanics. Knowledge in mechtronics is an asset. Electrical; Biomedical; Mechanical; Computer Engineering students would typically have the required background. The student must be familiar or willing to learn data acquisition; physiological measurements; and data/signal processing; human motion biomechanics; and biomechtronics.
Student academic background: Computer Science; Electronic Systems; Engg-Aeronautical; Engg-Biological; Engg-Biomedical; Engg-Computer; Engg-Electrical; Engg-Electrical; Engg-Mechanical; Engg-Software; Engg-Systems and Technology; Engineering; Computer Science; Management Information Systems; Medical Sciences; Physics; Physics; Rehabilitation Medicine; Sports Science; Studies Science and Technology

Name: Design of wearable rehabilitation robots for knee and elbow joints
Description: Motion rehabilitation plays an important role in helping disabled individuals to regain their neuromechanical abilities. The objective of this project is to design a modular wearable rehabilitation robot (exoskeleton) for at least 1-DOF joints in our body; i.e.; elbow and knee. In rehabilitation; the goal is to maximally involve the users in performing the rehabilitation tasks. This in long term leads to neural recovery and physical improvement. The designed device is going to provide required controlled torques at each joint; and help the user to perform the rehabilitation task. In long term; the user should be able to do the task independently; without any assistance. This project includes the hardware and controller design; fabrication and implementation of this device.
Skills: The student must be familiar with computer programming using MATLAB and engineering mechanics. Knowledge on mechatronics is an asset. Electrical; Biomedical; Mechanical; Computer Engineering students would typically have the required background. The student must be familiar or willing to learn data acquisition; physiological measurements; and data/signal processing; human motion biomechanics.

Name: Préparation d'un manuel universitaire sur la morale à la période moderne (17e-18e s.)
Description: Les stagiaires auront la chance de participer à un projet novateur: la création d'un manuel universitaire numérique ayant un contenu multimédia (texte; vidéos; images) et multidisciplinaire sur la morale à la période moderne; particulièrement la question de l'amour-propre. L'intérêt premier pour soi est-il la trace de la corruption définitive de la nature humaine; comme le croient les jansénistes ou Blaise Pascal; ou un élément neutre moralement conféré par Dieu pour garantir la survie individuelle et qu'il s'agit d'éduquer pour en tirer tous les avantages; comme le croient les jésuites ou les rationalistes cartésiens? Le manuel développera différentes positions philosophiques sur cette question aux 17e et 18e siècles. Le projet de recherche consiste à mettre en forme les chapitres et leurs illustrations multimédias.
Skills: Les étudiants doivent avoir une excellente maîtrise du français leur permettant de rédiger et de réviser des textes en français. Ils participeront aux recherches de matériel multimédia pour la préparation d'un manuel de cours numérique de niveau universitaire sur la question de l'amour-propre et de l'amour de soi. Des connaissances en philosophie et/ou en théologie reliées au XVIIe siècle sont un atout (querelles entre jansénistes et jésuites autour de la nature humaine et du péché originel). Je souhaite travailler avec des personnes entreprenantes et autonomes.

Name: Prime Ministerial Leadership in Canada
Description: The project is a study of prime ministerial leadership in Canada; focusing on individual agency within an institutional context. I am carrying out a comparative examination of Canadian prime ministers since 1957; asking how and under what circumstances leaders affect political outcomes. The focus is on leadership styles: how prime ministers budget their time; obtain information; make decisions; see that decisions are carried out; and interact with various groups of followers (political staff; bureaucrats; Cabinet ministers; and caucus members). The methodology is qualitative and historical. The research includes a thorough review of the published primary sources and secondary literature; extensive work in the archives for the earlier prime ministers; and interviews with those who worked closely with later ones. The intern's work will focus on archival research My approach is influenced by the prime ministerial predominance model proposed by Richard Heffernan and developed by Mark Bennister. They see the prime minister as the dominant figure in a Westminster democracy; a much more significant player than in the core executive model. A prime minister's influence comes both from the Westminster constitutional structure; which invests much power in the office; and the prime minister's personal resources; including the individual's reputation; personality; and political skill.
Skills: Skills: the student must possess strong organizational and analytical skills; a talent for working independently; and the ability to pay close attention to detail. Knowledge: the student should have an understanding of either the Westminster system of government or of post-1945 Canadian political history. Training in archival research will be provided; though experience in this area would be an asset.

Name: The Canadian Election of 1988
Description: The project is an examination of Canadian federal election of 1988. The output will be a book that will focus on the players; the issues; and the consequences of this key moment in Canadian history. The volume will be part of the Turning Point Elections series; published by the University of British Columbia Press. The methodology is qualitative and historical. The research includes a thorough review of the published primary sources and secondary literature; archival research; and interviews with key figures in the election. The intern's work will focus on archival research.
Skills: Skills: the student must possess strong organizational and analytical skills; a talent for working independently; and the ability to pay close attention to detail. Knowledge: the student should have an understanding of either the Westminster system of government or of post-1945 Canadian political history. Training in archival research will be provided; though experience in this area would be an asset.

Name: Basic mechanics of multistable metamaterials
Description: Multistable metamaterials possess exhibit multiple stable shapes. They can transition between various shapes through snapping structural instability and deformation sequences. This shape transition is dependent on the strength; direction and sequence of the external loading applied to them. This property makes them desirable for applications in deployable aerospace structures and soft robotics. The goal of the project is to understand the basic mechanical characteristics of multistable metamaterials.
Skills: Strong background in mechanics of materials is absolutely necessary. This involves energy methods and buckling analysis in addition to typical introductory topics. There is a significant computational component involved (coding).

Name: Survival and persistence of food pathogens in food products
Description: Food-borne diseases are a major threat for public health and incur significant economic losses. For instance; around 80.3 million cases of salmonellosis worldwide are annually linked to the consumption of contaminated food products. But what makes food pathogens so successful? Their success can be attributed to their remarkable genetic diversity as well as capability to adapt and survive during harsh environmental conditions such as starvation; heat; low moisture; low pH; or even disinfectants. The goal of this study is to expose food pathogens such as Salmonella; Escherichia or Listeria to different stressful conditions and investigate their survival rates as well as molecular adaptations using proteomics; transcriptomics or metabolomic methodologies. Since bacterial cells might undergo structural changes; we will complement our study with microscopic analyses.
Skills: Ideally the student will have a background or interest in microbiology; biotechnology and/or molecular biology. Having participated in a practical course involving aseptic and/or molecular biological techniques would be an asset. At minimum the student should have knowledge of laboratory safety standards; though specific training will be offered on-site.

Name: Motivations et risques pour la santé professionnelle parmi les étudiantes et étudiants internationaux en emploi précaire au Québec
Description: Our project investigates motivations and occupational health risks of international graduate students working precarious jobs (delivery; factory work; caregiver) in Quebec. We aim to validate existing hypotheses and uncover emerging occupational health issues. Through qualitative semi-structured interviews and analysis with NVivo; we seek insights into the experiences of these workers to inform future support measures and workplace improvements.
Skills: We're seeking students with an interest in labor studies; migration; and occupational health; experienced in qualitative research and NVivo. Fluency in English; French; and another language is required.
Student academic background: Anthropology; Cultural Studies; Educ-Psychology; Educ-Social Studies; Ergonomics; Health Studies; Humanities; International Studies; Occupational Health; Psychology; Sociology

Name: Development of an isothermal DNA amplification method for the identification of biological species in foods
Description: Food fraud has been estimated to cause $65B USD damage/year to the food industry. The global supply chain shortages elicited by the COVID-19 pandemic have only worsened the issue. Food fraud can also introduce harmful ingredients; such as toxic and/or allergenic compounds to the food value chain; as well as result in long-lasting mistrust of regulatory agencies and the food industry. The rampancy of food fraud can be partially attributed to the lack of effective analytical tools; especially for emerging food products. The current methods to authenticate the biological species in foods adopted by governmental laboratories and the food industry are mainly nucleic acid amplification based on polymerase chain reaction (PCR). Although PCR is well established; these analyses involve costly thermocycler; bulky laboratory instrument (e.g.; centrifuge) and lengthy analytical procedures (e.g.; electrophoresis gel analysis); preventing their use in resources limited areas; such as in a food processing plant or grocery store where the sampling of food products is happening. To provide better tools for authentication of biological species; we propose to develop a simple; rapid; and user-friendly method based on cutting-edge isothermal DNA amplification methods (e.g.; recombinase polymerase amplification; RPA) to amplify nucleic acid of different biological species involved in foods.
Skills: Students from biological science; food science; agriculture; botany and related areas are welcome. The student is expected to have fundamental knowledge and experience about molecular biology (particularly DNA amplification); be able to use bioinformatic tools such as NCBI to find DNA sequence; compare sequences and design primers for DNA amplification; have experience to perform DNA extraction; amplification and results readout (e.g.; gel electrophoresis). Other general kills that are expected include self-learning skill; teamwork skills and communications skills (both written and verbal in English).

Name: Development of new quantum machine learning techniques for chemical property predictions
Description: Chemical property predictions using quantum machine learning (QML) represent a highly relevant and interdisciplinary field situated at the intersection of machine learning; quantum computing; and computational chemistry. In QML; novel models in the form of parametrized quantum circuits (PQCs) can be developed via the application of quantum circuit learning algorithms. PQCs provide an abstraction layer that conceals the intricacies of gate-level operations on a quantum computer; but they possess limited flexibility in terms of adjustable parameters. Consequently; to enhance the generalizability of QML models and surpass the capabilities of quantum circuit learning; the ability to execute pulse-level operations; which are lower in the quantum computing stack than gate-level operations; becomes essential. We hypothesize that incorporating pulse-level operations into QML models will improve their performance by introducing more adjustable internal parameters and allowing for finer controls to improve robustness against environmental noise on real quantum hardware. The project objective will be to explore the effectiveness of novel QML models in predicting chemical properties (such as reaction barrier heights) through regression tasks. To achieve this; the project aims to develop new algorithms in the realm of hybrid quantum circuit-pulse learning; where various pulse- and gate-level parameters will be learned. The students will work with in-house quantum mechanically calculated chemical data. The nature of the generalization error; in relation to the size of the training data; will be investigated for the developed QML models. Furthermore; the students will evaluate whether the hybrid circuit-pulse learning approach offers any advantage over quantum circuit learning in accurately predicting chemical properties. By exploring these aspects; this project seeks to advance the field of QML for chemical property predictions. It addresses the limitations of standard PQCs and aims to establish the potential benefits of incorporating pulse-level operations into QML models.
Skills: Ideal candidates for this project are students seeking to expand their skill sets by combining quantum computing and machine learning while exploring new applications in the process. They should be motivated to work in highly interdisciplinary research settings; collaborating with researchers in the group from diverse natural sciences and engineering backgrounds. Preference will be given to students enrolled in natural sciences with strong computational/programming abilities. While knowledge of chemistry is not necessary; familiarity with it would be advantageous as the application aspect of the project involves regression tasks on chemical property datasets.

Name: Metabolism of folate and aging in the retina
Description: Homocysteine is an amino acid that; in excess; becomes toxic and requires of folates and other vitamins to be metabolized. Different studies revealed that patients with age-related macular degeneration (AMD); a major cause of vision loss; display low levels of folate accompanied by high levels of homocysteine. Unfortunately; we know very little about the function of folates in the retina in the context of AMD. AMD is characterized by inflammation and the protrusion of pathological blood vessels into the central region of the retina (macula). However; it is not clear whether the risk of having these pathological features depends on the efficiency of transporting folate into the cells. With this program; we will explore if with age; specific cells of the retina such as glia or vascular cells lose their ability to bind and transport folates; ultimately leading to the accumulation of homocysteine in the retina and contributing to AMD-linked vascular complications and inflammation.
Skills: The candidate must be familiar with principles in cell and molecular biology (mRNA; proteins; cell signalling; culture of mammalian cells) and preferably with background in the field of biomedical sciences (understanding of disease; more particularly of ocular pathologies involving the retina). Ideally; the candidate will benefit from having been enrolled at a BSc in Biology; Biomedical Sciences; Biochemistry or Medicine.

Name: China’s Rise and a New World Order
Description: China’s rise has been the subject of much speculation in the past decades. Today; academics remain divided on the particulars and effects of China’s rise at home and abroad. What will be the effect of China’s rise on its own political system? On the global order? Will China remain a regional power; or will it supplant the US as a global hegemon? Is China actively trying to shape a new world order? If so; what will be its defining features? This project will investigate debates and collect new data on these questions. In doing so; it will pay a particular attention to China’s development and policies abroad; such as the Belt and Road initiative; China’s military build-up and its sovereignty claims in the South China sea; its positioning on the Ukrainian war; etc.
Skills: Successful applicants will have the capacity to conduct documentary research in English. Advanced knowledge of spoken and written Mandarin will be a strong advantage. Applicants should also have some knowledge of Chinese politics and political institutions; especially as they relate to foreign policy and international relations. Interest in the topic of China's influences abroad and knowledge of political dynamics between China and at least one other region would be highly desirable. Knowledge of French is not required; but since the internship will take place in Montreal; prospective interns should show an openness to live in a French environment.

Name: Computational Finance using Machine Learning Techniques
Description: Optional pricing is one of the central activities in computational finance. The well-known Black-Scholes model of pricing the European option leads to a time dependent partial differential equation (PDE). While analytic solutions exist for special cases; numerical computation is necessary to approximate the solution. Beyond the standard Black-Scholes model for European option; many numerical methods have been developed for pricing American and exotic options such as Asian option. Furthermore; new features such as jumps in underlying asset prices and nonconstant volatility have been incorporated in jump-diffusion; Heston's; and regime-switching models. In practice; it is important that one can obtain the solutions fast and accurate. However; the complexity of the solution process depends on the number of underlying assets. When the number of assets are limited to 1 or 2; efficient PDE methods have been developed. In practice; the number of assets is often much higher in the order of tens or even hundreds. Statistical methods such as Monte Carlo have been proposed but still they are inefficient when the asset number is very high. The research project is to explore machine learning technology in order to solve option pricing equations from computational finance in high dimensions. The project will particularly focus on applying the state-of-the-art machine learning models to improve the efficiency of financial computation. Machine learning has been showing success in different applications such as computer vision; but relatively few in computational finance. This project is to investigate the possibility of solving finance equations using machine learning technology that would be more effective than traditional approach.
Skills: Students working in this project are preferred to have the following background: 1. Calculus and linear algebra 2. Numerical computation 3. Programming in python (Background in finance/machine learning is not required; but it would be useful)

Name: Design and Development of a Halbach Array for Low Field Portable MRI Applications
Description: With the onset of new machine learning and computer vision; MRI applications with low field (less than 200 milli Tesla) are being revisited. The economic costs to build high field systems continues to rise with the cost and maintenance of superconducting magnets; while low field systems that us neodymium remain cheaper; and have recently been shown for portable applications. This project aims to design a Halbach array for low field applications. Primarily; this project requires the careful placement of many smaller (approximately; 2 cm) neodymium magnets that produce a; strong as possible (50 to 120 milli Tesla); uniform magnetic field over a 30 cm imaging field. The design constraints include: 1) the strength and uniformity of the produced magnetic field and 2) the total weight of the system. The parameters that can modified to achieve the design aims are: 1) number of the neodymium magnets; arranged in a machined lattice. This project would be particularly exciting to students who have an interest in electromagnetic modelling; electrical; mechanical; or biomedical engineering. The student will gain advanced finite element modelling skills. The student will get to perform an advanced optimization relating the position and orientation of the magnets. machine learning strategies should be considered in this process. This can be conducted on our institutions supercomputing resources. The final deliverables will be the design that includes the positions seated in the metal lattice; and the simulated magnetic field; as well as documenting the processes used to achieve these first two deliverables in case additional iterations of the design are required. Although not to be completed during this internship; the lab aims to construct this magnet so the student will see their work realized. This work has the potential for publication in an academic journal and filing as a patent.
Skills: An ideal student should have a demonstrated interest in a technical domain; such as: Biomedical; Electrical; Computer; or Software Engineering; applications from candidates in (Medical) Physics and Computer Science can also be a good fit for this research program and will be considered. Experience in computing and programming is desirable. Some experience in machine learning; computer vision; or medical imaging processing would be ideal. Motivation; a good attitude; and ability to work with others is required. Primarily; we are looking for students who have an interest in graduate studies in this research area; and may be interesting in returning to

Name: Computational Graphics on Virtual Reality Systems
Description: In physically-based simulations; natural phenomena such as water; cloud; fire; and explosion arise frequently. To achieve high level realism; the modern approach in computer graphics is to utilize the underlying physical equations. The governing equations are often complex; nonlinear; with irregular geometry and high dimensions. As a result; solving those equations are time consuming and become the computational bottom neck. The research project is to investigate how the state-of-the-art computer graphics (CG) techniques can be applied to new emerging systems. Most of the existing CG techniques are designed for visualization on a 2D screen. The project will particularly focus on the new visualization platform; namely; virtual reality (VR) systems. VR has been a powerful tool for medical visualization; surgical training; treatment for patients; and game industry. It provides user the 3D visualization of the environment; which can be interacted with the user through an hand held device. However; the VR platform poses two challenges: 1) 3D visualization of the simulation results; and 2) computations in real time. New programming model and computational techniques are required. This project is to investigate how physically-based simulations can be done efficiently on VR systems.
Skills: Students working in this project are preferred to have the following background: 1. Calculus and linear algebra 2. Numerical computation 3. Programming in C/C++ (Background in computer graphics/virtual reality is preferred but not required)

Name: Modelling of the Cerebral Vasculature with Arterial Spin Labelling MRI for Age Prediction
Description: Arterial spin labelling (ASL) is an advanced form of MRI that is used to measure the capillary level blood flow. ASL works by labelling the blood in the neck; allowing some time for the blood to flow into the brain tissue. A difference image between the labelled and unlabelled images is computed; that is proportional to the cerebral blood flow (CBF). CBF is an exceptionally useful metric in the study of brain health; aging; and diseases. In this project we have data from approximately 250 participants that include anatomical and multi-delay time arterial spin labelling; and we seek to analyze changes in regional blood flow and arrival time across the lifespan. We previously published a paper with only a single delay time ASL; and now seek to extend that analysis (with new data) to a multi-delay time application. To do this analysis; a pipeline that includes several advanced neuroimaging steps is required. Brain extraction of the anatomical and CBF images; registration of these images; and registration to a standard template image with an atlas of brain regions. Partial volume correction and quantification of the ASL images. We conduct these analyses on our institutions supercomputer so that the pipeline can be massively parallelized; and all 250 participants can be run at one time. Once regional measurements have been done; tabular machine-learning and deep-learning models would be built to compare the performance of age prediction. The student will learn many advanced neuroimaging skills when doing this project; including packages such as FSL and FreeSurfer. There is also a chance to implement customized code with matlab; python and/or bash. In addition; the student will learn about tabular machine-learning deep-learning as well. This project is also supported by a graduate student; so there should be sufficient assistance to achieve the objectives.
Skills: An ideal student should have a demonstrated interest in a technical domain; such as: Biomedical; Electrical; Computer; or Software Engineering; applications from candidates in (Medical) Physics; (Computational) Neuroscience; and Computer Science can also be a good fit for this research program and will be considered. Experience in computing and programming is desirable. Some experience in machine learning; computer vision; or medical imaging processing would be ideal. Motivation; a good attitude; and ability to work with others is required. Primarily; we are looking for students who have an interest in graduate studies.

Name: Brain Emulation using Virtual Brain
Description: This project aims to elucidate the underlying circuitry of the brain to emulate the brain function. Consistent with other projects in our research group; this project will use magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) neuroimaging data. To determine the underlaying brain circuitry; an advanced MRI method known as diffusion tensor imaging (DTI) will be used to determine the underlaying white matter fiber tracts that connect regions of the grey matter cortex to other regions of the cortex. From this signal we seek to emulate the functional changes observed in blood oxygen dependant (BOLD) functional MRI (fMRI). The aim with this project is to use an existing emulator; VirtualBrain; to run these simulations and compare the results between the young and old participants; as well as people with brain disease and matched controls. Data for this project has already been collected! However; our research group has no experience with the VirtualBrain emulator; which has only recently been made available in an opensource software utility (https://www.thevirtualbrain.org/tvb/zwei). Required data preprocessing will be completed first. The emulator can be run on our institutional supercomputer resource. We hope to find differences between young and old participants; and people with brain diseases (such as Alzheimer’s disease). This project will provide notably useful findings about brain function between young and old; as well as healthy and diseased people. In this project the student will have the opportunity to work with several types of advanced neuroimaging data; for a cutting-edge application; brain emulation. This is transdisciplinary research or described as a ‘computational neuroscience’ project. Elucidating how the brain works through emulation represents a cutting edge research area.
Skills: An ideal student should have a demonstrated interest in a technical domain; such as: Biomedical; Electrical; Computer; or Software Engineering; applications from candidates in (Medical) Physics; (Computational) Neuroscience; and Computer Science can also be a good fit for this research program and will be considered. Experience in computing and programming is desirable. Some experience in machine learning; computer vision; or medical imaging processing would be ideal. Motivation; a good attitude; and ability to work with others is required. Primarily; we are looking for students who have an interest in graduate studies.

Name: Functional Magnetic Resonance Imaging of Brain Circuitry
Description: Functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) is an important technology is understanding brain function. fMRI can be used for understanding the connectivity of the brain; revealing regions of the brain that activate together. The networks of the brain have been recently shown to be represented by a graphical model. These graphical models can be seen as a resonant feedback neural networks. This project will involve using MRI data; and in particular; fMRI and diffusion tensor imaging to model brain function. There are a number of steps known to improve this processing; including: motion correction; brain extraction; drift correction. Removal of physiological signal confounds must then be conducting. Remaining signal is considered to be mostly related to neuronal activity. These signals are correlated and thresholded to obtain the connections of the graphical model. If time permits; this analysis can be extended to include the directionality modelling using dynamic causal modelling. The trainee undertaking this project will learn advanced neuroimaging skills and theory about fMRI. They will have the chance to work with high quality fMRI data; on supercomputing infrastructure. The projects will use a several neuroimaging software packages and Python. Adaptive resonance theory is a model suggesting that consciousness and adaptive learning arises from the resonance of brain circuits. Thus; the study of these circuits is important for expanding the understanding of the mind. This project will lay the foundation for more advanced work such as brain emulation from the graphical models.
Skills: An ideal student should have a demonstrated interest in a technical domain; such as: Biomedical; Electrical; Computer; or Software Engineering; applications from candidates in (Medical) Physics and Computer Science can also be a good fit for this research program and will be considered. Experience in computing and programming is desirable. Some experience in machine learning; computer vision; or medical imaging processing would be ideal. Motivation; a good attitude and ability to work with others is required. Primarily; we are looking for students who have an interest in graduate studies in this research area.
Student academic background: Engineering; Engg-Biomedical; Engg-Electrical; Engg-Software; Engg-Systems and Technology; Physics; Computer Science; Engg-Computer; Neuroscience

Name: Brain Volumetry using Data Analytics and Machine Learning
Description: Data analytics is a key area of my research program; and I regularly aim to train highly qualified personal in this research area. The application domain is in brain imaging; and you will have a chance to work with such data; hands on. I can offer a number of short timeline projects in this area; including: Application Development (using C++); Neuro-Imaging Pipeline Development (using bash; FSL;FreeSurfer; etc);and Machine Learning (using Python; Matlab). The Application development portion of the program is for big data management. Used to manage medical imaging and histology image data. This is particularly interesting application that has been development by several summer students before. There is a chance for the student to make a meaningful contribution to this project also. There are many features we would like to add; and such an internship project allows for a trainee to hone their skills in development for a broad system capable of distributed deployment. Databasing is an important skill for most scientific and industrial domains; and skills learned when working on this project are transferrable to many domains. The Neuroimaging portion of this project is focused on the deployment of pipelines for post processing brain data. Brain data comes in many shapes and sizes and it requires advanced processing such as registration; brain extraction; cortical parcellation and more. In these short timeline projects; we aim to build a new pipeline for obtain measurements of the brain. A student working on this type of project will learn advanced neuroimaging skills; and how to link together blocks to carve out a new finding about the brain. The machine learning projects also use brain data; this can include tasks such as simple disease classification; to more advanced deep learning projects such as noise suppression;and image translation. These projects use Python and Matlab.
Skills: An ideal student should have a demonstrated interest in a technical domain; such as: Biomedical; Electrical; Computer; or Software Engineering; applications from candidates in (Medical) Physics and Computer Science can also be a good fit for this research program and will be considered. Experience in computing and programming is desirable. Motivation; a good attitude and ability to work with others is required. Primarily; we are looking for students who have an interest in graduate studies in this research area.
Student academic background: Engineering; Engg-Biomedical; Engg-Computer; Engg-Electrical; Engg-Software; Engg-Systems and Technology

Name: Computed Tomography Perfusion of Stroke using Machine Learning
Description: Ischemic stroke is a leading cause of death and disability in the developed world. This type of stroke occurs when there is a blockage of the blood vessels to the brain; starving them of the nutrients and leading to death of the affected tissues. This can generally not be reversed. Imaging of the total affected tissue of the stroke is important for decision making and treatment. Although there are many methods to image the larger blood vessels; imaging of the flow in the capillary bed is more challenging. One of the most popular methods used for stroke imaging is called; Computed Tomography Perfusion (CTP); where the dynamic passage of a tracer is imaged repeated with CTP. This builds a time course of images that can be processed to obtain information about the tissue perfusion (ie – the capillary level blood flow). Our team has already done a great deal of research on this topic; but we believe that machine learning could play an important role in improving the CTP images. This project aims to apply methods such as: advanced signal processing; denoising autoencoder; or the convolutional neural network; to improve the performance of CTP at detecting stroke. Our research group is using advanced supercomputing resources for these applications. This project provides a unique opportunity to work with an academic research team; clinical collaborators (Calgary Stroke Team); and an industrial partner (Circle Cardiovascular Inc). This way the trainees work can the chance to make an academic; clinical; and industrial contribution. The trainee will gain advanced skills in medical image processing; linux supercomputing; and machine learning.
Skills: An ideal student should have a demonstrated interest in a technical domain; such as: Biomedical; Electrical; Computer; or Software Engineering; applications from candidates in (Medical) Physics and Computer Science can also be a good fit for this research program and will be considered. Experience in computing and programming is desirable. Some experience in machine learning; computer vision; or medical imaging processing would be ideal. Motivation; a good attitude and ability to work with others is required. Primarily; we are looking for students who have an interest in graduate studies in this research area.

Name: Design and Development of Gradient Coils for Low Field Portable MRI Applications
Description: With the onset of new machine learning and computer vision; MRI applications with low field (less than 200 milli Tesla) are being revisited. The economic costs to build high field systems continues to rise with the cost and maintenance of superconducting magnets; while low field systems that us neodymium remain cheaper; and have recently been shown for portable applications. This project aims to design gradient coils for low field applications. Primarily; the project starts by determining the current densities required to achieve the desired magnetic field gradients. Then the windings can be achieved to approximate those current densities while simultaneously minimizing the inductance. The project can be completed primarily with COMSOL multi-physics linked with python. This project would be particularly exciting to students who have an interest in electromagnetic modelling; electrical; mechanical; or biomedical engineering. The student will gain advanced finite element modelling skills. The student will get to perform an advanced optimization relating the electronmagnetics with the coil. Machine learning strategies should be considered in this process. This can be conducted on our institutions supercomputing resources. The final deliverables will be the design that includes the current densities and the winding configuration; and the simulated magnetic fields; as well as documenting the processes used to achieve these first two deliverables in case additional iterations of the design are required. Although not to be completed during this internship; the lab aims to construct this magnet so the student will see their work realized. This work has the potential for publication in an academic journal and filing as a patent.
Skills: An ideal student should have a demonstrated interest in a technical domain; such as: Biomedical; Electrical; Computer; or Software Engineering; applications from candidates in (Medical) Physics and Computer Science can also be a good fit for this research program and will be considered. Experience in computing and programming is desirable. Some experience in electromagnetics would be ideal. Motivation; a good attitude; and ability to work with others is required. Primarily; we are looking for students who have an interest in graduate studies in this research area; and may be interesting in returning to graduate school.
Student academic background: Engg-Biological; Engg-Biomedical; Engg-Computer; Engg-Electrical; Engg-Industrial; Engg-Manufacturing; Engg-Software; Engineering; Physics

Name: Controlling Anion Ordering in Quantum Materials
Description: The intern will work on a synthetic chemistry project to target phases with exotic optoelectronic and magnetic properties. Specifically; we are targeting materials which are non-centrosymmetric (NCS) or which do not have a center of inversion within their crystal structure. The lack of an inversion center creates a topologically non-trivial band structure; which is of interest to the field of quantum materials. In addition; certain classes of NCS materials interact with dark matter according to theory. More concretely; these materials display second harmonic generation which is essential in lasers; and have piezoelectric properties making them ideal pressure sensors. The wide range of symmetry related properties makes these materials an attractive synthetic target. Traditionally; synthesis of NCS materials has relied on chance to create the phases with the desired symmetry. While 18 of the 32 crystallographic point groups do not contain an inversion center; this does not translate to 56% of discovered phases being NCS. To increase chances; researchers frequently introduce polar ‘building blocks’ such as octahedra distorted by Jahn-Teller distortions or by the presence of heteroanions. While this approach is sometimes successful; more commonly materials crystallize with anti-aligned dipoles; related by a center of inversion. In the absence of an external field; there is an energetic benefit for the dipoles to align; favoring the formation of centrosymmetric phases. We hypothesize that by adding an external field during synthesis; we will be able to target NCS phases. We will be investigating the phase space generated both in the presence and absence of an applied electric field; adding an additional axis to the phase diagram. In this work the student will learn about solid state synthesis; basic principles of electrochemistry; and structural characterization.
Skills: Students should feel comfortable working in a laboratory setting. A background in either chemistry or materials science will be greatly beneficial. Training on specific techniques required for this research project will be provided to the student upon arrival. The ability to communicate any problems to either the PI or other group members is essential. Most researchers at the Université de Sherbrooke; including the PI; are fluent in both English and French; so either language may be used to communicate.

Name: Development of graphene end-of-life sensors for heat & flame protective clothing
Description: High performance fibers have been developed over the last fifty years for the manufacture of fire protective clothing. These fibres display high mechanical performance and are resistant to chemicals; fire; and high temperatures. However; the various conditions the materials are exposed to during their lifetime; e.g. heat; UV; and moisture; reduce their performance over time. In addition; destructive testing has shown considerable loss in performance before any sign of deterioration is visible to the naked eye. Currently; no non-destructive technique is available to assess the residual performance of the materials in service. Thus; workers at risk of heat and flame exposure have no way of knowing if their clothing is still able to protect them from the hazards associated with their tasks. In that context; graphene is opening a new range of possibilities for the manufacture of end-of-life sensors for fabrics. The avenue selected for this project relies on producing graphene conductive tracks on fabric substrate. Exposure to the aging agents causing the fire protective fabric to enter an unsafe range will cause the conductive track to degrade. The status of the end-of-life sensor will be assessed by measuring the electrical conductivity of the sensor tracks. The project is thus aimed at providing solutions to allow wearers of fire protective clothing to assess the condition of their clothing during use. It involves the preparation of graphene-coated fabric samples will then be exposed to aging conditions (intensity and duration of exposure to heat; UV; etc.) known to bring the high performance materials to different levels of loss in performance. The condition of the sensor will be assessed by measuring the electrical conductivity of the graphene track.
Skills: In addition to solid skills in polymer science and materials engineering; it is critical that the student is curious and rigorous. They should also be able to work independently while displaying a good ability for team work. Oral and written communication skills are important as well. Some lab work experience; for instance at preparing samples and characterizing materials performance; is an asset.

Name: Disruption management for the maritime transportation
Description: The research project aims to investigate and develop advanced strategies for disruption management in guided/autonomous ships (for example; GPS connectivity is lost or unreliable). The project will involve analyzing different disruption scenarios; such as bad weather conditions; or areas with poor satellite reception; and devising novel algorithms to enable autonomous vehicles to navigate and adapt their behaviour in real-time without relying heavily on GPS data. The research will explore the integration of innovative methods such as new/revised metaheuristic approaches; which can provide efficient and near-optimal solutions; combining mathematical modelling; optimization techniques; and heuristic methods. The project will involve designing and implementing algorithms; conducting simulations; and evaluating the performance of the developed methods using realistic scenarios and datasets.
Skills: The student should have a strong background in industrial engineering or computer science; with expertise in areas such as artificial intelligence; machine learning; optimization algorithms; and autonomous systems. Proficiency in programming languages commonly used in autonomous ships research; such as Python or C++; is necessary. Knowledge of mathematical modelling; algorithm design; and statistical analysis is also beneficial. Good problem-solving and analytical skills; along with the ability to work independently and collaborate with a multidisciplinary team; are essential for this research project.

Name: Hydrogen economy: challenges and solutions from a supply chain perspective
Description: The research project seeks to investigate the entire value chain of export-oriented low-carbon hydrogen; with a particular emphasis on its production; storage; transportation; and delivery via maritime shipping and chemical carriers. The project will involve assessing the technical; economic; and environmental aspects of blue and green hydrogen production methods; evaluating the optimal shipping routes and logistics for transporting hydrogen; and developing strategies for ensuring safe and efficient delivery to international markets. Through comprehensive analysis; the project aims to identify potential challenges; recommend best practices; and provide insights for the successful implementation of large-scale export-oriented low-carbon hydrogen systems.
Skills: The student engaged in this research should possess a strong background in industrial engineering; energy systems; or a related field. Proficiency in conducting techno-economic assessments; life cycle analysis; and modelling of hydrogen production and transportation systems is crucial. Knowledge of maritime shipping and chemical carrier operations; as well as familiarity with international trade and regulations; would be beneficial. Excellent analytical and problem-solving skills; along with the ability to work independently and collaborate with a multidisciplinary team; are essential for the successful completion of this research project.

Name: Development of testing & quality control methods for Joule heating textiles
Description: Joule heating textiles are based on the use of electrically conductive; yet resistive materials to generate thermal energy. This electrothermal actuation technology is used in the medical; protection and sportswear sector with several wearable textile products already on the market. However; no test standards are available to assess the quality of Joule heating textile products yet while several issues have been reported in terms of efficiency; durability and safety. This project is aimed at developing a set of universal test standards to assess the efficiency; durability and safety of Joule heating textiles. To ensure the universality of the methods to be developed; we are using different textile structures encountered in commercial products: woven; nonwoven; knitted; coated; inserted and embroidered heating fabrics. Five conditions corresponding to service conditions identified as most relevant to typical use of heating textiles in clothing applications have been selected for the durability assessment: abrasion; washing; exposure to perspiration; and repetitive stretching and bending. The effect of the damaging conditions will be assessed by comparing the heating performance of the aged specimens with their initial heating efficiency. Signs of damage on the textiles such as loss of the conductive material or disruption of the textile structure will also be recorded. Regarding safety; the test methods will characterize the propensity of the heating textile products to short circuits; ignition; and overheating among others. Once developed; these test methods will be proposed for adoption as standards to international standardization organizations. The standards developed will help the industry improve the durability of the Joule heating textiles for the benefit of users; and support the growth of the e-textiles market.
Skills: In addition to solid skills in science and engineering; it is critical that the student is curious and rigorous. They should also be able to work independently while displaying a good ability for teamwork. Oral and written communication skills are important as well. Expertise in textiles and lab work experience; for instance at preparing samples and characterizing materials performance; are an asset.

Name: Design and fabrication of microwave devices
Description: The research project involves device engineering and using devices made in house for technological; health and chemistry applications.. The students will help with design and fabrication of several electronics circuits for control of our in house made microwave system and the accessories for chemical and medical applications as well as with design and fabrication of safety systems involved like interlocks. In addition the students will take part in data taking and analysis of the data.
Skills: Background in electronics both in circuit design and hands on work on circuits. Willingness to do data analysis. Background in chemistry and physics would be advantageous too but it is not required as long as the student is willing to learn some chemistry and physics during the project.

Name: Radiation chemistry for energy and health applications
Description: Nuclear energy is an important source of energy that helps to significantly reduce green house gases and therefore global warming. It is an important source of energy that we can use to decrease the dependency on fossil fuels as sources of energy. However; their safe and economic applications require a very good understanding of radiation chemistry at the microscopic level. This is in particular very important for coolant as the medium that is used to transfer the fission energy to fluids that turn the turbine as well as for solid state material used in nuclear industry where they may have interface to fluids. It is now known within the nuclear industry that understanding the effects of metal ions and their interaction with coolant radiation products is important when controlling the chemistry in reactor coolants. For example; iron (Fe) transport and speciation in the heat transport system is key to controlling the transport of activated products and irradiation will change the speciation and properties of Fe-based material in reactors. Another very important types of materials that their interaction with radiation affects both nuclear energy and radiation therapy are nanomaterials. In this project; we will focus on such studies. The student will work on the project both in our lab and at different particle accelerators in the world that we travel to and the student will also be involved with beam time proposal applications. All the data analysis and sample preparations will be done in our lab. The student will also take part in the discussions with our industrial partners. Certain nationalities can also travel with us to Canadian Nuclear Laboratories and other particle accelerator based facilities if the timing of the students match such travels for some of our experiments. All travel costs to particle accelerators for research will be supported
Skills: Fourth year student in chemistry or physics with interests in physical chemistry or chemical physics and with good hands on and computer skills; and familiar with data analysis and error propagation. An engineering student in fourth year can also work on this project if the student has taken enough science courses and is good with programing and data analysis. A course in quantum (either physics or chemistry) is advantageous but is not required.

Name: Radiation chemistry for Nuclear reactors: effects of ions
Description: Nuclear energy is an important source of energy that helps to significantly reduce green house gases and therefore global warming. It is an important source of energy that we can use to decrease the dependency on fossil fuels as sources of energy. However; their safe and economic applications require a very good understanding of radiation chemistry. This is in particular very important for coolant as the medium that is used to transfer the fission energy to fluids that turn the turbine. It is now known within the nuclear industry that understanding the effects of metal ions and their interaction with coolant radiation products is important when controlling the chemistry in reactor coolants. For example; iron (Fe) transport and speciation in the heat transport system is key to controlling the transport of activated products and irradiation will change the speciation and properties of Fe-based material in reactors. In this project; we will focus on the effects of different ions on corrosion of solid materials at interfaces with fluids and their effects on radiation chemistry in water. The student will work on the project both in our lab and at different particle accelerators in the world that we travel to. All the data analysis and sample preparations will be done in our lab. The student will also take part in the discussions with our industrial partners. Certain nationalities can also travel with us to Canadian Nuclear Laboratories for some of our experiments. All travel costs to particle accelerators for research will be supported by the supervisor grants.
Skills: Fourth year student in chemistry or physics with interests in physical chemistry or chemical physics and with good hands on and computer skills; and familiar with data analysis and error propagation.

Name: Novel antimicrobial polymers: 1) understnading polymerization mechanism and characterization
Description: This work is on green polymer chemistry. Diversifying the monomers that are environmentally friendly for use in polymerization has great potential to synthesize novel materials with a wide variety of applications. Here we want to use different functional groups in environmentally friendly molecules for polymerization via energetically undemanding; solvent-free process; for a wide range of potentially polymerizable monomers with the hope to develop polymers with a number of functionalities and applications. The functionalities and applications we are investigating are non-selective antimicrobial activity; coatings; adhesive properties as well as other functionalities. The work will be ground breaking since we are developing novel polymers and new polymerization processes and we are developing novel formulations. The attributes of our processes are their simplicity; compatibility with a large variety of monomers; solvents; and reaction conditions. The student will work on the project both in our lab and may travel with us to different particle accelerators in the world that we travel to for some of our characterization experiments. All the data analysis and sample preparations will be done in our lab. The student will also take part in the discussions with our industrial partners. All travel costs to particle accelerators for research will be supported by the supervisor grants. The student can choose to work on the fundamental aspect of the project or the applied part in collaboration with industry. If the work is collaborative with industry; a non-disclosure agreement needs to be signed. The fundamental aspects are related to investigation of the electronic properties of monomers; reactive intermediates (during propagation step); and initiators and the mechanism of propagation while the applied aspects involve characterization of polymers and testing their functionalities. The most important functionalities are the anti-microbial properties.
Skills: Fourth year student in chemistry or indicated engineering students with good hands on and computer skills; and familiar with data analysis and error propagation.

Name: D'où viennent les terpènes des limaces?
Description: Slugs are formidable herbivores; but they seem vulnerable with their slow movement and lack of physical defence such as a shell. However; they manage to survive as they can be observed in large numbers in forests and gardens. The key to their success lies in their ability to produce mucus; a viscous liquid made up mainly of water; which serves as a lubricant for movement; a means of defence and an intraspecific recognition system. As a result of work done by my research group; molecules of the terpene family have been discovered in several slug species. For the moment; the function of these molecules is unknown. To help us in our investigations; we need a powerful tool to perform laboratory experiments with slugs or small insects. The objective of this research project is therefore to build a maze for in vivo experiments that will be fully automated and easily dismountable for cleaning. A concept of a central enclosure; connected by orthogonal tunnels; will be developed. It should also be dismountable and constructed from inert material in order to be able to clean the surfaces with organic solvents. Motion detectors will be placed at each end of the tunnels to track the movement of the subjects. The signals will be processed by a postcard-type computer using an algorithm capable of deconstructing the movements in the tunnels and storing the information in the form of a matrix (x; y; t). To validate the device; a pheromonal activity test will be performed with slugs that will have to follow a trail of chemical compounds traced on the ground before the arrival of a subject. Statistical analyses will be performed to evaluate different performance criteria.
Skills: The student must have skills in prototype design; electronics; programming and statistics. He/she should also have a basic knowledge of chemistry and/or biology in order to understand the objectives of the work. The student will have to demonstrate a high degree of autonomy since he/she will be joining a group of chemists with little experience in prototype design.

Name: Molecular mechanisms of obesity-induced cardiac dysfunction - role of lysophospholipase signaling_Clone
Description: Metabolic disorders; particularly insulin resistance and type 2 diabetes; are believed to be primary causative factors for obesity-induced heart disease; which accounts for 11%-14% of heart failure cases. Insulin resistance and diabetes can precipitate “metabolic cardiomyopathy”; which is characterized by changes in metabolism; structure and function of the myocardium that are not directly attributable to confounding factors including coronary artery disease and hypertension. Understanding the pathogenesis of this form of cardiomyopathy is important considering the current obesity and diabetes epidemic; which is expected to lead to a sharp increase in the prevalence of metabolic cardiomyopathy in the near future. Currently; no adequate therapies are available for obesity-related metabolic cardiomyopathy. The overall goal of this research is to identify signalling pathways in cardiomyocytes that not only play a critical role in the development of metabolic cardiomyopathy; but also exhibit great potential for therapeutic targeting. The lysophosphatidic acid (LPA) signalling pathway has been implicated by our group and others in obesity-related metabolic dysfunction. LPA is a bioactive lipid which stimulates cell signalling through G protein-coupled receptors. Several LPA receptor modulators have been developed that are in clinical trials or have been approved for the treatment of idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis; systemic sclerosis; and multiple sclerosis; demonstrating that LPA signalling modulators have promising therapeutic potential in chronic inflammatory diseases. Lipid phosphate phosphatases (LPPs) are integral membrane proteins that dephosphorylate intra -and extracellular lipids including LPA. Decreases in LPP3 function and the subsequent surge in LPA levels in the vasculature are a major contributor to the development of atherosclerosis and coronary artery disease. More recently; LPP3 has also been implicated in the regulation of energy metabolism. Adipose-specific LPP3 inactivation improved glucose homeostasis in mice fed a cholesterol-rich diet. Moreover; heart-specific LPP3 deletion perturbed mitochondrial ultrastructure and decreased respiration and ATP production in neonatal murine cardiomyocytes.
Skills: The student would need to have some experience in working in a research laboratory. Students with a background in biochemistry and/or cell biology are preferred.

Name: Role of artificial intelligence and digital marketing in green innovation of SMEs
Description: The research project focuses on the importance of green technologies including artificial intelligence and digital marketing on the green innovation within SMEs. The literature has confirmed that green innovation plays a vital role in achieving sustainable performance. Green innovation refers to the innovation in technology applied to minimize cost and waste for enhancing organizational social and financial performance. This project aims to explore; analysis and discover technologies in many fields that contribute to overall sustainable development and green innovation.
Skills: Literature skills (research; reading and synthesizing articles) Skills in research methodologies Conduct interviews to collect and analyze data
Student academic background: Accounting; Actuarial Science; American Studies; Arabic Language; Asian Studies; Australian Studies; Business; Canadian Studies; Comparative Literature; Computer Science; Development Studies; Electronic Systems; Engg-Computer; Engg-Enviromental; Engg-Manufacturing; Engg-Systems and Technology; Engineering; Environmental Studies; French Language; French Studies; Information Studies; International Business; International Studies; International Business and Trade; Land Information; Management; Management Information Systems; Manufacturing; Marketing; Media Studies; Quantitative Surveying; Russian Studies; Scandinavian Studies; Science and Technology; Studies Science and Technology

Name: Environmentally-friendly regenerated cellulose fibres from hemp and post-consumer recycled textiles
Description: The project is nested into a large R&D program that looks at establishing a made-in-Canada supply of regenerated cellulose fibres using Canadian sources of cellulose and the environmentally-friendly Lyocell process. It aims at determining the optimal characteristics of the sources of cellulose and parameters of the production process as well as the appropriate performance improvement technologies for regenerated cellulose fiber products through the Lyocell process for different applications. The applications targeted by the project include personal protective equipment (PPE); dental floss and healthcare products; nonwoven products; filtration media; and consumer apparel textiles. The project will determine the parameters leading to the production of high-performance regenerated cellulose filaments using local sources of cellulose and the environmentally-friendly Lyocell process. In the first phase of the project; the pulp dissolution and extrusion processes will be optimized to get the best performance for the pure cellulose filaments. In the second phase; the performance of the filament will be improved using different technologies to meet the requirements associated with the different applications of interest. This project will pave the way to produce made-in-Canada environmentally friendly cellulose-based fibres for a wide range of products.
Skills: In addition to solid skills in materials science and engineering; it is critical that the student is curious and rigorous. They should also be able to work independently while displaying a good ability for teamwork. Oral and written communication skills are important as well. Expertise in textiles and lab work experience; for instance at preparing samples and characterizing materials performance; are an asset.

Name: Investigating potential of thermal electric storage
Description: To reduce greenhouse gas emissions we need to stop using fossil fuels to heat the water and air used in buildings. The objective of this project is to study how thermal energy storage technologies can be used for this purpose. Specifically; we want to provide real estate managers with the necessary tools so they can easily identified buildings where thermal storage should be installed. We have access to detailed data from a building stock where thermal storage has been implemented in the past. The objective of our group is to develop a tool that can predict the potential of thermal storage to reduce GHG emissions in future projects. To do this; it will be necessary to test the impact of thermal electrical storage on the energy profile of different buildings through modelling. From these results we will be able to identify the caracteristics needed for an efficient coupling.
Skills: • Excellent motivation • Ability to work independently and with a team • Experience in reading architecture and / or engineering plans • Knowledge of HVAC systems • An interest in the energy simulation of buildings
Student academic background: Engg-Mechanical; Engineering; Science and Technology; Architecture

Name: Design principles of molecular machines
Description: The science of thermodynamics was initially developed in the 19th century largely to understand the operation of steam engines and to design new engines that were more efficient in making use of energy to do work. In the last 25 years scientists have developed the field of nonequilibrium statistical mechanics; this theory now permits the exploration of microscopic engines; which evolved to perform energetically costly cellular functions in essentially every living organism. This research project will explore the design principles of these molecular machines: what properties make for a well-designed microscopic machine or collection of machines that efficiently converts between chemical and mechanical energy? Specifically; we will examine models of: FoF1 ATP synthase; the strikingly efficient protein complex that uses electrical energy to make ATP; the high-energy small molecule that is the microscopic equivalent of fuel for living things; kinesin and dynein; the widespread transport motors that carry cargos ranging from nanometer-size vesicles to micron-size organelles; and actomyosin; the collection of myosin motors pulling on actin filaments to contract muscles. This research project will use stochastic simulations of simplified models of individual molecular motors; their interacting components; or their assembly into collective systems; to gain insights into how molecular motors are architecturally constructed; dynamically evolve; and work together to achieve such impressive performance. This work will further our basic understanding of what molecular machines have evolved to do. It will also help engineers design novel molecular machines for technological and biomedical applications; such as renewable energy harvesting; efficient computing; and targeted drug delivery.
Skills: Most important is excitement and enthusiasm to learn and explore. But the following academic exposure will certainly help: physics at the level of a course on thermodynamics and statistical mechanics; mathematics at the level of multivariable calculus; basic familiarity with command-line computer usage (UNIX/Linux-like systems); some experience with programming (especially Python; Matlab; or C++); some exposure to biophysics is a bonus.

Name: Block Copolymer Nanopatterning via Mixed Brush Nanoparticles
Description: The goal of this project is to produce films consisting of ordered arrays of inorganic nanoparticles embedded in polymer matrices. While directed self-assembly (DSA) of block copolymers (BCPs) offers the possibility of sub-10 nm patterning to satisfy the goals of the semiconductor industry to miniaturize electronic components; this approach may be limited in general due to difficulties associated with synthesizing BCPs with precise block lengths on an industrial scale. As an alternative; we have shown that nanoparticles (NPs) functionalized with mixed homopolymer ligands (polystyrene/poly(ethylene oxide; PS/PEO) self-assemble in solution into micelles; lamellae and vesicles; similar to their BCP counterparts with the same polymer volume fractions. (Macromolecules 2018 51; 9951). Previous work in polymer self-assembly of nanoparticles mostly focused on coating NPs with custom synthesized BCP ligands or using BCPs to template NP assemblies. In our approach; NPs with dense mixed polymer shells that span the complete composition range; are efficiently produced in large quantities through a simple ligand exchange protocol; eliminating both the need to synthesize a library of block copolymers with different block lengths as well as additional steps to incorporate inorganic components. The use of homopolymer ligands and our highly reproducible ligand exchange method allows precise control of molecular weights and polymer volume fractions. We have also produced poly(2-vinylpyridine) P2VP-PEO and P2VP-PS mixed brush metal oxide NPs and nanorods that self-assemble in response to pH; quaternization and selective solvents. The PS-PMMA combination widely used in industry will also be explored along with biodegradable biopolymers in the interest of sustainability. The mixed brush NP synthetic protocol is easily adapted to NPs of different sizes; shapes and compositions; allowing the incorporation of a wide range of functionalities.
Skills: The student should have basic laboratory skills as normally acquired from undergraduate organic; analytical and physical chemistry laboratory courses. Colloidal chemistry and surface characterization methods will be acquired as part of the research project. A general interest in polymer properties and nanoparticles is desirable.

Name: Functionalization of graphene electrodes for supercapacitor applications
Description: Graphene consists of a two-dimensional arrangement of carbon atoms in a honeycomb lattice and has gained significant attention in the field of energy storage due to its high specific surface area (SSA) of 2630 m2/g. This high SSA makes graphene an excellent choice for electrochemical devices like supercapacitors which can be used for applications such as back-up and regenerative energy systems. Unlike a battery; a supercapacitor stores energy via electrical double layer formation (ion adsorption) on the surface of the electrode material. The aim of this project is to make electrodes through a self-assembly process of graphene oxide (GO); a precursor to graphene. The oxygen groups on the surface of the graphene make the GO hydrophilic; which allows to disperse it in water with high concentrations. The oxygen groups can be removed with simple heat (hydrothermal) treatment of the GO dispersion resulting in the agglomeration of the reduced GO (rGO) in form of so called graphene hydrogels; which can be directly used as supercapacitor electrodes. The additional introduction of selected chemical precursors (such as phosphoric acid; urea or sodium sulfide) to the hydrothermal reduction of the GO changes the self-assembly process which can result in higher SSA and higher electronic conductivity. Moreover; it functionalizes the graphene by introducing new active surface groups that van be useful for electrochemical reactions. In the frame of this project; we test different recipes for making functionalized graphene hydrogels. These hydrogels will be characterized in terms of their SSA; conductivity; and hydrophobicity. Promising materials will be used in a supercapacitor and their performance will be tested.
Skills: The work is suitable for undergraduate students with a background in chemical; materials or mechanical engineering or in chemistry or physics with an interest in applied science. The student should have some experience in working in a chemical lab performing wet and analytical chemistry. A background/interest in electrochemistry/electrochemical engineering would be an asset.
Student academic background: Engg-Chemical; Engg-Materials; Engg-Mechanical; Engineering; Chemistry; Physics

Name: Studying Deep Learning Methods for Software Security Vulnerability Detection
Description: Software plays an important role in the implementation and operation of critical infrastructure; industrial automation; network management and emerging IoT systems. The growing demand for system interconnectivity; interoperability and scalability makes software development more complex & prone to security vulnerabilities (e.g. ransomware; malwares; system exploits; etc.). Recent research has reported; that more than 90% of the cyber security attacks occur due to application vulnerabilities and lack of security controls. The safe execution of a system depends on secure and reliable software. Recently; industry and academic researchers have shown keen interest in studying applications of machine learning and artificial intelligence to develop tools and techniques that can detect application vulnerabilities; run dynamic program analysis; automate test case generation; perform error mining and develop predictive security controls. The aim of this project is to develop new techniques to detect software security vulnerabilities by applying deep learning methods. The project will focus on investigating Deep Neural Network (DNN) and Genetic Algorithm (GA) for security bug prediction and compare the efficiency of both techniques in detecting security vulnerabilities.
Skills: Knowledge of Software engineering techniques and development lifecycle Knowledge of software testing techniques. Good Programming Skills – Python and data science libraries Basic Mathematical Skills – Probability; Calculus; and Statistics Data Analytics Skills – Knowledge of Machine Learning Algorithms Other Technical Skills – Data Interpretation and Writing Techniques

Name: The effects of ischemic preconditioning on exercise capacity during high-intensity interval training
Description: High-intensity interval training (HIIT); repeated bouts of high-intensity exercises interspersed by recovery periods; is a time-efficient training modality to improve exercise capacity. However; in order to increase training adaptations; there is a scope to identify new strategies that could increase this training stimulus. Ischemic preconditioning (IPC); a non-invasive technique who acutely increase performance; seems promising to achieve this goal. Thus; the specific aim of this project is to caracterize the effects of IPC on physiological responses and exercise capacity during different HIIT sessions (2 types) in males and females. To do so; participants will complete 6 visits. The first visit included a maximal incremental cycling test. The second visit will familiarize the participants to the training procedures. Finally; visits 3 to 8 allowed the participants to execute each HIIT session twice (preceded by IPC or placebo). During these training; we continuously monitored heart rate; power output; O2 consumption and muscle oxygenation changes (O2 uptake and local blood volume) to examine physiological response to each training and IPC-induced changes.
Skills: Autonomy at work Comprehension of written and spoken English Basic knowledge in physiology Computer programming an asset

Name: Clustering with Mixtures of Functional Linear Regression Models
Description: Functional data are used to represent curves; surfaces; or multidimensional functions; and sample elements are formed by random functions. For example; for analyzing traffic data and finding trends in traffic flow related to speed differences and weather conditions we work with four-dimensional random functions measured through a road section over a certain time interval; and representing the number of cars having a speed 5-10 km/h under the speed limit; the number of cars having a speed 0-5 km/h over the speed limit; the visibility; and the temperature. The main goal of the project is to construct a family of cluster-weighted models for clustering functional data. Cluster weighted models extend the finite mixture of regression models to include modelling of the covariates. We consider functional regression models for which both the response and the covariates are multidimensional functions. For the traffic data the response is represented by the values of the four-dimensional functions measured during the rush-hour interval in the afternoon; and the covariates represents the measurements made from early morning to the beginning of the afternoon rush-hour. The models in this project are based on a family of skewed distributions; and an expectation-maximization (EM) algorithm is constructed for parameter estimation.
Skills: Good programming skills in at least one of the following languages: R; Python; Matlab; or C. Statistical/Machine Learning background in: Probability theory; Statistical estimation: EM algorithm; Regression; Multivariate analysis or Machine learning/ Artificial Intelligence

Name: The Art of Persuasion: America’s Management of Reluctant Allies in an Era of Great Power Competition
Description: Experts ponder whether the United States can sustain its global leadership in the face of assertive and aggressive aspirations from China and Russia. In recent years; many have observed that formal US allies have pursued diverse strategic paths to enhance their security amid intense competition among great powers in places like Ukraine; Syria and the South China Sea. Some allies; such as France and Germany; have emphasized their strategic autonomy; called for the establishment of a European army; and questioned the dominant role of NATO in European defense. Other allies; like the Philippines and Turkey; have even distanced themselves from Washington and threatened to sever their ties with their security patron. How is America addressing the increasing number of reluctant allies on the global stage? This poses a significant challenge for the United States; which has diligently built a robust network of alliances over the past 75 years. This research project aims to explore whether the United States has developed a strategy to maintain its alliances and; specifically; whether it has a coherent approach to dealing with allies who exhibit unexpected and problematic behaviors—reluctant allies who resist aligning with Washington’s leadership (loose cannons; troublemakers).
