Does the United States rely on coercion; persuasion; bribery; or shaming? And are these strategies effective? The relationships between Washington and five key reluctant allies will be analyzed: France; Germany; Hungary; Turkey; and the Philippines.
Skills: L'étudiant.e. doit maitriser l'anglais et le français et doit connaître le champ d'études des relations internationales. Une connaissance des langues suivantes serait un atout: l'allemand; le hongrois; le turc et le philippin. Il ou elle doit également avoir un intérêt marqué pour la géopolitique et les enjeux de sécurité internationale. Une bonne connaissance du système politique américain et de la politique étrangère des États-Unis est également importante.

Name: Quantum-Enhanced Mobile Communications Beyond 5G
Description: To meet high expectations; and overcome many challenges; mobile communications require novel disruptive technologies. The upcoming 6G networks; in particular; move away from microwaves (1-100GHz; 3-5G networks) to higher-frequency sub-mm waves (~0.1-1Terahertz; wavelengths 3-0.3mm); enabling a 10-100 fold increase in data rates (~10-100Gbps). Moreover; as wavelength shrinks; communication devices become more compact and capable of emitting highly directional beams advantageous for secure communications. Importantly; the Terahertz range is unique as sub-mm waves can be generated both electronically and optically; presenting novel opportunities for classical and quantum photonics-assisted communications. This projects aims at pursuing several disruptive technologies for Terahertz communications using recent breakthroughs in quantum optics; optical computing; optical signal processing; and manufacturing. Optical data processing is faster and more energy-efficient than electronic processing. A focusing lens performs an Optical spatial Fourier Transform (OFT) of a monochrome image at light speed. Also; photonics can accelerate electronic signal processing by taking over vector-matrix multiplications. Optical co-processors were recently demonstrated in the infrared using interferometer meshes with tunable phase elements. Our first objective is to develop optical co-processors in the THz that can apply arbitrary unitary transformations to a vector of input modes. We will focus on devices for energy-efficient temporal signal transformations for wireless signal transmission; acceleration of data processing for Multiple-Input Multiple-Output systems; and implementation of quantum protocols (e.g. complex Hadamards) for quantum THz communications. Our second goal is to study quantum THz communications with the goal of finding novel quantum system designs. First; we will study the SPDC-based sources of THz/infrared entangled photons. Then; we will use such sources to explore a variety of quantum modalities for secure communications; nonlocal beamforming of THz light; quantum ghost surveyance of the communication environment; etc. Finally; additive manufacturing of 3D integrated THz optical circuits will be explored using advanced functional materials.
Skills: Students should be interested in experimental research in engineering or physics. While numerical simulations will be used during the project; most of the focus will be on the laboratory work. Solid understanding of linear optics is required. Basic understanding of non-linear photonics is an advantage; but not a requirement. The project is multidisciplinary; and it finds itself at the intersection of engineering; physics and information theory. The applicant should be comfortable with exposure to the concepts from different research fields. It is expected that teams of up to two students will be working on each of the two project objectives.

Name: Hybrid Solution Processed Solar Cells
Description: The research project involves studying the impact of several chemical treatment processes on the stability and performance of solution processed solar cells. These chemical treatment processes include integrating Lewis acid-base adduct approaches to the fabrication of high efficiency solar cells. The colloidal quantum dot films will be fabricated in the lab using a blade coating procedure on glass and ITO substrates. Optical microscopy; scanning electron microscopy; and x-ray powder diffraction data will be obtained to investigate the crystal structure and morphology of the fabricated quantum films. Absorbance and photoluminescence data will be collected to investigate the impact of the chemical treatments on the stability of the solar cells. Solar testing will be performed on the perovskite ITO films to test their electrical performance at varying illumination intensities. This electrical testing data includes current-voltage; responsivity; detectivity; light to dark current ratio; and photocurrent stability data. The impact of the chemical treatment processes on the degradation of the films will be analyzed by storing the samples inside a nitrogen glovebox for re-testing over prolonged periods of time. This experience will allow hands-on experience on the design; fabrication and testing of solar cells; all the way from material growth to a complete device. The student will be working with graduate students and learning all the techniques involved in characterization and testing which will be valuable in their future academic STEM careers.
Skills: The student needs to be interested in science and engineering; passionate about research. The preferred background of the student would be chemical engineering; materials science engineering or electrical engineering. Chemistry and Physics students are also welcomed or any related fields to those cited.

Name: Evaluating Emotion Theories with Emotion Recognition Models
Description: ACHAI (Affective Computing and Human-AI Interaction Lab) focuses on modeling complex emotional behavior during social interactions; to better understand human behavior and advance interactive technologies. This project will be a part of the larger research effort on advancing emotion research using and testing computational models. We specifically focus on different emotion representations in emotion recognition tasks; importance of contextual information in standard facial emotion recognition and sentiment analysis; and computational representation of appraisals and other cognitive theories of emotion. We welcome Cognitive Scientists and Computer Scientists with a focus of interdisciplinary approaches to AI. The project will involve utilizing readily available emotion datasets to test several emotion theories and their effectiveness in explaining and detecting human affect. The student is not expected to be an expert in Affective Computing; but an enthusiasm to learn and focus on emotion recognition will be required. The PI and other students in the lab will provide guidance in the dataset/model selection and overall project planning.
Skills: I am looking for a student who: - at least took one Artificial Intelligence or ML course; knows about basic Data processing/cleaning in R or Python - is experienced in Python and knowledgeable about popular ML libraries such as PyTorch; Tensorflow - is interested in Affective Computing or took a course / did projects in Affective Computing - is experienced with using git (please send your github info showcasing projects) and environment management systems such as conda or venv - is organized; excellent in time-management and can independently take on & deliver small research projects

Name: 2D Perovskite solar cells
Description: Metal halide perovskites have great potential as light-absorbing materials for solar cells but suffer from poor stability and scalability. By inserting organic molecules into the perovskite solution mixture more stable two-dimensional (2D) perovskites are created. Typically; 2D perovskites are deposited using spin-coating; which is a method that is difficult to scale. In the state-of-the-art Koleilat lab; solution-shearing is used; which is compatible with high-throughput industrial-scale processes. This project deals with building stable highly efficient 2D perovskite solar cells. Materials engineering and systematic design of the structure and its various interfaces are also required in this project. These unique solar cells will have the potential to set records for performance and stability of perovskite solar cells.
Skills: The student needs to be interested in science and engineering; passionate about research. The preferred background of the student would be chemical engineering; materials science engineering or electrical engineering. Chemistry and Physics students are also welcomed or any related fields to those cited.

Name: Stretchable solar cells
Description: With the freedom of simply using different types of fabric; employing diverse patterns; and connecting the fibers using various techniques such as weaving or felting; there exist considerable potential for pioneering electronic designs. In general; solution based materials can be spun into fibers and yarns themselves and they are highly elastic in all directions. Until now there is no solution to fabricating air-stable; large-surface; solution-coated power textiles. This project focuses on the top transparent conductive electrode properties and available solution-processed particles that can easily infiltrate fabrics; such as graphene nanosheets; conductive polymers or purely metallic carbon nanotubes. The student will investigate the adhesion of the materials to the fibers and their longterm stability. Secondly; they will explore structural issues that will arise from having multiple layers integrated into the fabrics: our group will develop processes that will shield the active layer from electrode diffusion through the fabric but simultaneously guarantee solid contact between all the interfaces of the various fabric layers. Ideally; every layer should remain undisturbed with each additional coat application. With the textile-based substrate being coarse; the processing of all layers will take into account the solubility; temperature stability; adhesion and chemical reactivity of all the underlying materials. Finally we will evaluate the performance of the solar cell created.
Skills: The student needs to be interested in science and engineering; passionate about research. The preferred background of the student would be chemical engineering; materials science engineering or electrical engineering. Chemistry and Physics students are also welcomed or any related fields to those cited.

Name: Electrospinner custom solutions
Description: Integrate a second solution stream to the electrospinner built in the Koleilat group The trainee will be in charge of building a second pump system; programming its specific interface; and connecting it to the electrospinner current setup; which would allow for two solutions to be spun in tandem with separate inputs. The trainee will have to design the needed parts on CAD or similar interface; have them 3D printed; then properly installed (ease of use and safety wise). Interfacing hardware with software is essential in this project and developing a data analysis tool that is user friendly is required.
Skills: The student needs to be interested in science and engineering; passionate about coding and computer engineering. The preferred background of the student would computer/software engineering/computer science or electrical engineering.

Name: Bioinformatic tools for plasmid analysis
Description: Plasmids are small circular pieces of DNA found in bacterial cells that are important due to their role in the spread of antimicrobial resistance (AMR); a major public health concern. Therefore; the problem of discovering plasmids in sequencing data from bacterial pathogens is a very active research area. The problem of discovering plasmids can be addressed through combinatorial optimization approaches that analyze a graph known as the assembly graph; that is generated when sequencing data is assembled; vertices of this graph are called contigs and represent assembled sequences; and edges encode potential contiguity of the contigs along the genome of origin. Over the last two years; in collaboration with Professor Cedric Chauve; we developed several methods for the discovery of plasmids: 1- plASgraph: is a machine-learning tool that classifies contigs as originating from plasmid or chromosomes. 2- Plasbin-flow: is a mixed integer linear programming model that groups contigs into bins; representing groups of contigs likely originating from the same plasmid. It is a hybrid approach that combines optimization with a reference data used to set the parameters of the model. 3- PlasEval: is a set of tools to evaluate the accuracy of plasmid discovery methods. Accuracy evaluation assumes that a ground truth dataset is provided. Considering the fact that these methods are related and the output of one method can be the input of the other method; it is not ideal for users to study plasmids with different methods in different environments. In this project; in collaboration with Professor Cedric Chauve; we are planning to integrate all these methods into a unique pipeline. We aim to start to create a pipeline of the tools plASgraph; Plasbin-flow; and PlasEval with the possibility of extending the unique pipeline to also use other classification; binning and evaluation methods.
Skills: The student need to have experience in: 1- Programming in Python 2- github 3- snakemake (useful but not necessary)

Name: Quels sont les impacts des bryophytes sur le recrutement des plantes vasculaires natives et envahissantes post-perturbation ?
Description: Forest floor mosses are well positioned to play key roles in plant-soil feedbacks and their importance in ecosystem functioning; including vascular plant recruitment; is increasingly recognized in northern boreal forests. Whether these contributions remain important at the southern edge of the boreal forest; where forest composition becomes mixed with deciduous species; is not yet known. New Brunswick; Canada; lies in this transition zone and has an active forest industry. Disturbances caused by logging operations that expose mineral soils; including alteration of the moss cover; can create opportunities for the establishment of exotic species. Bryophytes can have facilitating; inhibiting or neutral effects on plant germination. On a recently logged site; cores (15cm diameter) of exposed mineral soil; pioneer mosses; acrocarpous mosses and feather mosses will be collected (5 replicates/species/substrate). The percentage cover of the different substrates and the presence of exotic species will be noted. Then; in growth chamber experiments; we will compare the germination of four exotic species found after forest harvesting in New Brunswick (Plantago major; Ranunculus acris; Taraxacum officinale; Veronica officinalis) and of a very invasive shrub in the region (Frangula alnus) on the different substrates. Large-seeded species are expected to tolerate a greater variety of conditions than species with smaller seeds. Mosses are expected to inhibit germination compared to mineral soil. This project will better assess how disturbances to forest soils and moss communities during harvest may alter the likelihood of natural recruitment of native and exotic plants.
Skills: Although most of the knowledge is acquired through the internship; a basic knowledge and interest in biology; ecology and botany is preferred (studies in biology; botany or environment). The student must be prepared to work in an outdoor environment under variable weather conditions. This project also requires a responsible; autonomous; organized and meticulous individual; as the person will be responsible for maintaining the germination experiments in the laboratory and for data collection and management. A basic understanding of experimental design and statistical analysis is desirable; but not necessary.
Student academic background: Biological Sciences; Biology; Botany; Forestry; Environmental Studies; Ecology

Name: Omniphobic electronics
Description: Research and develop an omniphobic coating for polymeric materials; testing the coated material's washability and its stability after multiple washing cycles. The trainee will learn how to prepare different chemical solutions and polymer films while getting trained on proper equipment use and safe handling of chemicals. They will be expected to apply these solutions to a polymer's surface via different techniques (spray coating; dip coating; electrospinning ...). The trainee will then test the coated films in a simulated washing machine environment. They will then test the champion films' physical and electrical integrity by conducting specific experiments over a set number of consecutive measurements. Once the omniphobic property is established; the trainee will apply it to electronic devices.
Skills: The student needs to be interested in science and engineering; passionate about research. The preferred background of the student would be chemistry; chemical engineering; materials science engineering or electrical engineering or any related fields to those cited.

Name: Reaction--diffusion systems with anomalous diffusion
Description: As the experimental measurement techniques advanced; it became clear that the regular diffusion model failed to describe faithfully many diffusive processes; most often in biology and geology. Novel diffusion mechanisms; known as anomalous; currently are at the height of researchers' interest. The goal is to simulate an especially slow or fast type of diffusion that is often encountered in biological tissues and tracer diffusion through geological layers. This project is suitable for an inquisitive; critical and completeness seeking mind. The work combines abstract thinking and numerical implementation. This is a good training opportunity for students; who envision themselves working in inter-disciplinary research and development. The intern will gain valuable skills in working in the Unix environment; parallel computing and visualisation of multi-scale solutions. Adequate progress in this project might serve as a step toward continued research and a Master's or PhD degree. The expected outcomes are (a) code in C and/or Matlab performing the simulation of a reaction--diffusion system with anomalous diffusion (b) error analysis (c) insight into solutions in different parts of the parameter space (d) comparison with asymptotic solutions and with counterparts employing regular diffusion models.
Skills: Skills / background: (a) concepts in dynamical systems (b) concepts in numerical analysis (c) C language; MATLAB/Octave an advantage Background: engineering; physics; mathematics or combination of these disciplines.

Name: Application of Machine Learning tools for development and characterization of nanoparticles to improve agricultural sustainability
Description: Application of nanoparticles (NPs) is governed by their shape; size; dispersity; and surface chemistry. Hence to apply them for agricultural sustainability as nutrient carriers; for plant disease suppression or for pest management (nanopesticides/nanoinsecticides); it is important to synthesise them with precisely controlled characteristics and functional properties. Synthesis of NPs using bottom-up or top-down approach is resource-intensive and time-consuming and often requires multiple iterations (trial and error) of various combinations of reagents and experimental conditions such as reaction time; temperature; and reagent concentration; making the identification of the most efficient NPs synthesis recipe a challenge. To overcome this challenge a more efficient and controlled approach is required. Machine learning (ML) offers a promising platform that can be potentially used for the synthesis of NPs with specific or unique characteristics (size; shape and functionality). In recent years ML algorithms have been effectively employed to predict the antimicrobial property or toxicity profiles of NPs but limited to no study has been reported on prediction of synthesis recipes for NPs with specific or unique characteristics for application as nutrient carriers or for pest management. This study will apply ML tools to predict the synthesis recipe (experimental conditions and reagent combinations) for NPs from gathered in-vitro experimental data from literature studies. The literature data will be structured into comprehensive datasets; to train and test ML models. Supervised ML algorithms will be applied to accurately predict the NPs recipe.
Skills: The student applicant should have a background in engineering; or computer science. The applicant should have excellent oral and written communication skills in addition to being creative and ready to learn new tools and technologies.

Name: Augmented Perception for Autonomous Mobile Robots
Description: This project aims to develop cooperative state estimation and navigation systems for autonomous mobile robots; in presence of model uncertainties. The algorithms will be evaluated by existing unmanned ground vehicle (UGV) robots equipped with GPS/IMU integrated with ROS.
Skills: Background/knowledge: Machine/deep learning; constrained optimization; graph theory; SLAM Programming skills: C++; Python; MATLAB/SIMULINK; and algorithm development with system integration in ROS.

Name: Improving Autonomous Vehicle Navigation and Motion Planning in Dynamic Environments
Description: In this project; data will be collected from on-board vehicle sensory measurements and shared data over infrastructure to enhance motion planning; control and perception of automated driving systems. High-fidelity simulation will also be conducted.
Skills: Background/knowledge: Machine/deep learning; constrained optimization; graph theory; Programming skills: C++; Python; MATLAB/SIMULINK; and algorithm development with system integration in ROS.

Name: VR Cybersickness Symptoms Prediction
Description: Virtual reality (VR) technologies have witnessed remarkable advancements in recent years; enabling immersive and interactive experiences across various domains. However; one critical challenge that hinders the widespread adoption of VR is motion sickness. Motion sickness in VR refers to the discomfort and queasiness individuals may experience when their visual perception conflicts with their vestibular and proprioceptive senses. This sensory conflict arises due to the artificial and visually induced movements in VR environments. The prevalence of motion sickness symptoms in VR not only compromises user experience but also poses a significant barrier to the widespread adoption of this transformative technology. The research project aims to explore novel machine learning and artificial intelligence techniques to detect; estimate; and predict the type and intensity of motion sickness symptoms in virtual reality (VR) environments based on physiological and behavioral sensor data. This project has publication potential and could be the starting point to a master's or PhD thesis depending on the internship's outcome.
Skills: Experience; familiarity or demonstrated interest in the following: - Unity3D - Signal processing - Machine learning and artificial intelligence applied to time series - Conducting an academic literature review - Academic writing - HCI research
Student academic background: Computer Science; Design; Engg-Computer; Engg-Electrical; Engg-Software; Engg-Systems and Technology; Engineering; Industrial Design and Technology

Name: Alleviating Symptoms of VR Cybersickness using Multimodal Interaction Techniques
Description: Virtual reality (VR) technologies have witnessed remarkable advancements in recent years; enabling immersive and interactive experiences across various domains. However; one critical challenge that hinders the widespread adoption of VR is motion sickness. Motion sickness in VR refers to the discomfort and queasiness individuals may experience when their visual perception conflicts with their vestibular and proprioceptive senses. This sensory conflict arises due to the artificial and visually induced movements in VR environments. The prevalence of motion sickness symptoms in VR not only compromises user experience but also poses a significant barrier to the widespread adoption of this transformative technology. The research project aims to explore; design and evaluate novel multimodal interaction techiques (combines multiple human senses) aimed at reducing the serverity of VR cybersickness symptoms. This project has publication potential and could be the starting point to a master's or PhD thesis depending on the internship's outcome.
Skills: Experience; familiarity or demonstrated interest in the following: - Unity3D - haptic; audio and/or visual interactions - Conducting an academic literature review - Academic writing - HCI research
Student academic background: Computer Science; Design; Engg-Computer; Engg-Electrical; Engg-Software; Engg-Systems and Technology; Engineering; Industrial Design and Technology

Name: Haptic Smart Assistants: What if your smart speaker could touch you?
Description: Despite recent advances in large language model developments; smart assistant technologies remain limited in terms of interaction capabilities. Indeed; while they can entertain increasingly complex conversations; they remain relatively emotionless from a human perspective. This project proposes to explore how the sense of touch could be used to enhance speech-based interactions with such smart assistant technologies. How would users expect to interact with such technologies? What physical form would it have? What could it do and when should it do it? This project has publication potential and could be the starting point to a master's or PhD thesis depending on the internship's outcome.
Skills: Experience; familiarity or demonstrated interest in the following: - audio-haptic interactions - Applying design thinking; UCD and/or future studies methodologies - Conducting an academic literature review - Academic writing - HCI research

Name: Charting the Growth of Galaxies Across Cosmic Time
Description: Galaxies evolve on astronomical timescales of millions or even billions of years. The study of galaxy evolution is therefore based on inferring connections between various galaxy populations across cosmic time. This requires knowledge of galaxy properties; such as distances; sizes; masses; ages; and star formation rates. The student will learn how to extract such information from galaxy images and and spectra. Driven by the student's interest; the project will tackle one of these important research questions: What triggers or shuts down star formation in galaxies? How do active supermassive black holes influence star formation of their host galaxies? What happens to galaxies when they collide with each other? The student will apply their Python computing skills to handle large datasets and images; to make measurements and conduct an error analysis; to visualize and to present findings. These skills are relevant for a variety of projects in astronomy; other research disciplines and beyond academia. The student will have the opportunity to contribute as an author to a research publication or telescope proposal. Keywords: astronomy; telescope observations; data analysis; statistics; galaxies; black holes; images; spectra; python programming; optical and near-infrared astronomy; submillimeter and radio astronomy; big data
Skills: Required skills and background: - Knowledge in physics - Experience with Python programming - Communication skills; including good reading; listening; speaking and writing skills in English - Self-motivation and Independence - Critical thinking - Curiosity The following skills/knowledge are not required but will be highly beneficial: - Knowledge in astronomy and statistics - Experience in data analysis - LaTeX - GitHub - SQL

Name: The Evolving Arctic Security and Governance Environment
Description: The Evolving Arctic Security and Governance Environment project examines how the Circumpolar North is changing in the face of climate change; resurgent geopolitical competition; and technological change. This project is connected to research programme of the North American and Arctic Defence and Security Network (NAADSN – www.naadsn.ca) based at Trent University and comprised of leading experts from across Canada; the United States; and Europe. Canada’s defence policy describes the Arctic as an “important international crossroads where issues of climate change; international trade; and global security meet;” and commits to “work cooperatively with Arctic partners.” Our project seeks to: clarify how Canada and its partners can implement this policy direction; generate and provide immediate access to leading-edge research; and test assumptions about the changing Arctic security environment on international; regional; and national scales. Pursuant to this theme; we analyze the security implications of climate change and technology; international strategic drivers (such as evolving North American; Russian; European; and Asian Arctic interests); and global competition to frame the Arctic in ways beneficial to different stakeholders and rightsholders. We also adopt a broad definition of security that includes topics such as search and rescue; emergency management and disaster response; and Arctic Indigenous Peoples’ perspectives on safety and security. Our work on governance in the Arctic examines the role of the Arctic Council and other circumpolar bodies; many of which have been affected by the War in Ukraine. It also examines how international legal frameworks apply to the Arctic; including the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS) and the United Nations Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples (UNDRIP); and how different Arctic rightsholders and stakeholders might interpret and seek to apply international law differently.
Skills: The student must own a laptop computer; be familiar with Microsoft Office; and have experience conducting internet-based research. She/he/they must also have strong English reading and writing skills. The student also must be well organized; able to work with minimal supervision; and must be comfortable working as part of a team. Although the position does not require any specific disciplinary background and is open to interested individuals from across the social sciences and law; the student should have at least a basic familiarity with the Arctic region and international relations.
Student academic background: Political Science; International Studies; History; Canadian Studies; Economics; European Studies; Geography; Japanese Studies; Korean Studies; Law-International; Native Studies; Public Policy and Administration; Russian Studies; Scandinavian Studies

Name: Succession naturelle et perturbations en forêt boréale
Description: L'actuel aménagement forestier durable s'inspire largement de la succession naturelle en forêt boréale. Des placettes permanentes de 1ha sont installées dans la Forêt d'enseignement et de recherche du lac Duparquet en forêt boréale mixte dans des peuplements de stades successifs variés. Ces parcelles permettent un suivi réel depuis plus de vingt ans de la croissance des arbres; de la régénération naturelle et de la mortalité des arbres et ses causes.
Skills: Formation ou expérience en écologie forestière ou biologie végétale; habileté minimale avec les ordinateurs. Intérêt marqué pour le travail en forêt. Permis de conduire valide et au moins 21 ans; un atout.

Name: Development of an Open-Sourced Software Package for Structural Health Monitoring
Description: Structural health monitoring (SHM) is the process of continuously observing and analyzing a system utilizing sampled response measurements to identify damage in engineering structures like bridges and buildings. SHM is a very important research field that improves the sustainability and safety of current infrastructure systems. The successful implementation of SHM systems can significantly reduce the costs of maintenance by identifying the potential damage in structures in their early stage. The research in SHM involves the analysis of a large amount of data. However; there is a lack of robust and user-friendly software packages that can be used by researchers and companies to process the SHM data efficiently. Usually; the researchers and companies have to develop their own implementation of data analysis algorithms or use software packages which are not specifically designed for SHM. Some commonly used techniques; such as system identification and signal processing algorithms; have been repeatedly implemented by different researchers and companies. The project aims to develop a universal and open-source software package that can benefit the researchers and industrial companies who are using sensor data for SHM purposes. The student is expected to build the framework of the open-source project. The software system should have the following characteristics: 1) Universality: The software system should be able to process data from different sensors and in different formats. 2) Expandability: Researchers and companies can easily expand the functionality of the software by developing based on the framework and/or contributing to the open-source project; 3) Robustness: The software should be able to implement SHM algorithms efficiently across different platforms.
Skills: 1. Knowledge of software development using Python. 2. Highly motivated; well organized; and passionate about research with good communication skills in English. 3. Self-starter and motivator with the mindset of focusing on deliverables and getting the job done in time. 4. Experience in report writing and publishing is an asset. 5. Experience in signal processing or artificial intelligence is an asset.

Name: Extending an open-source static analysis tool (parser) for TypeScript
Description: The intern will improve the features of an open-source static analysis tool (parser) for the TypeScript language. This tool is used in a chain of tools used for doing research involving data-mining of object-oriented (TypeScript; Java; Python) code for understanding the evolution of software projects on popular web frameworks such as Angular and React.
Skills: Familiarity with open-source software repositories (GitHub) and tools (git; svn); programming and design with object-oriented design heuristics (GoF patterns). Familiarity with the TypeScript language. The tool to extend works within the ecosystem of the Pharo/Moose environment; which is a smalltalk dialect; and so it is a recommended skill for applicants. Applicants can become familiar with this technology via the MOOC: http://files.pharo.org/mooc/. Understanding of parsing and ASTs is a plus.

Name: Empirical analyses (data mining) of open-source software
Description: The intern will perform empirical analyses of various open-source projects using tools such as Pharo/Moose; R Studio; etc. The analyses will be done on design qualities such as stability; fault-proneness; change-proneness; etc.
Skills: Familiarity with open-source software repositories (Github) and tools (git; svn); programming and design with object-oriented design heuristics (GoF patterns); and ideally R Studio for statistical analyses. The Pharo/Moose environment is a smalltalk dialect; which is a recommended skill for applicants. Applicants can become familiar with this technology via the MOOC: http://files.pharo.org/mooc/

Name: L’élaboration du Recueil de textes essentiel en théories criminologiques
Description: La criminologie; comme la science de l’étude du phénomène criminel; émerge par les interactions des savants et scientifiques en sciences humaines; sociales et naturelles. Elle est; ainsi; considérée; comme un champ d’étude où les différentes disciplines se rencontrent. Le phénomène criminel est une notion assez complexe. C’est pourquoi; malgré la présentation des différentes théories criminologiques traditionnelles ou contemporaines; une meilleure théorie; sans défis; n’existe pas. Cependant; une étude approfondie des théories criminologiques; nous permet; d’une part expliquer le crime ou un type du crime et d’autre part; appliquer ces théories dans un cas réel. Dans ce projet; notre but principal est de recueillir et de présenter les textes importants de certaines théories traditionnelles et contemporaines dans une collection unique en français. En effet; une telle collection permet d’étudier l’évolution de criminologie dans sa globalité. Dans ce projet; en première étape; nous établissons une liste d’une trentaine d’auteurs parmi dix catégories des théories : les premières théories criminologiques; les théories biologiques et biosociales; les théories psychologiques; les théories de structure sociale; les théories de l’apprentissage social; les théories de contrôle social; les théories de réaction sociale; les théories critiques; les théories de l’acte; et les théories développementales. En deuxième étape; nous choisissons un texte pertinent de chacun des auteurs (des théories) qui comprend les éléments essentiels des théories mentionnées. Une brève explication pour chaque théorie se trouvera au début de chacun des chapitres. Dans la préparation de ce recueil; les articles anglais seront traduits en français. En plus; si le texte essentiel d’une théorie est un ouvrage ou un long article; nous les résumons en étant fidèles aux idées abordées par l’auteur ou les auteurs. Quelques exemples de tel recueil se trouvent dans la littérature criminologique anglaise; mais cela sera une initiative pertinente en français.
Skills: Dans ce projet; nous sollicitons la participation des étudiants en criminologie; en sociologie; en droit ou en traduction. Une connaissance avancée de l’anglais et du français spécialisée est requise dans ce projet.

Name: Organic Carbon Water Quality Analysis
Description: Canada annually treats over 2900 million m3 of water for household use; with nearly 88% coming from surface water sources. Water contains a number of dissolved constituents including particulates; dissolved anions and cations; natural organic matter (NOM) and microbes. NOM is present in all surface and ground waters sources and consists of a range of compounds with a wide variety of chemical compositions and molecular sizes. The presence of NOM affects the colour; odor and taste of the water; in addition it is common precursor for disinfection by-products; and is a component of material that may cause negative operational issues with membrane technology. Characterization of NOM in terms of quantity and composition are useful in gaining insights into NOM pre and post various water treatment strategies. Working within the Basu Research Group alongside a talented group of graduate students; the MITACS intern will have the opportunity to learn about and become engaged with a variety of environmental engineering projects. In particular; the Globalinks Intern will be given a specialized project related to Environmental Water Quality in order to enhance their understanding of the analytical needs within the water sector. For this project; the intern will be tasked with assessing the movement of NOM type organic contaminants subject to various treatment processes. The intern will map characterization tools to the organics and develop a view of which analytical measurements provide key information on the pollutant movements through an environmental system. The Globalinks Intern will be working with a Total Organic Carbon Analyzer; UV-Vis Spectroscopy; Fluorescence Emission Excitation Spectroscopy; and High Performance Liquid Chromatography in order to develop a characterization map of various organics in water and wastewater systems.
Skills: A strong background in analytical methods related to chemistry is required for this position. Hands on laboratory experience is a critical criterion for the project. Experience with wet chemistry (preparation of solutions) is required; some hands on experience with analytical equipment is required. Ability to work independently as well as in a team is a desired skill. Willingness and ability to read journal articles; in order to summarize and present information in required. Students will provide project meeting updates to the research team on a regular basis.

Name: Measuring insect emergence from wetlands as a valuable ecosystem service
Description: Wetlands are valuable for many reasons; but the general public still thinks of them as wasted land that can be drained or paved over or otherwise treated poorly. We are aiming to change that by understanding the role of wetlands in supporting healthy ecosystems and figuring out if people care about some of the ecosystem services that they provide. Work underway this year is measuring the total mass of insects leaving wetlands; and measuring concentrations of helpful (omega-3 fatty acids) and harmful (pesticides) compounds in their bodies. Since these insects get eaten by birds; bats and fish; it is important to know if they are a healthy and nutritious food source. Next year (2024); we will use a semi-controlled study to determine if the widespread use of pesticides on farmlands is reducing insect emergence and contaminating this prey source; hindering the ability of wetlands to provide ecosystem services. Parallel surveys will ask the general public if they think wetlands are valuable; and through choice experiments provide a dollar value to some of these ecosystem services.
Skills: The student only needs to be comfortable in an outdoor setting with an interest in the natural world; and willing to spend days in the field wading in wetlands and collecting insects from traps. Some experience keeping good data records would be an asset; but not required. A valid driver's license would be an asset but is also not required.

Name: Active Transportation Longitudinal Aging Study (ATLAS): An examination of supportive infrastructure for age-friendly active transportation on cognition
Description: physical and mental health
Faculty supervisor: The current study unites multiple disciplines from psychology; civil engineering; exercise science and geography to examine the impact of supportive infrastructure for age-friendly active transportation (e.g.; protected cycling lanes and walkways) on longitudinal changes in cognitive function; physical health; and well-being among older adults. The proposed study uses objective geospatial information systems (GIS) mapping of the built environment to identify physical regions that are considered safe and accessible relative to regions with fewer supportive infrastructure for active transportation. Ambulatory cognition and self-reported physical activity and psychological well-being measures will be collected seasonally across 12 months using the MyCogHealth experience sampling app; a data collection tool that permits ongoing survey and cognitive assessments throughout daily life. The proposed study will involve a sample of older adults (N = 100) living in the Capital Regional District (CRD) that comprises 13 municipalities in Greater Victoria on the Southern tip of Vancouver Island; British Columbia. Each municipality varies in the density of cycling and walking infrastructure (e.g.; proportion of separated multi-use pathways). The study will contribute to our understanding of the role that built environments play in facilitating cycling and walking activity among older adults; and whether changes in these activities are systematically related to physical and mental health.
Student academic background: The student is expected to have a strong interest in air pollution; transportation and public health. Students in the field of environmental and civil engineering; land use planning; geography; data science/statistics (with a strong interest in environmental issues) and similar areas of study are welcome to apply. Proficiency with geospatial analysis tools such as ArcGIS and QGIS; and/or knowledge in geospatial analysis using Python or R; are expected. Ideally; the student will also have knowledge in image recognition algorithms to extract information from Google Maps/Google Street View.
column11: Engineering; Engg-Civil; Engg-Enviromental; Environmental Studies; Geography

Name: Enhancing Natural Killer cell-mediated immunotherapy by knocking out regulatory genes
Description: Chimeric Antigen Receptor (CAR)-T therapy is a revolutionary therapy in which T cells acquire an enhanced ability to attack cancerous cells using genetic engineering. CAR-T cell therapy is highly effective but very expensive; mainly due to the need to perform genetic engineering on patients' own T cells. In addition; CAR-T therapies often result in side effects; such as cytokine release syndrome and severe graft-versus-host disease (GvHD) in allogeneic T cell infusion; impeding the enthusiasm for CART therapy. Recently; natural killer (NK) cells have been proposed as an alternative form of CAR therapy that can be used in an “off-the-shelf” allogeneic format without causing severe GvHD. Such CAR-NK therapies could dramatically decrease the cost and increase the affordability of cellular immunotherapies for cancer treatment. However; to play a critical role in anti-tumour activity; infused NK cells should persist. To increase in vivo persistence of NK cells; we are trying to knock out regulatory genes in NK cells using our recently developed Crispr-Cas9 method for editing NK cells. We expect the modified NK cells enhance their in vivo persistence and anti-tumour activity.
Skills: Cell Culture Techniques; Microscopy; Molecular Biology; Gene Cloning; Immunology; Cell Biology; Statistical analysis

Name: Control of Floating Offshore Wind Farms
Description: The goal of the research project is to develop controllers for floating offshore wind farms which optimize the efficiency of the farms. In particular; real-time turbine repositioning of wind turbines via aerodynamic thrust force is used to modify the wind farm layout so that turbines within the farm do not interfere each other due to the wake effect. The dynamical model will be obtained based on the simulation data; and the controllers will be designed based on the model and optimization techniques. The performance of controllers will be evaluated using the wind farm simulator FAST.Farm developed at National Renewable Energy Laboratory in US; in terms of power generation; platform oscillation; and structural loading.
Skills: The student should have a classical control background. It is also preferable (but not mandatory) that the student knows modern control techniques. The student should be familiar with Matlab/Simulink. Student's strong interest in sustainable energy systems in general and wind turbines specifically will be an asset. The student should have strong communication skill in both speaking and writing; and strong interpersonal skill for team work.

Name: Development of self-healing geopolymers concrete composites
Description: Geopolymers are an emerging environmentally friendly cementitious material that has the potential to reduce carbon dioxide emissions associated with the production of Ordinary Portland Cement. They are considered a class of green inorganic polymers suitable for the construction and infrastructure industry. Geopolymers are produced by activating aluminosilicate precursors such as clays or industrial by-products like fly ash; concrete waste; blast furnace slag; red mud; etc.; using an activator solution and appropriate temperature conditions. These materials have gained significant traction in the infrastructure and construction sectors. For example; geopolymer was successfully utilized for an in situ concreting project at the Brisbane West Wellcamp Airport; involving approximately 40;000 m3 of material. However; a key challenge faced by geopolymers is their susceptibility to cracking and subsequent deterioration over time; which can compromise the structural integrity. To address this issue; the application of self-healing geopolymers has emerged as a potential solution for autonomously repairing cracks. Self-healing materials offer several advantages; including reduced monitoring and repair requirements; enhanced reliability; durability; and cost-effectiveness compared to conventional concrete. These intelligent materials draw inspiration from naturally occurring biological phenomena; such as the regeneration of new tissues to replace old and dead plant tissues. The objective of this project is to develop a self-healing geopolymer that can effectively repair mechanical damage and cracks. The candidate will conduct a comprehensive literature review to explore recent developments in self-healing geopolymers and concrete materials. Based on the findings; the candidate will select the most suitable methods and healing agents for the project. The self-healing properties of the developed geopolymers will be studied under accelerated aging conditions; including abrasions and scratches. The physical and mechanical properties of the self-healing geopolymers will be evaluated using the exceptional existing infrastructure at UQAC.
Skills: Undergraduate student in Civil; ceramic; chemical and material engineering. Preference factors: The applicant has proven experience in scientific areas relevant to the project; namely with the concrete.

Name: RAN dataset generation and simulator
Description: We have recently witnessed a surge in the number of ML applications that can be attributed to the increasing availability of data and compute capabilities. In this context; legacy communication systems were designed to satisfy a global QoS constraint and therefore the available data usually lacks granularity and can only be used for limited applications. Moreover; the available data is usually proprietary to communication service providers and are not widely accessible. Quite recently there has been an increasing amount of datasets being made available on data platforms; e.g. IEEE dataport; however; data is generally tailored for a specific application and cannot be used to train/test several ML solutions is a communication system. Despite their recent conception; generative adversary network (GAN) models have been widely used for the creation of accurate synthetic data in numerous domains. The wireless communication research is relatively behind; where this approach has only been used to generate specific data for a certain application and no general framework is available. This project will develop a wireless 5G and beyond (5GB) PHY and MAC layer data generation and simulator for ML applications. To achieved said task; the proposed generative models will be combined with simulations to generate all the necessary features. For instance; generative models can be used to generate data related to the channel quality; traffic; hardware imperfections; noise; environment conditions; user mobility; etc. However; this data needs to be combined with simulations to reach the output of the different steps in RAN/baseband.
Skills: The candidates should have an education in wireless communications or related field. The students will require understanding and experience simulating different radio and baseband processing functions; such as user scheduling; modulation and coding scheme assignment; channel estimation; etc. Experience with programming languages; such as matlab and python; is a must. The ideal candidate would also be confortable with 3GPP specifications and have a good understanding of 5G mobile systems.

Name: Analysing quantum entanglement for quantum communication and quantum computing
Description: In 1935 Einstein; Podolsky and Rosen described a paradox that led them to question the completeness of quantum mechanics. The EPR paradox arose from the fact that measurements of one member of a correlated (entangled) pair of quantum objects seem to instantaneously affect the other member; no matter how far away - an effect Einstein called 'spooky action at a distance'. Quantum entanglement is now known to play an important role in quantum computing and information processing. It may help to revolutionize computing and secure communication; and allow new tasks such as teleportation. This project will explore the nature of quantum correlations between multiple quantum bits (qubits). Correlations in systems of two particles have been studied in the past; due to the feasibility of performing experiments with photons; atoms; or ions. Recently we have begun to analyze quantum networks of three or more particles and we have explored new tasks such as quantum voting and controlled teleportation. The next steps will be to study other interesting systems of 3 or more parties in order to develop a general description of the N-party case. The students will study different measures of quantum correlations such as entanglement and Bell’s inequalities; and work with others to characterize quantum correlations and design and analyze novel communication protocols. He/she/they will experimentally explore quantum correlations and implement small-scale algorithms on the IBM quantum computer. They will explore long-debated questions about the nature of quantum mechanics and gain an understanding of this cutting-edge field. The outcomes of the project will help towards developing quantum technologies and the quantum internet.
Skills: No skills available

Name: Quantum control of chaos for quantum computation and communication (1)
Description: The study of chaos theory has led to great progress in the modeling and control of various real-world systems including lasers; biological systems; robotics; signal processing and financial systems. The chaotic behaviour in these systems is characterized by their extreme sensitivity to small perturbations - a phenomenon popularly known as the butterfly effect. At the quantum level of atoms and photons; the concept of chaos is ambiguous due to the quantum uncertainty principle and the apparent linearity of quantum mechanical evolution. In this project; our goal is to characterize and control chaotic dynamics at the quantum level. These studies will give us a fundamental understanding of the connections between the microscopic quantum world and our macroscopic classical world. Furthermore; they will help to build a toolbox of quantum control necessary for a variety of future applications including ultra high-speed quantum computation; design of new molecules for chemical and biological purposes; precision measurements techniques; and quantum cryptography and security. This proposed research project will focus on analyzing a specific system called the quantum kicked top and developing a quantum simulation of it. Previously we have analyzed the effect of chaos on quantum correlations or entanglement - an important resource for quantum computing. The student will perform numerical simulations to identify and analyze this chaos in the quantum dynamics. This will include studies of entanglement and quantum phase transitions. The chaotic system we are studying has been experimentally implemented recently. The student will also have the opportunity to experimentally test the system in the IBM quantum computer. Our calculations will use experimentally feasible parameters and help guide future quantum control experiments. Waterloo is a major hub for quantum information science and the student will have the opportunity to interact with leading researchers in theory and experiment.
Skills: The student should have taken a course in Quantum Mechanics at the third or fourth year level. A background in linear algebra; and some knowledge of computer programming or numerical software such as Matlab or Mathematica is preferred. Knowledge of quantum computation or chaos theory is not required; but would be advantageous. The student should have good communication skills and be comfortable working with other students.

Name: Biocomposites à haute teneur en fibres
Description: The project aims to produce fully biobased biocomposites (BC) with a high fiber content using an injection process. Biobased polymers such as cellulose acetate and polylactic acid will be reinforced with up to 70% wood fibers to produce composite pellets using an extrusion process. The granules will be used for the production of biocomposites (BC) by injection. The objectives of this project are: 1) to optimize injection parameters (temperature; time; and pressure); 2) to evaluate the in-service behavior of biocomposites; 3) to model the BC's physicomechanical behavior.
Skills: Knowledge of materials science Good oral and written communication skills (French and/or English) Ability to work in a team Experience working in a laboratory environment Autonomy and leadership skills.

Name: 3D printing and multiscale modelling of cellular-based metamaterials
Description: Wasted energy in automobile; aerospace; and agriculture machines has negative impact on our economy and environment. The AM3L research project aims at increasing the efficiency of energy harvesters by using smart multifunctional metamaterials. Smart materials with energy harvesting capabilities and a low level of energy consumption can be used as self-powered sensors/actuators. Cellular solids also offer a robust low-mass alternative for applications requiring lightweight and stiff components. Specifically; recent advances in 3Dprinting/additive manufacturing have hastened the emergence of optimized lightweight materials with tailored architecture in multiple scales. In this project; we employ computational/theoretical simulation and experimental testing to develop lightweight energy harvesters made of smart materials. We use 3Dprinting/additive manufacturing and laser cutting to fabricate these novel microarchitectured energy harvesters. We aim at developing porous piezoelectric/piezomagnetic materials; which can not only harvest energy from the vibration; but also make structures lighter and multifunctional. Polymers with photovoltaic effects can be integrated within active materials to harvest solar energy along with harvesting energy from vibration and structural micro-deformation/strain. The research objectives of the project are: 1) Examining potential energy resources in automotive and aeroplane/helicopter; e.g. vibration of helicopter rotor system; embedded strain in vehicle frame; and solar energy received by the frame. 2) Developing a methodology for harvesting energy from the wasted resources using lightweight smart cellular solids made of piezoelectric materials or active composites. 3) Computational multiscale modeling of smart energy harvesters under a series of multiphysics load in both continuum (using finite element method) and molecular (using atomistic simulation) scales. 4) 3Dpinting/additive manufacturing; laser cutting; and experimental testing of smart cellular-based metamaterials as energy harvesters and evaluating their efficiency to convert wasted energy to sustainable electricity. 5) Optimizing the performance of the lightweight multifunctional energy harvesters using multi-objective and topology optimization through tailoring their multiphysics properties via changing their microarchitecture.
Skills: Considering the multidisciplinary and multiphysics framework of biobased composites; the research spans mechanical; material; and electrical engineering concepts and is of interest to material scientists; mathematicians; and biosystem/civil/biomedical engineers. The students should have an engineering background and capable of implementing either numerical or experimental techniques for characterization/simulation of lightweight cellular materials. Experience with finite element software like ANSYS; COMSOL; and Abaqus and programming within MATLAB is desirable. English proficiency is required. Previous experiences in research activities about smart composites; cellular structures; energy harvesting; 3Dprinting/additive manufacturing; and conducting experimental testing for material characterization (mechanical; thermal; electrical; chemical; and imaging) are asset.
Student academic background: Engg-Enviromental; Engg-Manufacturing; Engg-Mechanical; Manufacturing; Engineering; Engg-Materials; Engg-Manufacturing; Engg-Civil; Engg-Aeronautical; Engg-Ceramic; Engg-Electrical; Engg-Computer

Name: 3D printing of architected biocomposites
Description: Biobased materials; including biomass and wood pellets; are promising sustainable energy resources to replace expensive fossil fuels threatening our environment and global climate. Biobased residues and waste; as renewable multifunctional energy resources; cannot be only used for heating and power energy generation but also for greenhouse carbon dioxide enrichment and the improvement of soil structure via the biochar production. Thermochemical conversion of residues; using pyrolysis; gasification; and combustion; is among the typical approaches of biobased material utilization. Despite of remarkable potential of biobased materials as sustainable and renewable energy resources; enhancing their efficiency and reducing the toxic gas emission of this type of biofuels during the thermochemical conversion is essential to promote their commercial applicability. To reach these objectives; biobased materials are composed with a second agent. For instance; composite pellets of plastics and wood fibers are one of the industrialized alternative biomass with improved thermophysical properties. However; the energy sector still requires new composite biobased materials with optimized thermo-chemo-biological properties to increase their energy efficiency and decrease their negative environmental impact compared to conventional fossil fuels. The current research aims at developing novel composite biobased materials with an optimum combination of alternative constitutes. The research objectives are: 1) Multiphysics characterization of biobased pellets to identify biofuel compositions with dominant effects on thermal; chemical; and environmental properties. 2) Computational multiscale simulation of biobased composites for a wide range of constitute materials; particle size; and bulk geometry. 3) Developing a computational thermochemical model to simulate composite biobased materials in pyrolysis and gasification process. 4) Experimental studies on byproducts (biochar; syngas; and ash) of thermochemical conversion. 5) Conducting a multi-objective optimization to explore the optimum pellet geometry and volume fraction of material constituents to simultaneously maximize thermal energy generation and minimize the toxic gas emission during the utilization process.
Skills: Due to the multidisciplinary framework of biobased composites; the research spans mechanical; biosystem; chemical; and civil engineering concepts and is also of interest to material scientists and mathematicians. The students should have an engineering background and capable of implementing either numerical or experimental techniques for characterization and simulation of combustion/gasification of biobased materials. Experience with finite element software like ANSYS; COMSOL; and Abaqus and coding in MATLAB and English proficiency are required. Previous experiences in research activities about composite materials; heat/mass transfer; and renewable energy and conducting experimental testing for material characterization (mechanical; thermal; chemical; and biological) are asset.
Student academic background: Engg-Mechanical; Engg-Materials; Engg-Aeronautical; Engg-Civil; Engg-Biological; Engg-Chemical

Name: Educational Technology Courses in Teacher Education: Curriculum Revision Process and Measuring Efficacy
Description: Objective: Brock University’s Faculty of Education recognizes the importance of integrating technology in education and offers specialized courses about educational technologies. Yet; given the rapid technological advancements and the lessons learned from the COVID-19 pandemic; it is essential to reflect on teacher candidates’ (TCs’) preparedness in using educational technologies and to implement best practices in these courses to ensure that TCs strive in a digital world upon graduation. As the team lead of the digital technology courses; I am leading a research project aimed at 1) revising these courses in the Teacher Education program and 2) exploring the impact of the redeveloped courses on TCs’ digital competencies. Methodology: To explore the impact of the course; a mixed method approach will be adopted utilizing: 1) pre- and post-surveys administered to TCs enrolled in the digital technology courses; 2) TCs’ coursework analysis; and 3) an end-of-course survey administered to course instructors. The pre-survey explores TCs’ views; background knowledge in digital technology; and self-reflection on their digital competence. The post-survey explores TCs’ final views; self-reflection on their digital competence development; their evaluation of the course; and recommendations for improvement. Moreover; TCs will be invited to share their coursework for analysis to explore incorporated digital skills. On the other hand; the instructors’ survey addresses their reflections and experiences teaching the course; successes and challenges; details of how they addressed students’ digital competence development; and recommendations for course improvement. Implications: This research has direct positive impacts on TCs; teachers; and Teacher Education programs. The findings will identify gaps and strengths in existing course offerings and will document best practices in training teachers to other teacher education programs. As such; the project will contribute to the advancement of knowledge in the fields of educational technology and scholarship of teaching and learning in Canada and internationally.
Skills: 1.Education: The student should have a strong educational background in the field of education; preferably with a focus on teacher education and educational technology. Experience in curriculum development is essential as they will assist in revising the course based on its evaluation. 2.Research: The student should be proficient in conducting online research and literature reviews. 3.Data Analysis: The student should be able to analyze both quantitative and qualitative data. Proficiency in statistical analysis software (SPSS and MS Excel) and qualitative data analysis software (NVivo) would be beneficial. 4.Communication Skills: Clear and effective communication skills; both oral and written; are essential.
Student academic background: Educ-Curriculum Studies; Educ-Elementary; Educ-Foundations; Educ-Secondary; Educ-Science; Education; Educ-Admin

Name: Exploring the Needs and Competencies of Canadian Teachers in Using Educational Technologies: A Pan-Canadian Study
Description: Objective: The abrupt shift to online teaching during the COVID-19 pandemic has shed light on several shortcomings in educational systems worldwide. Research on Canadian K-12 teachers’ practices during the pandemic has documented a wide array of challenges facing them mainly related to lack of prior training on utilizing educational technologies. Accordingly; it is crucial to understand the needs and competencies of teachers in using these technologies to enhance educational outcomes. This research aims to conduct a comprehensive and pan-Canadian study that will: 1) identify the current educational technologies used by Canadian teachers across different provinces and territories; 2) examine the attitudes and beliefs of Canadian teachers towards the integration of educational technologies and the challenges they encounter; and 3) assess the technological competencies of Canadian teachers in utilizing educational technologies. Methodology: This research project will adopt a mixed-methods approach utilizing a large-scale survey. This survey includes quantitative Likert scale items and qualitative open-ended responses to gather comprehensive data. The online survey will be administered to a diverse sample of teachers across Canada; covering various grade levels and subject areas. The survey will assess teachers' current technology usage; perceived needs; attitudes; and competencies in educational technology integration. Additionally; a subset of open-ended questions will delve deeper into their experiences; challenges; and recommendations. Implications: The findings of this research project will inform educational policymakers; administrators; and teacher educators in designing effective professional development programs tailored to the specific needs of Canadian teachers. The study will also shed light on the barriers hindering the widespread adoption of educational technologies and will provide insights into potential strategies to overcome these challenges. Overall; this pan-Canadian study will contribute to the advancement of educational technology integration in Canadian classrooms; ultimately aiming to improve teaching practices and enhance student learning outcomes in the digital age.
Skills: 1.Educational Background: The student should have a strong educational background in the field of education; preferably with a focus on teacher education and educational technology. 2.Research Methodology: The student should have knowledge of both quantitative and qualitative research methods; including survey design and data analysis. 3.Strong Analytical Skills: The student should be able to interpret both quantitative and qualitative data. Proficiency in data analysis software; such as statistical analysis (e.g.; SPSS and MS Excel) and qualitative data analysis (e.g.; NVivo); would be beneficial. 4.Communication and Writing Skills: Clear and effective communication skills; both oral and written; are essential.

Name: Developing High Strength High Electrical Conductor Foundry Alloys
Description: The long-term objective of the current project is developing high strength high conductive foundry alloys. The developed alloy is targeted to be used primarily as aluminum rotors for induction motors (in electrical vehicles). Beside the high mechanical prosperities and conductivity; castability is also another important criterion in developing this value added Al-based products. According to literature; two main potential categories that can be used as rotor Al alloys; are Al-Si and Al-Ni based alloys. At the first step; the Al-Si based alloys containing various Mg; Fe and Sr content have been cast in our lab. The Al-Si based casts are composed of various Fe; Mg and Sr content. We aim to study the impact of these elements on mechanical properties; microstructures; and electrical conductivity. Therefore; this short-term project intends to characterize the mechanical performance; microstructures evolution and electrical conductivity by varying content of Fe; Mg and Sr in AL-Si based foundry alloys. All the required sample preparations and analysis (for mechanical properties evaluation; microstructure characterization and electrical conductivity measurements) will be done in our lab (CURAL) at UQAC. This project has a great potential to be extended for a MSc/PhD program to investigate other elemental contributions (like Zr; Sc; etc.) as well to consider other potential based alloys (like Al-Ni).
Skills: - Materials science and metallurgy; - Solidification and casting; - Knowledge on mechanical properties evaluation; and microstructure characterization - To work in an efficient manner within a team; - To be autonomous and deliver results; - Respect the deadlines.

Name: Manufacturing and Friction Stir Welding (FSW) of High Entropy Aluminum Alloys
Description: Designing a cost-effective high entropy alloy; and developing the associated modern manufacturing technique is an urgent need of our society. Consequently; the principal objective of the proposed project is to develop novel cost effective High Entropy Alloys (HEAs); and to study friction stir welding of the developed products. The project is divided to three main sub-objectives (O): O1 - Designing cost effective high entropy alloys (HEAs); O2 - Manufacturing the designed HEAs (via casting and rolling); O3 - Joining the developed products by FSW technique.
Skills: - Materials science and metallurgy; - Solidification and casting; - Knowledge on mechanical properties evaluation; and microstructure characterization - To work in an efficient manner within a team; - To be autonomous and deliver results; - Respect the deadlines.

Name: Valorisation des surplus de copeaux pour la production de bioproduits et de bioénergie
Description: The project explores strategies for exploiting wood chips in new bioproducts and bioenergy. Canada is a world leader in the global woodchip market with an annual production of approximately 16 million metric tons. The majority of the chips are used by the paper industry. Over the past decade; demand for pulp and paper has declined steadily due to the significant drop in demand for newsprint; global competition; and the use of recycled paper in the production of a wide range of pulp products; which; led to a surplus of chips for Canadian sawmills. Thus; this project aims to evaluate various alternatives for developing wood chips that will encourage valorization e of by-products from the wood industry. The specific objectives are to valorize the chips for other uses than pulp and paper including OSB panels; insulation panels; wood-polymer composites and for bioenergy.
Skills: Autonomy; good laboratory skills; good writing skills; Research experience; Good GPA average. Enrolled in one of the following BS programs: Materials; Chemical Mechanical; engineering or Forestry Engineering; or any other related field.

Name: Transparent Biocomposites
Description: The project aims at developing transparent biocomposites from wood fibers. These will be chemically treated to make them transparent. The biocomposites will be shaped by impregnation; thermoconsolidation; injection or 3D printing of fiber-polymer mixtures. The optical; mechanical and physical properties of biocomposites will be characterized. Their potential will be studied for high value-added applications such as visors; helmets; windscreens; etc.
Skills: Education: Materials engineering; chemical engineering or related discipline Experience in research and laboratory work Good oral and written communication skills (French and/or English) Ability to work in a team Autonomy and leadership skills

Name: Mobile App Coding/Development: The Linguistic Risk-Taking Initiative at the University of Ottawa
Description: Are you a gamer? A software/app developer? Are you interested in languages? This project may be for you. It focuses on a new language-learning initiative at the officially bilingual English-French University of Ottawa (Canada). At this university; courses; programs; and services in both English and French are available. However; not all students are bilingual. Some may speak only or mostly English while others may speak only or mostly French. The university values and encourages bilingualism; and since all services are offered by bilingual staff members; opportunities for students to practice English or French; respectively; abound on campus. However; some students may be shy to practice the language they are learning in such real-life situations and may choose to remain in their linguistic comfort zone; that is; they may use only the language they are comfortable in; instead of the second official language that they need to practice. To encourage learners to practice their second language; the university has created a Linguistic Risk-Taking Passport App with various tasks and activities called risks. The risks represent daily-life communicative acts that learners may be otherwise shy to undertake in their second official language (e.g. speak their second language at the library; approach a passer-by for directions; order food at the cafeteria; interact with a professor/administrator; attend an event; amongst many others). Learners are asked to check-off risks they have undertaken in their apps and are eligible for rewards for taking risks as they help increase second language confidence and proficiency. Gaming elements are included (progressing through levels/trophies/badges; etc.). The initiative has been recognized both by the institution and by outside agencies as an excellent and innovative language teaching tool. The Mitacs intern will have a unique opportunity to get acquainted with this cutting-edge program and assist in its continuous development; evaluation and dissemination.
Skills: Preferred experience (computer science/engineering): • MongoDB / Mongoose • Ionic / Angular • Node.js/express • APIs • MEAN stack • Mobile development (Android and iOS) • Working with web frameworks • Web development Additional assets: • Do you like cutting-edge mobile apps? • Do you like learning languages? • Are you creative and a critical thinker? • Are you able to work independntly? • Do you also speak some French (asset but not mandatory)

Name: Fire-resistant self-decontaminating electrospun membrane for firefighter protective clothing
Description: High exposure to carcinogenic chemicals generated during combustion have put firefighters at an increased risk of cancer compared to the general population. Although current firefighter protective clothing (FPC) can protect against high heat; liquids; and mechanical hazards; it shows limited protection against gases and vapors found in smoke. As a result; firefighters are at risk of dermal exposure to these compounds; which can easily penetrate protective clothing and accumulate on the skin. Inhalation exposure also creates a risk for firefighters; as carcinogenic particulate matter can be trapped within the FPC and later volatized; where it is inhaled by the wearer or those nearby the FPC. A method to improve protection against gas and vapor particles is needed to prevent exposure to carcinogens among firefighters. Electrospun membranes provide a unique opportunity to improve protection against gases and vapors without adding bulk or weight to the FPC. These membranes are composed of randomly oriented meta-aramid nanofibres which provide inherent flame resistance; light weight; and improved filtration. When added into the FPC; they will improve protection against aerosols due to their small pore size. To improve protection against gases and prevent delayed release of harmful vapors from trapped smoke particles; metal oxide nanoparticles will also be imparted into the nanofibrous membrane. These nanoparticles will catalyze reactions with the carcinogenic compounds; transforming them into less toxic byproducts. This project will proceed in multiple phases. During the preliminary phase; a method to electrospin meta-aramid nanofibres is achieved. As well; the best method to integrate nanoparticles into the nanofibrous membrane is determined. In the next phase; the function and durability of the membrane is determined by adapting textile test methods to nanofibrous materials. Finally; the last phase involves the integration of the membrane into the FPC to ensure its function and longevity within the clothing system.
Skills: The student should have a solid background in polymer; textile; or material science. A foundational understanding of nanomaterials is an asset. The student should be able to work independently and readily communicate with team members and supervisors. The student should have strong oral and written communication skills. Some lab experience and basic knowledge of safe chemical handling is an asset.
