Finally; the student should be curious and creative; ready to think outside the box to produce new solutions to emerging research challenges.

Name: Energy harvesting from human motion
Description: This project intends to develop an energy harvester to convert human motion into electricity for low-power devices. The envisioned energy harvester will be attached to a human limb. While the human is walking; the harvester will convert their limb swing motion into electricity. The energy harvester will consist of a swing pendulum attached by a Halbach array at its free end. The swing pendulum is pivoted to a frame that will be fastened to a human limb. A coil is placed on the frame properly so that it faces the Halbach array. In this way; the motion of the swing pendulum relative to the frame will induce electricity based on Faraday’s law of induction. The student will work with a PhD student to design; build; and test the device. Through the project; the student will receive the training in various areas including basic vibration theory; solid modeling; the use of 3D printer for rapid prototyping; and vibration testing. This project is suitable for someone who is inspired for a graduate study in the areas of vibration energy harvesting.
Skills: Math; physics; dynamics; vibration

Name: Black hole populations inferred with LIGO-Virgo-KAGRA
Description: The fourth observing run of the LIGO; Virgo and KAGRA gravitational-wave detector network is underway; with many new observations of black holes and neutron stars. As part of this project; students will analyze the masses; spins and merger redshifts of these black hole and neutron star events. The students will fit data-driven models to the distributions of masses; spins and redshifts across all events in order to infer the population properties of black holes. Some questions we will address include: do heavier black holes tend to spin more slowly than lighter black holes? How does the mass distribution of black holes evolve across cosmic time? Are their distinct subpopulations in the distribution of black hole masses and spins that point to different formation histories?
Skills: The project will require some familiarity with probability and statistics; particularly Bayesian inference; and knowledge of computer programming with Python. An interest in massive stars; high-energy astrophysics; and general relativity is encouraged.

Name: Innovative Approaches for Net-Zero Buildings: High Temperature Thermal Energy Storage Technologies
Description: This research focuses on high-temperature rock thermal batteries for generating electricity during peak demand. We aim to develop a pilot-scale model to analyze rocks that can operate above 1000°C; suitable for high-temperature energy storage coupled with waste/renewable energy sources. Collaborative experiments with industrial partners and the Solar Park at Université de Sherbrooke will investigate the impact of different rock types when coupled with a Solar PV panel. Thermodynamic and numerical analysis will confirm the viability of coupling RockTES with high-grade heat; validated against lab and field data. The numerical CFD model will develope to assess heat-transfer characteristics; RockTES designs; and operating parameters. Ultimately; the goal is to design next-generation high-temperature thermal batteries as promising alternatives for storing renewable electricity.
Skills: • Applicants from the field of Thermal Engineering; Energy Technology; Mechanical Engineering; or related discipline with a proven affinity to multidisciplinary projects; • Strong knowledge of the modeling and simulations (Finite Element/Volume methods and Discrete Element Methods); • Strong programming skills (Matlab; Python; etc); • Excellent English skills; both written and oral; • Motivation in conducting artificial neutral network research; • Motivation in developing experimental systems and working in the laboratory.

Name: Capture et stockage de CO2 industriel par carbonatation minérale de résidus miniers/industriels
Description: This research project is a continuation of experimental work on the use of mineral carbonation of industrial residues as a method of reducing CO2 emissions. Three areas of research focusing on the pretreatment of the reactive material; the evaluation of the variability of the CO2 source and the optimization of the carbonate precipitation are mainly invested. The aim is to provide results opening new research perspectives while offering the necessary tools to develop an innovative technology adapted to the problem of reducing CO2 emissions from the industrial sector.
Skills: The desired profile is a student who has completed or is undergoing a bachelor's degree; or a master's degree in science or engineering. The specializations sought are; chemical engineering; mining engineering; geological engineering; civil engineering; chemistry; geology and earth sciences. The student will have to demonstrate autonomy; innovation and curiosity. He will carry out laboratory experiments and analyzes; and report on his results in the form of presentations and a final report.

Name: Role of non-neuronal cells in Parkinson's disease
Description: The research conducted in our laboratory aims to understand the molecular mechanisms underlying Parkinson's disease. The research project for this summer internship will focus on studying how non-neuronal cells interact with each other to communicate and accelerate (or mitigate) disease progression. We are particularly interested in cells forming the neurovascular unit (astrocytes; pericytes; endothelial cells); and we use cutting-edge induced pluripotent stem cells to model this multicellular unit. The student will perform experiments to characterize cell-cell communication in our Parkinson’s disease models.
Skills: We invite application from students enrolled at a University-level program in Neurosciences; Cell Biology; Biomedical Sciences or related area; with a strong academic record; an ability to work independently and as part of a team; and highly motivated and dedicated to improving human health.
Student academic background: Biochemistry; Biological Sciences; Biology; Immunology; Medical Sciences; Medicine; Molecular Biology; Neuroscience; Pharmacology

Name: Fabrication and characterization of silicon-based thin film nanostructures
Description: The incumbent will join an active research group involved in the fabrication and characterization of thin silicon-based films (oxides; nitrides; carbides; and combinations thereof); and the development of new materials structures based upon such films. There is great potential for the use of these materials in optical components for integrated optical applications or in solid state lighting devices. The project concerns the deposition of thin films with a range of compositions and refractive indexes; the characterization of the deposition process through optical techniques; and the correlation of the plasma characteristics with the physical and optical properties of the thin films. We also plan to explore the influence of the deposition temperature on the visible luminescence from such thin films by linking changes in the film properties; including hydrogen concentration; film microstructure; composition; and stress conditions to the observed changes of visible light emission.
Skills: The student will gain hands-on experience with many tools of thin film fabrication and characterization; including plasma-enhanced chemical vapour deposition; reactive sputtering; photo- and electro-luminescence; and spectroscopic ellipsometry. Thus; an aptitude for experimental work and an interest in vacuum technology and optical instrumentation are required. The analysis of data obtained from a variety of characterization tools and the operation of the thin film deposition systems requires good computer skills and knowledge of LabView. Familiarity with COMSOL would be an asset.

Name: Positron Annihilation Spectroscopy of Thin Film Structures
Description: The McMaster Positron Laboratory is the only one of its kind in Canada and very few in all of North America. It includes the McMaster Intense Positron Beam Facility (MIPBF); which houses one of the world’s most intense sources of positrons; making the facility one of only a few of its kind operating worldwide. The MIPBF is made possible through a partnership with the researchers and staff of the McMaster Nuclear Reactor (MNR). The MIPBF infrastructure includes two experimental stations dedicated to materials research and thus; serves as a unique tool to meet the current and future demands for research in and characterization of advanced materials; with a focus on materials utilized in the development and fabrication of electronic and photonic devices. Our work is concerned with the characterization of defect structures – principally through positron lifetime and Doppler-broadening spectroscopy - in thin film and/or nano-structured materials utilized in the development and fabrication of electronic and photonic devices. In addition to positron annihilation spectroscopy; the student will gain hands-on experience with many "classic" tools of thin film and materials characterization; including photo- and electro-luminescence (P/EL); Rutherford backscattering spectrometry (RBS); and variable angle spectroscopic ellipsometry (VASE).
Skills: Strong interest in and an aptitude for experimental; hands-on work are required. Experience in vacuum technology and/or the use of nuclear and optical instrumentation would be considered major assets. The research also requires the ability to analyze complex data sets; using custom software.

Name: CFD modeling of coolant strategies for machining processes (1)
Description: Coolant strategy has a significant effect on the machining process efficiency and machined part quality. this proejct aim to develop a modeling tool that will enble us to simulate the effectiveness off different coolant strategies and test new coolant strategies.
Skills: Training will be provided; but the student must be enrolled in a mechanical engineering program. knowledge of CNC Machining; Matlab and Ansys is a plus

Name: Characterization of additive manufactured part quality
Description: The proposed project aims to assess and analyze AM processes in terms of: suitability for different engineering alloys; part quality; mechanical properties; cycle time; cycle cost and environmental friendliness [1-5]. Understanding the relation between the process parameters; micro structure and mechanical properties is fundamental to the control and optimization of the AM process. Analysis of the finished part using scanning electron microscopy; tensile testing and porosity measurements will be used to assess AM part quality; e.g. surface finish; accuracy (distortion); manufacturing cost and cycle time.
Skills: Mechanical/production engineering knowledge of Manufacturing processes and materials science Knowledge of software packages like Matlab; solidworks; master CAM is a plus

Name: Smart Defect Detection system
Description: The proposed project aims to develop a smart defect inspection system using Artificial intelligence and sensor fusion for manufacturing processes.
Skills: Mechanical/production engineering /Mechatronics knowledge of Manufacturing processes and materials science Knowledge of software packages like Matlab; solidworks; master CAM is a plus

Name: Topology optimization of parts for 3D printing
Description: The proposed project aims to assess and analyze AM processes in terms of: suitability for different engineering applications and the use of topology optimization to design light wieght and high strength parts that can be manufacturing using AM technologies. ;
Skills: Mechanical/production engineering /Mechatronics knowledge of Manufacturing processes and materials science Knowledge of software packages like Matlab; solidworks; master CAM is a plus

Name: Machinability of Difficult to cut materials
Description: Students will perform machinability study on High performance alloys to assess and enhance machining process efficiency and sustainability
Skills: Mechanical Engineering/ production or Mechatronics manufacturing processes Materials Science Mat lab; solid works software packages

Name: Chromatin-based epigenetic mechanisms in gene expresssion and genome maintenance
Description: Our work characterizes the structure and function of several protein complexes; identifying their intrinsic recognition modules for the epigenetic histone signature. Accurate writing and reading of these epigenetic marks lead to changes in chromatin dynamics; in a targeted manner within the genome. The project will aim to continue this work to understand the role and structure of multiprotein complexes modifying chromatin; controlling gene expression and maintaining the integrity of the genome in physiological or pathological context (see website). The model systems used are mammalian cells and the yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae. The techniques used are at the cutting edge of molecular biology and genetics as well as protein biochemistry and functional genomics (protein purifications; mutagenesis; CRISPR/Cas9-genome editing; recombinant proteins; Next-generation sequencing; molecular interactions; immunoprecipitations ; cellular imaging; etc.).
Skills: A student with laboratory work experience is sought for an internship from May to August 2024. A background in molecular biology is an asset and a good academic record is required (A). An interest in research and graduate studies is also very advantageous. An ability to communicate in English is also an advantage or a learning opportunity given that the laboratory has three non-French speaking people.
Student academic background: Biochemistry; Biological Sciences; Genetics; Molecular Biology; Biology; Microbiology

Name: Order-preserving automorphisms of free groups
Description: There is a conjecture in 3-manifold topology called "the L-space conjecture" which says that certain groups that one derives from topological spaces should be left-orderable whenever the spaces have nice topological properties. This conjecture has been verified for many infinite families of groups and associated spaces using high-powered theorems; and verified in hundreds of thousands of special cases using direct computation (i.e. computer verification). Motivated by this conjecture; several authors have investigated the bi-orderability of knot and link groups in recent years. With numerous theorems in hand; many knot groups are now understood in this regard; but link groups cannot be dealt with using the same techniques. There are some results that are specifically designed to deal with links (for instance; recent work of Rolfsen and Kin) but there is an obstacle in this case which is not as easy to overcome as in the case of knots. The underlying algebraic difficulty is to determine a solution to the following problem: Given an automorphism f of a finitely generated free group; when does the free group admit a bi-ordering (or left-ordering) that is preserved by the automorphism? The goal of this project will be to develop a computer program that will be able to determine when an automorphism does NOT preserve an ordering of the free group; and to apply this program to many cases of interest (e.g. automorphisms arising from braids via Artin's representation). There are already partial results in this direction--for instance; theorems that tell you when an automorphism is not order-preserving based upon its action on the abelianization of the free group. However; I hope to use the program to try and conjecture a new obstruction to an automorphism being order-preserving; generalizing previous results and arriving at a new theorem.
Skills: Students will be required to have some advanced knowledge of group theory (e.g. free groups; group presentations; automorphism groups) and some skill in computer programming. Knowledge of topology; for instance knots; braids; or knot groups; is an asset; but not required.

Name: Signal analysis for tactile human-robot interaction detection based on sound
Description: Physical interactions between robot and humans are typically measured using torque sensors at the robot joints; or a 6-axis force/torque sensor at the wrist of the robot. However; these sensors can be expensive; and not all robots are equipped with those. Additionally; they can only provide the general location of a contact: for example; somewhere on the arm or on the hand. Lacking more precise information; the ability of the robot to evaluate the intention behind the contact and to react appropriately is limited. In this project; we are exploring the use of microphones placed on the body of the robot to identify where contacts occur; from the sound that is produced when something touches the hard shell of the robot.
Skills: Prior knowledge of linear algebra; partial derivative equations; programming (Python and/or C); measurements; signal processing and system analysis will be of great help to complete this project! Teamworking skills are essential; as you will be closely collaborating with another student developing the hardware setup.
Student academic background: Engg-Biomedical; Engg-Electrical; Engg-Mechanical; Engg-Systems and Technology; Engineering

Name: Application of Machine Learning to Aerodynamic Design of Autonomous Vehicles
Description: Flow control has a tremendous technological and economic impact; such as aerodynamic drag reduction on road vehicles which translates directly into fuel savings; with a consequent reduction in greenhouse gas emissions and operating costs. In recent years; machine learning has also been used to develop new approaches to flow control in place of more laborious methods; such as parametric studies. The applicant previously combined computational fluid dynamics and genetic algorithms to generate unique and non-intuitive aerodynamic device geometries; which were used to demonstrate significant aerodynamic benefits in terms of lift and drag reduction [1]. The applicant proposes to extend this work to machine learning applications to generate various devices in the given design space. In particular; to create three-dimensional flow control devices that are aerodynamically efficient in terms of the cost function (i.e.; aerodynamic drag and lift). In addition; autonomous vehicles rely heavily on the input of sensors to capture environmental and traffic data. However; the performance of these sensors degrades due to soiling caused by precipitation and surface contamination. Therefore; it is crucial to develop effective strategies to mitigate soiling and hence signal degradation. The proposed method will be used to generate unique geometries that are optimized to reduce drag; lift; and soiling simultaneously. This has not been done before and has the high potential to create novel aerodynamic devices with significant contributions to intellectual property. [1] R. Aranha; N. A. Siddiqui†; W. Y. Pao and M. Agelin-chaab. 2023. Development of Intelligent Passive Device Generator for Road Vehicle Applications. Journal of Applied Fluid Mechanics; Vol. 16; No. 8; pp. x-x; 2023
Skills: The students must have a good background in fluid mechanics; as well as computational fluid dynamics. Working knowledge of machine learning will be a huge advantage. In addition; a passion for research and a willingness to learn new things are cornerstones of most research endeavours.

Name: Use of polymer and chiral layers to enhance the anomalous photo voltaic effect in Perovskite
Description: Development of green energy sources is crucial to the progress of our society and multitude of avenues such as wind; solar; thermal and electrochemical are being researched for this purpose. Solar is a prime candidate due to its omnipresence on the planet and significant energy density. Increasing the efficiency of the solar cells along with ease of production is being actively pursued to make it cost effective in comparison to traditional carbon based fuel sources. Inorganic solar cells based on nanomaterials though efficient have higher costs due to the materials involved and the manufacturing process required. In this project the use of CH3NH3PbI3 perovskite in conjugation with polymers and chiral active molecules will be developed to enhance the performance and stability of the observed anomalous photovoltaic (APV) effect in perovskite based systems. The chiral effects will be used to improve device performance while polymer chains will enhance the stability of the device. The project will develop the integration of perovskite-polymer films with chiral active layers deposited in a spatially controlled manner. The device structure will be integrated with a high surface area metal oxide nanostructure (such as ZnO) for current collection and characterization of the chiral effects. The characteristics of the resulting chirality in the perovskite; the geometry of the nanostructure and the interface between the nanostructure and the perovskite-polymer will also be studied to increase the efficiency of the APV as a potential solar energy harvester. The candidate in particular will focus the efforts to study the formation and integration of the chiral layer with perovskite-polymer layer. The candidate will get experience on; in house synthesis and assembly methods for these devices and also their photo-electrical performance. Characterization methods such as field emission electron microscopy; X-ray diffraction will be used at WatLabs facility at University of Waterloo.
Skills: Undergraduate student with background in engineering; physics or chemistry will be considered for this position. In particular academic courses in quantum mechanics; solid state/semiconductor physics; mathematics; engineering and physical chemistry will provide foundation required for this project. Basic knowledge of electrical circuits will also be needed for the project. Laboratory courses in chemistry will also be helpful. Prior research experience in nanomaterials such as quantum dots; nanowires though not necessary but will be useful for the project.

Name: Development of advanced photon-detection techniques for neutrinoless double beta decay studies with nEXO
Description: nEXO searches for 0nbb events in a liquid xenon time-projection chamber. Radioactive decays will produce an ionization signal and the emission of scintillation light at 175nm. Both of these signals have to be recorded. In order to greatly increase the sensitivity of nEXO compared to current 0nbb detectors; new and advanced photon sensors have to be developed; characterized and tested before they can be applied to nEXO to record the scintillation light. The challenge is identifying photon sensor that can be operated at liquid xenon temperatures (168K); and that are radio-pure without adding significant background to the 0nbb search. The collaboration has identified so-called Si photon multiplier (SiPM) detectors as the light detectors of choice and is pursuing their development. You will join the local EXO group at McGill; which focuses on integration of SiPMs into larger arrays and subsequent performance tests at room temperature and under cryogenic conditions. You will characterize UV light sources and use them to study SiPMs response functions at room temperature and at cryogenic temperatures. This project touches all aspects of lab work with a hardware component as well as some simple data analysis.
Skills: This project is aimed at undergraduate students at all levels; i.e.; no special skills are required. All you need is an interest in learning and improving lab skills; and an interest in particle and nuclear physics. We use SolidWorks; LabView; Mathematica; and Python in every-day-business. Some knowledge in any of these programs/languages will help you get started; but is absolutely not required as we have local experts that are happy to assist you.

Name: Development of a Ba-ion tagging technique for the future nEXO detector
Description: The search for neutrinoless double beta decays (0νββ) is extremely challenging. A unique advantage of a Xe time-projection chamber (TPC) detector is the possibility to locate the decay within the detector volume; and to extract into vacuum and identify Ba-136; the decay daughter of Xe-136. This so-called tagging possibility; combined with enough energy resolution to separate 0νββ from 2νββ decays; allows one to dramatically reduce the background of the measurement to virtually zero. The EXO collaboration has started development on nEXO; a multi-ton scale TPC. In addition; Ba-tagging techniques are under development. You will be working on the development of such a Ba-tagging technique with the EXO group at McGill. The focus of the development is the extraction of individual Ba-ions from xenon gas; i.e. the extraction of one ion from mols of xenon gas. We achieve this by using a radio-frequency ion-funnel and ion-manipulation techniques. So far; we could demonstrate that it is possible to actually extract ions from xenon gas of up to 10bar. The next step of the development will be the identification of the ion. In order to systematically study and optimize the ion-extraction mechanism; we will develop a laser-ablation ion source that will be placed in the xenon gas. A time-of-flight mass spectrometer is being developed to detect and identify the extracted ions. You will be working with other members of the group on SIMION simulations and the design of ion optics for the ion-extraction system. In addition; you will be involved in setting up hardware in the lab and testing ion-transmission efficiencies. For Ba-tagging; we are applying well established ion-manipulation techniques to further push the sensitivity of the future nEXO detector. This interdisciplinary research is very exciting because it applies different techniques to search for physics beyond the Standard Model.
Skills: A general background of physics would be helpful in understanding the concepts of our setup. However; an interested and motivated student will pick up the details while working on the project. A general understanding of computers will be helpful. SIMION is a powerful ion trajectory simulation toolkit with a gui that is very intuitive. For the lab work; excitement and motivation are all you need. We will instruct you in how to assembel ultra-high vacuum systems and design experiments.

Name: Restoration of eutrophic lake water
Description: The project involves the monitoring of lake quality in an area outside of the city of Montreal. Too high levels of nutrients such as phosphorus lead to the growth of algae and blue-green algae at too high levels. Therefore; restoration of these lakes is a priority. Few technologies are currently available. However this project is related to the development of an in situ method for the treatment of these lakes. The lake water quality needs to be monitored to determine the most appropriate treatment method. Both on-site and laboratory testing are currently underway and will need to be continued to develop a full scale system.
Skills: The background of the student should be in the area of environmental engineering or science and include familiarity with analyses of water such as methods for BOD; COD; suspended solids etc.

Name: Summer habitat associations of endangered bats on Canada’s prairie landscape.
Description: Bats play a multitude of beneficial ecological roles. In tropical regions; for example; bats are important pollinators; seed dispersers and consumers of insects. In Canada; all resident bat species are insectivorous – consuming numerous insect pests. Of great concern is that an introduced disease (white nose syndrome (WNS); caused by the fungus Pseudogymnoascus destructans) is leading to widespread and precipitous population declines. The population-level consequences of WNS are so severe (typically with >80% mortality following infection of hibernation sites) that three species of; previously assumed abundant; bats have recently been emergency listed as endangered. White nose syndrome was first detected New York and has since spread across much of eastern and central North America. It was recently detected in Saskatchewan. As a province with a vibrant agriculture sector; Saskatchewan stands to suffer severe economic consequences from a loss of bats (and the ecological services they provide). Two issues limit our ability to mitigate bat population declines in Saskatchewan: there is no known cure for WNS and our knowledge of bats in the province is severely limited (e.g.; Saskatchewan is the only province in which no hibernation sites have been identified). Consequently; the best management practices for bats here may be to identify and conserve summer habitat; so as to promote the survival and reproductive success of those few individuals that do survive WNS. In this project; the student will use a combination of acoustic monitoring; animal trapping and measurement; and engagement with local landowners to identify and conserve maternity roosts for one of the only endangered bat species in southern Saskatchewan - little brown bats.
Skills: These positions are best suited to applicants with interests in ecology; wildlife; field biology; and/or conservation biology. As evidence of this; applicants must either be enrolled in; or have graduated from; a relevant discipline. The fieldwork will involve regular vehicle travel to rural sites and; as such; successful applicants need to be able to cope under these conditions; have a valid driver’s license; be up-beat; positive; responsible; work well as a member of a team and be respectful. Evidence of these abilities (gained; for example; through previous involvement on field projects or extended back-packing trips) is required.

Name: Disentangling genetic and environmental components of energetic trade-offs in mammalian reproduction: investigating North American red squirrels (Tamiasciurus hudsonicus)
Description: Living organisms must strike a balance between energy acquisition and expenditure. To successfully survive and reproduce; organisms must employ behavioural and physiological strategies to optimize acquiring energy from the environment (which is frequently in limited supply); and selectively allocate its expenditure towards costly essential tasks such as somatic growth; maintenance; and reproduction. In long-lived iteroparous species; across years individuals may trade off reproduction in the current year to invest more in potential future reproduction; depending both on the condition of the individual and the surrounding environmental conditions such as food abundance and population density. Within years; individuals may shift their timing of reproduction to better match the energetically expensive aspects of reproduction (such as lactation) with seasonal environmental food abundance (i.e.; waiting until green up in the spring). Some of these strategies have a heritable genetic component but are labile in different environments. This study seeks to determine the relative contributions of genetic and environmental components to variation in energy expenditure and energy allocation towards reproduction. To do this; we study a population of North American red squirrels (Tamiasciurus hudsonicus) in the southwest Yukon; Canada; that has been followed since 1987. We follow individuals from birth to death and gather extensive data on reproductive success and territory ownership; and we are able to quantify population- and individual-level food abundance in this food-caching species. We take tissue samples to construct a detailed pedigree; allowing us to take quantitative genetics approaches to studying phenotypic traits. Additional work related to this project will be quantifying metabolic rates and body condition to fully characterize energetic phenotypes of individuals to link back into data on relatedness and reproductive success.
Skills: The successful applicant will have completed relevant coursework in biology; ecology; evolution; and statistics. Students should be comfortable working in the field in a physically demanding role; both alone and in a team. While not required to have extensive fieldwork experience; some animal handling experience is beneficial. The student should have excellent data collection and entry skills and have a minimum of beginner experience using R for statistics. The student should be able to demonstrate their skills in creative problem solving; leadership; and abilities to learn quickly and work well in field conditions.
Student academic background: Biological Sciences; Biology; Ecology; Environmental Studies; Zoology

Name: Impacts of climate change on health and wellbeing in LMICs
Description: Climate change is known to have a number of impacts on human health (mortality and morbidity from heat; drought; floods; etc). Few studies have recognized the importance of empirical investigations of the impacts of climate change on psychological health and wellbeing. We explore these relationships in three countries in Sub Saharan Africa: Ghana; Kenya and Uganda. In so doing; our interdisciplinary team has measured psychological impacts of climate change at baseline and is in the process of developing interventions to address the psychological stresses of climate threats in order to facilitate good decision making in the development of resilience in these communities. In so doing; we focus on the most vulnerable populations identified in the UN Research Roadmap: women and girls; seniors; the poor. This research is undertaken in partnership with local policy makers and non-governmental organizations who can implement the results of the work in the form of policy and practice; and secure the sustainability of the resilience building process.
Skills: The incumbent must have the following skills: good listening skills; good oral and written communications skills; be able to work well independently as well as part of a team; be ready to learn new skills: analysis; research; writing; research design.

Name: Structural biology of cancer cell signaling
Description: Cancer cells have drastically altered cellular signaling compared to healthy cells which often arrise due to changes in protein and nucleic acid expression or mutations. These changes in cell signaling lead to increase proliferation; cell motility and invasion. Cellular signaling is carried out by a very diverse group of molecules with can sense the levels of different molecules inside and outside the cell and transmit this information to various cellular processes; such as transcription factors; epigenetic regulators; cytoskeletal remodeler; etc. We are interested in the molecular details of this signal integration and computation by protein and nucleic acid. We study two broad categories of molecules: 1. Rho activators Rho GTPases are a family of proteins that regulate the cytoskeleton. Due to their role in cell shape and movement; their activity is often increased in metastatic cells. This increase in Rho activity is often tied to hyperactivation of their upstream regulators; the RhoGEF family of protein. We aim to better understand the normal function of RhoGEF in the regulation of Rho activity and how these functions are altered in cancer cells. 2. Long non-coding RNAs LncRNAs are a family of large RNAs which are expressed; often at low levels; in a variety of cell types and accomplish a broad range of functions. Intriguingly; select lncRNAs have been proposed to interact directly with the signaling machinery and mediate changes in growth factors signaling; cytoskeletal remodeling and protein homeostasis. We plan on applying biochemical and structural characterization techniques to understand if lncRNAs are indeed acting as scaffolds for protein in cell signaling; and how their - often conserved - structure helps them carry out these functions.
Skills: We expect the student to have training in biochemistry and molecular biology; including laboratory experience; either through university classes or hands-on academic lab experience. The student ought to know how to use a micropipette; prepare chemical solutions; and have basic knowledge of nucleic acid and protein purification methods. Any prior experience on structural biology or biophysical techniques; such as electron microscopy; crystallography; biological molecule NMR; light scattering or calorimetry would be seen as a major asset. Cell culture will also be a significant component of the project so prior knowledge would be valued.

Name: Next-generation bioengineered systems for sustainable production of bio-products from food waste
Description: Food waste is a resource. It generates enormous energy; chemical and material potential due to the functionalized molecules stored in it. In Ontario alone; a staggering amount of 3.7 million tonnes/year of food and organic waste is generated (3.1 billion tonnes/year globally); however; it is currently underutilized; and about 60% of it ends up in landfills; which is not a sustainable option. Thus; this project aims to develop transformative and advanced bioengineered processes for sustainable biomanufacturing of liquid biofuel and bioplastics precursors via upcycling of food waste. Specifically; it is poised to achieve UN Sustainable Development Goals 7; 9; 11 and 13 through advanced food waste biorefinery processes and high-value multi-product chain that will create economic benefits; promote advanced resource recovery and circular economy; and reduce environmental impacts. This will be achieved through bioconversion of food waste to carboxylates; which are high-value building blocks for synthesis of a wide array of currently fossil-fuel derived products such as polymers (plastics); alcohols (e.g.; bio-butanol as biofuel); ketones and olefins. This will be achieved via mixed culture fermentation to convert food waste to carboxylates; which are high-value building blocks for above products. However; this biosynthesis poses separation and recovery challenges. Carboxylates are usually present in diluted form which make their separation more difficult and expensive. Most extraction studies have employed synthetic acid solutions while reports on mixed acid recovery from real fermentation broth are scarce. Furthermore; the carboxylates inhibit the metabolic functions of microorganisms. Consequently; only low carboxylate yields and productivities can be obtained. Such limitations can be overcome by in-situ product recovery (ISPR) i.e.; removal of carboxylates as they are being formed in fermenter. Thus; the objective of this project is to develop efficient ISPR systems using green extractants for high recovery of carboxylates and their further conversion to secondary bioproducts (bioplastics).
Skills: Selected candidate is expected to possess a knowledge of chemical (or bio) separations or extractions; downstream bioprocessing; analytical chemistry; and mass transfer. Hands-on skills in setting up chemical dilutions; molarity and concentration calculations are needed. Knowledge and/or hands-on experience in chromatography is needed to select suitable extractants for carboxylates; understand the separation chemistry and discuss the results. Skills in data analysis and curation using Microsoft Excel are required. Candidates with a strong scientific writing experience in the form of technical reports; research articles; review articles; or book chapters are preferred.

Name: Analytical modelling of the fluid dynamics of multiple-vortex tornadoes // Modélisation analytique de la dynamique des fluides des tornades à tourbillons multiples
Description: Tornadoes are a fascinating feat of nature. A single supercell thunderstorm can even develop multiple tornadoes that interact with each other. In such an event; the weaker tornadoes (satellite tornadoes) will revolve around the much larger primary tornado. Another lesser-known phenomenon is also possible. A tornado can in fact possess multiple smaller tornadoes within itself; each of which revolve around the centre of the parent tornado. These internal tornadoes are known as subvortices or suction vortices and the parent tornado as a multiple-vortex tornado. Multiple-vortex tornadoes are among the largest; strongest and most destructive tornadoes known to date. Why is this so? Despite their destructive reputation; the behaviour of multiple-vortex tornadoes remains poorly understood. A study of the fluid dynamics of multiple-vortex tornadoes can provide valuable insight into how they behave and therefore serve to inform risk management and evacuation strategies in practice. The objective of this research project is to develop a fundamental analytical model of multiple-vortex tornadoes. The analytical model will consist of a set of n irrotational point vortices (the subvortices) embedded within a background rigid body rotation (the parent vortex). We will first study stable systems of two and three vortices using their potential and stream functions as well as their circulation and vorticity. We will also perform more advanced fluid dynamic analyses to further describe the physics such as modal decomposition and extraction of material curves. We will then model hypothetical attenuation and intensification processes between stable systems of two and three vortices. As part of this work; the flow of stable and transitioning systems of two and three vortices have previously been acquired using a simple experimental model. The experimental data will serve as a means of comparison for the analytical model.
Skills: The student should have a good understanding of undergraduate fluid mechanics (e.g.; velocity fields; potential function; stream function). Good mathematical and programming skills are required. The programming language used for this project is MATLAB and/or Python.

Name: Catalysts for direct CO2 hydrogenation to aromatics
Description: Contribute to an on going research project aiming at the production of an appropriate catalyst support and an optimized supported catalyst for a process of CO2 hydrogenation to aromatic hydrocarbons. CO2 hydrogénation is a hot topic as it is one of the most significant approach to Carbon Capture and Utilization (CCU). Targetting the production of small aromatics (BTX) is most challenging. This project just started in April 2023. It is supported by the only Canadian producer of paraxylene which is also the largest user of BTX.
Skills: The student should be working toward a BSc in Chemical Engineering; in Chemistry or the equivalent.

Name: Designer Materials to Meet Tomorrow's Needs
Description: This project will pursue materials by design that aim to meet the challenges of tomorrow's applications in energy conversion; energy storage; and high durability nanoscale sensors. We will meet these challenges through the synthesis; assembly and other soft manipulations of matter; creating materials that have the desired properties and structures. For example; we will pursue a customized porous material that will serve as a platform to build upon our understanding of the dynamics of transport within energy conversion and energy storage materials. This work will also pursue an understanding of how materials behave under extreme conditions of temperature; pressure and corrosive environments that the materials will likely encounter within these applications. Of equivalent importance is to understand impurities and defects in these materials; which will have widespread importance in long-term stability. Through this work we aim to develop the most efficient and durable materials for use in electrocatalysis; and highly sensitive materials for chemical sensing. Through the design of the custom materials; we aim to improve the sensitivity of detection in the hopes of extending electrochemical and optoelectronic sensing applications to a number of trace analytes. Aside from these areas of research we are also developing sensing materials for incorporation into flexible electronic platforms. Sensors are ubiquitous to our daily lives and we aim to improve the performance of materials incorporated into these devices to enable operation under extreme conditions. In this work; we aim to prepare materials for in-the-field work; to improve the lives of humanity through enhanced sensing devices; and to optimize energy storage and conversion in materials as demand increases for both applications. We seek these solutions through designing materials to meet these challenges while also understanding the fundamentals behind these materials; their limitations and their benefits.
Skills: I look for a student that is self-motivated to learn; curious about science; and aspiring for continual self-improvement. They will need to be willing to work on and lead their own project; while also managing their schedule to work collaboratively with other students in the research group. They will need to be patient with others as they will receive a lot of hands-on training that requires multiple steps; and willing to help others in return. I also look for a student that is safety conscious. Importantly; I also seek someone that is creative and a problem solver.

Name: Computational Enzymology: modelling potential enzymatic drug targets in pathological bacteria
Description: We are facing a global health crisis; the rise of drug-resistant pathogens. As a result; our global society faces the real prospect of returning to a time when common diseases; that are presently easily treatable; could again become deadly. Hence; there is a need to identify; characterize and/or design new therapeutic agents and their targets. Aminoacyl-tRNA synthetases are a class of enzymes found in all living organisms. Furthermore; they have been found to have a broad range of biochemically essential roles.1 While they are perhaps best known for their critical role in protein biosynthesis; they are now known to be involved in a range of important physiological processes including viral assembly; porphyrin biosynthesis; inflammation; and apoptosis. Mechanistically; it is known that they catalyse the aminoacylation of their corresponding transfer-RNA (tRNA). First; they catalyse the activation of their respective amino acid by reacting it with ATP to give an aminoacyl-adenylate derivative. The latter is then reacted with their respective tRNA to give the desired aminoacylated-tRNA species.1 It is only quite recently that we have begun to more fully understand the atomistic details of the catalytic mechanisms. For instance; it has been shown that many aaRS's have not only an aminoacylation activation/transfer active site; but also an editing site. The former catalyses the amino acid activation and subsequent aminoacylation of the tRNA. In contrast; the latter site catalyses the removal of incorrect aminoacyl groups from aminoacylated-tRNA. As a result; aaRSs present potentially rich targets for therapeutic agents. However; to date; only a few drug agents that target aaRS's; in any organism; have been identified. In this project; building upon our recent studies and consequently greater understanding oof the catalytic and editing mechanisms of several related aaRS (e.g.; MetRS; LeuRS and ValRS); we will use computational chemsitry to identify potential new therapeutic drugs.
Skills: The student should have a broad knowledge of fundamental chemical principles; e.g.; knowledge of organic; inorganic and physical chemistry. While at least some Quantum chemistry and biochemistry background and knowledge is advantageous; it is not essential. Previous students in my group have come from pharmacy; chemistry; biochemistry and biology backgrounds. Our research group has experience and is adept at training undergraduates in such skills and also teaching them related knowledge during the course of the project. Computer coding skills are not essential as all software used (Gaussian 09; Molecular Operating Environment; NAMD) is commercially available.

Name: Exploring the connectivity and resilience of dopamine neurons in Parkinson's disease
Description: Dopamine neurons in the brain are particularly vulnerable and degenerate in Parkinson's disease. We hypothesize that their great vulnerability results in part from their very complex connectivity and from the high level of oxidative stress that results from an hyperactive mitochondrial network. This project will make use of mouse primary dopamine neurons to examine some of the molecular mechanisms that drive the axonal branching of dopamine neurons and the high activity of their mitochondria. We will also explore the ability of small molecules to increase the resilience of dopamine neurons by acting on mitochondria to improve their efficiency to produce ATP or their ability to handle oxidative stress. The experiments will be performed using molecular approaches such as viruses to manipulate gene expression; genetically-encoded sensors of mitochondrial function and of oxidative stress and confocal imaging techniques.
Skills: The student is expected to have basic university undergraduate training in the fields of biology; neuroscience; cell biology and pharmacology. The rest of the more advanced training will be provided during the internship. A high level of motivation and enthusiasm for science is also expected.

Name: Quebecol metabolism and potential neuroprotective properties
Description: We are investigating the liver metabolism of the natural product quebecol and have determined that quebecol mainly undergoes Phase 2 glucuronide conjugation in vitro. Surprisingly; quebecol does not undergo Phase 1 metabolism to a reactive para-quinone methide. We attempted to prepare para-quinone methide standards of quebecol using chemical oxidation methods; but instead produced catechols that subsequently underwent intramolecular cyclization. We would like to determine how this intramolecular cyclization occurred and whether 5 or 6 membered rings were formed or if coupling between aromatic rings occurred. This project would involve the synthesis of model di-catechol diphenylethane analogues of quebecol that would allow for identification and a full characterization of these products using nmr and mass spectrometry. We anticipate that fragment ions identified during the mass spectrometric characterization would provide us with a diagnostic method to rapidly distinguish between the different ring products and be used as a tool when investigating the quebecol products. In addition; the student would determine the rates of these cyclization reactions to better understand the relative formation of aromatic coupling products and 5 and 6-membered ether rings. This research is important as analogues of quebecol are being prepared elsewhere as potential therapeutic compounds and a thorough understanding of the factors influencing metabolic and oxidative reactions will be important for both safety and pharmacological assessment of these analogues. We will also assess the ability of the di-catechols to form reactive intermediates; such as ortho-quinones; through trapping experiments with glutathione. Finally; simple diphenylethane di-catechols have been shown to inhibit in vitro aggregation of alpha-synuclein; a protein involved in the pathophysiology of Parkinson's disease. In order to better understand the importance of di-catechols to this process; alpha-synuclein aggregation studies with the di-catechol diphenylethane analogues will be carried out.
Skills: The student should have knowledge of organic and analytical chemistry; additional knowledge of biochemistry or xenobiotic metabolism would also be helpful but is not required. Students will be working in a research laboratory so any experience they have with organic synthesis and measuring chemical properties with analytical instruments will help them be more comfortable. Some of the analytical instruments they will be using include nuclear magnetic resonance spectrometry; high-pressure liquid chromatography; UV-Vis spectrophotometry; mass spectrometry and fluorescence spectrometry.

Name: Granzymes in aging-related impaired wound healing
Description: The research project will focus on characterizing the role of granzymes in tissue injury and wound healing pertaining to aging-related; chronic inflammatory conditions using in vitro assays; in vivo disease models; and patient samples. Methodologies used will include: histology; immunohistochemistry; immunofluorescence; immunoblotting; protease assays; ELISAs; and cell culture. The student will have the opportunity to co-author research publications should significant findings arise from their contributions.
Skills: No skills available
Student academic background: Biochemistry; Biological Sciences; Biology; Genetics; Immunology; Medicine; Medical Sciences; Microbiology; Molecular Biology; Pathology; Physiology

Name: Geopolymer and superplasticizer
Description: Large CO2 emission; climate change; and quarry depletion together with soaring demand for housing; accommodation; and infrastructure have led to a large body of research on sustainable alternative construction materials to curtail cement production. According to the researchers; geopolymer is one of the most potential and cleanest materials to partially or completely substitute cement. According to the literature; coal fly ash is the most interesting precursor material for geopolymer. However; excessive usage of the coal fly ash in the construction sector has led to the scarcity and increased price of this material. On the other hand; wood fly ash produced by the pulp and paper mill industry has the capability of substituting coal fly ash in geopolymer production. Despite the benefits introduced by the abundance and waste nature of wood fly ash-based geopolymer; the relatively large quantity of alkaline activator needed in the production process can seriously hinder its vast usage. This study aims to reduce the amount of alkaline activator by using superplasticizers employed in cement-based concretes. The effect of different types of superplasticizers such as sulfonated melamine-formaldehyde condensate; sulfonated naphthalene-formaldehyde condensate; polycarboxylate; and polycarboxylate ether on such properties as setting time; flowability; compressive; and tensile strength of the geopolymers will be studied. As a result of this project; wood fly ash-based geopolymers will be more suitably formulated for usage in construction projects and the optimum amount of alkaline activator and superplasticizer will be identified.
Skills: The intern needs to have a great perseverance and enthusiasm for the sake of the research project. Besides; the student needs to have high levels of communication and time management expertise and the ability to work independently and within a team. The student should also have general problem solving and multitasking skills as well as a motivation for learning new technologies to have a satisfactory progress in their assigned project along with courses. Furthermore; the student is required to attend weekly research group meetings and to protect confidential research outcomes of the project.

Name: Evaluation of Seasonal Effects on Biopolymer treated soils
Description: Many indicators such as more frequent heatwaves; changing precipitation patterns; and reduced snow and ice cover now clearly show that Canada’s climate is changing. Civil engineering projects such as roads and embankments on clay soils; together with climate warming; can lead to deeper freezing during winter months and thawing during summer months. These seasonal cycles can produce large vertical and horizontal deformations that are only partly recoverable and thus affecting their long-term stability or durability. Sustainable engineering discourages the use of conventional soil stabilizers such as lime and cement owing to their higher carbon emission rates. To address these challenges; many researchers considered practical uses of microbiological techniques to improve the strength and durability properties of geomaterials. Through the laboratory-based experiment program; this study will investigate the utilization of xanthan gum; an eco-friendly biopolymer obtained from microbial sources; for the stabilization of clay soils. The mixing of xanthan gum biopolymer has been reported to form cementitious products that fill the pores of the soil structure; yielding a denser soil fabric with stronger attractive forces. The study will be focused to understand the effect of drying-wetting and freeze-thaw cycles on straining developed in soft clay layers under idealized repetitive traffic loading conditions using a series of macroscale and microscale test approaches. The purpose of this research is to discover innovative materials for an effective; sustainable; and resilient build environment as well as to promote the production of bio-based materials that can be fit to the principles of the circular economy. Many factors that will be investigated in this research is novel to the literature and will be the first step to exploring bio-based stabilizer for their possible applications to the service settlements of highways; runways; and metro rail tracks under the impact of adverse climate change.
Skills: The intern needs to have a great perseverance and enthusiasm for the sake of the research project. Besides; the student needs to have high levels of communication and time management expertise and the ability to work independently and within a team. The student should also have general problem solving and multitasking skills as well as a motivation for learning new technologies to have a satisfactory progress in their assigned project along with courses. Furthermore; the student is required to attend weekly research group meetings and to protect confidential research outcomes of the project.

Name: Development of sustainable bio-aggregate
Description: In this era of booming industrialization and urbanization; the construction sectors pose serious threat to the environment in terms of consumption and exploitation of non-renewable resources; as well as the ecological pollution and carbon footprints. This study intends to develop a green construction technology by investigating the potential application of hemp waste fiber as a sustainable bio-aggregate in fly ash stabilize rammed earth construction to the improve structural and thermal performance. The influence of hemp waste inclusion on the mechanical and hygrothermal properties of rammed earth will be assessed based on laboratory experiments. This study is inspired by the environmental and energy saving criterions for buildings based on clean energy concept; as well as the economic interests based on the circular economy model. The innovative applications of plant waste-based organic raw materials in the green building sector not only helps to combat climate changes by reducing the carbon dioxide emissions; but also has a positive health impact.
Skills: The intern needs to have a great perseverance and enthusiasm for the sake of the research project. Besides; the student needs to have high levels of communication and time management expertise and the ability to work independently and within a team. The student should also have general problem solving and multitasking skills as well as a motivation for learning new technologies to have a satisfactory progress in their assigned project along with courses. Furthermore; the student is required to attend weekly research group meetings and to protect confidential research outcomes of the project.

Name: Immigration in Brazil and Canada
Description: This project will be done in collaboration with researchers (Dr. Bruning and Dr. Ragnini) at the Universidade Federal do Parana. Research done in Brazil (Faria et al.; 2021) suggests that many immigrants arriving in Brazil from other countries in the Global South see Brazil as a transitory country and hope to migrate to North America for long-term settlement. This desire stems from an undeveloped settlement system that results in immigrants experiencing precarity characterized by a lack of security; predictability; and protection (Schierup et al.; 2015; p. 2; Standing; 2011). This project employs a multilevel framework comprising several levels of subjectivity (individual; interactional; organizational; and societal) (Nardon and Hari; 2022) to understand and compare Brazil and Canada's immigrant work integration ecosystem. We analyze the implications of experiences of precarity in immigrants' mental and physical health and its impact on long-term settlement. We see precarity as a labour condition and an ontological and embodied experience (Neilson & Rossiter; 2008). The ontological experience of precarity is woven into memories; experiences; aspirations; and practices of resistance. The embodied experience of precarity is marked on the flesh of living labour – the workers’ body (Tsianos & Papadopoulos; 2019). We will explore the role of macro discourses and policy frameworks; key organizational players such as universities; employers; and community organizations; and individual experiences across both countries to understand the factors implicated in precarization; mental health; and multi-step migration trajectories. We will draw on literature; previous data collected in Canada by the applicant and in Brazil by the partners; new data collected from public texts; demographic and economic data; and interviews with key informants. The project relates to the following UN´s Sustainable Development Goals: (3) Health and Well-Being; (8) Decent Work and Economic Growth; (10) Reduction of Inequalities; (16) Peace; Justice and Effective Institutions.
Skills: The ideal student for this project can work well independently and as part of a team and has some experience and skills in the following areas: • Excellent written and oral communication in English and Portuguese • Knowledge of qualitative research methods • Knowledge of ethical research principles • Understanding of theoretical frameworks related to mental health • Understanding of the migration system in Brazil (policies; practices; and discourses) • Ability and experience working with vulnerable populations • Interviewing skills (in English and Portuguese) • Experience engaging in academic literature reviews

Name: IoT based platform for serviceability performance monitoring of mass timber buildings
Description: Mass timber building is gaining increasing interest and a growing market in North America. The high stiffness-to-density ratio makes wood resilient to earthquakes; however; causing challenges in meeting serviceability requirements; such as wind-induced vibration in tall wood buildings; human-induced vibration of floor systems; and the sound transmission between rooms. The research program is to develop serviceability design guidance for tall wood buildings by understanding the dynamic properties of both whole buildings and components through laboratory and in situ measurements and numerical modeling. At the same time; we try to develop a mass timber building performance monitoring and assessment platform based on IoT which can be used to collect post-occupancy performance physical data and subjective comfort data. The data will then be used to assist decision-making in the design stages and to develop physics-informed data-driven design methods to achieve satisfactory serviceability performance in mass timber buildings.
Skills: Civil and Mechanical Engineering should have a solid background in mechanics; and preferably knowledge of dynamics and vibration. Electric and Computer Engineering students should have a solid background in programming; signal processing; and raspberry pi. Additional knowledge of IoT is an asset.

Name: EmoSense: Predicting Stress and Engagement through Physiological Bio-Signals and Facial Gesture Recognition
Description: The aim of our research project; "EmoSense;" is to utilize wearable Galvanic Skin Response (GSR) and photoplethysmography (PPG) sensors; along with a camera system; to accurately measure and quantify the physiological response to engagement in games delivered via a robotic system or a virtual reality (VR) environment. We intend to leverage artificial intelligence (AI) techniques; specifically feature extraction and classification using deep learning methods; to analyze the real-time data obtained from GSR; PPG; and facial gesture recognition systems. By combining multiple physiological indicators and facial expressions; we seek to develop a comprehensive framework that provides a more nuanced understanding of user engagement during interactive experiences. The GSR sensors will capture changes in skin conductance; reflecting the emotional arousal and stress levels of the participants. Simultaneously; PPG sensors will enable the measurement of heart rate and blood flow; providing additional insights into the participants' physiological states. Moreover; our project will employ a camera system to detect and track facial gestures; allowing us to analyze expressions such as smiles; frowns; and eyebrow movements. These facial expressions serve as valuable indicators of emotional states and can offer a deeper understanding of the participants' engagement levels. Through the integration of AI techniques; we will develop algorithms capable of extracting meaningful features from the collected data and applying classification models to accurately quantify user engagement. The real-time analysis will enable us to provide immediate feedback and adaptive responses; enhancing the interactive experience for the participants. Ultimately; the EmoSense project holds significant potential in various domains; such as gaming; virtual reality applications; human-computer interaction; and affective computing. The insights gained from this research can contribute to the development of more immersive and engaging experiences while also informing fields like mental health; user experience design; and personalized learning environments.
Skills: Possessing all of the skills listed below is not a prerequisite but can be beneficial. - Understanding of Physiology: familiarity with physiological concepts related to emotions; stress; and engagement. - Signal Processing and Data Analysis: familiarity in signal processing techniques and data analysis methods (e.g.; filtering; feature extraction; time-series analysis). Experience with tools like MATLAB; Python or other relevant software packages. - Machine Learning: familiarity with machine learning and deep learning and MATLAB or Python libraries (e.g.; TensorFlow). Knowledge of computer vision libraries (e.g.; OpenCV) will be beneficial. - Programming Skills: Proficiency in programming with Python or MATLAB.

Name: Scale-up and commercialization of a digital health tool to treat low desire in women
Description: The goal of this project is to assist in the scale-up; and commercialization of a digital sexual health tool that delivers mindfulness and cognitive behavioural therapy to women with low desire. Over the past 4 years; we have assessed the program; called eSense; feasibility; and efficacy in a randomized clinical trial. We are now moving to larger scale implementation; with a plan towards commercialization.
Skills: Strong scientific method and research design skills; ideally she experience with digital health; preferably a student who has been involved with knowledge translation.

Name: Expanded tubes
Description: The nuclear; oil and gas industries often experience shutdowns due different types of failures. The main cause of failure of tube-to-tubesheet joints is due to mechanical loading under harsh environmental conditions. The stress corrosion cracking enhanced by the relatively high residual stresses and plastic deformations generated during the expansion process is considered the most critical type of failure. They are the very weak link between the heat transfer process thermos-fluids and separation boundary. The complex elasto-plastic behavior of the expanded joint and the lack of a proper design procedure of the expansion process are the two main factors contributing to the low quality and low performance of this kind of assembly. The inadequacy of a proper control of the residual contact pressure during the process of expansion gives rise to higher residual stresses that make the joint vulnerable and prone to leakage failure. Although their use is still very popular even today; their fabrication is still based on trial and errors and internal recipes that are not made publically available by manufacturers. It is proposed to study the elasto-plastic behavior and the residual stress state by modelling the expanded joint behavior during the expansion process as well as during operation both analytically and numerically. Such a study would provide general guidelines on how to control the expansion process and help the design engineer to predict accurately the residual stresses that are the major source of stress corrosion cracking and leakage failure.
Skills: The candidate must have a good knowledge of stress analysis and have used in the past a general purpose finite element program such as ANSYS; ABAQUS; LS-DYNA etc....

Name: BEYOND THE SURFACE: VARIATIONS IN MICROSTRUCTURE OF PRETREATED PULSES USING HIGH RESOLUTION X-RAY MICRO TOMOGRAPHY
Description: Samples from three different pulses i.e. chick peas; navy beans and pinto beans will be collected. X-ray micro tomography data will be collected prior to the pretreatments using SKYSCAN 1275 X-ray micro tomograph instrument. The same samples will then be divided into two groups and will be roasted and soaked. The X-ray micro tomography images will be acquired for the pretreated samples. For processing the X-ray micro tomography data; Bruker CATn software will be used. 3D models will be developed to visualize the structural changes and for their elaboration.
Skills: The preferred skills of the student include MATLAB; image analysis; and multivariate data analysis. The student should be good at interpreting statistical data.

Name: Study of phase behaviour and viscosity correlation of Petroleum Mixtures.
Description: The main project aims are to: (a) examine the solubility characteristics of several hydrocarbon solvents used for reducing the viscosity of heavy oils in enhanced oil recovery processes; (b) evaluate the effects of polar additives on the viscosity and stability of the oil-solvent mixtures at different temperatures and concentrations; and (c) use the data obtained from these evaluations to develop a generalized and accurate viscosity model for the oil-solvent mixtures at different temperature; and solvent concentrations. The significance of the project is to determine the mixed solvent synergy and develop accurate viscosity correlation which will benefit petroleum industry.
Skills: The student will be required to have basic knowledge of crude oil characteristics; the ability to work with analytical instrumentation; have skills for basic computer applications such as xcel; ms word; and maple will be an advantage. The ability to read; interpret and carry out experimental procedure and be comfortable to work independently on several occasions. A background in either chemical engineering; petroleum engineering or chemistry is essential.

Name: Translating Quantum Mechanical Molecular Models into Chemical Language
Description: In quantum mechanics; substances are composed of electrons bound by atomic nuclei. This viewpoint is extremely powerful; and underlies modern computational approaches to electronic structure theory; e.g. quantum chemistry. These approaches—using methods like density-functional theory—are unquestionably useful; and are sufficient to provide quantitative information about energies; molecular responses; and electron distribution functions for almost all the molecules and materials of routine chemical interest. However; these computational methods and the results therefrom are in opposition to the language and concepts of chemistry. In quantum mechanics; there are no atoms; functional groups; or chemical bonds; there are no inductive effects or steric effects; there is no electronegativity or hardness; there is no electrophilicity or nucleophilicity. This makes it very challenging to gain chemical insight using modern computational quantum chemistry methods. The goal of this project is to try to translate the (numerical) output of quantum chemistry methods into the language of chemistry. The primary goal is to formulate a mathematical description of a chemical concept; implement it into the ChemTools package (www.chemtools.org); then test the concept on a database of molecules. Depending on student interests; different facets of this research workflow (mathematical modelling; computer programming; high-performance computing) can be emphasized. The project would occur under the QC-Devs (qcdevs.org) umbrella; so there will be ample resources/support for all facets of the project.
Skills: The student should have at least one year of chemistry at the university or advanced high-school level. Familiarity with quantum mechanics and computer programming is advantageous; but inessential.
Student academic background: Chemistry; Computer Science; Engg-Chemical; Engg-Computer; Engg-Software; Mathematics; Molecular Biology; Physics

Name: New Machine Learning Methods for Molecular Potential Energy Surfaces
Description: Traditional computational approaches for modelling molecules and materials are thwarted by the inevitable tension between cost and accuracy. It is relatively easy to generate low-accuracy results; but increasing the accuracy and reliability of these results requires directly solving the Schrödinger equation to find the wavefunction and/or the partition function. In machine-learning approaches; one does not attempt to computationally evaluate mathematical models for the underlying physics; but instead tries to deduce results from data. Such an approach can be used either to avoid costly computations. The specific goal of this project is to model isomerization reactions: Modelling molecular rearrangements directly is extremely difficult because it is difficult to; a priori; predict what sorts of rearrangements might occur. This is particularly true of molecular rearrangements under extreme conditions and/or geologic time scales. As part of our research with the Origins Institute; we seek to model these sorts of processes; so that we can understand how the few-atom molecules that were abundant in the early days of the Solar System combined and rearranged to form the biological precursor molecules. There are also interesting applications to environmental (especially atmospheric) reactions of pollutants and fragmentation patterns in mass spectrometry. To achieve this goal; we need to accurately solve the Schrodinger equation for specific molecular structures and then combine the data from these solutions to provide a complete global model for the molecular potential energy surface; which is the key quantity that undergirds chemical reactions (including chemical kinetics; equilibrium; and thermodynamics) and intermolecular interactions (including binding affinities; crystallization; solubility; etc.).
Skills: The student should have knowledge and familiarity with statistics; calculus; and linear algebra. It will be very helpful if the student also knows about scientific/mathematical programming and computer scripting; but any student with interests and skills in mathematics and/or computational modeling; however; could be productive.

Name: New Machine Learning Methods for Predicting the Effectiveness of Drug Candidates
Description: The goal of this project is to develop accurate and efficient ways to estimate the properties of molecules and materials in cases where rigorous computational approaches are either impractical or impossible. To do this; we will adapt recent theoretical and computational advances in machine learning methods to the problem of property prediction. The specific approach we plan to use is called kriging; or Gaussian processes. Gaussian processes corresponds to a neural network of infinite width or infinite depth; and while it is the best linear unbiased estimator for properties; it is too expensive for routine use with large datasets. However; for many applications in (bio)chemistry; where experimental data is scarce; Gaussian processes is believed to be the best possible machine-learning method. To use Gaussian processes to predict difficult-to-measure medicinally-relevant properties like toxicity; bioavailability; and drug binding affinity; one needs to quantify the similarity of different molecules: similar molecules will have similar properties. Specifically; we use a quantitative measure of the “dissimilarity between molecules.” Our specific approach is based on measuring the surface properties of molecules; as these properties are usually the most relevant properties for determining interactions with other biomolecules. The task of the student is to take a pharmacologically relevant property; find a database of experimental data for training (or use one of the properties/datasets we already have in hand); and then compute molecular surface descriptors and dissimilarities; so that a computational model for property prediction can be formulated. Of special interest are toxicity; blood-brain-barrier permeability; bioavailability; and drug-binding affinity.
Skills: The student should have knowledge and familiarity with statistics; calculus; and linear algebra. It will be very helpful if the student also knows about scientific/mathematical programming and computer scripting; but any student with interests and skills in mathematics and/or computational modeling; however; could be productive.

Name: Developing Software to Gain Chemical Insights from Quantum Chemistry Calculations
Description: The immediate outputs of quantum chemistry calculations are approximate energy and wavefunction for a chemical substance. However; extracting a molecule’s intrinsic chemical characteristics from the gigabytes of raw numerical wave-function data is neither unique nor straightforward; because chemical concepts (e.g. atoms & bonds) do not correspond to well-defined observables in quantum mechanics. This has led to a proliferation of post-processing methods for interpreting the wave-function in terms of chemical language. Unfortunately; only a limited number of these interpretive tools; and rarely the most modern ones; exist in quantum chemistry packages. To bridge this gap; stand-alone software packages have been developed to take the numerical output of quantum chemistry packages to further extract chemical concepts. However; most of these packages have a narrow scope; follow old-style coding practices; and are monolithic and unfit for testing ideas and active development. This led us to the development of the free and open-source ChemTools software package (https://chemtools.org/) to make it easy for theorists to test and implement new ideas and non-specialists (e.g. experimental or computational chemists) to use the most recent tools from conceptual quantum chemistry in their research/teaching. In doing so; ChemTools strives to provide unbiased support for all mathematically rigorous post-processing tools defined within the conceptual quantum chemistry research field and complement various quantum chemistry software packages. ChemTools emphasizes on principles of sustainable software development and is well-tested; well-documented; and user-friendly.
