The specific aim of this project is developing; implementing; and testing novel tools for visualizing molecular orbitals and analyzing their interactions to understand chemical reactivity. This project has multiple facets including mathematical development (converting the chemical problem to a mathematical problem); software implementation (programming mathematical equations within the HORTON and ChemTools packages); and computational modeling (running calculations and analyzing results) of molecular reactivity.
Skills: The student with the proper background will get trained during the first few weeks to successfully perform the project during the internship period. Ideally; the student should have knowledge and familiarity with chemistry; physics; linear algebra; and calculus. It will be very helpful if the student also knows about computer programming and scripting (specifically Python); but any student with interests and skills in computational modeling is welcome to join our team.

Name: Physics-Based Machine-Learning Models: Combining Speed and Accuracy in Computational Chemistry
Description: Machine learning (ML) is becoming increasingly prevalent in chemistry; promising a powerful alternative tool for addressing problems of chemical significance. ML algorithms automate analytical model building; enabling computers to find hidden patterns by iteratively learning from training data without being explicitly programmed. Recent advances in ML algorithms and the abundance of computational data have enormously expedited the training of novel ML algorithms to circumvent costly quantum-mechanical calculations. This success has lead to big promises by ML proponents in theoretical chemistry. However; these models are only suitable for interpolation and fail to scale to larger systems. That is; when a model is trained on small-to-medium-size molecules; it can only be applied to systems of similar size. Modeling long-range intermolecular interactions with machine learning (ML) requires sampling the vast diversity of chemical environments occurring on an extended length scale. This leads to a combinatorial explosion in the required amount of training data. This specific project incorporates physical knowledge into the machine-learning modeling process to achieve the accuracy of high-level quantum chemistry at the cost of molecular mechanics; this is philosophically different from the commonly used “black box ML modeling”. This not only allows one to compute interaction energies of large molecules (e.g. drug-target binding) and run long-time molecular dynamics simulations of (macro)molecules but also enables accurate and efficient computational screening of large databases to select the most promising molecules for follow-up experiments.
Skills: The student with the proper background will get trained during the first few weeks to successfully perform the project during the internship period. Ideally; the student should have knowledge and familiarity with chemistry; physics; linear algebra; and calculus. It will be very helpful if the student also knows about computer programming and scripting (specifically Python) and machine-learning algorithms; but any student with interests and skills in machine learning and computational modeling are welcome to join our team.

Name: South Korea Stands With Ukraine
Description: On February 24; the Russian Government Genocide of the People of Ukraine entered a new stage: the physical elimination of Ukrainians from their homeland on all territories of Ukraine. In one month; more than 25% of the total population of Ukraine (+10 Million People) has been displaced; and thousands have died. The global community has seen the thread that Russia created in the democratic world; and democratic governments worldwide joined the global movement to stand with Ukraine. The project is designed to document how South Korea stands with Ukraine and what initiatives have been created in South Korea to support the people of Ukraine. It is also essential to note the efforts of global communities to stop the war and recognize its worldwide impact on how to support displaced populations.
Skills: Ideally; the student should be from the School of Social Work in South Korea and interested in the Ukrainian-South Korea community development. Excellent technology usage skills are required. Excellent literature review and academic writing skills are needed to create a bibliography of resources on the South Korea-Ukrainian community and provide assistance in developing brief / article on how South Korea Stands with Ukraine. Excellent community engagement skills will help the student build a relationship with South Korea-Ukrainian organizations.

Name: Taiwan Stands With Ukraine
Description: On February 24; the Russian Government Genocide of the People of Ukraine entered a new stage: the physical elimination of Ukrainians from their homeland on all territories of Ukraine. In one month; more than 25% of the total population of Ukraine (+10 Million People) has been displaced; and thousands have died. The global community has seen the thread that Russia created in the democratic world; and democratic governments worldwide joined the global movement to stand with Ukraine. The project is designed to document how Taiwan stands with Ukraine and what initiatives has been created in Taiwan to support people of Ukraine. It is also essential to note the efforts of global communities to stop the war and recognize its worldwide impact on how to support displaced populations.
Skills: Ideally; the student should be from the School of Social Work in Taiwan and interested in the Ukrainian-Taiwan community development. Excellent technology usage skills are required. Excellent literature review and academic writing skills are needed to create a bibliography of resources on the US-Ukrainian community and provide assistance in developing brief / article on how Taiwan Stands with Ukraine. Excellent community engagement skills will help the student build a relationship with Taiwan-Ukrainian organizations.

Name: Energy-Efficient
Description: City-Scale Point Cloud Compression on Heterogeneous Laptops
Faculty supervisor: Last year; Intel released their newest computer processor; making it even harder for software to scale as well as hardware will allow. You see; with their "Alder Lake" generation; Intel switched to a big.LITTLE design where different cores have different strengths; invalidating the classic (i.e.; pre-2022) PRAM view that all parallel cores are the same. (This already was wrong for phones and for memory.) It's yet another step in a multi-decade trend towards ubiquitous heterogeneous computing. Our work is on energy-efficient analytics for large datasets. Specifically; we want to compress really large 3D point clouds (say; covering the entirety of metro Vancouver) into smaller; realistic approximations that require much less energy and power to analyse. This compression is quite expensive and required us to adapt (or; more accurately; completely redesign!) algorithms to take better advantage of parallelism; it has applications in computer graphics; AR/VR; digital twinning; and gaming. While our algorithm redesign was quite successful; it is clear that we have missed a lot of potential on 2022-vintage computers by using different cores more strategically. In this project; you would investigate what we had missed: how can we adapt this point cloud compression algorithm for a mixture of "performance" and "efficiency" cores? The goal would be to achieve similar run time performance but with less energy. It is possible to decide which threads run on which cores and it is possible to decide which parallel tasks are executed by which threads. The research would involve deeply studying the problem to understand how to map algorithmic work to specialties of cores; adapting (or redesigning?) our parallel algorithm; implementing your algorithmic ideas into our pre-existing C++/OpenMP code base; and running experiments to evaluate performance relative to cost. Positive results in this direction could inspire rethinking how most parallel algorithms are designed.
Student academic background: For this project; interns should: * have a first-rate standing in their study program * be comfortable with the C++ programming language; including the use of STL; smart pointers; and multi-threading (or equivalent knowledge) * have good communication skills in English; both written and verbal * be comfortable working under the guidance of and in collaboration with a multi-cultural team * have an interest in nuanced data structure design and empirical evaluation * be eager to learn and to follow through independently on tasks * access to an "Alder Lake" generation Intel laptop/computer (or newer)
column11: Computer Science; Engg-Computer; Engineering; Engg-Software; Engg-Electrical

Name: Investigation of metal-organic framework composite nanomaterials to develop a cost-effective sensors
Description: Dr. Kim’s group is currently focusing on the development of the nano/micro-sensors and sensing systems with micro/nanotechnology and novel nanocomposite and quantum materials. In addition; Dr. Kim’s group has expertise in the design; development; modeling; and testing of novel measurement setups and procedures. Some of the recent achievements include the development of the new characterization techniques for cokes; ceramic composites; polymeric nanocomposites; and oil sands.To ultimately develop a cost-effective; portable sensing device; we propose investigation of MOF nanocomposite materials which can be exploited as chemoselective interface on many sensing platform. The following tasks are proposed: Task 1 : Literature survey; material selection; and synthesis of MOF nanocomposite materials on a gravimetric/electric/optical sensor platform; Task 2 : Testing and characterization of the developed MOF composite-based sensors. Two selected MOF nanocomposite materials will be synthesized; tested and characterized for sensitivity; selectivity; dynamic range; humidity effects; and reproducibility.
Skills: Previous hands-on experience on chemistry and nanomaterials synthesis is highly desirable but not required. Chemistry or Materials Science and Engineering or Chemical Engineering background is recommended.

Name: FireWatch: Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) and Image Processing for Real-time Wildfire Detection and Risk Assessment
Description: The research project titled "FireWatch" aims to develop an innovative system for proactive monitoring of fields to detect and assess the risk of wildfires. The project leverages Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs); image processing techniques; and GPS navigation to enable efficient and timely detection of potential fire outbreaks. The UAV is equipped with a high-resolution camera that continuously captures images of the field below. These images are processed using advanced image processing algorithms to identify and analyze patterns indicative of fire; such as smoke; flames; or changes in temperature. By employing real-time image analysis; the system can swiftly detect the presence of wildfires; even at their early stages; providing valuable time for prompt intervention. To facilitate navigation and ensure accurate data collection; the UAV relies on GPS data to autonomously fly over designated areas of interest. The UAV's connection to a server enables seamless communication and data transfer; allowing real-time monitoring and analysis by wildfire management teams. The primary objectives of this research project are to enhance the effectiveness and efficiency of wildfire monitoring; minimize response time to potential fire outbreaks; and reduce the risk of extensive damage to natural landscapes and human settlements. By combining the capabilities of UAVs; image processing; and GPS navigation; the proposed system offers a proactive approach to wildfire management; enabling authorities to take preventive measures and allocate resources more effectively. The research findings and developed system have the potential to significantly improve current wildfire detection and monitoring strategies; contributing to the preservation of ecosystems; protection of lives and properties; and overall enhancement of wildfire management practices.
Skills: Possessing all of the skills listed below is not a prerequisite but is beneficial. - Background in mechanical/electrical engineering is desirable. - Familiarity with image processing techniques; such as image segmentation; feature extraction; and pattern recognition. - Familiarity with programming languages (e.g.; Python; MATLAB) and experience in software development. - Basic knowledge of UAV systems; including flight control and GPS navigation; would be beneficial. - Good problem-solving skills; attention to detail; and the ability to work both independently and collaboratively in a research team are essential for success in this project.

Name: AutoTrader: Integrating Technical Indicators
Description: AI
Faculty supervisor: and Reinforcement Learning for Enhanced Automated Trading Strategies
Host Province: The “AutoTrader” research project aims to revolutionize the world of automated trading by integrating fundamental quantitative finance concepts such technical indicators; with artificial intelligence (AI); and reinforcement learning. Our primary objective is to develop a robust system capable of predicting future price movements and executing rule-based trading strategies with optimal efficiency. By harnessing the power of technical indicators; we aim to extract valuable insights from historical price data. These indicators; combined with AI algorithms; will form the foundation of our predictive models; enabling us to identify patterns; trends; and potential market signals. The utilization of AI techniques will enhance the accuracy and speed of our predictions; empowering traders with valuable information for making informed trading decisions. To further elevate the capabilities of our system; we will incorporate reinforcement learning. This innovative approach allows our trading system; AutoTrader; to continuously learn and adapt to changing market conditions. By interacting with the market in real-time; AutoTrader will receive feedback on its trading decisions and refine its strategies accordingly. This iterative learning process will enable the system to continuously improve its performance and optimize trading outcomes. Through extensive backtesting and simulation; we will evaluate the effectiveness and profitability of AutoTrader's strategies across diverse market scenarios. The system will be trained on historical data to develop robust rule-based predictors that capture key market patterns. By considering factors such as price trends; volatility; and volume; AutoTrader will generate signals to trigger automated trades; minimizing human intervention and potential biases. The research project also aims to address risk management and portfolio optimization within the automated trading framework. By implementing risk control measures and exploring portfolio diversification strategies; AutoTrader will prioritize capital preservation while striving for consistent profitability.
Skills: English
column11: - A foundation in computer science; mathematics; and finance would be beneficial. - Proficiency in programming languages such as Python is crucial for implementing the algorithmic trading systems and integrating technical indicators. - Familiarity with machine learning concepts; including supervised and reinforcement learning; is required to develop AI-based predictors. - Knowledge of financial markets; trading strategies; and risk management principles is an asset. - Strong analytical and problem-solving skills; as well as the ability to work with large datasets; are also important for conducting rigorous backtesting and performance evaluations.

Name: HealthSync: AI-enabled Cloud-based System for Personalized Health Monitoring
Description: The “HealthSync” research project aims to revolutionize health monitoring and assessment through the integration of wearable technology; cloud systems; and artificial intelligence (AI). By utilizing smartwatches equipped with sensors; this project collects comprehensive movement and physiological data from individuals in real-time. The primary objective of HealthSync is to develop a robust system that seamlessly transfers the collected data to a cloud-based infrastructure. This cloud system serves as a centralized hub for data storage and analysis; enabling efficient processing of vast amounts of information. Leveraging the power of AI algorithms; the project aims to detect movement and daily activity patterns; as well as identify meaningful changes in physiological data such as heart rate; blood oxygen levels; and blood pressure. One of the key strengths of HealthSync lies in its ability to provide real-time feedback to users. By continuously analyzing the incoming data; the system can generate immediate insights and notifications to individuals; encouraging healthy behaviors and offering personalized guidance. For instance; if the system detects prolonged periods of sedentary behavior; it can prompt the user to take breaks and engage in physical activity; thus promoting a more active lifestyle. Additionally; the project emphasizes personalized assessment and prevention. By establishing baseline patterns and individual thresholds; HealthSync can identify deviations from the norm and alert users to potential health risks. Through regular monitoring and analysis; the system can proactively detect early signs of conditions like hypertension; irregular heart rhythms; or other physiological abnormalities; enabling timely intervention and prevention. Overall; the HealthSync project aims to empower individuals to take control of their health through wearable technology; cloud infrastructure; and AI-driven analysis. By providing real-time feedback and personalized monitoring; the system has the potential to significantly improve health outcomes; encourage healthy behaviors; and facilitate proactive preventive care.
Skills: - Proficiency in programming languages such as Python is essential for data analysis and AI implementation. - Familiarity with cloud computing platforms and databases would be beneficial. - Knowledge of wearable technology and data collection methods; as well as an understanding of physiological signals and their interpretation; would be advantageous. - Strong analytical and problem-solving skills; as well as an ability to work in a team and adapt to new technologies; are highly desirable for this research project.

Name: Trans-national Indigeneity
Description: Displacement
Host Province: This research project is informed by the author’s lived experience as a Black Indigenous Liberian migrant woman in Canada. The research also builds upon her PhD dissertation entitled: Systematic Violence and the Rule of Law: Indigenous Communities in Post-war Liberia and Australia. The peculiarity of the doctoral dissertation lies in documenting and validating Indigenous Peoples collective experiences with colonial violence impacted by “rule of settler law”; land dispossession; forced displacement; systemic racism; and ongoing exclusion from the nation-building building process. This unique experience of Indigenous Peoples the world over converges at the imposition; transplantation; and dominance of oppressive settler law on Indigenous communities marked by the persistence of intergenerational trauma despite their resistance and advocacy. Assessing displaced Indigenous peoples’ experience in Canada and elsewhere will affirm that Indigenous Peoples unified by their shared experiences despite inter- and intra- group differences can unshackle the indelibility of systemic colonial violence by adopting a holistic research approach. Four critical inquiries emerge in this research: 1) an assessment of whether Indigenous identity can be defined by genetics; geographical boundary; a spiritual connection to the land via ancestral; physical; and ceremonial traditions; Eurocentric patriarchal colonialism; shared global experiences; or transplant of settler law; 2) understanding the impact of intergenerational trauma on displaced Indigenous girls and women who are survivors of systemic violence; 3) documenting survivorship experience to give agency to displaced Indigenous peoples in owning their stories and charting the path they want; and 4) disrupting and deconstructing patriarchal norms across institutional; cultural; and community settings using attributes of transformational leadership for social change. Therefore; in documenting; establishing; and acknowledging the experiences of displaced world Indigenous citizens and transnational Indigenous Peoples; the research examines the multiplicity of indigeneities in Liberia; Canada; Ghana; Australia; Zimbabwe; and the United States; and Zimbabwe using a complex (mixed method).
Skills: English
column11: Be a postgraduate student in law; public health; Indigenous studies; gender studies; forced migration studies; interdisciplinary studies or other relevant graduate programs with commitments to equality and social justice  Have an ability to work both independently and as part of a team with minimal supervision  Have excellent organizational skills; high attention to detail; and ability to meet deadlines  Have strong written and verbal communication skills  Have grounded understanding in and/or connections to marginalized groups (e.g.; Black Peoples; Indigenous Peoples; Displaced Peoples; and migrants)  Be self‐motivated; goal‐oriented; and results‐driven
column12: Womens Studies; Statistics; Social Work; Public Health; Psychology; Political Science; Native Studies; Law-International; Law; International Studies; Humanities; History; Health Studies; French Language; Development Studies; Canadian Studies; Education

Name: Investigation of CO2 electrolysis reversibility in seawater
Description: The project will take place in the department of chemistry at St Francis Xavier University; within the group of Dr. Bertin. Recently; we have started to study the electroreduction of CO2 into seawater. Seawater has a suitable pH for CO2 reduction; and its ionic strength is sufficient to sustain moderate electrolysis current without additional salt. We have successfully demonstrated that bismuth nanoparticles prepared by PLAL can successfully operate in either seawater or the conventional bicarbonate buffer with no loss of performances. On bismuth; the product of the reduction of CO2 is formate. Formate is an environmentally benign salt; that has application in the leather industry; as deicing salt; but also has fuel in formate (or formic acid) fuel cells. Formic acid fuel cells have been widely studied in the last two decades; but to the best of our knowledge never in seawater. Yet; it would be highly interesting to determine if direct formate oxidation in seawater is possible. If it is; it could allow the CO2 electrolyzer to operate as an electrolyzer in periods of high renewable (solar; wind) electricity generation; but also as a fuel cell in times when renewable electricity sources are less productive. Formate is also a stable salt; so it could be easily stored long enough to compensate for seasonal variability of renewable energy sources as well.
Skills: To positively contribute to the project; the student should have completed courses equivalent to a 2nd year chemistry student at St Francis Xavier University; with particular emphasis on analytical chemistry and physical chemistry. The student should have basic experience in accurately preparing aqueous solutions using standard glassware (volumetric; micropipettes) as well as an understanding of Beer-Lambert law. The student should also have an introductory knowledge of redox equations and the concept of potential and current. Finally; knowledge of the global harmonized system (GHS) for classification and labelling of chemicals is required. Further specialized training will be provided at St FX.

Name: Encapsulation de molécule active pour le traitement de l'ACG de type 1B
Description: Congenital Glycosylation Anomalies (CGAs) are genetic disorders that disrupt protein glycosylation. Type 1A CAGs are caused by phosphomannomutase (PMM) deficiency; and result in moderate to severe mental retardation. In contrast; type 1B ACG; linked to mutations in the PMI1 gene; causes exudative enteropathy and hypoglycemia in infants; without neurological manifestations. Treatment of type 1B ACG currently involves daily oral mannose. However; this requires several doses a day to maintain constant serum levels; which can lead to compliance problems. In addition; variations in mannose levels can lead to long-term complications; including liver fibrosis and thrombophilia. To address these issues; it is important to develop a formulation that allows a gradual release of mannose throughout the day; mimicking its physiological release. This would help maintain stable serum mannose levels and reduce the complications associated with type 1B CAG. In this context; the project proposes to develop a juice suspension containing two forms of mannose: a rapid-release non-encapsulated form and a sustained-release encapsulated form. The use of encapsulation systems offers several advantages; not least the possibility of controlling release over time. The technical challenge lies in obtaining mannose microparticles that release the sugar in such a way as to maintain a constant concentration in the body. In conclusion; this project aims to develop a formulation that can control the release of mannose over time; thus maintaining a constant concentration in the body. Such advances could improve the quality of life of CAG patients and offer better prospects for long-term treatment.
Skills: The candidate must have skills in chemistry and analytical chemistry

Name: Creating diverse digital characters to study empathy
Description: Empathy is the ability to share and understand the affective state of others. This ability varies depending on the people we interact with and the context in which the interaction evolves. People tend to feel more empathy towards individuals from the same ethnic group than from a different group. Two strategies have been suggested to alleviate this bias in empathy: 1) repeated and controlled exposure and 2) promoting the adoption of the point of view of others. However; these techniques were not tested together in contexts with good ecological validity. This project aims at studying and optimize empathy in ingroup-outgroup interactions by varying the visual characteristics of digital characters (MetaHumans); or contextual elements in virtual environments; to increase exposure to outgroup individuals and promote adopting the point of view of others. Method: Controlled online experiments will be conducted in the general population using a new adapted version of the Empathy-Enhancing Virtual Evolving Environment (EEVEE; 1st version; Jackson et al.; 2015) called AffectiveStudio. In this platform; new realistic characters from MetaHuman Creator (Epic Games) whose characteristics related to age; gender; and ethnicity can be produced. The facial expressions of the different characters are animated by moving several features of the face independently (i.e.; Action Units). AffectiveStudio currently comprises 16 characters representing young adults (women and men) from four ethnic groups. This project will integrate new features to AffectiveStudio (e.g.; accessories; postural behaviors; older characters; other ethnic and culture groups) and a novel method to measure the users’ representation of facial expressions through an interactive mode. Implications: This project will generate new knowledge on how the ingroup versus outgroup effect affects empathy. It will contribute to developing novel tools through which empathy can be optimized and maintained as a viable solution to embrace diversity and promote equity and inclusion.
Skills: Qualifications: - Minimum of two years in a recognized program of Computer Sciences/Engineering; Graphic Design or relevant program - Experience with 3-D animation or human-machine systems (e.g.; apps; video games) - Experience with animation tools (e.g.; Unreal/Unity) and relevant programming languages (e.g.; C# and C++) Core Skills and Abilities: - Strong interest in affective computing research and scientific programming within an academic setting - Excellent verbal and written communication skills (English or French); including the ability to work effectively with others in an interdisciplinary team Additional assets: - Experience in Python (or other languages used in data sciences and web)

Name: Knowledge Representation to Combat False Claims on Social Media Platform
Description: This project aims at developing new techniques to detect false narratives on social media. In recent years; we have witnessed how social media can be used to influence people (e.g.; voters) with misinformation and disinformation campaigns that if amplified by AI algorithms can reach millions of people. In this research; PLM and KG will be combined to mitigate this problem. Specifically; knowledge can be implicitly encoded on PLM; such as BERT; GPT-3 and T5; using unstructured data. These models have been very successful in several NLP tasks related to semantic retrieval. Despite the strong performance attained by these models; they often struggle with examples not seen during the fine-tuning stage. Previous research has shown significant improvement with the combination of structured knowledge from KGs and the representations learned by PLMs. Although; this approach has attracted NLP researchers; it is still an open question how to integrate the KG and PLM for specific semantic related tasks. In this research; the focus will be on infodemic and disinformation campaigns during political election.
Skills: • Pursuing a degree in Computer Science; Computer Engineering; Electrical Engineering; Mathematics or equivalent • Knowledge in Python • Knowledge in machine learning theory and practice (especially deep learning) • Energetic; self-motivated and execution-oriented individuals that are passionate about producing new knowledge

Name: Reducing Model Complexity in Federated Learning Settings
Description: This project aims at developing new techniques to reduce the complexity of deep neural networks in order to enable their deployment on edge devices. Tech companies around the world have been demanded to treat user data carefully and in accordance to user-privacy laws. Deep learning AI systems often require the user data to be sent to the cloud in order to be processed remotely on large data processing clusters. This raises concerns as sensitive data need to be sent over the internet. Enabling on-device computing can mitigate security and privacy concerns by keeping users' data within their devices. In this research; the aim will be to improve the efficiency of deep learning applications by exploring techniques such as model compression; knowledge distillation in order to enable powerful AI algorithms to run more efficiently on low-power mobile devices. This will allow to confine the processing of private sensitive data at the IoT device itself. Federated Learning will be explored as it enables AI models to learn from multiple decentralized edge devices using only local data; thus avoiding exchanging such data through the network.
Skills: • Pursuing a degree in Computer Science; Computer Engineering; Electrical Engineering; Mathematics or equivalent. • Knowledge in Python • Knowledge in machine learning theory and practice (especially deep learning). • Energetic; self-motivated and execution-oriented individuals that are passionate about producing new knowledge.

Name: Contagion in financial markets: the application of network analysis in finance
Description: The 2008 financial crisis highlighted the connectedness of financial institutions around the world. This networking can have important consequences; both positive and negative; for global and national financial systems. In this context; network theory and social network analysis (SNA) can provide helpful tools and measures to better understand the effects of networks or any other phenomena of finance or; to quote Allen and Babus (2009): “Mapping the networks between financial institutions is a first step towards gaining a better understanding of modern financial systems.” The objective of this project is to study and analyse the topology and structure of different financial markets or networks; such as the mutual and pension funds networks; the syndicated loan market network and all the main securities markets. To do so; a comprehensive network theory approach that includes novel financial network analysis tools and metrics will offer an essential perspective on the underlying connections in the networks. Basic network structure metrics will be estimated; such as small-world statistic; scale-free parameters; etc. Further; novel network measures; which are typically developed in other fields; will be applied to the financial networks identified above: herd behavior; sources of diffusion; influential spreaders; bridges; adoption probabilities; mobility traces; etc. Because different networks can emerge from the same connections (e.g.; dual-mode network; correlation network; etc.); the metrics will be estimated for a variety of networks. The expected contributions of the project are both scientific and practical.
Skills: 1. Intermediate programming skills (R) 2. Basic / intermediate understanding of financial markets and securities 3. Strong reading; understanding and analysis skills The student will either have a background in finance (or economics) with complementary programming skills or have a background in other fields (e.g. computers; physics; mathematics; sociology; etc.) with a knowledge of financial markets and securities. A basic knowledge of network theory is as asset. The student must be very autonomous and show initiatives. The student must speak and write in english or french

Name: Dark Matter Search with the PICO Bubble Chambers
Description: PICO is operating a large chamber at SNOLAB; Canada's deep underground physics research laboratory. The chamber is used to measure if signs of dark matter interactions can be seen in the bubbles of the superheated liquid of our detector. The project involves sophisticated optical triggering algorithms and acoustic data analysis because a large fraction of the information encoded in bubble chamber events is in the sound that the boiling liquid emits. Students will be part of the team analyzing optical and acoustical data from the PICO bubble chamber. PICO is developing new techniques for acoustic signal processing and optical data selection involving machine learning. PICO also offers opportunities to develop new equipment for sensitive acoustic detectors and can also benefit from students with extensive experience in a lab environment; developing building and testing new equipment for the experiment.
Skills: Ideally the student knows Python or C++. Students should be familiar with basic computational concepts; such as pattern finding; fast Fourier transformations and neural networks. A background in particle physics tools like CERN root or GEANT 4 is an advantage. PICO employs a blind data analysis approach to prevent biases introduced by the researchers. A basic understanding of blind data analysis is also beneficial.

Name: The Pacific Neutrino Experiment
Description: We aim to explore how to optimally construct an experiment in the depth of the Pacific to study neutrinos. The experiment will consist of multiple underwater moorings (strings) with 20 digital optical modules each. The layout and installation sequence of the modules will be studied as part of this project. We will also be working with the existing data from the small pilot project that is operating underwater. We will be extracting optical parameters; bioluminescence and the performance of the optical components of the underwater systems.
Skills: Students will be familiar with weak interactions and neutrinos. They will already have been exposed to working in a research environment and know how to use python and visualize data. Being familiar with root or other particle physics specific programming tools such as GEANT4 is highly desirable.

Name: Blockchain-Based Federated Learning
Description: Federated Learning is nowadays used to maintain secure distributed learning and data modelling in various sectors and applications. On the other hand; the features of Blockchain will help us with transparent; immutable and secure operations. In this research project; we will design a blockchain-based federated learning system to get the benefits of the inherited features of blockchain in federated learning techniques.
Skills: At least one advanced programming language; like Java; Python; and C# Knowledge of Data Analytics such as Data Mining; Machine Learning and Federated Learning methods Knowledge of Blockchain

Name: Improving ion selective membranes through a greener approach to biofouling prevention
Description: A major stream of our research involves developing safer alternative materials to act as antifouling agents in membrane-based technologies; particularly fuel cell and battery storage technologies as well as reverse osmosis water treatment systems; which are currently limited in application by the energy costs associated with biofouling.
Skills: Introductory laboratory experience; intro chemistry; biology. Experience in a "wet lab"; and with project design and management is an asset. Experience culturing cells is an asset but not required. Experience working with membrane systems may be beneficial. The student is expected to be responsible; professional; and communicate clearly and promptly with members of our team. We are a diverse group and we are thrilled to have international students joining us!
Student academic background: Biological Sciences; Chemistry; Engg-Chemical; Engg-Civil; Engg-Materials; Engineering

Name: RevolveRL
Description: The project focuses on enhancing reinforcement learning (RL) through the evolution of a reward function using genetic programming (GP). RL is an artificial intelligence approach where an agent learns to achieve a specific objective; such as winning a game of Starcraft 2. The agent interacts with the environment; receiving feedback in the form of rewards after each action taken. The challenge lies in defining an effective reward function. Traditionally; researchers rely on their experience to tune this function; but it may not be optimal. The project aims to address this issue by evolving the reward function using GP. GP; a type of evolutionary computation; employs principles inspired by natural evolution to iteratively refine a population of reward functions. By evolving the reward function over time; the project aims to improve training time and enhance the overall performance of the RL agent. The evolution process will involve generating a diverse set of reward functions and evaluating their effectiveness in achieving the desired objective. Through iterative selection; crossover; and mutation; GP will refine the reward functions; favoring those that lead to better performance. This approach aims to overcome the limitations of manually designed reward functions and enable the RL agent to learn more efficiently and effectively while also removing human biases. The project offers an opportunity to explore the potential of GP in enhancing RL. By evolving the reward function; it aims to reduce training time and optimize the performance of the agent in accomplishing the specified mission. Through this research; valuable insights can be gained into the impact of reward function design on RL algorithms and the potential benefits of evolutionary approaches in this context.
Skills: We are seeking a motivated student with a background in AI; and data analysis science for our research project. The ideal candidate should have a solid understanding of data structures; and be able to implement and manipulate them. Understanding of AI concepts is crucial and any experience with popular libraries like PyTorch is a plus. The candidate should be proficient in statistical analysis; data visualization using Python. Familiarity with RL and GP is an asset. Experience with classic video games is is also advantageous; as the is also advantageous; as the project may involve working with game-related data.

Name: Nanoengineered Hydrogels for 3D Bioprinting Applications
Description: Biocompatible injectable hydrogels hold immense potential to be used in the development of minimally invasive therapeutics; as well as in additive manufacturing to tissue engineer complex 3D structures. However; weak mechanical properties of currently available conventional hydrogels result in limited control over structural stability; printability and degradation characteristics. Dr. Paul’s research project will introduce a novel family of nanocomposite hydrogels; utilizing the interactions between 2D nanomaterials and bioactive polymers; to mechanically reinforce the hydrogel network. The resulting shear-thinning nanoengineered hydrogel will be mechanically resilient; 3D printable; and capable of delivering drug molecules and cells.
Skills: Student with strong academic background and training experience in cellular and molecular biology; nanomedicine and drug delivery will be helpful.

Name: Python platform for Engineering Applications
Description: My group recently created the MecSimCalc platform for creating and sharing computational tools on the web. With a few very simple steps; educators and professionals can create interactive web applications for their students or clients. MecSimCalc has been a work in progress since I joined the Engineering Faculty at the University of Alberta in 2007. The project involves working on the frontend and the backend of MecSimCalc to create new apps (frontend) or multiple additional features (backend) that are tailored to different user profiles including advanced templates; specialized python packages; and advanced input parameters.
Skills: Student should be skilled in programming using python Familiarity with javascript and/or React is an asset.

Name: The Role of Meteorite Impacts in the Origin and Evolution of Life
Description: This project aims to better understand how meteorite impacts events generate hydrothermal systems; which can generate unique habitats for heat-loving (thermophilic) organisms and produce secondary minerals such as clays; which form catalysts for organic reactions. A comprehensive review of the literature on all craters on Earth will be conducted to determine where in a crater hydrothermal alteration occurs; the types of mineral species produced; etc. This is part of a larger ongoing team effort to which the student will contribute to. This summer research will also study samples from the Mistastin and West Clearwater Lake impact structures; both in Canada; where hydrothermal alterations has been recognized but not studied in any detail. Thin sections of these samples will be studied using optical microscopy (for textures); electron microprobe analysis (EPMA) (for micro-textures and elemental mapping); and raman spectroscopy (for organics). The results of these investigations will enhance our understanding of how hydrothermal systems in impact craters generate and whether such systems may have provided habitats for life on Mars.
Skills: Basic knowledge of geoscience; geobiology and geochemistry. Previous laboratory experience in microscopy and geochemistry is considered an asset.

Name: A Comparative Study of Impact Melts on the Earth and Moon
Description: Constraining the initial conditions of impact melt remain a challenge. Geothermometer systems that are commonly used in geosciences are not sufficient to constrain the temperature of impact melt since most are not able to withstand the high pressure conditions of impact cratering and none are known to exceed 1700 °C. Zirconia (ZrO2); a dissociation product of zircon; is one mineral phase that can constrain temperature in the geologic record because they exhibit diverse polymorphs across a wide range of temperatures. During the summer research; the student will study the properties of zircon in samples of impact melt from various Canadian impact craters; lunar meteorites and Apollo samples. Samples will be studied via optical microscopy (for textures); scanning X-ray fluorescence (XRF) (for micro-textures and large-scale elemental mapping) electron microprobe analysis (EPMA) (for micro-textures and fine-scale elemental mapping); and electron backscatter diffraction (EBSD) (to study the microstructure and crystallographic orientations). In addition to this; satellite images of lunar impact craters will be used to map the distribution and properties of impact melt deposits on the Moon allowing for a comparative study of samples with remote sensing data.
Skills: Basic knowledge of igneous and metamorphic petrology; mineralogy and geochemistry; geographic information systems (GIS) and remote sensing. Previous laboratory experience in microscopy and geochemistry is considered an asset.

Name: Legal Constructions of Religion and Nonreligion
Description: This project examines the use of religion and nonreligion in Canada and in the other project sites (Australia; the Nordic countries [Sweden; Norway; Denmark; Finland]; the United States; the United Kingdom; and Latin America [Brazil and Argentina]); through the lens of public controversies. Examples of public controversies include sexual and reproductive rights; ‘conversion therapy’; state funding of religion in various formats (schools; tax subsidies; social service programmes); anti-discrimination and religious freedom laws; medically assisted dying; climate change and religious symbols in the public sphere. This project will allow us to understand the dynamics of social and political conflicts that organize the configuration of the public sphere in each country; and analyze the impacts of these articulations on the development of religious/moral regulations and public policies. The MITACS Globalink internship will provide an important learning opportunity for a student to participate in collaborative research between Lori Beaman (University of Ottawa); Paula Montero (University of Sao Paulo) and Juan Marco Vaggione (National University of Cordoba).
Skills: The skills and background required of a student would be experience in and enthusiasm for examining legal cases and in data collection; including using a variety of databases and local websites (each county; city and municipal region will store data in their own way). This position would enable the student to develop a range of skills; including data collection; research; writing; and organizational skills. They would also have the opportunity to strengthen their multi-tasking and time-management abilities in a highly professional workplace. Although team members will be actively engaged in supervising the student; they should be capable of working independently.

Name: Death and Dying: Changing Policies
Description: Practices and Laws
Faculty supervisor: Religion has been an important force in shaping understandings of the meaning of death; narratives and practices around dying; and legal approaches to issues such as assisted dying. The shift from religious affiliation to nonreligion (including atheism; agnosticism; humanism; the spiritual but not religious and indifference) has potential impact on palliative care; organ donation; medically assisted dying; obituaries and funeral rituals as well as memorials (including ghost bikes); among other things. Moreover; the Covid-19 pandemic has exposed fissures around life; death; and dying. Religion has often been used to make meaning of death. How are life and death conceptualized in nonreligious ways? This series of projects aims to examine changing social practices related to these areas: Palliative care; Death cafes; Medically Assisted Dying; Obituaries/Funerals; and National narratives of dying. The MITACS Globalink internship will provide an important learning opportunity for a student to participate in collaborative research with Lori Beaman; (University of Ottawa).
Student academic background: The skills and background required of a student would be experience in and enthusiasm for data organization; textual; content and discourse analysis; visual arts analysis; website and blog analysis. This position would enable the student to develop a range of skills; including data collection; research; writing; and organizational skills. They would also have the opportunity to strengthen their multi-tasking and time-management abilities in a highly professional workplace. Although team members will be actively engaged in supervising the student; they should be capable of working independently.
column11: Religious Studies; Sociology

Name: Application of additive manufacturing for Nanomedicne production
Description: The journey of a nanoparticle in the human body can be very complex and often unpredictable. With the increasing number of potential applications of nanoformulations in the biomedical world (in sensing; imaging; drug delivery; vaccines) it has become clear that more knowledge about their interactions with living cells is necessary in order to predict their fate after administration. In this project; we propose to study the chemical and colloidal stability of nanoparticles in biological media and in vivo. Using 3D fabrication techniques; the student will design; fabricate and utilize a micromixing device capable of producing rapidely hundreds of different nanoparticle formulations. The library of formulation will be based on chemically distinct polymers already available in the lab. Once produced; formulations will be characterized for their physical chemical properties and capacity to enter targetted cells. The student will be trained on microfab techniques and in numerous techniques widely used in the nanomedicine field. The analysis of the results will be performed under the supervision of a doctoral researcher leading this research program.
Skills: Some necessary skills and academic background necessary: Experience in experimental science (lab work). Academic training in Physicochemistry (formulation; characterization of the nanoparticules); Physics (micormixing; data analysis); microfabrication (3D printing CAD design) is a plus.
Student academic background: Chemistry; ; Engg-Biomedical; Engg-Chemical; Engg-Materials; Engg-Mechanical; Engineering; Physics; Physics; Pharmacy

Name: Wait! What am I inhaling?! Toxic metals analysis in soil using ICP-MS
Description: Inductively Coupled Plasma - Mass Spectrometry (ICP-MS) will be utilized in order to study both toxic and essential metals in a variety of soil samples. A worst case risk assessment will be conducted using the concept of bio-accessibility in order to see what fraction of metals are leached out in each subsequent body fluid (ie. Saliva; Gastric Juice and Intestinal Juice). The value of this research is it can be applied to commonly consumed foods where little to no research may have been conducted before or little to no regulations have been put in place. Arsenic (As) is a toxic metal that is commonly found in the earths surface; in pesticides and thus can be introduced into our food system either naturally or through human involvement. Soil has the ability to hold metals (both toxic and essential) for decades and thus a farm that is currently treated as organic with no added pesticides could actually have contaminants from decades past. It is up to us to find ways to optimize analysis techniques; efficiency and sample type in order to maximize results obtained and ensure safety to human health.
Skills: This project will involve students to be creative in regards to sample selection and analysis strategies. In addition; an interest or experience in analytical chemistry will be a great asset. Although the study does involve biological concepts; that is not a requirement for students to have. Finally; a great deal of the work will require data analysis; processing and dissemination. Thus; there is value in having a strong comfort level with excel and strong communication skills. Whatever level you arrive with; the goal is to enhance it and send you home a stronger analytical chemist!

Name: Catalysts for cyclic carbonate production
Description: In this project we develop heterogenous catalyst for the reaction of epoxides with CO2 which produces cyclic carbonates. In an other project we work on the production of a variety of epoxides and diepoxides from different molecules of vegetable origin. The cyclic carbonates generated out of these materials are potentially monomers for different polymers including polycarbonates and polyurethanes. The outcome of this project will therefore be a series of new polymers entirely generated out of biomass and CO2.
Skills: The student should be working toward a BSc in Chemical Engineering; in Chemistry or the equivalent.

Name: Polymers for biomedical applications
Description: The project involves the synthesis and characterization of a wide range of custom made polymers mainly for applications in the biomedical fields. More specifically; we are interested in the development of new materials for (1) therapeutics nano-delivery systems; (2) for tissue engineering and (3) for cryopreservation of cells. Experience in chemistry; chemical engineering; polymer science and engineering or biomaterials is an asset.
Skills: Some background on organic; polymer or biochemistry will be useful.

Name: Biochemical investigations of the delivery system for improving safety and efficacy of therapeutic RNA delivery
Description: RNA-based drugs represent a paradigm shift in the treatment and prevention of critical diseases of global significance like viral infections and cancer. A major hurdle in RNA therapy is drug delivery to the correct intracellular location; which requires a delivery system. Cationic lipid nanoparticles (LNPs) represent the most clinically advanced delivery system. Despite recent success; a major impediment for the usage of lipid-based delivery systems for RNA delivery is their safety; e.g.; COVID-19 mRNA-LNP vaccines are associated with systemic side effects like inflammation and myocarditis. Gaps in our understanding of causes and mechanisms of this undesired inflammation and immune activation calls for new fundamental insights to guide rational NP-design. The intracellular sensing of RNA by pattern recognition receptors (PRRs) is well understood. However; the innate sensing of the RNA delivery system by the immune cells is poorly understood. We hypothesize that cellular sensing of RNA delivery systems by PRRs is dependent on the specific molecular features of the lipid molecules (e.g.; chain length; saturation); which can be modulated by controlling the packing of lipid molecules within the NP structure. We will formulate nanoparticles with different lipid packing arrangements and evaluate their nanostructure and innate immune activation.
Skills: 1. Educational background in pharmacy; biochemistry; nanotechnology; or biomedical engineering. 2. Evidence of academic excellence. 3. Effective organizational; time management skills; and prioritization skills as well as effective verbal and written communication skills are required. 4. Motivation to perform laboratory-based research.

Name: Biopolymer-Graphene Oxide Hydrogel Beads for Removal of Legacy and Emerging Contaminants from Water
Description: In this project; we will use graphene oxide (GO); a novel carbon-based 2D nanomaterial for developing 3D porous macrostructures such as sponges and beads for removal of various contaminants from water. Our lab is a pioneer in developing high performance GO-based filters for removal of a suite of legacy (dyes; heavy metals and bacteria) and emerging contaminants (hormones; pharmaceuticals and microplastics) from water. Our goal is to develop a point-of-use (POU) modular device to remove a multitude of legacy and emerging contaminants from water. Our strategy is to develop porous biopolymer beads (such as alginate and chitosan) reinforced with GO and other nanomaterials; and to pack them in glass columns to develop flow-through modules for treatment of complex matrix waters containing multiple contaminants. The science behind the processing of the nanocomposite beads has been developed by two of my graduate students in the past 2 years; and the undergraduate trainee will focus on developing the flow-though water treatment device and conducting water treatment tests. The modular POU devices will be especially useful for remote areas where access to centralized water treatment facilities are limited; such as Canadian Northern communities; as well as the various communities in the Global South.
Skills: 1. Basic chemistry lab training (wet lab) at undergaduate level including safe handling of chemicals such as acids and bases; and basic hands-on lab experience. 2. Basic science and/or engineering research skills such as finding journal articles in scholarly databses; academic literature survey techniques (reading; understanding; and summarizing academic papers) 3. Sufficent communication skills in English at advanced intermediate level and above (B2 level and above in Common European Framework of Reference for Languages)

Name: Mathematics of Scientific Machine Learning
Description: The overarching aim of the wider research programme is to develop machine-learning methods for coarse-graining physical laws; for example the laws of interaction between atoms and electrons. Mathematically speaking; this work builds on numerical analysis; approximation theory; inverse problems; statistics and representation theory; as opposed to traditional "ad hoc" modelling. A paradigm example are interatomic potentials and force fields: while traditionally thought of as ad hoc mechanistic models; there is now a major push towards a new generation based on machine-learning methodology with the aim to match them to high fidelity quantum chemistry models to within very high precision. The underlying electronic structure is "coarse-grained" leaving only mechanical response to describe. The general ideas and much of the fundamental methodology apply to a wide range of scenarios. Other topics of current interest include: solving the electronic Schrödinger equation; learning coarse-grained electronic structure models; or coarse-grained dynamical systems. This project will focus on theoretical understanding of ML methods in this general context. The work can be either purely analytical; purely algorithmic or anything in-between. The concrete direction can be decided with the student. Possible directions include but are not limited to: - Develop robust uncertainties: If a computed property comes with an error estimate (uncertainty) attached then this can provide confidence in a simulation. During model development; such error estimates can be used to improve the representation; training set generation or for model refinement. - Universality (completeness) of ML architectures: Which parameters must be converged? Can we provide rates of convergence? - Analysis of extrapolation capabilities: in scientific ML; predictions must often be made on inputs that are very different from the training dataset. We try to explain why this is usually not genuine extrapolation (i.e.; not "out-of-distribution").
Skills: BACKGROUND: The student will have a strong background in one of - computational statistics; baysian statistics; uncertainty quantification - numerical analysis; scientific computing; inverse problems - machine-learning MOTIVATION: The student should be motivated - to contribute to interdisciplinary research project and be open to engage in cross-disciplinary collaborations. - and have the confidence to drive the direction of the research (with help and close guidance by the advisor) CODE DEVELOPMENT: - Some programming experience is essential. The advisor and research group will help the student in contributing to our existing code base if and as needed.

Name: Machine Learning Force Fields for The Dark Matter of the Protein Universe
Description: Machine-learned force fields (MLFFs) for molecular dynamics simulation promise quantum chemistry accuracy at vastly reduced computational cost. This has the potential to revolutionize biochemical research and discovery; including for example rational drug design and synthetic biology. The main barrier to fulfilling this promise is the limit in time-scale that can be reached with the approaches available for the foreseeable future. To overcome this; we propose to exploit MLFF model hierarchies to develop parallel-in-time simulation algorithms that will be capable of accelerating the sampling of non-equilibrium trajectories by a factor 10-100. This will enable ab initio accuracy molecular dynamics simulation on biological time-scales. Our long term aim is the simulation of biological systems with ab initio accuracy on biological time-scales. The application of particular interest to our collaboration is the computational modelling of intrinsically disordered proteins; and their contributions to cellular regulations. A reliable and efficient “virtual laboratory” to study these proteins has the potential to create step-changes in rational drug design and synthetic biology. The first ingredient we require is a highly accurate machine-learned force field (MLFF). The computational cost of such MLFFs will prevent us from reaching biological timescales in the foreseeable future; and we require new methods to accelerate time-integration. Specifically; we propose to develop a "coarse-grained" MLFF that is capable of much faster but less accurate exploration of dynamical properties; which can subsequently be refined using a high-accuracy force-field.
Skills: The ideal student will fall within one of two categories: either (1) with a strong computational mathematics background (e.g.;numerical analysis; scientific computing; machine learning; computational statistics; statistical mechanics) with some exposure and a strong motivation to get involved in modelling of complex physical processes. or (2) have a background in a quantitative science (e.g. physics; bio-physics; bio-chemistry; ...); with focus on theory; modelling and computational aspects. Either student must be ready to work with collaborators from other disciplines. A strong background in either Python or Julia is desirable.

Name: Derive Stress-Strain Curves of GTA Soils from Soil Physical Indices
Description: This research will characterize the stress-strain curve of glacial deposits obtained during the pressuremeter test (PMT) and derive it from basic soil parameters. The overburden soils covering the Greater Toronto Area (GTA) are deposits formed mainly through glacial actions with the characteristics of highly variable material properties and complex non-linear stress-strain characteristics (Baker et al.; 1998). Among many testing methods; the PMT has become one of the most reliable in-situ testing techniques for glacial deposits. The basic idea of PMT is to conduct a cavity expansion experiment inside the soil and derive the soil parameters from the stress-strain curve during the expansion of the probe. The PMT has been used to derive various geotechnical parameters for the design of foundations and underground structures (Baguelin et al.; 1978; Briaud; 2013). Recently; a total of over 400 PMT tests were collected from a local transit project in Toronto; which provides an excellent opportunity to characterize the geotechnical properties of local soils. Evaluation and interpretation of geotechnical data is still a great challenge though it is crucial for any safe and economic infrastructure development. A high level of risk is built into many projects because of limited geotechnical investigation program due to budget and schedule restraints. This research is to study the characteristics of stress-strain curves of local soils and derive the stress-strain curves from basic tests without incurring expensive and time-consuming field tests; such as PMT. Research findings will be extremely valuable to the local geotechnical community and applicable for any infrastructure development in the GTA and Canada.
Skills: The ideal candidate should be a civil engineering undergraduate who has finished their second-year studies with related courses like statistics; probability; and soil mechanics.

Name: Systematically Review of Statistical Learning Methods for Big Data
Description: In this project; we target to build a complete guideline of the current methods and recommendations for their use for different data. The summer internship student will help to explore various methods; including regression models; tree-based methods; Random Forest; and SVM; etc.; and apply these methods to the benchmark data. Through validation studies; we will systematically evaluate and compare approaches based on comprehensive evaluation metrics and develop guidelines on using the methods with specific recommendations for big data.
Skills: The basic requirements for the project are four-fold: (1) have basic statistical knowledge; including probability and likelihood inference; (2) have experience in data management and analysis; (3) know how to use regression models; and (4) have working knowledge in R or Python. Priority will be given to students who have taken machine learning courses or have research experience with machine learning.

Name: Metabolic reprogramming in sarcoma
Description: Cancer cells rewire metabolic pathways and energy production to support the enhanced proliferation; invasion and resistance to treatment. The three main glucose metabolism pathways that support growth of cancer cells are: a) the glycolysis pathway for energy production; b) the pentose phosphate pathway for biomass production; and c) the hexosamine biosynthesis pathway (HBP) for protein glycosylation. Activation of HBP leads to altered glycosylation of oncogenes; transcription factors and kinases in many types of cancer. These aberrations contribute to increased proliferation and survival of tumor cells; and are associated with resistance to treatment. In this project; we study metabolic reprogramming through HBP in two types of sarcoma: leiomyosarcoma and desmoid tumors. Our study will explore the potential of therapeutic targeting of HBP and the functional consequences of the activation of HBP in sarcoma.
Skills: Experience in molecular biology techniques (e.g.; extraction of nucleic acids; polymerase chain reaction); histology; mass spectrometry; and/or cell culture experiments. Basic knowledge of statistical methods to analyze and summarize the results of experiments; and basic knowledge of software and databases for molecular biology.

Name: Ensemble Learning for Biomarker Identification
Description: Machine learning methods generally focus on prediction and ignore the association between predictors and outcome variables. For this summer project; I propose to build ensemble models that target accurate prediction and the ability to identify significant associations. This method is an extension of our current development on the bless algorithm. Students will be able to learn how to design ensemble models and evaluate their performance in these two aspects.
Skills: The basic requirements for the project are four-fold: (1) have basic statistical knowledge; including probability and likelihood inference; (2) have experience in data management and analysis; (3) know how to use regression models; and (4) have working knowledge in R or Python. Priority will be given to students who have taken machine learning courses or have research experience with machine learning.

Name: Machine Learning for Survival Outcome
Description: This project will be focused on the use of machine learning for survival data. Survival outcome records the time until an event of interest occurs; such as diagnosing a disease or mortality. Censoring is a common feature in which the time to the event cannot be completely observed. Traditional statistical methods for survival outcomes include the Cox model based on the proportional hazard (PH) and the Accelerated Failure Time model (AFT). Regularized Cox models (Lasso Cox; Elastic Net Cox) and ensemble learning (CoxBoost algorithm; Bagging Survival Trees and Random Survival Forest) are recently developed methods for high-dimensional data. We will apply those models to the real world large data with survival outcomes; compare model performance; and make reasonable interpretations.
Skills: The basic requirements for the project are four-fold: (1) have basic statistical knowledge; including probability and likelihood inference; (2) have experience in data management and analysis; (3) know how to use regression models; and (4) have working knowledge in R or Python. Priority will be given to students who have taken machine learning courses or have research experience with machine learning.

Name: Developing clinical practice guidelines relating to cognitive assessment in stroke and traumatic brain injury
Description: This research project aims to develop a best practice guideline for occupational therapists providing services to individuals post-stroke and brain injury. Currently; a few general best-practice guidelines are available; but none of them are specified for occupational therapies. Different assessment approaches and interventions should be provided depending on the disease stage; the disease severity; and the unit in which occupational therapists are providing their services to this population. Therefore; developing a best practice guideline for occupational therapists; whose role is to improve the level of independence of their clients; will fill this gap and support them in their decision-making. This project will consist of an extensive literature review for phase one and then conducting interviews with senior occupational therapists and educators in phase two. Finally; the information from the two phases will be combined to guide us in developing the best-practice guideline. Prospective students will engage in phase one of the study for most of their training; and if time allows they will be engaged in activities related to phase two of the study.
Skills: The successful candidate will have the following skills: 1- attention to detail 2- strong organizational skills 3- having experience with literature search and literature review is an asset 4- strong writing skill 5- good communication skills and fluent in English 6- having background information about neurological conditions is an asset

Name: Global Studies of Healthy Development and Wellbeing of Children and Youth
Description: Stage Nine
Faculty supervisor: Our research has five inter-related international human developmental foci. First; we examine cross-culturally; context and culture in Moral Development of children and youths' verbal deception and truth telling (Cameron; et al.; 2022). We have gathered data from youth in China and Canada]; and are now investigating the development of Truth and Trust in Canadian and Chinese children and Integrity in Western children. We have successfully completed Year 2 of a three-year cross-lag longitudinal study of the integrity of young children (Gill et al.; 2022). This summer we are launching Year 3. Our second research programme employs quasi-ecological methods for studying Thriving across the lifespan and around the globe. We have collected data in Thailand; Canada; Italy; the UK; Peru; Turkey; and USA with toddlers and their families; filming a "Day in their Lives" (Gillen & Cameron; 2015; Cameron & Stella; 2022) and resilient mobile adolescents in China; Thailand; South Africa; India; and Canada (Cameron; et al.; 2014). As well; we are filming "Days in the Lives" of preschool children in transition to school in Italy; Canada and Brazil (Cameron; et al.;2022); and older adults in Canada; Brazil and Switzerland; Cameron et al.; 2022). This is ‘cultural’ rather than ‘cross-cultural’ research: it seeks not to make generalizations from quantitative findings; but rather to understand the nature of wellbeing through in-depth qualitative analyses of individual cases; to create vivid pictures of thriving in varying contexts and cultures. This year; we have documented a "Day in the Life" of one Canadian toddler boy and one kindergarten girl. And we have just published a paper on psychosocial factors affecting adolescents’ adjustment in transition to university (Cameron et al.; 2023). Finally; we are examining gendered expectations of adolescent girls’ close female Friendships and boys’ intimate dating Relationships (Cameron; Luft; et al.; 2017; 2022; 2023).
Student academic background: Micas internships undergraduate students who have most successfully served in our lab if they have focussed their studies to courses and research in psychology and who have a plan to complete an honours degree in psychology because they intend to proceed to graduate studies in psychology. They are particularly successful if they enjoy applying attention to the kind of detailed required in social sciences. The enjoy working with children and families and have a genuine interest on young people. They work well collaboratively in teams but are also fine with working independently.
column11: Psychology

Name: Effet du changement climatique sur la dynamique du crabe des neiges dans le sud du golfe du Saint-Laurant
Description: La pêche au crabe des neiges dans le sud du golfe du Saint-Laurent est un atout économique important pour le Nouveau-Brunswick. La mise en place de règles de décision; visant à maintenir un taux d'exploitation optimal du stock de crabes; est cruciale pour une gestion durable de cette pêche. Afin de prendre des décisions éclairées; le développement d'outils d'aide à la décision fiables; basés sur des modèles mathématiques; est d’une importance capitale. Plusieurs aspects ont un impact sur la dynamique du crabe des neiges dont la mort naturelle et l’exploitation humaine. Cependant; un des facteurs le plus inquiétant est le réchauffement des eaux de mer dû au changement climatique. Le crabe des neiges est une espèce très sensible aux variations de température et un réchauffement de l'eau pourrait avoir un effet néfaste sur sa distribution spatiale; sa croissance; sa reproduction et ses relations trophiques. Ce réchauffement peut également entraîner l’apparition de prédateurs; la présence d'espèces exotiques envahissantes ainsi que l'introduction de maladies et de parasites représentant un risque à la santé et à la dynamique du crabe des neiges. Le but de ce projet; en partenariat avec le ministère des Pêches et des Océans (MPO); est d’étudier l’impact du réchauffement des eaux du golfe du Saint-Laurent sur la dynamique de la population des crabes. Je développerai un modèle; basé sur des techniques mathématiques et statistiques; qui tiendra compte de l’effet climatique. Ce modèle permettra une estimation de l'état actuel du stock du crabe des neiges; et une prédiction du stock futur (à moyen et long terme). Il fournira ainsi des descriptions qualitatives et quantitatives de cette pêche; dotera le MPO des avis et renseignements scientifiques de qualité; et permettra une prise de décision rigoureuse et fiable dans la gestion de cette pêche.
Skills: L'étudiante et l'étudiant intéressé(e) doivent avoir des connaissances aux: 1) équations différentielles; 2) notions de modélisation; 3) notions d'analyse numérique de base.

Name: Determining environmental determinants of multidrug resistance in Acinetobacter baumannii
Description: In this project; we plan to study the role of temperature in the multidrug resistance of Acinetobacter baumannii. Cells will be grown at incubation temperatures of 15 deg C and 37 deg C. RNA will be isolated and the expression of efflux pumps determined using qPCR. RNA-Sequencing will be carried out to determine the global impact of low incubation temperature on A. baumannii. Virulence of cells grown at different temperatures will be analyzed using the worm infection model. Preliminary data from our laboratory shows that perturbations in fatty acid synthesis impacts multidrug resistance of A. baumannii via the expression of efflux pumps. Also since low incubation temperature affects the membrane lipid profile; we are interested in learning if altered lipid profile of the cells grown under low incubation temperature affects the multidrug resistance of A. baumannii. This project will help understand the environmental triggers of multidrug resistance in A. baumannii. The findings from this work will inform efforts to design therapeutic options that target multidrug resistance in A. baumannii.
Skills: Basic microbiology skills (aseptic techniques; pipetting; plating etc) Basic knowledge of DNA; RNA extraction Background in molecular biology

Name: KL divergence in new Physics
Description: The detection of small deviations from usual quantum behavior is a common feature of various theories motivated by either quantum measurement or Planck scale corrections. The detection of such corrections is difficult as they are very small. So; even though it is essential to have some universal criteria to know which system is most suitable for a certain deviation; so such universal criteria has been ever proposed. Thus; we for the first time propose a method motivated from statistics to measure measure which system is better suited to measure such small deviations from the usual quantum behavior. We will use the Kullback–Leibler divergence between the modified and original probability distributions to know the distance between them. Even though the Kullback–Leibler divergence is not a statistical distance; it can provide important information about the seperation between two distributions. We thus propose that it would be easier to measure deviations from quantum mechanics for a system if it has a higher Kullback–Leibler divergence.
Skills: Wave functions for a system in Physics Kullback–Leibler divergence in Statistics Matlab/R/Python software Latex

Name: Inference based on Data depth
Description: High-dimensional data are encountered in many applications of statistics and most prominently in biological studies. A specific large dimension; small sample size situation arises when testing whether two sample sets are from the same distribution; motivated by identifying significant genes in genetic sequence studies. Consider two samples that come from two distributions; F and G; respectively. We consider testing the following hypothesis: F=G. Existing hypothesis testing methods based on the rank of one-dimensional samples for data; is not appropriate under the high-dimensional situation because it lacks a natural ranking. The concept of statistical depth allows us to generalize the ranking of data into multi-dimensional space. We will consider data depth-based methods for the homogeneity test.
Skills: Two sample comparison High-dimensional data analysis Matlab/R/Python software Latex

Name: Relevance analysis in high-dimensional samples
Description: For the task of relevance analysis; the conventional Tukey's test may be applied to the set of all pairwise comparisons.
