However; there were few studies that discuss both nonparametric k-sample comparisons and relevance analysis in high dimensions. Our aim is to capture the degree of relevance between combined samples and provide additional insights and advantages in high-dimensional k-sample comparisons. Our solution is to extend a graph-based two-sample comparison and investigate its availability for large and unequal sample sizes. We will consider some graph methods such as minimum spanning tree (MST); shortest Hamiltonian path (SHP); and maximal matching (MM). MST and SHP have been applied to sample comparison and change point detection. However; MM is very new and compelling in some cases. We will compare their performance.
Skills: Graph theory Two sample comparison High-dimensional data analysis Matlab/R/Python software Latex

Name: AI-powered web application using pre-trained language models and fine-tuning for real estate data
Description: The goal of this project is to help users to visualize; analyze; and extract useful information from publicly available real estate data to assist them to understand the market and make decisions. This research project involves collecting publicly available real estate data from various sources; visualizing data; fine-tuning pre-trained language models using collected real estate data; and building a chatbot and a user-friendly web platform/mobile app.
Skills: This project is suitable for students with two types of backgrounds: 1. the student is familiar with pre-trained language models; deep learning; data visualization and statistical analysis. 2. the student has skills or experience in extracting data from websites and creating web platforms or mobile apps for Android and iOS. The student needs to be familiar with front-end development using HTML/CSS; JavaScript; React; TypeScript; Python; or other programming languages.

Name: Approche Thermodynamique concernant la Réduction de la Consommation d'Énergie des Systèmes d'Air Comprimé et Amélioration de leur Performance.
Description: Most factories cannot do without electricity; water; natural gas; and of course compressed air. This compressed air is used for multiple applications such as pneumatic systems; refrigeration systems; heat pumps; and cleaning systems. The air is compressed using a compressor usually driven by an electric motor. Motor power varies from a few horsepower (Ch) to more than 10;000 Ch and its energy consumption is among the highest in electrical equipment. It is estimated that nearly 50% of the electrical energy consumed by compressors could be saved simply by respecting the rules of installation and maintenance of equipment. The annual cost of running compressors often exceeds their acquisition cost. For example; in a market where the electricity rate is $0.085/kWh; it costs $52;820 annually to run a 125 HP (93.21 kWmec) compressor powered by a motor for 6;000 hours. electricity with an efficiency of 90% (equivalent to 103.57 kWel). The objective of this research project is to study; from an energy and exergy point of view; the options for reducing the energy consumption of compressors in order to improve their performance in a practical environment. For the evaluation of the costs of compressed air systems and the potential for savings; the topics that will be covered in this research project are: - Sealing of air leaks in compressed air lines. - Use of efficient motors. - Admission of fresh outside air to the compressors. - Reduced compressed air pressure. - Heat recovery for heating.
Skills: The skills sought in the student: ▪ A good academic record. ▪ A good knowledge of Thermodynamics; Energy conversion; Thermal machines; Renewable energy systems; Heat transfer; and refrigeration systems. ▪ Engineering software: EES (Engineering Equation Solver); increased training will be given for this important engineering software for the project; Matlab; TRNSYS; (CFDs if possible) ▪ The ability to write high-quality scientific articles (newspaper articles); and one or two publications (newspaper; conferences; symposia; etc.) will be an asset.

Name: Modelling the Early Evolution of Dense Star Clusters
Description: Young dense star clusters are found throughout our Galaxy; and are a common mode of star formation. Studies estimate that between 50% and 100% of all stars were formed in such systems; including our own Sun. The transition between a star-free cloud of molecular gas to a gas-free star cluster; however; is poorly understood. We know that many dense clusters must disperse early in their life; as we only see a handful of massive dense clusters at older ages but a plethora of young systems. A recent survey of nearby star-forming clusters has recently created a complete stellar census down to stars much less massive than our Sun; including stellar positions; masses; and ages; as well as information about the nearby gas from which these stars have formed. It is clear from these data that our assumptions about the initial conditions for star cluster models are entirely too simplistic. Unlike most models; real clusters are not spherical; isolated; gas-free systems. Instead; they are elongated; clumpy; located in groups or along filaments of the molecular cloud; and start with a significant fraction of their mass in gas instead of stars. We would like to understand how these complex and messy systems evolve to populate the field of the galaxy with individual stars; or to form the mass old star clusters that also populate the galaxy. Using computer simulations; we model both the stellar and gaseous components of these systems; and their host galaxy environment; to elucidate and confirm their evolutionary histories.
Skills: Undergraduate courses in physics and mathematics: classical mechanics; thermodynamics; differential equations; linear algebra; statistics at the 3rd year undergraduate level. One course in astronomy and one course in fluid mechanics are recommended. Experience with computer programming; preferably in python. Experience with large-scale simulations and data analysis recommended.

Name: Narratives of emotional experience of Brazilian during the pandemic COVID-19
Description: This project refers to the data analysis phase of 93 interviews conducted in Summer 2021 with Brazilians living in Canada and Brazil aiming to explore their experiences of anxiety; loneliness and adopted strategies to promote emotional stability and wellbeing during the Covid-19 pandemic. Method: Qualitative data will be analyzed using thematic analysis method supported by the software Atlas ti. Data dissemination includes writing factsheets to be posted in social media (Facebook; Instagram; etc.) to help individuals to learn about successful coping and adaptation strategies used by resilient families and individuals to protect their emotional health and reduce unnecessary safety concerns. Knowledge translation plans include production of short summary in plain language to be disseminated by lay media; as well as the submission in scholarly manuscripts in Portuguese to a Brazilian peer-review journal; in English for an international immigrant health' journal; as well as interview in local radio and TV hosting multicultural programs. Scholarly abstracts will be submitted to scientific; national and international meetings.
Skills: Required personal skills include: excellent reading and verbal communication skills in English and Portuguese; creativity; inquisitiveness; independent; autonomy; and excellent organizational skills. Skills and experiences in designing messages to social media; as well as experiential knowledge of qualitative research methods is an asset. The ideal candidate has completed a research method; and a psychology or mental health course. Advanced level of computer literacy is required.

Name: Innovation in community health literacy by Brazilian nurses' practice during the COVID-19 pandemic
Description: The project is an educational evaluation research after the delivery of a course implemented in January 2020 in 3 Brazilian federal universities with 63 participants. The project's first objective is to document the social impacts of the knowledge gained from a professional development course for nurses on individual health literacy (IHL) and community health literacy (CHL); which could influence changes; innovations and accomplishments in practice during the pandemic. The second objective is to respond to the following research questions: (a) Which experiences indicate that the course influenced the attitudes and practices of nurses?; (b) Which actions/projects on IHL/CHL indicate innovation and creativity in the practice of nurses?; (c) How has the implementation of IHL/CHL projects been successful and/or unsuccessful; and which are in the process of consolidation and/or are likely to happen? The project design is inspired by the theoretical perspective of Appreciate Inquiry (AI); which assembles methodological principles of action research; organizational learning and organizational change. AI focuses on a collective vision and action to generate knowledge or ideas within social systems and promote the use of knowledge and dialogue to achieve congruence between values and practices. AI unfolds with the 4D cycle: Discovery; Dream; Design; and Destiny ; (a) Discovery: appreciating the best of what is; (b) Dream: imagining what might be; (c) Design: co-constructing the ideal condition; and (d) Destiny: sustaining of life is acknowledged to empower; learn or improvise. AI can posit the inquiry in a strength-based perspective by “holding myriad potential benefits for individuals; communities; and macro systems to build resilience and promote growth during and after COVID-19".
Skills: The student should be a Brazilian senior undergraduate nursing student with a record of a successful clinical placement in the area of community health nursing; primary health care and/or nursing/health services management mostly developed in the health facilities belonging to the National Unified Health System (SUS). The student should be bilingual (Portuguese-English); demonstrate previous experience or training in a curricular; extracurricular or volunteer research-related activities. The student should be able to work under direct and indirect supervision; demonstrate superior time management skills; autonomy and independence in work-related context. Interpersonal and team playing skills are required.

Name: Exploring non-genetic sources of phenotypic heterogeneity
Description: Genetically identical cells grown in the same environment often differ in their cellular morphology; growth characteristics; behavior; and fate. This phenomenon is known as phenotypic heterogeneity; and it can be an advantageous or an undesirable feature of biological systems. It can; for example; help cell populations adapt to new and varying external conditions or; on the other hand; lead to development of resistance to drug treatment. Numerous mechanisms can give rise to heterogeneity; however; the influence of different combinations of non-genetic factors on phenotype development in genetically identical individuals remains largely unexplored. Our key objective is to advance our understanding of the mechanisms of phenotypic heterogeneity; and of the interplay between genotype; the environment; and cell physiology in shaping a cell's behaviour. High-content screening (HCS); that combines high-throughput microscopy with quantitative multi-parametric image analysis; provides rich information about the properties of biological systems at the single cell level; and is thus ideally suited to study phenotypic heterogeneity. We have used HCS to image subcellular phenotype and cell state markers for > 25 million cells from a large number of mutant budding yeast strains grown in different environments. With machine learning-based image analysis we are extracting phenoptype and cell state information for each single cell; and penetrance information (fraction of abnormal looking cells) for each imaged cell population. The proposed research project aims to: a) mine this dataset and explore phenotype dependence on genotype; environment and cell state; b) use the extracted information to formulate and test hypotheses on the role of non-genetic sources in phenotypic heterogeneity.
Skills: Solid understanding of undergraduate level genetics; cell biology; molecular biology is a must. Lab experience in molecular biology; cell biology; microbiology is a plus. Basic understanding and/or experience with bioinformatics and computational biology is a plus.

Name: Cognitive Cloud-edge Continuum Orchestration System
Description: The evergrowing resource requirements of modern-day applications concerning guaranteed low latency and the massive data transfer rate constantly push the boundaries of technologies and require a paradigm shift. To cater to these escalating resource needs; modern IT computing platforms have evolved beyond the more traditional central cloud with bleeding edge processing powers and high-capacity networking infrastructure to extend their coverage to the network edge. This creates a new paradigm called cloud edge computing continuum (CECC); whereby the services span from core cloud to edge. The services that require a high data rate or low latency should be shifted toward the edge closer to end users and data producers (sensors; smartphones; etc.). To efficiently manage and continuously optimize resources through this new model using the CECC approach; we propose a cognitive cloud edge continuum orchestration system (C3OS). This framework will play a critical role in providing scalability; agility; effectiveness; and dynamicity in service delivery over the CECC infrastructure. C3OS will offer a common federated platform that manages data sources; CECC resources; and application behavior in a unified and harmonized manner to ensure the desired service level agreement (SLA). C3OS will leverage artificial intelligence (AI); machine learning; and mathematical optimization techniques to provide an efficient life cycle management system of services and CECC resources for ensuring low response time and high data rate. This project will empower C3OS with sufficient proactive mechanisms; tools; and Algorithms for orchestrating CECC resources (computation; memory; storage; and networking) in an efficient and timely manner to meet the desired SLA with the lowest cost.
Skills: The students should have a strong background in software coding. It will be great if he has some background on artificial intelligence and networking.

Name: Defining and targeting drug toxicity pathways in vitro
Description: Cisplatin is a highly effective chemotherapeutic widely used to treat solid tumours in children. Unfortunately; over half of treated children develop treatment-related toxicities. Ototoxicity is a frequent adverse drug reaction to cisplatin treatment that causes permanent hearing loss in both ears. This can have a significant impact on speech and language development in children; as well as a prolonged socio-economic impact. This research project will study cisplatin toxicity using in vitro models. Cellular responses to cisplatin treatment will be characterized in cultured ear cell lines. These responses will be used as reporters of cisplatin-signaling. Drug-gene interactions; e.g. transcriptomic changes induced by cisplatin treatment; will be used to identify genes and pathways required for cisplatin signaling that may contribute to the development of ototoxicity. Signaling components identified through these analyses will be validated by gene silencing and tested in the cisplatin response assays characterized above. Genes critical to cisplatin signaling will be examined as candidates for the development of protectant therapies that prevent the development of ototoxicity. Existing small molecules targeting these candidate genes will be leveraged in this regard. Otoprotective agents are in demand given the high rates of ototoxicity in cisplatin-treated patients but currently none are approved for clinical use. Otoprotectants identified through this research project would be fit for preclinical animal studies of cisplatin-induced ototoxicity and would serve as a proof-of-principle for this research program.
Skills: The student should have a background in biological sciences and be familiar with molecular biology and biochemical concepts. Experience with tissue culture and cell-based assays would be an asset. The student must be able to effectively communicate and must be well-organized. The student should be comfortable with; and have the ability to; work largely independently after initial training. A high degree of critical thinking skills is expected.

Name: Analyzing the effect of insecure Single-Sign-On Delegation on Users
Description: Delegation of services and/or operations is a common Internet practice. Examples include the delegation of user authentication (e.g.; Single-Sign-On; SSO); delegation of server authentication (e.g.; using Certificate Authorities; CAs); zone delegation in Domain Name System (DNS); and delegation of Content Distribution Networks (CDNs). Our research group is currently analyzing the security of various delegation mechanisms over the Internet. SSO is one example; where a content provider (Relying Party; RP) delegates authentication procedures to an Identity Provider (IDp). Simultaneously; users delegate an IDp to endorse them and their identities to the RP. Analogous to other Internet-based delegation practices; SSO suffers from multiple security weaknesses; including the lack of formal user-delegation to the IDp; and the lack of proper communication of RP-to-IDp delegation intent. This results in an IDp's ability to impersonate users to the RP; and an RP's ability to phish a user's IDp credentials. In this specific project; we will analyze users' mental models of such delegation process; and their awareness of security risks; such as an IDps' ability to impersonate users to RPs and RPs' ability to phish users' IDp credentials. These findings will inform further projects to improve the security of SSO and ultimately other delegation practices over the Internet.
Skills: Programming skills; data analysis; some basic stats; and networking knowledge.

Name: 'Cannamoms': exploring social media descriptions of cannabis use among mothers
Description: Mommy wine culture; or the acceptance and celebration of using alcohol to cope with parenting struggles; exploded on social media in the early 2010’s. More recently; a similar movement to gain acceptance for cannabis use among mothers seems to be gaining traction with bloggers titled; ‘Marijuana Mommy’; ‘Weed Mama’; and ‘Cannamoms’. We seek to explore the content of these blogs and social media posts from similar groups to understand 1) how is cannabis use framed? And 2) how is motherhood represented? The urgency of this exploration in a Canadian context was recently enhanced through legalization of cannabis in 2018; followed by legalization of edibles in 2019. The Mitacs Globalink student will develop a search strategy to identify social media content for inclusion and begin preliminary qualitative; thematic content analysis. They will receive training in qualitative data analysis and the use of NVivo software.
Skills: Strong English language skills (reading); organizational skills; time management; independent worker; and computer skills

Name: Learning Discrete Dynamical Systems
Description: A discrete dynamical system is a graph in which each node can assume a value in a pre-defined range of values. In a series of discrete time steps; the value of each node changes; how it changes is determined by a function that considers as input the value of all neighbouring nodes. In other words; the values of the nodes in the neighbourhood of node v determine the next value of node v. In this project; we will assume that a learning algorithm observes partial information on the changes of the values of (some of the) nodes in the graph. The goal of the learning algorithm is to fully determine the discrete dynamical system based on such information. In particular; we are interested in finding efficient learning algorithms for reaching this goal. Applications of this research include social network analysis (e.g.; analysis of the spread of disinformation or misinformation in a social network).
Skills: Familiarity with basic concepts of graph theory; possibly also boolean functions. Ability to understand formal theorems and proofs. Basic knowledge of discrete computational structures.

Name: Closed-Control Loop based Service Management Controllers for Teclo-Cloud Computing Sytems
Description: This project will design and implement several AI-based resource and service management closed-control loop controllers for cloud computing systems hosting network services (Telco clouds). The designed controllers will target to minimize the resource contention and failures to increase the availability and optimize the performance of the network services.
Skills: A student must have a background in computer science; computer engineering; software engineering or information technology. Following technical skills will be required to meet the objectives of this research project: 1. Programming (Java; Python; Matlab are preferable) 2. Machine Learning and Methods 3. Knowledge about optimization methods Besides the technical skills; student must have a good problem solving and analytical skills. The student should have a good command on English (reading; writing and speaking) and interpersonal and time management skills.

Name: Galaxy evolution with cosmological simulations
Description: Cosmological simulations aim to produce a mock universe; where galaxies are simulated from their origins as the first stellar populations; evolving over billions of years into the complex galaxy population observed today. They are therefore a useful tool for astronomers seeking to study the transformation and evolution of galaxies over cosmic time. Our group works with several large cosmological simulations that are a treasure trove of data for a student to study various aspects of simulated galaxy evolution. Several possible projects exist depending on student interest and the status of the group's research at the time of the internship. Example projects include: analysing the resolved star formation rate; gas content; or metallicity of interacting or recently merged galaxies.
Skills: All projects will focus on coding; interfacing with the simulation outputs in order to study galactic properties. The ideal candidate will be in a physics or computer science discipline; with an interest in astronomy. They must be proficient in using python for data analysis. Experience working in a remote linux environment is not required but is an asset. Excellent oral communication skills essential.

Name: Predictors of Alcohol Consequences in Transgender Adults
Description: This study will use a mixed methods design in order to refine and test a clinically-informative model to explain alcohol use and harms experienced by transgender people. Specifically; we will use ecological momentary assessment (EMA); involving completing brief surveys on their phones in their day-to-day lives; with 100 transgender adults who drink. The surveys will ask questions about experiences leading up to times that they drink (such as victimization; discrimination); experiences while they drink (such as mood and drug effects); and experiences after they drink (such as harms; like a hangover; missing work; having a fight). At the conclusion of their participation; qualitative interviews will be used to further contextualize the provided EMA responses. Using the quantitative and qualitative data; we will consider how some factors may increase risk for drinking and harms (like stress related to being a minority in society) and protect transgender individuals from drinking when experiencing minority stress (such as social and community support). These findings will improve our understanding of the health risks and contributors of alcohol use among transgender adults; which can help us develop gender-inclusive public health policies and interventions to prevent alcohol-related harms.
Skills: Ideal candidates will have taken psychology courses as part of a psychology minor or major; and have successfully completed their program's required research methods/statistics course(s). Ideal candidates have an interest in conducting research focused on transgender health and well-being. It is preferred that candidates have prior experience with research; either as part of their coursework; honours thesis; or other paid or unpaid positions.

Name: Super-resolution Imaging in High Dimensions
Description: Given a pixelized and blurry image taken by an optical device; such as a telescope or a microscope; super-resolution imaging aims to deblur the image and increase the resolution. Every imaging device has a corresponding point-spread function; which convolves the true image when the image is observed through the imaging device. We will assume that the point-spread function is known. This project is concerned with proposing an optimization program whose optimum solves the super-resolution imaging problem. More precisely; we will propose an optimization program; and we will show that its optimum is the true image provided that the true image is sparse. This problem has been solved in the case when the point-spread function factorizes into a product of functions; one for each dimension. Our aim will be to extend this theory; and; first; solve the problem when there exists an orthogonal transformation such that the point-spread function factorizes after the transformation is applied to its coordinates. This will generalize many known point-spread functions. If successful; we will aim to extend our theory to a larger family of point-spread functions.
Skills: This is a theoretical mathematics project; which will require mainly strong mathematical maturity as well as expertise in linear algebra and analysis. In addition; it may be necessary to test our theory computationally; therefore; familiarity with a programming language such as Python; Julia; or R will be useful.

Name: Enhancing Transparent Machine Learning Predictive Models through an Automated Feature Engineering Module
Description: The use of data-driven models in decision-making is increasing due to advancements in data collection and machine learning; particularly deep learning. However; these models cannot explain their decisions; posing challenges to ensuring their trustworthiness in decision-making processes. One approach to address this issue is using transparent machine learning models; which offer explainable predictions. The problem with transparent models is that their predictive accuracy is usually lower than deep learning models. This can make them less attractive for data-driven systems; where high accuracy is often a top priority. One way to improve the predictive performance of transparent models is to include a feature engineering module that can craft features to build models with high accuracy and interpretability. However; this process requires domain knowledge and may not always be included in the design of transparent models. Therefore; there is a need to investigate new methods for automatically generating optimal feature sets. In this Globalink Research project; the intern will support the development of an automatic feature engineering module using multi-objective evolutionary algorithms to derive an optimal feature set to build transparent machine learning. Specifically; the intern will work on the following specific objective: O1. Develop an automatic feature engineering module using multi-objective evolutionary algorithms to derive an optimal feature set for performing supervised machine learning. This module can be a preprocessing step for interpretable machine learning (e.g.; logistic regression; decision trees; and fuzzy modeling) to improve their predictive performance. The intern will help to implement comparison scenarios to test the feature engineering module with various transparent machine-learning models applied to different data sets Building more explainable models is beneficial because we are subject to data-driven models that affect our lives; such as in loan applications.
Skills: Python Machine learning Analytical skills

Name: Common Ground: Connecting Communities & Politics
Description: Political communities are fracturing in today’s “culture wars”. Progressives and conservatives are worlds apart in their politics. They support different political parties; gather in different corners of the internet; receive political news from different sources; and live increasingly separate personal lives. These divisions are even affecting public health; as people on the left and right disagree over mask-wearing and global warming. In short; the political common ground appears to be shrinking in Western societies. What about Canada? Led by political scientist Jared Wesley; a group of researchers from the University of Alberta is treating Western Canadian provinces as case studies in an intriguing new approach to studying the culture war. Instead of poring over survey results – which routinely fail to register the sort of group dynamics seen in places like the US and UK – Wesley and his team are meeting face-to-face with Canadians in over a dozen communities. Through innovative ethnographic activities; the researchers are learning what unites and divides our communities. Since 2019; the Common Ground initiative has engaged with over 3000 Canadians through a series of surveys; focus groups; and coffeehouse meetings. While hard to see in social media echo-chambers; politicians’ rhetoric; or news stories that emphasize extremism; conflict; and division; their findings reveal Western Canadians share a lot of common ground within their provinces and with the rest of Canada. Departing from the conventional view; their research shows that Western Canadian political culture is only moderately conservative when it comes to the role of government in society; the economy; and the environment.
Skills: Our team is seeking social science students with an interest and background in the study of populism and conservatism in Western democracies. Skills and experience in empirical research design; ethnography; qualitative analysis; quantitative analysis; and/or focus group facilitation are assets. Students from the United States and the United Kingdom; or students with a knowledge of the culture of Trumpism and Brexit; are encouraged to apply. So; too; are students with a knowledge of the rise of resentment between conservatives and progressives in other countries.

Name: Modeling the impact of cristae on diffusion inside mitochondria
Description: This project aims to understand how cristae structures inside mitochondria impact diffusion in distinct regions of the mitochondrial interior. This work will describe the degree to which the ATP synthesis inside cristae structures is independent of other cristae and how cristae can affect diffusion along the mitochondrial axis. Mitochondria have two membranes; one inside the other; known as the outer membrane and inner membrane. While the outer membrane is approximately bean- or tube-shaped; the inner membrane folds into tubular structures that project into the centre of the mitochondria; known as cristae. This project develop simulations and calculations to explore how cristae structures impede the rate of diffusion of molecules in the mitochondrial matrix (inside both membranes) and of molecules between the membranes; including those inside the cristae. Evaluation of the impact of cristae on diffusion in the mitochondrial matrix will build on an existing Brownian dynamics algorithm for simulating diffusion inside a tube with obstacles. The specific outcome for this investigation of diffusion in the mitochondrial matrix will be a relationship between number and size of cristae to a decrease in diffusion. Evaluation of diffusion between the mitochondrial membranes will combine consideration of diffusion within and between cristae. Within cristae; diffusive escape will build on established narrow-escape problem solutions; while between cristae the confined volume will be considered as effectively two-dimensional. The specific outcome for this investigation of diffusion between the two mitochondrial membranes will be to assess the independence of concentrations between cristae.
Skills: The student should have an academic background in physics; including math courses. The student should also have some computer programming/coding knowledge; either from courses or from personal experience; and enjoy computer programming/coding. Student enthusiasm for and interest in biology is important; and although biology experience (e.g.; from courses) can be helpful; it is not necessary for project success.

Name: Computer-Aided Convex Analysis
Description: The project aims at extending a numerical library to more easily manipulate convex and nonconvex functions of two variables. The resulting toolbox aims at computing and visualizing convex operators thereby facilitating computer-aided convex analysis. The goal is to implement new hybrid symbolic-numeric algorithms to manipulate operators (a generalization of derivatives); to validate the algorithms numerically; and to develop a user-friendly visualization method for data in 4D.
Skills: An interest in mathematics; good programming skills; and good oral communication skills are all that is required. Most of the development will be performed in MATLAB or Julia like mathematical software. Some programming familiarity with C will be helpful but is not required. Similarly; some knowledge of software engineering and/or Human-Computer Interaction will be helpful but can be taught at the beginning of the project. Mathematical concepts and ideas in convex analysis; complexity; and numerical analysis are elementary and at the level of a third year undergraduate student.

Name: Nanostructured thin film devices
Description: Nanoparticles will be used in this research project to create nanostructured thin film devices. The resulting nanostructured films will be characterized and studied with an eye towards developing potential applications including electronics; memory devices; sensors; clean energy; and superhydrophobic/philic surfaces. Semiconductor and other nanoparticles will be produced using solution-based methods and studied via microscopy. The nanoparticles will then be incorporated into different thin film coatings and device structures and their properties examined as part of the project.
Skills: Experimental skills are an asset. Some experience with materials processing (solution-based; chemical); electronic characterization (current-voltage measurements) and optical characterization will be beneficial. General computing skills.
Student academic background: Chemistry; Engg-Chemical; Engg-Electrical; Engg-Materials; Engineering; Physics; Engg-Mechanical; Engg-Metallurgical; Engg-Ceramic; Engg-Biomedical; Electronic Systems

Name: Molecular Simulations Exploring the Stability and Mobility of Bulk Aqueous Nanobubbles
Description: Bulk aqueous nanobubbles; gas-filled bubbles in water with typical diameters of ~100 nm; have only recently come under scientific investigation. While several features of nanobubbles are consistently reported; most notably their unexpected stability over long periods of time; there remains considerable uncertainty and debate regarding their nature. The focus of this work will be to investigate important questions about nanobubble behaviour; namely to identify the molecular origins for their unexpected stability. Molecular simulations will be performed to probe the molecular origins of the stability and mobility of bulk nanobubbles and to test theoretical models we have been recently developing. The key questions to be addressed include: 1) can forces arising from surface polarization that counter the Laplace pressure contribution be demonstrated by molecular simulations; 2) can molecular simulations confirm mobility of uncharged nanobubbles in electric fields. Large-scale MD simulations of empty nanobubbles of sizes ranging from 5 to 15 nm in systems up to ~5x105 molecules will be examined. The structure at the water surface; e.g. density profiles and dipole and quadrupole distributions; will be measured and results for different nanobubble sizes compared. Results will also be obtained for nonpolar (e.g. cyclopentane) and simple polar (e.g. CH3CN) liquids; since most experiments have focused on bulk nanobubbles in water. It has been conjectured that nanobubbles do not possess permanent charge and that their mobility is analogous to di-electrophoresis. To test this; extensive simulations will also be performed to measure responses; both mobility and any changes in surface structure; of nanobubbles to small applied electric fields. This work will provide key molecular-level insights into this fascinating phenomenon; thereby helping to guide new experiments and allowing us to predict in which liquids nanobubbles might be stable; while also yielding new fundamental understanding of some unique aspects of aqueous systems.
Skills: The student is expected to have the following skills/background: - A strong background in Chemistry (or related fields); particularly physical chemistry (2nd year University level). - Basic computer skills are a requirement; and experience with scientific computing and visualization (in a Linux environment) would be an asset. - Good foundation in mathematics (1st year university level). - Willingness to learn and a keen interest in the molecular world.
Student academic background: Chemistry; Engg-Chemical; Engg-Enviromental; Engg-Materials; Engg-Mechanical; Physics

Name: Thermal Image-based Fall Detection
Description: This research project aims to advance the field of fall detection using thermal image processing and deep learning. Falls are a significant concern; especially for the elderly population; as falls can result in severe injuries or even fatalities. Detecting falls promptly is crucial for providing timely assistance and medical intervention. Thermal imaging has emerged as a promising technology for fall detection due to its ability to capture body heat patterns and operate in low-light conditions; whilst maintaining the anonymity of the elderly individual. However; accurately identifying falls in thermal images remains challenging due to limitations; like low resolution and the absence of color information. To address these challenges; this research project will investigate an ensemble approach with a combination of Autoencoder (AE) and 3-D Convolutional Neural Networks (3D-CNN). In this case; autoencoders are semi-supervised learning models that learn to reconstruct their input; while 3D-CNN models excel at capturing spatiotemporal features from video-like data. By leveraging the strengths of both supervised and semi-supervised learning methodologies; the ensemble aims to enhance fall detection performance. To improve the quality of each component; the project will further investigate additional parameters; various baselines in ensemble learning; and transfer learning techniques. By expanding the architectural complexity and capacity of the models; the project aims to capture more nuanced patterns and features relevant to fall detection. Moreover; transfer learning enables the utilization of pre-trained models from related domains or tasks; which can provide valuable initializations and enhance the learning process. By pushing the boundaries of fall detection; this project aims to contribute to the development of effective and robust fall detection systems. The outcomes of this research project will have practical implications for healthcare systems; as accurate and timely fall detection can improve the well-being and safety of individuals; especially those vulnerable to fall-related injuries.
Skills: Ideal applicants are required to have a strong background in computer vision; deep learning; and image processing. Experience in programming languages; such as Python; along with deep learning frameworks; like Keras; TensorFlow; or PyTorch; is essential. Familiarity with Autoencoders; Convolutional Neural Networks; and transfer learning techniques are desired. In general; the candidates are expected to have strong analytical and problem-solving skills; as well as the ability to plan their tasks; conduct experiments; analyze results; organize their findings; and draw meaningful conclusions are also essential for the success of this research project.

Name: Non-Equilibrium Molecular Dynamics Simulations of the Growth of KDP Single-Crystal Fibres from Aqueous Solutions
Description: Potassium dihydrogen phosphate (KDP) is one of the most investigated optoelectronic materials. Its unique piezoelectric; ferroelectric; and electro-optic properties are of great importance; and its birefringence and nonlinear optical properties have made KDP a general reference material. Large; high-quality KDP crystals are now frequently grown from aqueous solution. Yet; recent experiments have shown some rather intriguing crystal growth and nucleation behaviour from supersaturated KDP solutions. Three different polymorphs; one tetragonal (the expected stable phase) and two monoclinic; have been found to nucleate depending on the degree of supersaturation. Growth of single-crystal microfibers; indicative of quasi-one-directional crystal growth; have also been observed. Although the underlying molecular mechanisms responsible have not yet been discovered; an apparent change in solution structure has been reported; and pre-nucleation clusters and multistep nucleation pathways have been proposed based on limited experimental evidence. Molecular Dynamic (MD) simulations represent an excellent tool for probing questions such as: What is the nature of the structural changes as the supersaturation of an aqueous KDP solution increases? How might these changes couple to the observed nucleation pathways? Can these changes be responsible for the observed highly directional crystal growth of KDP? In this project; MD simulations will be performed for a model aqueous KDP solutions to explored how the solution structure changes with supersaturation. Two-phase crystal/solution systems will be set up under various levels of saturation and MD simulations performed to investigate the crystal growth behaviour and the structure at the crystal interface for different crystal faces of both the tetragonal and monoclinic crystal polymorphs. Several novel methods; involving advance molecular simulation; visualization and analysis tools; will be used in conjunction with non-equilibrium MD simulations to provide important new insights into the key mechanisms of crystal growth and details of the molecular structure of KDP systems.
Skills: The student is expected to have the following skills/background: - A strong background in Chemistry; particularly physical chemistry (2nd year University level). - Basic computer skills are a requirement; and experience with scientific computing and visualization (in a Linux environment) would be an asset. - Good foundation in mathematics (1st year university level). - Willingness to learn and a keen interest in the molecular world.

Name: Web-development and client-server architecture for object-storage-based data portal in digital agriculture
Description: TerraByte is at the forefront of research where machine learning intersects with agriculture with the goal to optimize food production. The project encompasses three core pillars: generating labeled plant data; developing machine learning models; and constructing a comprehensive plant image database. The generation of labeled plant data is the first key aspect of TerraByte's research. With embedded and robotic systems; the team captures a diverse range of plant images. This process has resulted in the creation of hundreds of thousands of labeled plant images; a dataset that covers various plant types; for example weeds and staple crops such as Canola and Soybeans. Further TerraByte has expanded its data acquisition techniques to include hyperspectral and 3D imaging; as well as collection of data in the fields through drones and rovers. By generating comprehensive and accurate labeled plant data; TerraByte ensures a solid foundation for subsequent machine learning applications in agriculture. The development of machine learning models forms another critical component of TerraByte's research project. Leveraging high-performance GPU servers; the team trains deep neural networks using our extensive repository of labeled plant images. These models will become the “brains” of future agricultural agents; capable of performing tasks such as classifying plants as crops or weeds or evaluating the well-being of individual plants. The third pillar of TerraByte is the construction of a comprehensive plant image database. All the data generated by TerraByte is stored and made accessible to researchers and the wider public through our own online portal. The team is continuously developing a user-friendly front-end that enables efficient browsing; filtering; and retrieval of the data based on specific application requirements. By providing open access to this extensive plant image database; TerraByte facilitates collaboration; knowledge sharing; and accelerates advancements within both the research community and the agriculture industry.
Skills: The ideal student for this position should have a strong background in computer science or a related field; with proficiency in database management (MongoDB); web development; and Python programming. Knowledge of data ingestion protocols; API development; and machine learning concepts will be advantageous. While prior experience is preferred; we offer the opportunity for students to learn these skills during their internship. In any case problem-solving abilities and collaboration skills are essential.

Name: CO2 diffusion through Nanocomposite membrane
Description: Nanocomposite protective layers are generally used to improve mechanical strength and barrier properties. However; for developing an improved nanocomposite protective material; the physical and engineering phenomenon representing the actual permeation process should be known. Therefore; it is essential to characterize the transportation process of permeants and their interactions with the barrier nanocomposite protective layers. Though there are several models used in characterizing transportation behavior; the advection-diffusion-reaction model is preferred due to its competence in governing the physical and engineering process of permeation. Since the diffusion phenomena are directly associated with discrete atomic events of molecular diffusion and their interactions; it negotiates the requirement for nano (atomistic) scale numerical modeling. Moreover; the nanofillers used in reinforcing nanocomposites will also affect the molecules' diffusive motions and modulate the diffusion process; thus emphasizing the importance of including the alignment of nanofillers and interfacial adhesion between the nanofillers and the polymer matrix within the atomistic scale modeling. The interaction between the molecules and the composite liners will be quantified and expressed as a dependency of the diffusion coefficient. The atomistic results will then be coupled with the macroscale model for analyzing the electrochemical interactions on the protective layers. An advection-diffusion-reaction solver will be developed using the finite element method for analyzing the macroscale protection behavior of the nanocomposite protective layers.
Skills: The student should have a mechanical or materials engineering background. The ideal candidate will possess 1. Experience in numerical characterization of polymeric nanocomposite materials. 2. Experience in concepts and tools used in engineering environments for FEA analysis and multiscale modeling 3. Knowledge of ANSYS and LAMMPS

Name: Hydrogénation verte du furfural
Description: L'alcool furfurylique est un intermédiaire chimique important pour la production de produits chimiques; tels que la vitamine C; la lysine; les plastifiants; les agents dispersants; les lubrifiants et les résines. En raison de l'importance de l'alcool furfurylique dans l'industrie chimique et de la fabrication de furfural à partir de ressources renouvelables; l'hydrogénation chimiosélective du furfural en alcool furfurylique suscite un grand intérêt. Basée sur mes travaux d’hydrogénation de produits naturelles comme les pinènes et le limonène (1;2); je propose une stratégie verte pour l’hydrogénation du furfural. Des tests d’hydrogénation sans solvants du furfural seront menés. Différents métaux actifs (Pd; Pt; Ru et Rh) et supports (carbone et alumine) seront systématiquement testés. La sélectivité vers l'alcool furfurylique sera étudiée pour chaque catalyseur et chaque condition de réaction par des analyses au GCMS (Gas chromatography–mass spectrometry). Les taux de lixiviation de chaque métal seront déterminés par ICPMS (Inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry) pour l’identification de la nature hétérogène ou homogène de l’hydrogénation du furfural dans nos conditions réactionnelles. Références: 1/ 28. Selka; A.; Levesque; N.; Foucher; D.; Clarisse; O.; Chemat; F.; Touaibia; M. (2017) A Comparative Study of Solvent-Free and Highly Efficient Pinene Hydrogenation over Pd on Carbon; Alumina; and Silica Supports. Organic Process Research & Development; 21(1); 60-64. 2/9. Ndongou Moutombi; FJ; Fabiano-Tixier; AS; Clarisse; O; Chemat; F; Touaibia; M. (2020). Partial and Total Solvent-Free Limonene’s Hydrogenation: Metals; Supports; Pressure; and Water Effects. Journal of Chemistry 2020: 1-11.
Skills: L'étudiante ou l'étudiant dois avoir les bases de la chimie générale et de la chimie organique.

Name: Piping Design analysis using CAESAR-II
Description: Piping systems are the core of industrial growth as such the industries must have proper engineering tools to analyze the piping behavior under potential loadings as well as satisfy the regulatory requirements imposed by the governing codes and standards. To achieve these; the industries are implementing stress analysis tools and also searching for engineers with stress analysis experience. Hence; this research project will focus on developing piping stress analysis using CAESAR II. The stress analysis comprises modeling of various piping components relevant to the industrial piping systems and optimizing the piping systems based on the stress analysis associated with operating pressure; temperature; and flow behavior. Further; the project will analyze the effect of piping materials on the piping stresses; which will further be expanded in optimizing the piping materials suitable for various industrial applications. Moreover; the stress analysis will include both CSA Z662 and ASME B31.3 codes to satisfy the regulatory requirements for the piping stress analysis.
Skills: Those who have completed the piping engineering design courses are strongly encouraged to apply. The ideal candidate should 1. Have experience in engineering design software 2. Have knowledge of mechanical design calculations and the ability to understand codes and standards associated with mechanical and material design

Name: Failure and Contention aware Meta-Controllers for Telco Clouds
Description: The objective of this project is to design and implement several site-level and domain-level (Cloud; Edge or Communication Service Provider (CSP)) controllers. Controllers (AI; state-machine and Markovian process based) are required to manage the resources in telco cloud computing systems to eliminate the resource failures and contention causing service unavailability and performance degradation.
Skills: A student must have a background in computer science; computer engineering; software engineering or information technology. Following technical skills will be required to meet the objectives of this research project: 1. Programming (Java; Python; Matlab preferable) 2. Machine Learning and Methods 3. Knowledge about optimization methods Besides the technical skills; student must have a good problem solving and analytical skills. The student should have a good command on English (reading; writing and speaking) and interpersonal and time management skills.
Student academic background: Computer Science; Engg-Computer; Engg-Software; Engg-Systems and Technology

Name: Design of touch screen displays in cockpit environment
Description: You know those touchscreens in cars that can be difficult to use? Now they’re making their way into airplane cockpits. Imagine you’re a pilot and you have to enter data into the flight computer. The only interface is a touchscreen; and it’s at arm’s length away. The plane is going through turbulence. You reach out your arm to write the name of the next waypoint; but you select the wrong control as the airplane shakes around you. We are conducting research to design new ways for the pilot to interact with touch screen when using the flight computer and the datalink communication… while undergoing vibrations! The project involves: -Reviewing the flight displays currently in use in aircraft to find their features and problems -Ideation and brainstorming to design novel interactions in the cockpit to make them intuitive and highly usable -Design the prototypes of new flight displays for touch screen for time-based navigation or datalink communication (note: we already have prototypes that you can improve) -Human subjects will interact with the prototype to complete data-entry tasks. -Track how long it takes for them to complete a task and how many errors they make; using various physiological indicators to gain greater insight into the usability of the prototype. This includes eye tracking and perspiration sensors to monitor stress levels. -Analyze the data and determine the effects on user performance; error rate and other factors. -Propose design solutions to improve user interactions The project is led by two PhD students; with whom you will work closely. Keywords: usability; UX; user experience; human computer interaction; HCI; human factors; aviation
Skills: - Scientific background is required for data collection and data analysis (engineering; science; experimental psychology...) - Experience in designing user interface mockup is beneficial e.g.; Figma; Adobe XD; Axure - Knowledge of aviation and piloting is beneficial - Be familiar with test involving human participants is beneficial: ethics; subjective measurements (ex. questionnaire); objective measurement (ex. completion time; error rate) - Be familiar with data analysis techniques in Excel (formulas; macro) or R or Python - Knowledge of hypothesis testing with human participants is beneficial (Student test; ANOVA test; etc.)

Name: Performance Evaluation of Contention and Failure Aware Resource Management Controllers in Telco-Clouds
Description: The objective of this project is to compare and evaluate the efficiency of various combinations of different resource management controllers designed to manage the resource contention and failures in telco-cloud computing environment. The resource management controllers will be based on techniques; such as Fuzzy logic; Neural networks; Markovian Processes and State-machines.
Skills: A student must have a background in computer science; computer engineering or information technology. Following technical skills will be required to meet the objectives of this research project: 1. Programming (Java; Python; Matlab preferable) 2. Machine Learning and Methods 3. Knowledge about optimization methods Besides the technical skills; student must have a good problem solving and analytical skills. The student should have a good command on English (reading; writing and speaking) and interpersonal and time management skills.
Student academic background: Computer Science; Engg-Computer; Engg-Software; Engg-Systems and Technology

Name: Exploring the "Woman
Description: Life
Faculty supervisor: Freedom" Revolutionary Movement in Iran: Origins
Language: This project aims to delve into the feminist revolutionary movement in Iran known as "Woman; Life; Freedom;" with a focus on understanding its origins; influences; and transnational dynamics. The project seeks to shed light on the transformative power of feminist activism in the SWANA region and the strategies employed by women and ethnic minorities at the forefront of this movement. Through an interdisciplinary approach; this research project will explore the historical and socio-political context that gave rise to the Woman; Life; Freedom movement in Iran. By examining the evolution of the movement; its impact; and the challenges faced by people; the project aims to provide valuable insights into the complexities of feminist and ethnic resistance in authoritarian contexts. One of the key objectives is to examine the role and contributions of women in the movement. By analyzing their strategies and confronting patriarchal power structures; this research will highlight the resilience and determination of women who have emerged as change-makers. Furthermore; this project will investigate the transnational influences on and of the Woman; Life; Freedom movement. By studying its connections with other women's and LGBTQ+ movements in the SWANA region; the project aims to illuminate the interconnectedness and solidarity efforts within feminist activism. The project will also explore the impact of the movement on women's resistance in Afghanistan; analyzing the transfer of ideas; strategies; and solidarity efforts. By understanding the influence of the Woman; Life; Freedom movement on women's movements in Afghanistan; this research seeks to uncover the dynamics of transnational feminist solidarity. The project will utilize qualitative research methods; including literature reviews; in-depth interviews; and content analysis of primary sources. Research will be conducted in various languages spoken in the SWANA region to capture the cultural nuances and diverse perspectives related to the movement.
Skills: Alberta
column11: English
column13: Ideally students involved in this research project should possess the skills and backgrounds that align with the project's objectives. They should have a strong academic foundation in social sciences; gender studies; or related disciplines. Proficiency in English is a must. Proficiency in one the relevant languages spoken in the SWANA region; such as Persian; Kurdish; Turkish; Arabic; or Pashto; is desirable (but not necessary). The students should demonstrate excellent research skills; including literature review; data collection; and qualitative analysis. Critical thinking and a passion for social justice and feminist activism are also essential qualities for their effective participation in the
column14: Anthropology; Communication; Comparative Literature; Cultural Studies; Humanities; International Studies; Media Studies; Sociology; Womens Studies

Name: What makes a brain resilient to Alzheimer's disease
Description: In human subjects; we collect neuroimaging; cognitive; and sleep data to create a dataset tailored for understanding the biological; behavioural; and social factors that influence resilience capacity. In mouse models of Alzheimer's disease; we collect sleep (EEG); circadian rhythm; cognition; and neuropathology assessments.
Skills: The ideal student would have: (1) previous research experience working with either mice if they want to work on the mouse-side of the project or human subjects if they want to work on the human-side of the project (although not required); (2) taken courses in neuroscience; biology; and psychology; (3) strong analytical skills; (4) strong problem solving skills; and (5) enjoys team work.

Name: Freshwater Macroinvertebrate Diversity of the Coast Mountains
Description: This research project is part of an interdisciplinary; multi-university collaboration to study climate change and recreation impacts to alpine ecosystems in south coastal British Columbia. The overall goal of the project is to project changes in biodiversity and ecosystem services in this unique alpine zone; which is provides valuable recreation opportunities to the population of lower mainland B.C. but which is understudied ecologically. Because of the substantial precipitation received by Coast Mountains; it is not straightforward to extrapolate research findings from other mountain regions in Canada or globally. As part of the development of the project; we have identified a significant data and knowledge gap in terms of the freshwater invertebrate communities in alpine streams in the region. There is extremely minimal published data and no species list to work from; which makes it very challenging to predict how the biodiversity of these ecosystems may respond to climate change. Therefore; a key component of the overall research project – and one that the student on this specific project would contribute to – is filling this data gap by assembling data from unpublished studies and grey literature; and by conducting stream surveys in the alpine zone during the summer. With these two sources of data; we will be able to describe the freshwater invertebrate biodiversity of the Coast Mountain alpine zone. Freshwater invertebrates are key indicators of environmental conditions; so a subsequent goal is to identify potential indicator taxa that can be used to measure the pace of climate change and evaluate the impacts of recreational activities on aquatic ecosystems.
Skills: The student should: - have undertaken some coursework in ecology or environmental science - be detail-oriented and organized - enjoy working both in a team (for fieldwork) and independently (for research into existing data). The student should be willing to work outdoors in mountain settings and to camp in a tent for multiple nights; at a remote camp that requires hiking in. (Note – extensive fieldwork and outdoor experience is NOT required; but willingness to gain experience is. The student must know how to swim (field access is by boat and this is a requirement of our safety plan.)

Name: Consciousness and Creativity in brains and machines
Description: The human brain displays rhythmic neuronal activity and complex network dynamics at multiple temporal and spatial scales. These neuronal activation patterns are present during active tasks but also during spontaneous resting states. Brain recording techniques used in our lab; such as MEG and EEG; directly measure neuronal activity and offers a high temporal resolution. Analyzing brain dyanmics using these methods carries the potential to significantly extend our knowledge of how the healthy brain operates and what causes its breakdown in neurological disorders. Several short-term project opportunities will be conducted. Some will focus on data from normal participants; others will examamine the alterations in data from neurological disorders. All projects will involve processing brain data with state-of-the-art techniques using advanced tools available in our lab. The methods used will include signal processing and machine-learning. In particular; calssification techniques (such as SVM; Random Forests and Artificial Neural Networks) will be used to attempt to automatically differentiate brain states in healthy subjects; or to automatically identify brain dysfunction in patient data. Modeling projects; where deep neural network architectures are used to model information processing in biological networks are also available. All projects will be conducted in close collaboration with doctoral or post-doctoral students in the lab who will assist the students with their projects. More information: www.karimjerbi.com / Twitter: @karimjerbineuro
Skills: The required skills include any of the following: Programming (proficient in Python) Signal processing knowledge (e.g. time and frequency-domain analyses; fractal analyses) Experience with brain data analysis (e.g. MEG or EEG) Machine-learning methods (theory and practice; Scikit-Learn and/or Pytorch) Knowledge of (or at least a strong interest in) neuroscience and higher-order cognitive processes; including consciousness and creativity Prospective students are not expected to have all the above skills; but at least 2-3 skills from the above list is expected.

Name: From individual mindfulness to team success: Exploring relationships between individual and team mindfulness
Description: team processes and outcomes.
Faculty supervisor: An increasing number of organizations are employing teams to manage work. However; many teams operate inefficiently; affecting employee morale and profitability negatively. Given the widespread use of teams and their intricate dynamics; it's crucial to explore factors that enhance team efficiency and devise affordable strategies to boost team operations and outcomes. The proposed project will examine the mindfulness as a factor that may augment teamwork. Mindfulness – a state of present-focused nonjudgmental attention and awareness of internal processes (thoughts and emotions) and external stimuli (behaviours of others; nonverbal cues; environmental features) – has caught the interest of many scholars and practitioners. This is understandable given the wide array of benefits mindfulness provides to employees (Good et al.; 2016; Shahbaz & Parker; 2021). However; it remains unclear if these benefits extend to team contexts. This project will employ teamwork theories and mindfulness research to investigate (1) if and how the mindfulness levels of team members relate to a shared state of team mindfulness; and (2) if and how team mindfulness relates to team processes; engagement; and performance. This study serves to further the understanding of two key research areas – mindfulness and team dynamics. Firstly; it enhances mindfulness research by connecting two well-established research fields—individual and collective mindfulness. While these two phenomena bear similarities; they are distinct in theory (Sutcliffe et al.; 2016; Yu & Zellmer-Bruhn; 2018); and it is still uncertain how a group of individuals with diverse levels of mindfulness can collectively develop a shared mindfulness state. Secondly; the research contributes to both mindfulness and team dynamics studies by exploring how team mindfulness is linked to team processes and outcomes.
Student academic background: An ideal candidate for this project has a background in organizational behavior or industrial psychology; has a foundational understanding of teams (especially input-process-output model); is able to read and critically assess academic articles; has advanced writing skills; has basic knowledge/some experience in at least one of the following: grounded theory analysis of qualitative data; linear regression/multilevel regression analysis (especially in RStudio); and has excellent time management skills.
column11: Management

Name: Development of Sustainable Concrete Bridge Barrier using Glass Fiber Reinforced Polymer Bars
Description: In 2007; The Residential and Civil Construction Alliance of Ontario (RCCAO) released a report on the state of Ontario bridges; entitled “Ontario’s Bridges: Bridging the Gap.” The report warns that the integrity of Ontario’s municipal bridge infrastructure and public safety are at risk after years of deferred maintenance and irregular inspections. The study noted that many of Ontario’s bridges were built in the 1950s and 1960s; and “it is expected that most bridges will require costly rehabilitation or replacement after 50 years of life.” Bridges built prior to the 1970’s did not use air-entrained concrete and coated reinforcing steel bars to protect from the effects of freeze-thaw cycles and the application of winter de-icing salt. This leads to corrosion-induced degradation in bridge decks and barrier that will need expensive replacement. The RCCAO report stated some recommendations to be made to promote the public’s safety and the sustainability of Ontario’s bridges. One of these recommendations includes promoting bridge engineering designs that improve the life expectancy and reduce maintenance costs of bridges. This can be achieved by using rust-free glass fibre reinforced polymer (GFRP) bars. The proposed research is a continuation of Dr. Sennah’s research; supported by Ontario Ministry of Transportation and two GFRP manufacturers to develop crashworthy bridge barriers reinforced with rust-free bars. After being successful in developing PL-3 barriers for heavy-traffic highways (i.e. search for “Ryerson University Barrier” at www.youtube.com); the current research will be extended to develop sustainable PL-2 barrier for medium traffic-volume highways and municipal bridges. This research will include laboratory tests on the developed GFRP-reinforced PL-2 barrier under static loading to-collapse; simulating the equivalent static load to vehicle impact.
Skills: The student must be finishing third year and going to the fourth year of the civil engineering program at the time of the intern. The student may be physically able to work in the laboratory. The student will be assisted to read documents regarding laboratory safety and obtain safety certificates after arrival and before starting the working in the laboratory.

Name: Development of a Simplified Analysis Method of Shear-Connected Girders due to Truck Loading for Accelerated Bridge Replacement
Description: The evolution of the construction industry has revolutionized the way of building. Modular construction is one of the fastest-growing sectors of this very industry. Today; from housing to high-rise buildings to bridges; everything can be made using modular construction. Accelerated Bridge Construction (ABC) is an extensively used modular construction technique in North America. ABC involves the placement of pre-cast structural components to develop Bridges and Overpasses in a reduced amount of time. This technique is getting popular day by day due to speedy construction and less disruption to surrounding traffic flow. The broad utilization of ABC; which includes new construction; renovation; and reconstruction of existing bridge structures; has encouraged many researchers to conduct detailed study load transfer mechanisms and to develop efficient longitudinal and transverse connections. The pre-cast members used in ABC include pre-cast beams; slabs; piles; and abutments. There are many types of beams available to be used in ABC which include box girders; I girders; Tee girders; Double Tee girders and Inverted U girders etc. (PCI; 2014). In modular bridge construction; members are connected through longitudinal and transverse joints to transfer shear and moments effectively. Recent research has led to the development of efficient shear connections between box girder bridges; where; the transverse members are connected through a strip; filled ultra-high-performance concrete; called shear key (Sennah; 2020; Jajjawi; 2014). The provision of a shear key ensures transverse continuity across the bridge section for the transfer of vertical shear between adjacent girders. The Canadian Highway Bridge Design Code has no procedures or guidelines available to determine maximum transverse vertical shear for I; Tee; Double Tee or Inverted U girder bridges; for the design of shear keys under CHBDC truck loading. However; CHBDC design charts for the applied factored transverse vertical shear for shear-connected box beam bridges.
Skills: The student must be finishing third year and going to the fourth year of the civil engineering program at the time of the intern.

Name: Flow distribution in manifolds
Description: Flows in manifolds are of great importance in quite diverse fields of science and technology; including fuel cells; spargers; solar collectors; microchannels; porous infiltration and irrigation. Study of flow distribution and pressure drop is vital to predict process performance and efficiency of manifold systems. In this project; students will perform research and development of theoretical models and methodology of solutions in flow in manifolds. The generalised model will be developed to be applicable to not only designs of continuum manifolds but also those of discrete manifolds with constant or varying factors. The theoretical model provides easy-to-use design guidance to investigate the interactions among structures; operating conditions and manufacturing tolerance under a wide variety of combination of flow conditions and geometries through three general characteristic characterization and to minimize the impact on manifold operability. Ref. • JY Wang; (2017). System integration; durability and reliability of fuel cells: challenges and solutions; Applied Energy. 189: 460-479. • JY Wang; (2015). Theory and practice of flow field designs for fuel cell scaling-up: a critical review. Applied Energy; 157: 640-663. • JY Wang; HL Wang; (2015). Discrete method for design of flow distribution in manifolds; Applied Thermal Engineering; 89: 927–945.
Skills: Mathematics; python or fortran; fluid mechanics; differential equations; Microsoft Excel and word.

Name: Modelling multicomponent flows in porous media
Description: This project aims to understand how water content and flow; soil spatial heterogeneity and microbial activities in porous media drive processes to stabilize nutrient. We will do this using lattice Boltzmann model (LBM) embedded with iBM for the coupling water; nutrient and microbes processes that govern nutrient dynamics and microbial activities in porous media. Our lattice Boltzmann codes developed by our team provide a mathematical framework to simulate multi-species transport and degradation (e.g.; nutrient; water; oxygen; and product) in micro-scale. We will further integrate it with individual-based model (iBM) or Cellular Automata (CA) to simulate biofilm growth. Such an analysis of the system based on the fundamental laws of physics; chemistry and biology will enforce quantitative and comprehensive clarification of concepts and assumptions and imposes rational methods for approaching a problem. Results will provide insight on processes of nutrient stabilization at the micro scale soil pore architecture. The understanding of the fundamental process of nutrient movement in micropores could help to store levels of nutrient in porous media with applications to waste water treatment. Ref: • MA Delavar; JY Wang; 2021. Numerical investigation of pH control on dark fermentation and hydrogen production in a microbioreactor; Fuel; 292; 120355. •MA Delavar; JY Wang; 2020. Modeling combined effects of temperature and structure on competition and growth of multispecies biofilms in microbioreactors; Industrial & Engineering Chemistry Research; 59(37): 16122-16135. • Z Tian; JY Wang; 2019. Lattice Boltzmann Simulation of Biofilm Clogging and COD Reduction in Porous Media; AIChE J; 65(9): e16661 • MA Delavar; JY Wang; 2020. Pore-scale modeling of competition and cooperation of multispecies biofilms for nutrients in changing environments. AIChE J; 66 (6); e16919 • Z Tian; JY Wang; 2018. Lattice Boltzmann Simulation of Dissolution-induced Changes in Permeability and Porosity in 3D CO2 Reactive Transport; Journal of Hydrology; 557: 276-290
Skills: Computer (e.g; programing languages (C; C++; or Fortran); fluid mechanics; physics; engineering; and mathematics
Student academic background: Engineering; Environmental Studies; Geology; Mathematics; Physics; Engg-Chemical; Engg-Mechanical; Engg-Petroleum; Engg-Aeronautical

Name: Modelling for water resources and quality using machine learning
Description: Water is essential for life. This project aims to understand how water content and flow; spatial heterogeneity and microbial activities in porous media drive processes to stabilize nutrient. Machine learning methods can identify the characteristics of water quality and trace industrial point sources of pollutant. Therefore; we will do this using ML for modelling of water resource and water quality. Such an analysis of the water system will enforce quantitative and comprehensive clarification of concepts and assumptions and imposes rational methods for approaching a water problem. Results will provide insight on processes of water pollution at watersheds. The understanding of the fundamental process of water dynamics can help to reduce water pollution and with applications to waste water treatment.
Skills: Computer (e.g; programing languages (Python); physics; engineering; or mathematics

Name: Modelling of hydrological processes
Description: This project aims to understand how water content and nutrient; vegetation and soils activities interact. We will do this using process-based model (e.g.; Soil and Water Assessment Tool: SWAT) to simulate hydrological processes; such as stream flow; sediment and water quality. Our SWAT codes developed by our team provide a mathematical framework to simulate coupling dynamics of water; nutrient; soils and microbes processes in soils. We will further compare the modeled results with field data. Such an analysis of the will enforce quantitative and comprehensive clarification of concepts and assumptions and imposes rational methods for approaching a problem. Results will provide insight on processes of water and nutrient cycles in watersheds. This could help watershed and water resource management. Ref.: JY Wang; NK Shrestha; MA Delavar; TW Meshesha; SN Bhanja; 2021. Modelling watershed and river basin processes in cold climate regions: A review; Water; 13(4):518. TW Meshesha; JY Wang; ND Melaku; 2020. Modelling spatiotemporal patterns of water quality and its impacts on aquatic ecosystem in the cold climate region of Alberta; Canada. Journal of Hydrology; 587 (124952). JY Wang; et al.; 2020. Modelling spatio-temporal patterns of soil carbon and greenhouse gas emissions in grazing lands: Current status and prospects. Science of the Total Environment. 739 (139092) ND Melaku; JY Wang; TW Meshesha; 2020. Improving hydrologic model to predict the effect of snowpack and soil temperature on carbon dioxide emission in the cold region peatlands. Journal of Hydrology; 587 (124939) S Bhanja; JY Wang; 2020. Estimating influences of environmental drivers on soil heterotrophic respiration in the Athabasca River Basin; Canada. Environmental Pollution; 257 (113630) TW Meshesha; ND Melaku; JY Wang; 2020. A modified Hydrological model for assessing effect of pH on fate and transport of Escherichia coli in the Athabasca River Basin. Journal of Hydrology; 582 (124513)
Skills: Civil engineering; hydrology; earth science; agriculture; Computer; Physics and Environment

Name: Catalytic Synthesis of N-Containing Heterocycles and Amines using Metals of Low Cost and Low Toxicity
Description: This research project will focus on the development of novel catalytic complexes and their investigation in the synthesis of amines and heterocycles of relevance to the pharmaceutical industry. By elaborating the N;O-chelating ligands investigated in the Schafer group we can enhance reactivity and selectivity to design improved catalyst systems that are better suited for applications in advanced synthesis. We are most interested in developing chiral ligands for substitution onto group 4 and group 5 metals for enantioselective hydroamination and hydroaminoalkylation respectively.
