This project entails the synthesis of new N;O-chelating ligands and their complexation to early transition metals (Ti; Zr and Ta specifically). Synthetic protocols will afford opportunities to learn Schlenk line and glovebox preparatory techniques. All proligands and metal complexes will be rigorously characterized by NMR spectroscopy; mass spectrometry; elemental analysis and X-ray crystallography where appropriate. These novel coordination and organometallic complexes will then be investigated in catalytic reactions. Such reactions will be completed on small scale and monitored by gas chromatography/mass spectrometry and/or NMR spectroscopy. In the case of asymmetric catalysis; ee's will be determined using chiral UHPLC. Products will be isolated using organic synthetic techniques for yield determination and full characterization. Data will be assembled that is consistent with publication standards in leading peer-reviewed journals. Progress in this project will result in the co-authorship of a paper for submission to a top journal.
Skills: Students will be pursuing a bachelor's degree in chemistry and will have an interest in organic and/or organometallic chemistry and will expect to continue on in research at the post-graduate level. Students should have a keen interest in synthetic chemistry (organic and/or inorganic). Previous research laboratory experience is an asset; but not required. Students will be required to maintain a laboratory notebook; complete experiments in a safe and controlled manner; participate in group-meetings; assemble bi-weekly reports that summarize research progress; present their work to the group upon project completion and support the maintenance of a tidy and safe laboratory.

Name: Robotic Imaging Systems for Collection of Labelled Plant Data in Digital Agriculture
Description: TerraByte is at the forefront of research where machine learning intersects with agriculture with the goal to optimize food production. The project encompasses three core pillars: generating labeled plant data; developing machine learning models; and constructing a comprehensive plant image database. The generation of labeled plant data is the first key aspect of TerraByte's research. With embedded and robotic systems; the team captures a diverse range of plant images. This process has resulted in the creation of hundreds of thousands of labeled plant images; a dataset that covers various plant types; for example weeds and staple crops such as Canola and Soybeans. Further TerraByte has expanded its data acquisition techniques to include hyperspectral and 3D imaging; as well as collection of data in the fields through drones and rovers. By generating comprehensive and accurate labeled plant data; TerraByte ensures a solid foundation for subsequent machine learning applications in agriculture. The development of machine learning models forms another critical component of TerraByte's research project. Leveraging high-performance GPU servers; the team trains deep neural networks using our extensive repository of labeled plant images. These models will become the “brains” of future agricultural agents; capable of performing tasks such as classifying plants as crops or weeds or evaluating the well-being of individual plants. The third pillar of TerraByte is the construction of a comprehensive plant image database. All the data generated by TerraByte is stored and made accessible to researchers and the wider public through our own online portal. The team is continuously developing a user-friendly front-end that enables efficient browsing; filtering; and retrieval of the data based on specific application requirements. By providing open access to this extensive plant image database; TerraByte facilitates collaboration; knowledge sharing; and accelerates advancements within both the research community and the agriculture industry.
Skills: The ideal Mitacs Globalink student for this role should have a strong background in computer science; robotics; or a related field; with proficiency in programming languages such as Python or C++. The selected student will have the opportunity to learn and enhance their proficiency in robotics systems; image processing; hardware optimization; algorithm development; and UI design principles. Strong problem-solving abilities; attention to detail; and a collaborative mindset are essential. Guidance and mentorship from the TerraByte team will support the student in acquiring new skills and expanding their expertise.
Student academic background: Computer Science; Engg-Electrical; Physics; Engg-Computer; Engg-Software; Mathematics; Statistics

Name: Development of a remote data logging system for dendrometers
Description: The research project aims to develop a logging device capable of efficiently collecting and transmitting data from circumference dendrometers deployed in field settings. A circumference dendrometer measures very precisely (at the resolution of micrometers) how tree trunks expand and shrink during the day and over seasons due to intake of water from the roots. These measurements (usually from several dendrometers at once) are sent to logging devices. Currently; these devices require physical visits for data retrieval via USB. The goal is to design and implement a remote data logging system that enables near real-time data access. The new logging devices will not only streamline the data collection process but also enhance the capabilities of the logging system by incorporating additional environmental sensors. These sensors could measure soil moisture; air humidity; air pressure; and temperature; providing comprehensive environmental data alongside tree growth measurements. The project will explore various logging platforms. One possible platform could leverage wireless communication technologies such as LoRaWAN or cellular networks to establish connectivity between the logging devices and a central data collection hub. The logging devices will autonomously transmit the collected data to the hub; enabling researchers to access the data remotely and in a timely manner. Efficient power management will be a critical aspect of the logging devices since they will operate in off-the-grid environments. Researchers will explore power-efficient hardware components; low-power communication protocols; and energy harvesting techniques (e.g.; solar panels) to ensure prolonged device operation without the need for frequent battery replacements or recharging. The research project will involve hardware design and prototyping; firmware development; and system integration. Furthermore; work will involve optimizing the data collection process and developing robust communication protocols for reliable data transmission in challenging field conditions.
Skills: We welcome students with backgrounds in electrical engineering; embedded systems; or related disciplines. While prior experience with logging devices or wireless communication is beneficial; it is not a prerequisite. The research team will provide the necessary guidance; training; and resources to enable participants to contribute effectively to the project. By engaging in this research initiative; participants will contribute to advancing logging technology; enabling remote data access and real-time monitoring in field environments. The developed logging devices and associated platforms will have broad applications in ecological research; forestry management; and environmental monitoring; supporting data-driven decision-making and fostering sustainable practices.
Student academic background: Engg-Electrical; Physics; Computer Science; Engg-Computer; Engg-Software; Engg-Systems and Technology

Name: Automatic Speaker Verification Robustness Towards Deepfake Speech
Description: Automatic Speaker Verification (ASV) has significantly matured over the last few years due to recent advancements in machine learning and artificial intelligence (AI). The deployment of voice recognition solutions has already become a reality in many fields (e.g.; financial; forensic; educational and general voice based assistants). Despite all the advances; malicious spoofing attacks have been recognized as a serious threat to ASV systems. Characterized by an attempt of a person or a program to illegitimately bypass security by masquerading one’s identity; there are growing concerns towards the vulnerability of ASV in the face of spoofing attacks; such as impersonation; replay attacks; speech synthesis; and voice conversion. Recently; the increasing sophistication of DNN models; capable of generating human-like content; is another threat to ASV systems. For instance; an attacker can manipulate public voice data (e.g.; posted on social media) in a malicious way and post the generated deepfake speech; which resembles the voice of a victim; with the intention to harm the her/his reputation. In this research project; we are concerned with deepfake speech signals in which an adversary fabricates an utterance in the voice of a target speaker in order to deceive an ASV system. Such fabricated signal can be used by an impostor to adopt another person's identity to gain access to their assets. Our main goal will be to develop countermeasures to improve ASV robustness which will consequently mitigate identity theft based on deepfake speech signal.
Skills: • Pursuing a degree in Computer Science; Computer Engineering; Electrical Engineering; Mathematics or equivalent. • Knowledge in Python • Knowledge in machine learning theory and practice (especially deep learning). • Energetic; self-motivated and execution-oriented individuals that are passionate about producing new knowledge.

Name: Valuation of data during machine learning training processes for improved model performances
Description: In this research program; we aim to investigate the value and costs associated with data throughout its entire lifecycle in the context of machine learning (ML). We research the interplay between data collection and usage; with ML model performance informing the data collection process and vice versa. The program revolves around three main objectives. Objective 1: We develop lightweight surrogate models and heuristics that integrate the costs of data collection into a mixed objective function. Traditional methods of data valuation are computationally expensive or fail to consider collection costs; making them unsuitable for real-time or edge device execution. By addressing this limitation; we aim to enable efficient and cost-effective data collection strategies that optimize model performance. Objective 2: We redefine data value by incorporating data age and propose strategies for replacing deprecated samples in existing ML models. Current data valuation methods assume stationary sample distributions and overlook the potential for individual data points to become outdated. Our research will address these limitations; particularly in applications where data relevance evolves over time; such as finance or security. Objective 3: We develop innovative data-driven strategies to enhance the efficiency of model training. Using learning curves; we can estimate model performance based on training volume; enabling faster model exploration and optimization. Additionally; we leverage lightweight surrogate models to identify redundancies within ML datasets; facilitating the removal of samples that impede the training process. By streamlining the training mechanisms; we can improve the overall efficiency and effectiveness of ML models.
Skills: The ideal student for this role should have a strong foundation in machine learning and data analysis. Prior experience with neural networks; feature extraction; and metrics analysis is desirable. However; we also welcome students who are passionate about ML and eager to learn. We provide comprehensive training and guidance to develop the required skills. This is an excellent opportunity for students to expand their knowledge in ML and gain hands-on experience in heuristic development and performance evaluation.

Name: Cloud resource allocation using stochastic network calculus
Description: This research project investigates and applies Stochastic Network Calculus (SNC). SNC is a mathematical framework that enables the modeling; analysis; and optimization of networked systems under stochastic conditions; meaning that arrivals of workload and the speed at which it is processed is considered random. The project focuses on exploring the core concepts; theoretical foundations; and practical implications of SNC in diverse scenarios such as communication networks. In this project we delve into the fundamental principles of SNC; including queuing theory; stochastic processes; and performance metrics. We employ these concepts to assess and evaluate the performance of networks; considering factors such as backlog (queue length); latency; packet loss; throughput; and other crucial performance indicators. The project involves the development of mathematical models and simulations to accurately represent and analyze the behavior of networks. Then we use these models to investigate network performance under varying conditions; workloads; and traffic patterns. By conducting simulations; we gain valuable insights into network design; resource allocation; and optimization strategies. Optimization techniques based on SNC will be explored to enhance the performance and resource utilization of networks. Further; the results of SNC themselves often contain many free parameters that contribute in complex ways to the achieved performance metrics and thus must be optimized. We thus devise algorithms and policies for efficient traffic management; routing; scheduling; and other network-related aspects. These optimization strategies will contribute to improving network efficiency; reliability; and overall quality of service. The findings and methodologies derived from this research project will have practical applications in a wide range of networked domains; including telecommunications systems; data centers; Internet of Things (IoT) networks; and cloud computing infrastructures. By leveraging SNC; researchers will advance the understanding of network engineering; performance analysis; and optimization strategies in real-world scenarios.
Skills: The ideal student for this role should have a solid background in mathematics; computer science; or related disciplines. While prior knowledge of Stochastic Network Calculus is advantageous; it is not a prerequisite. The research team will provide guidance; support; and training to equip participants with the necessary skills and expertise throughout the project. This is an excellent opportunity for students to expand their knowledge in communication networks; modelling; and optimization.

Name: Neuroinflammation during multiple sclerosis
Description: For a long time; the central nervous system was considered an immunoprivileged site for its limited arsenal to mount an inflammatory response. In recent years; the work of many researchers throughout the world demonstrated that the immune system plays a critical role in maintaining CNS homeostasis during a healthy state and disease. Neuroinflammation emerged as a common denominator in many neurodegenerative diseases; including multiple sclerosis; Parkinson’s disease; Alzheimer’s disease; amyotrophic lateral sclerosis; Huntington’s disease; epilepsy; stroke; etc. In our lab; we study neuroinflammation on different levels; including cellular molecular biology; classic immunology and neurosciences; and computerized animal behavior assessment using a state-of-the-art behavior recognition system that will facilitate break-through discoveries in the domain of neurodegenerative diseases. Recently we initiated human studies that will investigate the potential of wearable devices in the diagnosis and prognosis of MS. The results of these studies will lay the foundation for the development of new therapeutic agents to treat neurodegenerative diseases.
Skills: We are looking for students with general science background and knowledge of molecular biology. In addition; we are developing a project detecting animal movements; so if you know R or Python we can have fun in programming. Most importantly; we are looking for highly motivated; enthusiastic people with excellent academic standings and good team players.

Name: Voice/Audio cloning
Description: Recent years progress in deep learning techniques applied to different type of signals has led to impressive results that were impossible to achieve in the past. Recent work by Baidu; Google; etc. has shown the possibility of cloning voices and using the model for text to speech synthesis. In this project; we want to further explore the possibility of using these approaches to generate a new singing voice. For example; you might want to perform a karaoke with a voice of your preferred artist; the objective then is to transform the voice to the desired output using learned voice cloning models. The intern will work on transforming existing models to achieve this objective. We will use source code and deep learning models available in our Lab.
Skills: Programming (Python; Matlab; etc.) Machine leaning or deep learning are considered a plus
Student academic background: Computer Science; Engg-Computer; Engg-Electrical; Engg-Software; Computer Science; Engg-Biomedical; Engg-Electrical; Engg-Systems and Technology; Engineering

Name: Deep learning for face recognition and multi-Biometrics
Description: The use of biometric techniques for the assessment of affective and cognitive status is an emerging area of research. The goal is to extract salient features that can help predict an individual's affective and cognitive state in order to intervene when necessary (social problems) or to personalize the individual's experience (business problems). These states can be of a different positive or negative nature; for example: happiness; depression; health problems; drug addiction; lying; etc. Each of these states is of particular interest depending on the context. For example; border security may be more interested in detecting lies; nervousness; etc. For example; border security may be more interested in detecting lies; nervousness; etc. For medical personnel and social services; it may be useful to detect depression or suicidal attitudes in advance. Several techniques use computer vision to extract facial features and analyze them for these purposes. In recent years; some techniques have been developed to extract emotional states using voice signal processing. In this work; we want to use both voice signals and facial images to extract an individual's emotional state. The goal is to build a deep learning neural network that can use speech and facial images as inputs and classify them into different emotional states. We will use public databases to test the developed deep learning models.
Skills: Programming (Python; Matlab; etc.) Machine leaning or image processing are considered a plus

Name: Autonomous vehicles (UAV
Description: UGV) navigation using vision and deep learning
Faculty supervisor: This project aims to develop a high-level vision-based navigation algorithm for UAVs and autonomous vehicles. The objective is to develop deep learning algorithms to allow the robot to automatically learn to navigate in a given environment. Other scenarios include the navigation of several autonomous vehicles to perform the same task; to follow each other in training; etc. The learning will be done in simulation and with real autonomous vehicles in a controlled environment.
Student academic background: Programming (Python; Matlab; etc.) Machine leaning or image processing are considered a plus

Name: AI and computer vision for autonomous robots
Description: This project aims to develop computer vision and AI programs for robot navigation (eg. Mobile robot platform). Depending on the equipped platform; we can also program a robot arm to collect/manipulate objects. The applications can be in video surveillance; security; agriculture; etc. Our primary applications are the detection of objects using computer vision and AI to guide the robot using the detected data of interest.
Skills: Programming (Python; Matlab; etc.) Machine leaning or image processing are considered a plus

Name: Deep learning for medical imaging
Description: The progress of deep learning techniques in recent years has led to impressive results in the field of medical diagnosis. Several techniques have been developed to detect cancer tumours; detect diabetic retinopathy; segment cells precisely; analyse the genomic profile of individuals; etc. These advances offer the prospect of applications in the near future in the fields of precision medicine and personalized medicine. Our team has worked on these types of subjects and has developed algorithms for : (i) tumor segmentation and classification to detect cancer tumors; (ii) detecting diabetes from images of the retina; (iii) segmenting cell nuclei for DNA extraction; etc. In this project; we want to further develop deep learning algorithms to perform tasks similar to those mentioned above. In particular; we want to develop deep neural networks for extracting features from medical data to detect abnormalities (e.g. cancer). The student will be able to build on our past work to carry out his developments/programs.
Skills: Programming (Python; Matlab; etc.) Basic knowledge of Matrix computations Machine leaning or image processing are considered a plus
Student academic background: Computer Science; Engg-Computer; Engg-Electrical; Engg-Software; Computer Science; Engg-Biomedical; Engg-Electrical; Engg-Systems and Technology; Engineering

Name: Game-based Learning of Game Theory
Description: The objective of this project is to design; develop; and test a series of web-based interactive games for learning algorithms. It includes presenting topics of data structures and algorithms using visualizations and interactive problems for learners to apply their knowledge ; implementing AI/machine learning evaluation methods; where the system can monitor learner’s behaviors and provide relevant feedback on their approach to problem solving; and demonstrating improved learning performance through the iterative practice-feedback loop approach.
Skills: Data structure; algorithms; JavaScript or Python.

Name: LLM-Powered Intelligent Educational Systems
Description: The deployment of artificial intelligence in online education systems has become very popular in recent years and recently published large language models (LLMs) tend to have a huge application potential on developing intelligent online education systems. This project is to develop and test a personalized online learning system where we will use LLM-powered AI systems like ChatGPT to generate learning paths; to plan learning activities; and to conduct adaptive practicing and formative assessment.
Skills: Python programming; algorithms; reinforcement learning

Name: Enhancing Search and Rescue Operations: Advanced Robotic Systems with Computer Vision and AI
Description: This project aims to develop advanced robotic systems for search and rescue scenarios using computer vision and AI. The goal is to enhance the capabilities of mobile and legged robots in navigating challenging environments and identifying objects and individuals of interest. The robots will be equipped with real-time data analysis and decision-making abilities to optimize search efforts and save time. Additionally; the robots can be customized with robot arms for object manipulation tasks. Beyond search and rescue; the technology has applications in video surveillance; security; and agriculture. The project aims to make a meaningful impact by leveraging robotics and AI to save lives and improve society.
Skills: Programming (Python; C/C++; Matlab; etc.) Machine leaning or image processing are considered a plus
Student academic background: Computer Science; Engg-Electrical; Engg-Computer; Engg-Software; Computer Science; Engg-Electrical; Engg-Systems and Technology; Engineering

Name: Enhancing Forest Fire Management with AI and Computer Vision
Description: This project aims to advance forest fire management by leveraging AI and computer vision technology. Through the development of advanced multimodal vision systems; equipped with computer vision algorithms; the project focuses on autonomously detecting and responding to fire hotspots in forested areas. We will use recent deep learning algorithms to develop this solution. For this project; multiple multimodal datasets are available for aerial and ground captured images of wildland fires. The application fits in the areas of video surveillance and security. By utilizing AI and computer vision; the project aims to improve response times; minimize fire spread; and save lives in forest fire scenarios.
Skills: Programming (Python; Matlab; etc.) Machine leaning or image processing are considered a plus
Student academic background: Computer Science; Engg-Electrical; Engg-Computer; Engg-Software; Computer Science; Engg-Electrical

Name: Iwasawa theory of elliptic curves and modular forms
Description: In Iwasawa theory; we are interested in studying arithmetic behaviours of mathematical objects over a tower of number field extensions. In this project; we will study generalizations of classical results in Iwasawa theory in the context of elliptic curves and modular forms; using p-adic and numerical methods.
Skills: Knowledge in Number theory; Algebra; some programming experience with mathematical softwares.

Name: Isogeny graphs and Iwasawa theory
Description: Isogeny graphs defined using elliptic curves have very rich arithmetic and combinatorial structures. In this project; we shall study towers of coverings of such graphs and compute Iwasawa invariants of these towers. In particular; we shall study the distribution of these invariants as we vary the level of the graph.
Skills: Knowledge in number theory; graph theory; some programming experience with mathematical softwares.

Name: Increasing Construction Industry Productivity through Industrialization and Digitalization
Description: This research project aims to explore the areas of industrialization and digitalization to help improve construction industry practices in Canada. The student is expected to design and conduct surveys through the faculty's research group and industry collaborators to develop benchmarks and metrics for measuring the current maturity of technology levels in industrialized construction. A literature review will be conducted to compare current construction industry practices with other industries such as manufacturing; and eventually; research frameworks will be designed to move the construction industry towards greater productivity and a technology-centric approach.
Skills: The student is required to have proficiency in English writing and speaking; along with civil engineering or related engineering training. Understanding general construction practices is necessary; and the ability to use digital tools (e.g.; BIM software) is considered an asset.

Name: Decarbonization of Construction Processes through Industrialized Construction
Description: This research project aims to explore how to decarbonize construction processes in an industrialized construction or offsite construction context. By transitioning onsite construction to indoor controlled production environments; industrialized construction provides opportunities to decrease greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions through automation and digital technologies. However; currently; there is a lack of research defining the carbon footprint in the industrialized construction supply chain. This research will design a theoretical framework for assessing the carbon footprints of industrialized construction processes; both qualitatively and quantitatively. The student will conduct surveys to develop mind maps; identifying key measurements that can be used to develop the research framework. The student will closely collaborate with local industry partners through the faculty researcher's research group and research partners.
Skills: The following skills are required but not mandatory: - The students need to have good attitude; teamworking mindset; and be flexible and hardworking. - Proficient in Microsoft Office. - Good communication skills in English. - Experience in construction technologies is an asset (e.g.; BIM; CAD)

Name: Triboelectric generators
Description: Triboelectric nanogenerators convert mechanical energy into electricity; however their most exciting feature is the use of biocompatible dielectric layers as their active material and substrates; hence their ease of application in wearable technologies and human-machine interfaces. Therefore; advanced materials engineering is applied to develop polymeric thin films that act as charged triboelectric layers; with the aim of generating electricity through friction. Optimization of these layers is crucial to increase surface charge density; and in turn the electricity generated. This is achieved through the introduction of microstructures to the thin film’s surface; and the addition of compounds to the polymer matrix through additive reactions and surface functionalization; which leads to an increase in the overall surface charge density. The goal of the proposed project is to develop an omniphobic thin film with the use of electrospinning technology; producing a microstructured triboelectric polymer ready for use in a wearable generator device. This thin film will possess an ordered microstructured surface meant to enhance the surface charge density of the material; inherent omniphobicity to improve its resistance against all liquids; making it ideal for washability which is a crucial property for wearable technologies; and good tensile strength to resist the abrasive force of the washing cycle and environmental wear and tear. Electrospinning will be used along with different collectors and masks to optimize the surface of the produced thin film. Organic and Inorganic additives will be employed to create different composite materials for use as triboelectric layers. The work plan for the project can be summarized as such: a. Development of omniphobic composites using a base material and additives. b. Structural tuning of produced films via electrospinning by making and using masks on the film collector. c. Implementation of thin films in triboelectric nanogenerators and simulating a washability test.
Skills: The required background of the student is in the field of Materials Science; mechanical; or Chemical Engineering. Skills in materials preparation through chemical reactions and/or experience with common laboratory equipment will help ease the student into the work. Knowledge on microstructured materials and surface science will help the student better understand the synthesis and characterization steps of the project. Background in electrical engineering and an understanding of the fundamentals of electricity will enhance the students’ appreciation for the electrical characterization accompanying the triboelectric device’s power production parameters.

Name: Synthèse de nouveaux analogues des acides hydroxycinnamiques
Description: L'inhibition de la biosynthèse des leucotriènes catalysée par la 5-lipoxygénase (5-LO) est une stratégie thérapeutique validée contre certaines maladies inflammatoires et allergies. Malheureusement; le seul inhibiteur approuvé à ce jour a une utilisation clinique limitée en raison de son mauvais profil pharmacocinétique et de sa toxicité hépatique. Basée sur les précédents résultats de mon laboratoire (1;2); une nouvelle série d’analogues d’acides hydroxycinnamiques sera synthétisée. Les acides hydroxycinnamiques sont présents dans de nombreuses plantes et fruits comestibles. Les nouvelles molécules seront synthétisées en utilisant des méthodes classiques de chimie organiques (estérification; condensation aldoliques; …). Toutes les molécules obtenues seront caractérisées par les méthodes d’analyses disponibles au laboratoire et au département (IR; RMN). Les nouveaux analogues seront testés pour leur capacité inhibitrice de la 5-LO. Avec les nouveaux analogues synthétisés dans ce projet; le rôle de la portion phénolique; de la fonction ester sera investigué. Références: 1/ Touaibia; M; Faye; D C; Doiron; J A.; Chiasson; A I; Blanchard; S; Roy; P P; Surette; M E. (2022). Structure-Activity Relationship Studies of New Sinapic Acid Phenethyl Ester Analogues Targeting the Biosynthesis of 5-Lipoxygenase Products: The Role of Phenolic Moiety; Ester Function; and Bioisosterism. Journal of Natural Products; 85(1); 225-236. 2/ Chiasson; AI; Robichaud; S; Ndongou Moutombi; FJ; Hébert MPA.; Mbarik M; Surette ME; Touaibia M. (2020). New zileuton-hydroxycinnamic acid hybrids: synthesis and structure-activityrelationship towards 5-lipoxygenase inhibition. Molecules 2020; 25; 4686. 25(4686): 1-18.
Skills: L'étudiante ou l'étudiant dois avoir les bases de la chimie générale et de la chimie organique.

Name: A metaheuristic Algorithm for Breast Cancer Classification and Diagnosis
Description: Optimization algorithms such as Genetic Algorithm; Particle Swarm Optimization; Ant Colony Optimization etc. may be used to build classification models. The obtained classification model can be further used for diagnostic purposes. But; none of the available optimization algorithms are precise and leaves us with the scope of improvement in classification sensitivity and specificity. UC Irvine Machine Learning Repository provides open access to 301 datasets. Wisconsin Diagnostic Breast Cancer (WDBC) dataset is chosen for our cancer classification study. The breast Cancer Wisconsin dataset consists of features computed from a digitized image of a Fine Needle Aspirate (FNA) of a breast mass. Fine needle aspiration is a type of biopsy procedure which involves the insertion of a thin needle into an abnormal appearing tissue area or body fluid. In the WDBC dataset; each record represents follow-up data for consecutive patients seen. Each data entry consists of cell nuclei characteristics like radius; texture; perimeter; area; smoothness; compactness; concavity; concave points; symmetry and fractal dimension. Metaheuristic algorithms are popular for solving complex optimization problems. Bio-inspired algorithms are very efficient as it imitates the best features in nature. In this project; we plan to study cancer prediction through the cell nucleus of breast mass and use WDBC dataset; which illustrates the instances of malignant and benign breast cancer and the cell nucleus features associated with it. We would like to propose a metaheuristic algorithm. The algorithm has been modified to be suitable to carry out classification rule mining. Through the proposed algorithm application on WDBC dataset; we will drive classification rule which can be used in decision making process during breast cancer diagnosis. The rule derived emphasizes that the malignant breast cells can be distinguished from benign cells; based on irregularity in shape of the cell nucleus. This can help in early diagnosis and decision-making
Skills: Students know Matlab software and/python/and or R. Knowing metaheuristic algorithms and machine learning will be an asset
Student academic background: Computer Science; Engg-Biological; Engg-Biomedical; Engg-Chemical; Engg-Industrial; Engineering; Mathematics; Statistics

Name: Predicting Confirmed Cases of COVID-19 by optimization technique
Description: The world population is being quickly infected by the SARS-COV-2 virus pandemic (is known as Covid-19). Covid-19 has grown very quick throughout the countries; with a very high contagion rate; spreading all continents in just over three months since the first confirmed case in China. The numbers have grown exponentially reaching; roughly; more than 3.7 million cases and more than a quarter of a million deaths. In the current study; we present a new forecasting model to estimate and forecast the number of confirmed cases of COVID-19 in the upcoming 14 days based on the previously confirmed cases recorded in China. The proposed model is an improved adaptive neuro-fuzzy inference system (ANFIS) using swarm algorithm. The ANFIS is broadly employed in time series prediction and forecasting problems; and it had good performance in many various real-life applications. It offers flexibility in figuring out nonlinearity in the time series data; as well as integrating the features of both artificial neural networks (ANN) and fuzzy logic systems. It has been employed in variety of forecasting applications such as a stock price forecasting model and weather models. In this project; we plan to study an efficient predicting model to predict the confirmed cases of the COVID-19 in China (Italy) for the upcoming ten days based on previously confirmed cases. 2. An improved ANFIS model is proposed using a swarm intelligence algorithm such as spider algorithm and its variants. We compare the proposed model with the original ANFIS and various swarm intelligence algorithms such as particle swarm optimization; social-spider optimization; sine-cosine algorithm Ant Colony Optimization algorithm; Genetic Algorithm. n order to show the performance of the proposed model. Aslo; we will aplly non-parametric statistical tests on the proposed model with other models to show superoity of the proposed model.
Skills: Students know Python or R or Matlab software. Knowing swarm intelligence algorithms and data mining will be asset.

Name: A hybrid metaheuristic algorithm for multilevel thresholding image segmentation
Description: Thresholding is one of the known methods in image segmentation (IS). It has two classes: bi-level thresholding (BT) and multilevel thresholding (MT). The BT divides the image into two categories; whereas MT is utilized to segment complex images and it can generate multiple thresholds; which divide pixels into multiple similar parts based on intensity. BT can generate enough outcomes in the case that the image contains only two principal gray levels; but the foremost restriction is the time-consuming computation which is often high when it is extended to MT. Researchers get the optimal thresholds by maximizing some criteria such as the Otsu criterion and Kapur’s entropy. In the Otsu-based method; the best threshold is the one that maximizes the between-class variance of the regions. Kapur’s entropy measures the homogeneity of the classes by using the maximization of the entropy. Thus; the selection of optimal thresholds in multilevel is an NP-hard problem. When the threshold number is small; classical techniques are appropriate; but if this number grows; the accuracy of segmentation will be influenced. Therefore; to overcome this drawback; many swarm intelligence algorithms (SIAs) have been applied and combined with thresholding algorithms In this project; we develop a new hybrid metaheuristic by combining Otsu’s criterion and Kapur’s entropy (combination of both) to determine MT for IS. We will use our new hybrid algorithm as a preprocessing method prior to the IS. The image is preprocessed to get the optimum pixels and then k-means clustering is applied to the image for segmentation. Also; we compare our proposed approach with other existing approaches in the literature and apply nonparametric statistical tests to show the superiority of our proposed algorithm over other algorithms. We will use various image databases of Berkeley University and other resources.
Skills: Writing extensive computer programs in Python; or R; or Matlab; Knowing swarm intelligence algorithms and optimization will be assets. Knowing image segmentation; clustering; and swarm intelligent algorithms

Name: Solving a vehicle routing problem by swarm intelligence algorithm
Description: In the last decade; new insights and algorithms have been obtained for the classical deterministic VRP as well as for natural stochastic and dynamic variations of it. These new developments are based on theoretical analysis; combined probabilistic and combinatorial modeling; and lead to new and effective algorithms and a deeper understanding of uncertainty issues in vehicle routing problems. The VRP is an NP-hard problem with many extensions such as the Vehicle Routing Problem with Time Windows (VRPTW). The goal of this project is to use and develop swarm intelligence algorithm for a provider of software planning tools for distribution logistics companies. The algorithm computes a daily plan for a heterogeneous fleet of vehicles; that can depart from different depots and must visit a set of customers for delivery operations. Besides multiple capacities and time windows associated with depots and customers; the problem considers incompatibility constraints between goods; depots; vehicles and customers; maximum route length and durations; upper limits on the number of consecutive driving hours and compulsory drivers’ rest periods; the possibility to skip some customers and to use express courier services instead of the given fleet to fulfill some orders; the option of splitting up the orders; and the possibility of “open” routes that do not terminate at depots. Moreover; the cost of each vehicle route is computed through a system of fares; depending on the locations visited by the vehicle; the distance traveled; the vehicle load and the number of stops along the route. We will develop hybrid swarm intelligence algorithms (combine two algorithms) and show the perofrmance of the proposed algorithm by comparing other algorithms in the literature and applying on-parametric statistical tests to show the superority of the proposed algorithm.
Skills: Writing extensive computer programs in Python; or R or Matlab; Knowing swarm intelligence algorithms and optimization will be assets.
Student academic background: Computer Science; Engg-Electrical; Engg-Industrial; Engg-Software; Engineering; Management; Management Information Systems; Mathematics

Name: Swarm Intelligence algorithms and routing in wireless sensor networks
Description: Due to advances in low-power wireless communications; low-power analog and digital electronics; the development of low-cost and low-power sensor nodes that are small in size has received increasing attention. Sensor nodes have the ability to sense the environment nearby; perform simple computations and communicate in a small region. Although their capacities are limited; combining these small sensors in large numbers provides a new technological platform; called Wireless Sensor Networks (WSNs). WSNs provide reliable operations in various application areas including environmental monitoring; health monitoring; vehicle tracking system; military surveillance and earthquake observation In this project; we will present a new protocol for WSN routing operations. The protocol is achieved by using Swarm Intelligence algorithms (such as Hybrid Genetic Particle Swarm Optimization Algorithm; and Hybrid recent swarm Algorithms ) based optimization technique in network routing to optimize routing paths; providing an effective multi-path data transmission method to achieve reliable communications in the case of node faults. We will aim to maintain network life time at a maximum; while data transmission is achieved efficiently; so an adaptive approach is developed according to this goal. The proposed approaches are compared to a well known other algorithms such as ant based algorithm named EEABR using an event-based simulator. Our goal is to offer significant reductions of energy consumption which is used as a performance metric for different sized WSNs. Also; we will implement our approach on a small sized hardware component requiring minimum connections suitable for tiny node designs and we will develop an methods for handling the routing tasks by using the proposed approaches router chip. We will test the performace of the proposed algorithms by comparing the proposed algorithm with other existing swarm algorithm in the literature and applying non-parameteric statistical tests.
Skills: Writing extensive computer programming (Python; or Matlab software or R or others); Swarm Intelligence algorithms Writing report and using statistical nonparametric tests

Name: Examining the Use of Social Impact Bonds in Community Sports Programs
Description: Sports are widely considered a tool to promote health; well-being; and psychosocial development; especially among youth. This is particularly relevant in underserved communities that rely on sports to teach important life skills that will help youths’ future success. Thus; community sports organizations are critical to providing opportunities for individuals to enjoy the physical; psychological; and social benefits of sports. Financially supporting these programs is of key interest to federal and provincial/state governments. Governments seek ways to allocate and disburse funding for community organizations to deliver sports initiatives that increase participation among underrepresented groups. One strategy is Social Impact Bonds (SIBs); which are outcome-based contracts between social investors and the public sector that aim to attract private funding for pressing social issues. With SIBs; investors provide upfront funding for community initiatives seeking social and financial returns; and governing authorities pay the investors if their community initiatives achieve predetermined targeted social outcomes. SIBs were developed in the UK and are largely present in Europe and the US. Canada has eight SIBs projects providing services in health; child and family welfare; etc. However; none of these provide sport-based services. Given its potential to increase private funding and improve the allocation and disbursement of government funding; using SIBs in sport-related projects in Canada can further improve the positive impact of sports in underserved Canadian communities and their youth. As such; the purpose of this study is to examine the facilitators and barriers to implementing sport-based SIBs in Quebec; Canada. The questions guiding this research are: (a) What are the key characteristics of SIBs projects in Canada (e.g.; how do they work; how were they implemented; and who are the key stakeholders)? (b) What are the key characteristics of sport-based SIBs in other countries? (c) What social; economic; and political factor influence of SIBs?
Skills: The student must have a background in management and/or sports sciences (e.g.; sport management; sport psychology; sport sociology). The student must have a general interest in sports research. The student much be proficient in English. Ability to read French is an asset. Knowledge of community and youth development through sport is an asset. Knowledge of Social Impact Bonds (SIBs) is an asset. Experience working with underserved community organizations or their members is an asset.

Name: Development of Vapochromic Sensors using Coordination Polymer Materials for Detecting Toxic Gases
Description: Our group research focuses on the general synthesis and characterization of coordination polymers for a range of applications. Coordination polymers are metal-containing solid-state materials that self-assemble from appropriately chosen building blocks and can be designed to show useful magnetic; optical; electronic properties or porosity (for example). The Leznoff lab concentrates on using metal-cyanides as building blocks for coordination polymers; particularly the unusual linear d10-metal M(CN)2- (M=Au;Ag) units; to take advantage of metallophilic interactions as supramolecular glue; and actively are designing useful functional materials that act as sensors; optical components; emissive materials etc.
Skills: The student should have a substantial inorganic chemistry background: completed at least 3rd year inorganic chemistry lectures and laboratory and ideally some laboratory research experience as well would be preferred. Any experience that the student has with inorganic/materials chemistry synthetic methodology and crystal growth; characterization techniques including elemental analysis; FT-IR and Raman spectroscopies; UV-vis fluorescence spectroscopy; X-ray diffraction (single crystal and powder) structure solution is useful but the student intern will be trained in these areas over the course of the summer as appropriate and thus is not a prerequisite for the internship.

Name: Examining National Sport Federations' Support of Athletes with a Disability: Stakeholders' Perceptions of Cycling Canada
Description: Despite numerous calls for additional research in Parasports; studies in the fields of Management; Psychology; and Sport Sciences are still lacking. The limited knowledge of Parasport leads stakeholders (e.g.; athletic directors; coaches; and mental performance consultants) to either ignore the unique needs of Para-athletes with a disability or; more problematic; learn how to support them by trial-and-error. This can be detrimental to the psychological state of athletes; as well as their athletic performance. This is important because elite parasports; such as the Paralympics; are an important tool to advertise physical activity participation that can lead to physical and psychological benefits to individuals with a physical disability in the general population. However; despite the unique needs of athletes with a disability; elite parasport athletes continue to be affiliated to the National and International Governing Federation that regulates both the able body and parasport modalities of each sport. This raises questions regarding the kind and quality of services provided to athletes with a disability by the sporting Federation. As such; the purpose of this study is to examine the perceptions of Paralympic athletes; coaches; and sports administrators regarding the services provided by their National and International Governing Federations to support athletes with a disability. This study will be conducted with Paracycling athletes in Canada and address the following research questions: (a) Who are the key stakeholders in the National and International Governing Federations that support the work of elite athletes with a disability? (b) What services are provided and how do they address the specific needs of athletes with a disability? (c) What can these Federations improve to better serve athletes with a disability?
Skills: The student must have a background in management and/or sports sciences (e.g.; sport management; sport psychology; sport sociology). The student must have a general interest in sports research. The student much be proficient in English and French. Knowledge or experience working with parasport is an asset. Knowledge or experience working with individuals with a physical disability is an asset.

Name: Design and development of a patient-controlled health information repository using the Solid web-decentralization framework
Description: Over the last two decades; healthcare has moved from a paper-based reality to an electronic one. But the transition has taken place in a piecemeal manner and it is disjointed and incomplete. As a result; healthcare data are fragmented and scattered in digital silos. Although many projects have tried to break down these digital silos; none have succeeded and a new approach is needed. Therefore; in this project we will explore a completely new way to manage healthcare data by putting them fully under the control of patients using the Solid web-decentralization framework of Tim Berners Lee (solidproject.org).
Skills: Experience with data handling and software development; ideally using Python and Django. Experience with Javascript; SQL would be useful. Some knowledge of cybersecurity would be a benefit. An understanding of the Solid framework would be a benefit. An understanding of healthcare data would be a benefit.

Name: Neutron-Induced Carcinogenic Effects
Description: This project will examine the relative biological effectiveness (RBE) of neutrons to produce mutations in DNA; accounting for direct and indirect damage and DNA repair. To do this; we will make use of the Geant4 and Geant4-DNA radiation simulation packages. We will model direct action and indirect action DNA damage as well as DNA repair. Findings from the project will be compared with mutations measured experimentally using single-cell whole genome DNA sequencing of irradiated cells.
Skills: The student should have a basic understanding of nuclear physics and some programming skills.

Name: Software Solutions and Algorithms for Compressed Data Structures
Description: Data structures such as tensors; graphs; and meshes are widely used in AI and scientific applications; but they often require large amounts of storage and computation. Compression techniques can reduce data movement and the number of floating-point operations (FLOPs) by exploiting the sparsity or redundancy of these data structures. However; compression techniques also introduce challenges for software design and algorithm development; such as irregular code patterns and trade-offs between accuracy and memory usage. This research explores new software solutions and algorithms that can efficiently operate on compressed data structures. • Research Problem: The research problem is to design software solutions and algorithms that can iterate over compressed data structures efficiently while maintaining or improving the accuracy and scalability of AI and scientific applications. • Methods: The research methods include developing new lossy and lossless compression techniques for high-order tensors; graphs; and meshes; designing new parallel algorithms for sparse tensor algebra and numerical optimization; and implementing software frameworks that can generate optimized code for compressed data structures. • Results: The research results show that the proposed compression techniques can significantly reduce the storage costs and FLOPs of various AI and scientific applications; such as computer graphics; pruned neural networks; linear solver preconditioners; and factorization. The research also shows that the proposed software solutions and algorithms can achieve high performance and scalability on different platforms; such as CPUs; GPUs; and distributed systems.
Skills: This project requires students who are passionate about creating new computing systems and who have excellent problem-solving skills. Students should also be proficient in C/C++; CUDA/OpenCL; and Python; as the project involves working with large open-source code bases. Moreover; students should have good communication skills to collaborate effectively with other researchers in the project. Knowing Git is also essential for the project. The ability to write scientific reports is a desirable skill.

Name: Enabling Machine Learning for Cyber-Physical Systems
Description: By enabling the interaction and coordination of computational; physical; and human elements in cyber-physical systems (CPS); various goals such as efficiency; safety; resilience; and adaptability can be achieved. However; real-time constraints can pose a challenge for machine learning models that show promising results in several CPS goals due to the limited memory and computing resources in controllers used in CPS. Tensor algebra kernels such as matrix multiplication are necessary to execute ML models stored as tensors; which can be memory and computation intensive. Although many accelerators are used in servers and embedded devices to speed up ML workloads; industrial controllers typically rely on a single-core CPU with limited memory size ranging from 2KB to 512MB; and the processor's instruction issue rate lower than GHz; making it much more restrictive than server processors. Therefore; ML models for CPS must be modified to use lower memory and computing resources efficiently. This project aims to build a framework for CPS; such as drones and small robots; to facilitate the creation of new applications benefiting from ML models. The framework supports a wide range of algorithms and modules such as model predictive control; Kalman filter; autopilot algorithm; and image processing used in industrial controllers. Additionally; the framework should consider the real-time and memory constraints of the target architecture.
Skills: This project requires students who are passionate about creating new computing systems and who have excellent problem-solving skills. Students should also be proficient in C/C++; and Python; as the project involves working with large open-source code bases. Moreover; students should have good communication skills to collaborate effectively with other researchers in the project. Knowing Git is also essential for the project. The ability to write scientific reports is a desirable skill.

Name: Heterogenous Programming for Accelerating Artificial Intelligence Applications
Description: When it comes to creating machine learning applications; software frameworks are incredibly helpful. They can automatically generate code that is optimized for the hardware being used; making the process much more efficient. These frameworks take a high-level description of the application and convert it into an intermediate representation expressed as a task graph. The vertices within this graph represent tensor operations; while the edges show dependence between them. Graph partitioning techniques are used to ensure that the load is balanced across CPUs and GPUs; enabling parallel execution. To optimize the task graph further; ML frameworks use algebraic transformations to rewrite some tensor operations with more efficient ones. This is done using algebraic and domain information. Once the optimized task graph is created; it is passed to back-end compilers such as LLVM to generate optimized code for a given architecture. This is an ongoing computational challenge; as finding efficient graph-level and architecture-specific transformations is not always an easy task. To solve this issue; heuristic approaches such as hierarchical search and genetic algorithms are used to find efficient schedules. Verification techniques are also important to ensure that the program is correct and that different transformation combinations can be explored. As AI models continue to grow in size; it becomes more challenging to build a fast and power-efficient program using all the available resources. To address this issue; this project is exploring new code generation techniques that can benefit the heterogeneity of existing architectures. For example; CPUs; GPUs; and domain-specific accelerators such as tensor cores can be used to improve performance. A new search heuristic will also be developed to select the most efficient compiler transformations and tuning parameters. Overall; software frameworks are an essential tool for creating machine learning applications; and they continue to evolve to meet the demands.
Skills: This project requires students who are passionate about creating new computing systems and who have excellent problem-solving skills. Students should also be proficient in C/C++; CUDA/OpenCL; distributed programing; and Python; as the project involves working with large open-source code bases. Moreover; students should have good communication skills to collaborate effectively with other researchers in the project. Knowing Git is also essential for the project. The ability to write scientific reports is a desirable skill.

Name: Depression at Work: An Systematic Review of Literature
Description: According to recent data from the World Health Organization (2023); an estimated 280 million individuals worldwide are grappling with depression – a debilitating mental disorder characterized by persistent feelings of sadness; loss of interest and pleasure in daily activities; spanning over a prolonged period. This indicates an overwhelming prevalence of this mental health concern globally. Depression carries significant economic implications. The high costs of depression are predominantly borne by employers; a major portion of which arises from a decline in employee performance (Stewart et al.; 2003). Work-related stressors; while not always the primary cause; can exacerbate the intensity of depressive disorders (Bonde; 2016). Despite the pervasiveness and costs of depression; little is known about how it affects employee experiences and outcomes as well as when and how work environment can alleviate or worsen the symptoms. This scarcity of research; I argue; could be attributed at least in part; to the deficient integration of depression within theoretical frameworks of organizational behavior and industrial psychology. To address the void in the current body of knowledge; this project is designed with the objective of collating existing empirical evidence on depression in the workplace by employing a systematic literature review methodology. The goal of this comprehensive examination is to develop a conceptual framework that encompasses the multifaceted aspects of workplace depression. This framework is expected to provide a robust scaffold to support and guide future research endeavors in this critical area of mental health. This comprehensive research initiative can potentially contribute to the advancement of our understanding of depression in a professional context; illuminating the ways to foster healthier; more supportive; and more productive workplaces.
Skills: A successful candidate will be able to follow specific instructions to search scientific databases; read academic articles; and summarize them using a template. The candidate must have good time management skills; personal accountability; and be able to communicate effectively with the PI.

Name: Enhancing the recovery of critical metals
Description: indium and germanium
Host Province: Indium (In) and germanium (Ge) are technologically important elements with applications in electronics; solar cells; power amplifiers; and catalysts. Demand for them is projected to increase by 225% and 2130%; respectively; by 2050. However; In and Ge are rare metals; found in 50-200 ppb and 1.6 ppm in the earth’s crust; with current dissipation rates of ~90% and ~99%; respectively. They are the by-products of lead (Pb) and zinc (Zn) production. It is essential to improve their recovery rates during the process; currently limited by inadequate knowledge of their thermodynamic behavior in a multi-phase and multi-element chemical system. Understanding the thermodynamic behavior of a complex process solely based on trial and error is challenging. Alternatively; the thermodynamic behavior of indium oxide (In2O3) and germanium oxide (GeO2) in the PbO-ZnO-FeOx-CaO-SiO2 (PZFCS) slag can be modeled. A dilute solution of these components in slag (typically in the order of 300-400 ppm) is of practical interest. Therefore; the assumption of the constant activity coefficients for In2O3 and GeO2; independent of composition; could be reasonable. We can assume that their behaviors conform to Henry’s law (ai=γi.xi; where ai is the activity of either In2O3 or GeO2; γi is the activity coefficient which is constant; and xi is the concentration in slag). With the advancement in the field of computational thermodynamics; it is possible to add In2O3 and GeO2 as dilute species to the available database (PZFCS) in the thermochemical software FactSage; and predict their thermodynamic behavior under a set of operational parameters (reduction extent equivalent to an oxygen partial pressure; temperature; flux addition). The outcomes of this project in combination with the thermodynamic behavior of In and Ge in metal and gas; already available; will enable us to better control the operational parameters to increase the recovery of In and Ge.
Skills: Either English or French
column11: Studying in the field of materials science and engineering; metallurgy; or geochemistry Knowledge of thermochemistry and thermodynamics of inorganic materials Knowledge of thermochemical software such as FactSage or Thermo-Calc is an asset Hardworking and motivated to complete a challenging capstone project with many important real-world applications Good time-management; planning; and organizational skills Good critical thinking; and problem-solving skills Good communication and teamwork skills

Name: Identification and characterization of DDX41-binding proteins by BioID and affinity pulldown
Description: DDX41 (DEAD-box helicase 41) is a member of the DEAD-box helicase family. It senses intracellular DNA in the myeloid dendritic cells and secondary messengers such as cyclic di-GMP or cyclic di-AMP to activate type I interferon immune response upon viral or bacterial infections. We recently found that DDX41 is required for cGAS-STING activation against DNA virus infection (Cell Reports: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.celrep.2022.110856). Hematological disorders like myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS) and acute myeloid leukemia (AML) have been associated with mutations in DDX41; where the most common somatic mutations is c.1574G>A; p.R525H. Recent studies have shown that DDX41 is a spliceosomal protein and it interacts with different proteins in spliceosomal C complex; and the R525H mutant alters its splicing activity owing to its altered interaction with major snRNPs like U2 and U5. Our lab has found that DDX41 displayed a dynamic protein expression pattern and sub-cellular localization under disparate stress conditions. However; the factors which regulate these dynamic changes remain unknown. Therefore; we hypothesize that the functions and sub-cellular localization of DDX41 may be regulated by its interacting proteins. To testify our hypothesis; we will use the technique of Biotin Identification (BioID) and affinity purification pulldown to identify and characterize DDX41 interacting proteins.
Skills: Background and skills in biology and life science; especially in biochemistry; molecular biology; genetics; and medical science.

Name: Role of DDX41 in P-bodies Assembly and its Connection to MDS/AML
Description: DDX41 is a DEAD-box helicase and acts as an intracellular DNA sensor for type I interferon production in vertebrates upon virial infection. Mutations in DDX41 cause myelodysplastic syndromes (MDS) and acute myeloid leukemia (AML). DDX41 point mutation R525H is the most frequently identified patient mutation. Processing bodies (P-bodies) are membraneless organelles formed by ribonucleoprotein aggregates located in the cytoplasm. P-bodies play an important role in mRNA storage; mRNA decay; and translation repression. We recently found that DDX41 is required for cGAS-STING pathways for type I interferon production; which dysregulation leads to MDS/AML (Cell Reports: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.celrep.2022.110856). In addition; we found that there is reduced P-bodies formation in DDX41 knockout cells; indicating DDX41 is required for P-bodies assembly; however; the molecular mechanism remains unknown. We hypothesize that DDX41 is essential for P-body assembly and failure of P-body assembly might lead to MDS/AML. To test this; using DDX41 CRISPR knockout cell line (compared with wild type); we will challenge the cells with poly (dA:dT) (a DNA mimics); sodium arsenite (oxidative stress); and herpes simplex virus (HSV-1); then examine EDC4; 4E-T; and LSM14A's expressing by qPCR (mRNA level) and Western blot (protein level). Because EDC4; 4E-T; and LSM14A bind to each other; and this complex is pivotal for P-bodies formation; we will determine the EDC4; 4E-T; and LSM14A interactions by Co-immunoprecipitation (co-IP). Lastly; we will reconstitute DDX41 knockout cells with DDX41-R525H mutant (compared with DDX41-WT) and examine the status of P-bodies formation.
Skills: Background and skills in biology and life science; especially in biochemistry; molecular biology; genetics; and medical science.

Name: Identifying Synthetic Lethality Targets in DDX41-mutated MDS/AML
Description: DDX41 is a DEAD-box helicase. Mutations in DDX41 cause myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS) and acute myeloid leukemia (AML) and the missense mutation R525H is found in over 70% of affected patients. MDS/AML typically occurs in the ageing population but can also occur in younger individuals due to inherited mutations; including DDX41. Direct targeting DDX41 is challenging because DDX41 is one of the 37 DEAD-box helicases in humans that share a similar structure. Synthetic lethality (SL) represents an effective strategy instead of direct targeting. Two genes are said to exhibit SL interaction; if the loss of function of both these genes affects cellular viability; while neither has any effect on their own. Collaborating with Dr. Franco Vizeacoumar’s group; we have used bioinformatic analyses and identified several potential SL interactions of DDX41. Using DDX41 knockout cell lines that we established (Singh et al.; 2022); we validated some potential SL candidates by shRNA knockdown and drug inhibitors. In this project; we will continue to use cell-based assays to validate the SL hits generated by computational methods. Second; we will use a pooled CRISPR/Cas9 screen to identify SL interactions of DDX41. Third; combining computational analysis and CRISPR screening; we will choose and validate some hits in cell-based and mouse models of DDX41-mutated MDS/AML. Our success in this proposal will significantly improve the treatment and survival of MDS/AML patients by identifying novel targets for DDX41 mutated blood cancers.
Skills: Background and skills in biology and life science; especially in biochemistry; molecular biology; genetics; and medical science.

Name: Derivation and Implementation of an Orbital Localization Method
Description: Molecular orbital theory usually produces delocalized molecular orbitals. Some applications of quantum chemistry require orbitals that are maximally localized in space. There are different ways to define and construct such orbitals. The objective of this project is to derive; implement; and test a new orbital localization procedure that is based on our recent insight into the relationship between the the exchange energy and orbital locality.
Skills: The project is intended for students interested in scientific computing. The most important skills include calculus; linear algebra; and working experience with at least one programming language.

Name: iMobilité : un outil d'aide à la navigation intérieur
Description: Les personnes qui présentent des incapacités (motrices; sensorielles; intellectuelles ou cognitives) peuvent être amenés à vivre différentes situations de handicap en lien avec la mobilité; notamment dans les édifices publics. Aucun établissement du réseau de la santé ne dispose actuellement d'un système d'orientation intérieure permettant aux usagers de s'orienter de manière intuitive; en temps réel; pouvant ainsi contribuer à la prévention de la transmission de maladies infectieuses en déterminant des itinéraires personnalisés à l'intérieur des établissement. En étroite collaboration avec les groupes de travail responsables des plans d'action en matière d'accessibilité à l'égard des personnes handicapées au sein de leur établissement; un prototype de système intuitif de repérage et de navigation intérieur utilisant l'intelligence artificielle (IA) pour se positionner; s'orienter et naviguer en temps réel sera déployé. Son utilisabilité sera validé auprès des groupes cibles : personnes de tous âges ayant des incapacités motrices; sensorielles; intellectuelles et cognitives. Découlant de ces test; nous proposerons un guide de conception universelle de systèmes de signalisation intérieure; bornes d’inscription; d’orientation. Une approche partenariale et participative centrée sur l’utilisateur potentiel sera adoptée. Ainsi; un comité de suivi composé de chercheurs; de représentants des milieux preneurs et des milieux utilisateurs sera constitué. Il aura pour mandat de s’assurer que les livrables du projet faciliteront l’accès aux services de leurs établissements et feront les liens avec d’autres comités d’action à l’égard des personnes handicapées. Soixante usagers potentiels participeront à la phase de conception et 30 aux tests d'utilisabilité pour lesquels un ou une stagiaire est recherché.
Skills: - Capacité de travailler en équipe. - Capacité d'interagir avec des personnes qui présentent des incapacités variées. - Intérêt pour la recherche dite "clinique" - Bonne capacité de rédaction et de communication orale. - Capacité de mener des analyses qualitative est un atout - Bilinguisme (anglais-français) un atout.
Student academic background: Engg-Biomedical; Engg-Mechanical; Rehabilitation Medicine; City/Regional Planning; Public Health; Humanities; Medical Sciences

Name: Amysoft : une application de gestion des risques associés aux plaies de pression chez les utilisateurs de fauteuil roulant
Description: L’objectif du projet proposé consiste à développer et évaluer une application (Amysoft) qui permettra de gérer les risques associés aux plaies de pression découlant d’une posture assise prolongée. L’apparition de plaies de pression chez les utilisateurs de fauteuil roulant engendre des problématiques de santé importante ainsi que des coûts considérables pour le réseau de la santé et des services sociaux. Ce projet collaboratif; réalisé avec le Réseau d’évaluation et de l’Innovation en santé durable (REIS-D)ainsi que du programme des aides techniques à la mobilité du CIUSSS de la Capitale-Nationale; permettra de proposer une solution répondant aux préoccupations et exigences des utilisateurs de fauteuil roulant ainsi que des professionnels de la santé des aidants. Par l’atteinte de cet objectif; l'entreprise du secteur des technologies médicales et des technologies de la santé avec laquelle nous collaborons pourra avoir bonifier son accès au marché en réalisant d’importants jalons technologiques et cliniques de son plan de R&D. En s’associant au REIS-D et au milieu clinique du CIUSSS de la Capitale-Nationale; nous accélèrerons le développement de notre application Amysoft en répondant à des besoins cliniques et évaluatifs qui sont requis pour le développement de celle-ci et pour son cheminement vers la commercialisation. Plus spécifiquement; ce projet permettra de : • Élaborer une échelle d’évaluation clinique des facteurs de risque liés à l’apparition de plaies de pression • Élaborer un protocole générique de prévention et de traitement conforme au niveau de risque individuel d’apparition ou de traitement de plaies • Évaluer l’utilisabilité (efficacité et satisfaction) clinique de l’application • Proposer des améliorations de contenu et techniques à l’application proposée
Skills: - Capacité de travailler en équipe. - Capacité d'interagir avec des personnes qui présentent des incapacités variées. - Intérêt pour la recherche dite "clinique" - Intérêt pour les technologies en santé - Bonne capacité de rédaction et de communication orale. - Capacité de mener des analyses qualitative est un atout - Bilinguisme (anglais-français) un atout.

Name: Analog and Mixed-Signal Integrated Circuits Design
Description: This project focuses on analog and mixed-signal integrated circuit (IC) design. We aim to explore and develop novel techniques and designs for high-performance and energy-efficient ICs in the analog and mixed-signal domain. The potential research topics for the summer include the design of integrated circuits (ICs) for various applications; such as analog-to-digital converters (ADCs); digital-to-analog converters (DACs); low noise instrumentation amplifiers; clocking circuits; and power management circuits. These topics offer exciting opportunities to delve into the design and optimization of ICs that play critical roles in different electronic systems and devices. This summer research opportunity offers a valuable learning experience in the field of analog and mixed-signal IC design; providing you with practical skills and knowledge that are highly sought after in the industry and academia. By the end of the project; you will have acquired a comprehensive understanding of the design process and simulation techniques using Cadence; preparing you for future endeavors in the field of IC design.
Skills: 1. Solid knowledge background in analog electronics and digital signal processing 2. Experience in IC design and simulation 3. Familiar with EDA tools (e.g.; Cadence)

Name: Machine Learning and Interaction of very Large Dataset of Medical Images
Description: Medical Images can be particularly overwhelming to analyze; despite their crucial importance to relate one patient with another. Having the capacity to find similar images provides vital information to clinicians in evaluating diagnostics and specific risks in new patients. This is where Machine Learning techniques come into play. This internship aims at developing a state-of-the-art solution for the analysis of very large datasets of medical images. You will learn about modern machine learning methods and use innovative medical image analysis techniques to build a new analytics platform in medical imaging. ETS Montreal is the Youngest and Fastest-Growing University in Montreal. It offers a thriving research environment to conduct state-of-the-art research in multiple areas; including Machine Learning; Computer Vision and Medical Image Analysis. You will be welcome in a brand new team on Shape and Data Analysis in Medical Imaging; with ample opportunities to collaborate with the best teams in North America and Europe. Located in vibrant Montreal; you will experience a unique blend of North American and European culture with one of the lowest cost of living on the continent.
Skills: The candidate should have strong computer programming skills; and adequate algorithmic and mathematical skills; all necessary to improve his creativity in designing new machine learning and computer vision algorithms.

Name: Architecture as spatial and social fabric: Japanese perspectives to promote multi-scale relationships
Description: Tokyo is the emblem of a city that has become denser over time. Faced with multiple opportunities and challenges; this metropolis has always been a pioneer in exploring new solutions for high-density housing. In recent years; cases of social isolation and confinement have rapidly increased due to the densification and change of lifestyle towards the individualization of society; in Japan as elsewhere. As a response to this trend; new architectural concepts have been created and tested for individual home improvement. The objective is to understand which architectural elements promote social interaction through the socio-spatial analysis of four dwellings designed for single people.
Skills: Students need to be knowledgeable of qualitative analysis (i.e. ethnographic methods such as participant observation; interviews; and archival research or others) or qualitative data analysis software (like Nvivo) or Japanese studies research or Asian studies research or Japanese language.
Student academic background: Architecture; Anthropology; Asian Studies; Cultural Studies; East Asian Studies; Japanese Language; Japanese Studies

Name: Utilisation de la méthode de Lattice Boltzmann pour la prédiction numérique de l’orientation des fibres dans le béton fluide
Description: Le projet de recherche vise à développer une interface de modélisation 3D sous Python pour la modélisation de l’écoulement fluide de béton fibré en utilisant la méthode de Lattice Botzmann (LBM).
