Cette méthode est de plus en plus utilisée en mécanique des fluides; et se distingue par rapport aux méthodes CFD conventionnelles utilisant les équations de Navier-Stokes (Éléments finis et volumes finis) par le fait qu’elle est basée sur des particules et ne nécessite donc pas de maillage. Les méthodes particulaires sont développées depuis plusieurs décennies et commencent à émerger récemment pour des applications industrielles complexes. Parmi elles; la méthode Lattice-Boltzmann (LBM) qui résout bon nombre des inconvénients présentés par les méthodes CFD traditionnelles : le processus de maillage est supprimé car la simulation repose sur une génération automatique de treillis; la formulation mathématique de l'équation de transport de Boltzmann est naturellement simple à résoudre numériquement et se prête bien au calcul parallèle impliquant des centaines de mini-cœurs GPU. Ce projet Mitacs s’insère dans un cadre plus global qui vise la modélisation du comportement mécanique des éléments en béton fibré et l’optimisation des séquences de coulée pour une performance optimale. Le comportement mécanique de ces éléments utilisant ce nouveau matériau performant est très dépendant de l’orientation des fibres lors de la phase de coulée. Ce projet initiateur peut être décomposé en quatre phases : (i) revue de littérature des méthodes numériques en CFD et compréhension de l’algorithme de la méthode LBM; (ii) programmation de la méthode LBM pour un environnement de calcul 3D parallèle; en utilisant l’environnement adapté du langage Python; (iii) vérification et validation utilisant des benchmarks de la littérature; (iv) introduction des fibres métalliques dans la modélisation.
Skills: Les connaissances de base en génie sont requises; en particulier : Mathématiques et analyse numérique; mécanique des fluides; mécanique des structures. Les connaissances suivantes sont très recommandées : connaissances de la méthode des éléments finis avec ses formulations lagrangiennes et eulériennes; programmation sous Python; programmation des interfaces 3D de pré et post-traitement de modèles 3D; parallélisme et calcul haute performance. Les compétences recherchées : excellente capacité de communication en Français; autonomie; bonne capacité d’apprentissage de nouvelles connaissances et de résolution de problèmes numériques/mathématiques; à l’aise avec la lecture des références scientifiques en anglais.

Name: Efficient Network Architecture Search for Visual Recognition
Description: This research project aims at improving the computational efficiency of network architecture search (NAS). Deep networks such as convolutional and recurrent neural networks have shown impressive results in the last years; sometimes even reaching human level performance. However; these approaches require the manual tuning of many hyper-parameters (e.g. number of layers; type of activation function; number of neurons; etc..); which can require a brute-force optimization and/or human expertise. To overcome the manual tuning of hyper-parameters; NAS aims to find techniques to automatically discover the optimal configuration of such networks. The main drawback of such approach is the exponential large number of configurations that should considered and therefore the computational cost required to automatically optimize the networks hyper-parameters. In this project we aim at reducing the computational cost of NAS. Recently; some methods have shown that some of the hyper-parameters are differentiable (or can formulated in a differentiable way) and therefore their optimization can be speeded-up by using gradient based approaches. In this project we will further investigate those approaches; by analyzing in which conditions they can provide good results and extending the range of hyper-parameters that can be optimized with this methodology. The proposed method will be evaluated in terms of the classification accuracy of the found architectures as well as computational cost on standard computer vision datasets such as CIFAR10 and ImageNet. In case of positive results; the work will be submitted to a peer-reviewed conference article or a journal in the field.
Skills: - Strong mathematical background - Strong programming (possibly Python and pytorch) and algorithm development skills - Knowledge and previous experience on basic Deep Learning and Computer VIsion algorithms - Ability to collaborate in a project with other students

Name: Creating Autonomous Driving Systems
Description: Autonomous driving systems are a complex; up and coming technology. Through this project the student will be a part of the development and evolution of an autonomous driving platform and will learn about the various subsystems involved in a complete autonomous driving pipeline. These subsystems include: - the hardware platform and the operating system - the algorithms used for answering the important questions for an autonomous vehicle: where am I (localization); what is going on around me (perception); and what is the course of action I need to take and how will I take it (planning and control) - the cloud platform: simulating the system offline; storing data; mapping surroundings; and training deep learning models As part of the project; the student will be exposed to working with industry sensors for autonomous driving including high accuracy GPS/IMU systems; LIDARS; radars; and cameras. They will become familiar with different representations of autonomous driving data and how to extract meaningful information from the raw data in order to understand the surrounding environment and make the decisions about driving actions. They will also learn how to combine data from different sensors together and how to correlate what one sensor can observe with a completely different type of sensor.
Skills: - Experience building software systems; prefarably with C++ or Python; and adaptable to new technologies - Project experience using operating systems for robotics such as ROS - Familiarity with robotics sensor based systems such as calibration; interfacing; data capture; coordinate transformations; etc. - Working experience in the Linux environment and using source control - Data driven approach to problem solving with high attention to detail - Team player with strong communication and collaboration skills - Experience with any of the following is a bonus: OpenCV; PCL; TensorFlow; CUDA; Prescan; ROS 2.

Name: Exploiting Traffic Accident Data for Optimal Emergency Vehicles Routing Strategy
Description: High-density cities face a high risk of traffic accidents; posing a threat to vehicle occupants; cyclists; and pedestrians. Efficient response times from emergency services are crucial in such situations. Openly available traffic accident data in Canadian cities has been utilized to develop predictive models that enhance city safety measures; including speed limit reductions and infrastructure modifications. However; this data can also be leveraged to anticipate accidents; thereby reducing emergency service response times. This research proposal aims to devise a patrol strategy for emergency vehicles by utilizing publicly available traffic accident data. By analyzing accident data from cities like Halifax; which includes accident time and location; researchers can investigate the spatial and temporal distribution of accidents and construct a predictive model. Subsequently; a routing strategy can be developed using this model to position emergency vehicles in close proximity to accident locations as they occur. Integrating traffic accident data into patrol strategies has the potential to significantly reduce emergency response times and minimize the occurrence of fatal accidents. The proposed research focuses on developing an optimal routing strategy based on open traffic accident data to minimize emergency vehicle response times in urban environments. The Dynamic Travel Repairman Problem (DTRP) is a mathematical model suitable for dynamic routing problems where the objective is to minimize service wait times in environments with dynamically generated tasks. In this context; tasks represent accidents requiring emergency services; and the probability distribution of accidents can be derived from real data. Utilizing open-access traffic accident data from major Canadian cities like Halifax and Toronto; a realistic DTRP model will be created. Similar to previous works; Deep Reinforcement Learning (DRL) can be employed to solve DTRPs by learning an optimal strategy.
Skills: We are seeking a motivated student with a background in data structures; machine learning/AI; and data analysis science for our summer research project. The ideal candidate should have a solid understanding of data structures; and be able to implement and manipulate them effectively. Understanding of machine learning and AI concepts is crucial and any experience with popular libraries like PyTorch is a plus. The candidate should be proficient in statistical analysis; data visualization; and exploratory data analysis using Python. Although not required; familiarity with reinforcement learning (RL) is an asset.

Name: Learning and Evolution of Gene Networks
Description: There are multiple new computational tools inspired by machine learning allowing to efficiently and deterministically explore the dynamics of complex; non-linear systems. The goal of the project will be to leverage such tools to recast and study evolution itself; elaborating on our work on computational evolution and coarse-graining of gene networks (see e.g. the phi-evo software https://journals.plos.org/ploscompbiol/article?id=10.1371/journal.pcbi.1006244 ). We will encode formal models of evolving gene networks; and then study the dynamics of evolution. Is evolution funneled ? Is stochasticity needed ? Can we describe evolution as motions in a well-defined landscape ? We will study problems ranging from immunology to developmental biology.
Skills: Students should have formal training in either physics or computer science; and some practical knowledge of machine learning algorithms and concepts (dimensional reduction; neural networks; etc...). Students should also have a strong interest in biology.

Name: TRuST Research Network
Description: We have several research projects students may work on; depending on their areas of interest and expertise; and will be assigned as skills and interest are aligned. Research projects include collecting survey responses from participants about subjects related to trust in science and technology; qualitative research including online data collection and/or interviewing subject; and building measures of trust for pre- and post- intervention evaluation. The methods drawn on for this research include those in the social sciences (including psychology) and humanities (including communication studies; English for Specific Purposes/genre studies.
Skills: Interest in learning about and conducting research is required. Previous research experience is an asset but not required. Ability to learn new software applications important. Ability to write into academic genres such as reports and research outputs and also ability to communicate through presentations to research team and possibly wider audiences. Willingness to work in team-oriented environment crucial. Background in communication; language studies; rhetoric; psychology; sociology; etc.; advantageous; but also looking for students with an interest in the concept of trust from across the disciplines.
Student academic background: Business; Canadian Studies; Communication; Classics; Computer Science; Cultural Studies; Design; Earth Science; Economics; Education; Engineering; English Literature; Environmental Studies; Geography; Genetics; Geology; Humanities; Immunology; Journalism; Linguistics; Media Studies; Philosophy; Psychology; Public Health; Public Policy and Administration; Public Relations; Science and Technology; Sociology; Studies Science and Technology; Marketing; Native Studies; Womens Studies; Library Studies

Name: Climate Change Communication
Description: This research investigates the persuasive techniques and communication strategies of people discussing and debating climate change and climate action in Canada. Questions emerging from this research also include how experts can more effectively communicate about science; health; and technical matters; what sources are trusted authorities; and how to combat misinformation and disinformation. This study investigates persuasive techniques and communication technologies for addressing anthropogenic climate change and climate action in order to advance communication strategies related to climate change risk; mitigation; and resilience. This will be accomplished by carrying out the following three short-term objectives: 1) cataloguing how participants communicate about climate change; including identifying rhetorical strategies participants have employed while persuading skeptical individuals; 2) investigating how experts in climate-impacted fields communicate research and coordinate social action; and 3) developing a simulation game and a “rhetorical toolbox” of resources that will be used to increase awareness of climate change and climate action options.
Skills: Interest in learning about and conducting research is required. Previous research experience is an asset but not required. Ability to learn new software applications important. Willingness to work in team-oriented environment crucial. Background in communication; language studies; rhetoric/composition; psychology; sociology; environment; etc.; advantageous; but also looking for students with an interest in communication problems across the disciplines (previous hires in the Demos Lab have included engineering students and science students).

Name: Integrating emotions into the design process
Description: The main topic of this research project is emotional design. To be more precise; the goal is to integrate emotional design in a computer-aided design software. By doing this; the software can help users to include different style and/or shapes in their design in order to improve the consumers’ experiences. To do this; it is first needed to associate styles and shapes to emotions. Hence; the project is to develop a methodology and implement a code to do this association.
Skills: Computer science; software engineering; emotional design (asset); test-driven development (asset)

Name: Génération d’une base de données historicisées SQL à partir d’un modèle temporel
Description: Les données relatives à la santé d’une personne existent dans plusieurs sources internes à un même établissement (service de radiologie; service d’urgence; laboratoire; etc.) ou externes (pharmacie; soins à domicile; cabinet du médecin de famille; objets connectés; etc.). À la dispersion des données dans de nombreuses sources peu; mal ou pas interconnectées s’ajoutent le problème d’interopérabilité et celui du suivi de l’évolution des données. L’exploration des données historicisées présente un potentiel important pour comprendre et interpréter divers phénomènes en santé et leur évolution dans le temps. Une base de données historicisée requiert l’application de règles systématiques afin de garantir l’intégrité et la qualité des données. Plusieurs modèles temporels existent; mais rares sont ceux qui ont été efficacement mis en œuvre directement dans une base de données relationnelle et évalués en termes d’expressivité et de performance. Le projet consiste à : 1. élaborer les règles d’équivalences entre le composant du modèle temporel et les composants SQL ; 2. concevoir et mettre en œuvre d’un outil de génération de code SQL performant à partir d’un modèle temporel ; 3. évaluer l’outil avec un cas d’étude.
Skills: Les connaissances/compétences suivantes sont un atout : * Programmation : SQL; Java; StringTemplate; JooQ; Gradle * Outils : PostgreSQL; MariaDB; MSSQL; Teradata; DataGrip; Git

Name: Arrimage des bases de données relationnelles à l’aide d’ontologies
Description: Les données relatives à la santé d’une personne existent dans plusieurs sources internes à un même établissement (service de radiologie; service d’urgence; laboratoire; etc.) ou externes (pharmacie; soins à domicile; cabinet du médecin de famille; objets connectés; etc.). À la dispersion des données dans de nombreuses sources peu; mal ou pas interconnectées s’ajoutent le problème d’interopérabilité et celui du suivi de l’évolution des données. Pour assister les cliniciennes-chercheuses et les cliniciens-chercheurs; de même que les gestionnaires face à l’augmentation du nombre d’intervenants et de la variété de données générées; il est indispensable de mettre à leur disposition une vue unifiée; temporalisée et annotée sémantiquement à différents niveaux de granularité. Cependant; la transformation de l’annotation de ces données est un défi majeur par manque de procédure standardisée et d’outils informatiques qui favorisent la réutilisation et la maintenance à long terme. Le projet consiste à : 1. apprendre les méthodes existantes sur la transformation de bases de données relationnelles vers une ontologie ; 2. mettre en place un arrimage en utilisant une ontologie et une base de données à l’aide d’un outil d’arrimage ; 3. évaluer l’outil avec un cas d’étude.
Skills: Les connaissances/compétences suivantes sont un atout : * Programmation : SQL; OWL/RDF; Java; Gradle * Outils : PostgreSQL; Virtuoso; GraphDB; DataGrip. Git
Student academic background: Information Studies; Engg-Computer; Computer Science; Management Information Systems

Name: Genome editing to study microtubules and MAPs
Description: The goal is to create CRISPR-Cas9 mediated knock-ins and knock-outs of MAPs in human cell lines as well as analysis of these cells using molecular biology techniques and microscopy.
Skills: Strong theoretical background in genome editing and cell culture. Ideally; hands-on lab experience.

Name: Characterization of protein-microtubule interactions
Description: The project will explore the biochemistry and biophysics of microtubule-associated proteins (MAPs) using single-molecule TIRF microscopy and biochemical protein characterization techniques. Training will be provided in various protein biochemistry and microscopy techniques. The MAPs we are working on are involved in cell division and neuronal function with implications in cancer and neurodegenerative diseases.
Skills: Strong theoretical background in protein biochemistry and microscopy. Ideally; hands-on lab experience.

Name: mechanism of action of Srcap mutations in neurodevelopmental disorders
Description: Srcap is the ATPase subunit of a chromatin remodelling complex whose activity is mainly restricted to the deposition of histone variant H2A.Z into nucleosomes thus regulating gene expression. However; Srcap can regulate transcription also through the recruitment of Crab binding protein (Cbp) and DNA methylation machinery. Numerous mutations have been identified in Srcap in patients suffering from different neurodevelopmental disorders including autism; floating harbor syndrome; and schizophrenia. Yet; how different mutations in the same protein cause different diseases has not been addressed. We will use CRISPR/Cas9 to generate human induced pluripotent stem cells (hIPSC) carrying different mutations of Srcap. The selected mutations impact 3 different protein domain; hence we expect different outcomes. We will investigate how different Srcap mutations affect the protein ability to: - Incorporate H2A.Z into nucleosomes - Recruit Cbp -induce changes in DNA methylation Specifically; we will use CUT&Tag; a variation of ChIP-sequencing; to screen for H2A.Z deposition and Cbp recruitment. This approach will allow us not only to investigate if there is an impairment in these mechanisms but also to screen which genes/genomic loci are affected. We will use Methyl-seq to screen for changes in DNA methylation. These tests will be followed by RNA-sequencing to profile how impairment in Srcap functions affects gene expression. We will then differentiate hIPSC in neurons and repeat the same screening to understand how Srcap mutations can cause neurodevelopmental disorders.
Skills: Background in cell culture and sterile techniques is a plus but not required. Deep knowledge of molecular biology and basis of epigenetics will be taken into account.

Name: Spinal Cord Damage Modeling
Description: Traumatic spinal cord injuries are severe injuries. While they are not the most frequent injuries; they are amongst the most debilitating and they lead to drastic changes in patients’ independence and quality of life. The spinal cord is a difficult structure to test mechanically due to its anatomical complexity; its softness; anisotropy and viscosity and the fact that it quickly degenerates after death. Finite element modeling has been used in the recent years to advance our knowledge on the biomechanical behaviour of the spinal cord. However; there is still no accepted injury criteria; i.e. a parameter able to discriminate between a not-injurious and an injurious mechanical load for the spinal cord. This limits our ability to assess neurological deficits probability using numerical simulations. In our research group; we have developed a simplified model of the spinal cord including different structures of the central nervous system (cerebrospinal fluid; spinal cord; pia mater and dura mater) showing good results in contusion. However; to our knowledge no paper has been published to propose a damage model for the spinal cord. Not including damage models in dynamic and traumatic simulations restricts the model validity range to spinal cord deformation remaining under the damage threshold which significantly limits its context of use. Furthermore; since the spinal cord is an extremely soft structure; not including damage model may lead to numerical instabilities. That is why the present project proposes to include damage simulation in a previously developed simplified spinal cord model. Repercussions of this project include improvement of numerical modeling of spinal cord injury which will enable to better understand the injury mechanisms of spinal cord injury and ultimately to improve patients’ treatments and patients’ injury assessment using personalized models.
Skills: The student must be part of a mechanical or biomedical engineering program or a similar program. The student will need a good background in structural mechanics or biomechanics. Having priorly performed finite element modeling is an asset as well as knowledge of tissue biology and spine anatomy. The student also needs to be autonomous; curious; rigorous and strongly interested in the subject. A good capacity to read and write in English is important.

Name: Positive psychology in consumer behaviour: Fostering positive emotions and strong relationships in the marketplace
Description: I am seeking a student to help with a variety of research-related projects over the summer; with one "core" project; described below. In many of my experiments; I ask people to try to find something that amuses them or makes them happy every day and to take a picture of it. I initially collected these images just to make sure participants did the task as instructed. But now; I am looking for a student who is interested in learning image analysis techniques to help me analyze these photos. Knowing what type of stimuli elicit emotions is important for understanding the role an emotion (like amusement) plays in our lives. Prior research on amusement has largely shown participants images; and asked them to classify the images as humorous or not. Although this technique allows us to get a basic idea of what types of stimuli elicit humor; it is constrained by the images the researchers decide to display. For (ridiculous) example; it's possible that everyone finds lemons hilarious; but researchers have never shown participants a photo of a lemon. It is therefore more powerful to allow participants to generate their own content; and annotate it. The student and I will work together to learn machine learning techniques for semi-supervised image classification. We will have help of a co-author who specializes in these techniques. Most of the students time will be taken up learning these image analysis techniques and applying them to my data. However; other research needs may arise during the summer. These would be for my other projects in the vein of consumer relationships and positive emotions. Smaller tasks could include: proofreading manuscripts (including double-checking statistics); hand-annotating text data; mocking up surveys in Qualtrics; and helping me collect data for in-person studies.
Skills: REQUIRED -- The student must have taken at least one statistics course; and must be comfortable interpreting statistical tests NICE-TO-HAVE -- Familiarity with a coding language like R or Python -- The student should be interested in developing machine learning skills; whether for a future academic or corporate career -- A student who has completed some RA work in a psychology or marketing lab in the past

Name: Plant ecology and restoration of metal-contaminated wetlands in Sudbury
Description: Ontario
Faculty supervisor: Sudbury; Ontario is one of the world's largest metal mining centres; and historically has been the largest global point source of sulphur dioxide and metal particulate pollution from copper and nickel mining. We aim to develop novel restoration techniques to address the impacts of industrial contamination on peatlands. Peatlands are terrestrial wetlands that play a vital role in combatting global climate change by acting as long-term carbon sinks. Currently there are no methods for restoring metal-contaminated peatlands. This proposed research will contribute to novel restoration techniques with the larger goal of achieving net zero carbon within the region; and broadly in Canadian mining-impacted landscapes. The research project combines techniques and expertise in hydrology; biogeochemistry; plant; soil and microbial biology. This position is part of the plant biology research team led by Dr. Ellie Goud; and will determine impacts of metal contamination on plant growth and physiology in order to inform restoration trials. The 2024 field season from May – August will involve extensive field studies to measure plant physiological and morphological traits in key species in peatlands sites with increasing levels of metal and sulphur contamination. A major area of investigation involves understanding physiological thresholds and species interactions between the moss and shrub plant communities.
Student academic background: This is a field assistant position; and the student will be spending a lot of their time outdoors conducting field measurements. Training in specific field and lab skills will be provided for the student; including plant species identification; plant trait measurements; soil and water sampling and analyses. A background in ecology; plant biology; ecological or environmental chemistry; soil science or a related field is required. Field work experience; lab experience; or hobbies that involve outdoor activities are an asset. We are looking for someone who is excited about ecological research and being outdoors; who works well in a team; and
column11: Biology; Botany; Ecology; Soil Science

Name: Plant responses to multiple interacting stressors: water-use traits as precursors to ecological transitions
Description: One challenge that all terrestrial plants face is how to gain carbon for photosynthesis without losing too much water. This arises from the fact that as carbon dioxide diffuses into leaves; water vapor simultaneously diffuses out; resulting in a tradeoff between carbon gain and water loss. This tradeoff is a major evolutionary driver of plant diversity and adaptations to variable environments. The ability to tolerate a stress like water limitation can pre-adapt an organism to other stresses; possibly enabling transitions into new environments. This project will test hypotheses on the mechanisms underlying ecological shifts between water-limited and other harsh environments; including adaptations to acidity and salinity. Our study system is the Ericaceae (heath) family - a broadly diverse; globally distributed plant family ranging from parasitic herbs to large broad-leaf trees. Ericaceae species grow in tropical forests to arctic tundra; including extreme acidic; water-limited; and saline habitats. Ericaceae species are so often associated with stressful environments that a whole group of ecosystems are named after them: heathlands. Heathlands are characterized by multiple environmental stressors (acidic; nutrient-limited); and dominated by Ericaceae species (e.g.; heather; blueberries; rhododendrons). To test mechanisms that may have facilitated ecological shifts from water-limited to other harsh environments; we will conduct field surveys and measure plant traits related to water-use and other stress tolerances (e.g.; leaf and root morphology; chemistry; stable isotopes; gas exchange) in Ericaceae species from Nova Scotia heathlands that vary in moisture; soil texture (e.g.; sand; organic; rock); and chemistry (e.g.; pH; salinity; nutrients). Detailed soil measurements will link environmental variables to trait variation and identify potential shared mechanisms within a comparative phylogenetic context.
Skills: Training in specific field and lab skills will be provided for the student; including plant species identification; vegetation surveys; plant trait measurements; soil and water sampling; chemical extractions; and stable isotope analyses. A background in ecology; plant biology; ecological or environmental chemistry; soil science or a related field is required. Field work experience; lab experience; or hobbies that involve outdoor activities are an asset. We are looking for someone who excited about ecological research; is capable of working in a team and independently; with strong organizational and time management skills.

Name: Conversion of waste plastic
Description: Canada has set a target to be net zero in carbon emissions by 2050. To achieve this target requires the development of multiple technologies that make the best use of the materials available. Millions of tonnes of waste plastic have accumulated in Canada. This waste is actually a resource that can be converted to hydrogen through thermo-chemical treatment. Small scale processes are needed for remote communities for whom the transportation of goods is expensive and where the environmental impact of waste and greenhouse gas emissions (i.e.; CO2) is most adverse. Instead of adding to a landfill; community plastic waste can be converted onsite to a clean; zero emission (at point of use) fuel hydrogen with the byproduct carbon used as an absorbent for water treatment or as a soil additive to enhance moisture retention. Two of the challenges with using waste material are the diversity of the composition (there are many different types of plastics that are discarded in different quantities week to week); and the impact of plastic additives. These additives flame retardants; pigments; antistatic agents; thermal stabilizers impart positive properties to the plastic and although present in small amounts (less than a few percent); they may negatively impact the conversion of the plastic. In this project appropriate catalysts will be developed; which will maximize the hydrogen yields and produce solid carbon with the desired properties.
Skills: The student requires a strong knowledge of chemical engineering fundamentals including kinetics and thermodynamics; careful experimental skills with an attention to detail and proper safety requirements; good oral and written communication skills; an ability to critically assess results including those in the literature; and a passion for research. While the student will be part of a group; they should be able to take initiative to move the project forward.

Name: Urban Regeneration Revisited: Micro-scale Residential Neighborhood Rehabilitation in China
Description: This research probes several research questions regarding the temporal and spatial patterns of micro-scale urban renewal and the interactions between local state and non-state interests in the micro-scale old residential neighborhood rehabilitation. (1) How has the ideology of sustainable urban renewal promoted by the central government been grounded on local old residential neighborhood rehabilitation? (2) How have the local state’s spatial selectivity strategy and the market logic in urban renewal imposed their influence on community engagement and socioeconomic sustainability in micro-scale old residential neighborhood rehabilitation? (3) How does the practice of micro-scale old residential neighborhood rehabilitation involve communities and residents; address property rights complexity; and serve local economic interests? The project will contribute to a systematic investigation of how China’s state-orchestrated old residential neighborhood rehabilitation under the rhetoric of micro-scale intervention; community empowerment; and urban sustainability has influenced residents’ socioeconomic circumstances; livelihood; and community wellbeing in residential neighborhood renewal. It will advance our understanding of the socioeconomic transformation processes and consequences of affected residents during and after the implementation of micro-scale old residential neighborhood rehabilitation. Theoretical insights and policy implications will be drawn regarding the main forces and consequences of state-orchestrated residential neighborhood rehabilitation and the effects of building stakeholder partnerships and advocating market integration on affected residents and local communities.
Skills: The student should be able to conduct scholarly literature review and collect relevant media reports in both English and Chinese. They are expected to write literature reviews; summaries; working reports in English and Chinese on a biweekly or monthly basis. The student should be able to conduct research document and archive searches in both Chinese and English databases. They should be able to produce diagrams; tables; figures; charts in relation to the research project.

Name: Assessing Anti-Amyloid Compounds in a Mammalian Tissue Culture System
Description: Cellular stress triggers the reversible formation of natural amyloid aggregates; which possess the same biophysical properties as the plaques observed in the brains of Alzheimer's; Parkinson's; and Huntington's disease patients (Audas; Developmental Cell; 2016). The only known regulator of this pathway is a family of noncoding RNA derived from the ribosomal DNA intergenic spacer (termed rIGSRNAs); a region of the genome traditionally viewed as transcriptionally silent junk DNA (Audas; Molecular Cell; 2016). Upon exposure to unfavorable growth conditions (e.g.; high temperature or acidosis); these noncoding RNA are induced and mediate a shift in the structure of a large family of cellular proteins; converting them from a native to amyloid state. Interestingly; the pathological Alzheimer’s beta-amyloid peptide can also convert to an amyloid conformation during this stress treatment; suggesting that these physiological and pathological aggregation pathways may be linked. The goal of this research project is to identify new cellular regulators of in vivo amyloid aggregation. A panel of targeted small molecules; which inhibit specific cellular proteins; have been recently found to possess anti-amyloid aggregation properties in our cellular setting. First; we will use fluorescence microscopy and the amyloidophilic dye Congo red to validate the efficiency of the small molecule on physiological aggregation. Second; we will explore the effects of positive compounds on the expression of the regulatory rIGSRNA transcripts; to determine if they are effecting the ncRNA regulatory axis. Third; siRNA that knockdown the novel protein targets will be purchased and assessed to further validate a link between the cellular regulator and physiological/pathological amyloid aggregation.
Skills: Interested students should have a background knowledge in molecular and cellular biology; with basic experience using common lab techniques (including RT-PCR; western blotting and electrophoresis). Some experience maintaining; transfecting and staining cultured mammalian cells would be highly beneficial.

Name: Federated learning in edge computing
Description: In the traditional machine learning (ML) approach; data collected by local nodes is uploaded to data center and being processed centrally where formidable computational resource can be exploited. However; this approach is no longer suitable for edge computing networks. Firstly; users’ data is privacy sensitive than ever. Secondly; transferring data generated by large number of nodes for processing burdens the network and becomes the bottleneck of overall performance. Thirdly; the centric-fashion involves long propagation delay and incurs unacceptable latency; which is unbearable for many applications with instantaneous decision making. Therefore; with concerns mentioned above; a natural question rises: How to train a ML model from decentralized data at resource-constrained edge node? Federated Learning (FL) is a technique that fulfills this purpose. FL is a ML setting where many nodes collaboratively train a model under the orchestration of central server (e.g. service provider) while keeping training data decentralized. However; FL also faces challenges. One major challenge is system heterogeneity. FL involves the heterogeneous participants whose local dataset; computational ability; channel condition; power level and willingness to participate may vary with each other. Given the system heterogeneity; optimal strategy for resource allocation needs be developed to maximize the efficiency of FL. Another challenge is communication cost during global model training. Compared with traditional distributed machine learning; where several computational centers are involved; FL framework is usually related to large amount of edge nodes; incurring an extremely high communication cost. Therefore; effort on reducing communication cost (e.g.; model compression) is needed to improve the efficiency. In this project; we will focus on developing cutting edge FL techniques to address these challenges.
Skills: The student is required to have some programming skill and have some background knowledge on machine learning algorithms.

Name: Développement d’un engin d’exécution pour Discipulus
Description: un langage d’exploitation de bases des données relationnelles
Faculty supervisor: L’histoire des systèmes de gestion de bases de données (SGBD) a connu plusieurs développements depuis les années soixante. Le plus important est vraisemblablement l’établissement du modèle relationnel par Codd. Après plusieurs tentatives diverses; un langage s’est imposé : SQL [ISO 9075:2016]. Au fur et à mesure des normalisations successives et à la suite de l’intégration de l’objet dans les systèmes relationnels; la définition du langage s’est complexifiée au point qu’elle comprend désormais plusieurs milliers de pages; sans pour autant être complète). Plusieurs révisions de la norme ont été réalisées; des études ont tenté de la simplifier; mais l’envergure continue à être démesurée et rend hors de portée la connaissance exhaustive et l’utilisation pratique du langage en conformité avec la norme. La situation est encore plus complexe lorsqu’on considère le grand nombre de dialectes soutenus par les principaux éditeurs de SGBD (voir par exemple : Oracle; DB2; TeraData; Hana; MS-SQL; PostgreSQL; MySQL). En pratique; le transport des programmes SQL est une tâche couteuse et complexe. L’équipe de recherche a spécifié un nouveau langage; nommé Discipulus; fondé sur le modèle relationnel et qui évite les erreurs de SQL tout en se basant sur un système de typage fort et extensible afin de répondre aux exigences des nouvelles applications. Le projet consiste à développer un engin d’exécution pour Discipulus et mettre en place des essais pour évaluer son expressivité et sa complétude.
Student academic background: Les connaissances et compétences sont un atout : Théorie relationnelle; Systèmes de bases de données relationnelles; Grammaires formelles; Compilation; Machines virtuelles.

Name: Incorporating AI for Mobile 5G
Description: Future generation wireless networks; i.e.; 5G and beyond; have to accommodate the surging growth of mobile data traffic and to support a high density of mobile users with a variety of services and applications. Meanwhile; the networks become increasingly dense; heterogeneous; decentralized; and ad hoc in nature; involving numerous and diverse network entities. As such; different objectives; e.g.; high throughput and low latency; need to be achieved in the service and resource allocation has to be designed and optimized accordingly. However; with the dynamics and uncertainty inherently existing in the wireless network environments; conventional approaches of service and resource management that require complete and perfect knowledge of the systems become inefficient or even inapplicable. Inspired by the success of machine learning in solving complicated control and decision-making problems; in this project; we focus on developing AI/machine learning-based approaches; which allow network entities to learn and build knowledge about the networks to make optimal decisions locally and independently.
Skills: The student is required to have some programming skill and have some background knowledge on mobile communications and machine learning algorithms.

Name: Évaluation et conception d’un pont en béton armé renforcé en cisaillement
Description: une étude de cas
Faculty supervisor: In North America; a large number of concrete bridges are affected by advanced degradation; particularly in Canada; where harsh climatic conditions accelerate this state of degradation due to temperature variations and the massive application of de-icing salts. Moreover; these structures are subjected to heavier loading; making it a major challenge to keep them in service safely. Maintaining these critical structures in service using rehabilitation techniques offers economic; ecological and social benefits. A number of bridges in Quebec and Canada have been shear strengthened with reinforcing bars inserted and anchored within the concrete structural sections. However; lack of knowledge about the specific behavior damaged bridged strengthened in shear can lead to inadequate and unsafe strengthening. The aim of this project is therefore to study the effect of a bridge's deterioration state on its shear resistance and on the rehabilitation method studied. The project is multi-faceted (prototyping; laboratory testing; computer modeling and analysis; structural design and verification) and can be tailored to suit the interests and skills of the applicants.
Student academic background: - Initiative; - Self-starter; - Creative; - Rigorous; - Basic knowledge of reinforced concrete structures; - Basic knowledge of structural analysis; design and modeling an asset.

Name: Uncertainty-Awareness in Autonomous Driving
Description: Autonomous vehicles (AVs) are increasingly becoming adopted and continue to be deployed in highly urban and uncertain environments. Uncertainty is present everywhere on our roads; whether it comes from multimodality in an agent’s potential future motion or measurement uncertainty from onboard sensors. Despite this; most AVs today operate agnostic to this inherent uncertainty; even though some modules of their own software stack can provide highly uncertain outputs depending on the scenario. To improve the safety and robustness of AVs as they continue to be adopted in more challenging environments; we need to develop autonomy stacks that are uncertainty-aware and can use such information to better inform the various components ultimately driving the AV. Towards this end there are several potential projects that include: investigating the role of uncertainty propagation in downstream tasks like planning; designing uncertainty-aware motion planners with safety guarantees; exploring alternative methods of uncertainty propagation and uncertainty estimation in perception and prediction; investigating methods for incorporating risk-awareness in perception; prediction; and/or planning; formulating and investigating different output representations for perception and prediction; investigating ways of making perception models adapt to new; unseen; and uncertain environments; exploring different methods for measuring performance of perception; prediction; planning; and control methods; exploring speed versus accuracy tradeoffs for deep learning models; and accelerating data delivery during deep learning model training. Through working on the project; the student will gain valuable experience in training neural networks and implementing novel deep learning pipelines and would eventually write and submit their work at a top-tier AI/Robotics conference or workshop (CVPR; NeurIPS; ICRA; etc).
Skills: Familiarity with popular deep neural architectures (CNNs; LSTMs; Transformers; etc). Strong preference for candidates who have prior experience working with autonomous vehicle software stacks.

Name: Self-supervised representation learning for event-based vision
Description: Event-based cameras have recently gained significant interest in computer vision due to their high temporal resolution; low energy consumption; and high dynamic range properties. Event-based vision has shown promising results in a variety of applications; such as object recognition; detection; tracking; depth; and optical flow estimation. However; this novel imaging modality poses unique challenges; including the need for specialized models to handle the asynchronous nature of events; and the lack of large-scale datasets. In RGB computer vision; scaling up datasets and model sizes has led to the recent breakthrough in vision foundation models. These models demonstrate strong performance and generalizability over different domains. However; we cannot replicate such success in event-based vision due to the lack of labeled datasets. Instead; we seek to train good models with self-supervised representation learning (SSRL). Through SSRL; we can learn useful event data representations; which serve as a good starting point for data-efficient fine-tuning in any downstream tasks. We might borrow ideas from SSRL in RGB images and 3D point clouds; and add event-specific designs to fit in our data. Through working on the project; the student will gain valuable experience in training neural networks and implementing novel deep learning pipelines and would eventually write and submit their work at a top-tier AI/Robotics conference or workshop (CVPR; NeurIPS; ICRA; etc).
Skills: Familiarity with popular deep neural architectures (CNNs; LSTMs; Transformers; etc); and computer vision tasks (detection; segmentation; etc). Previous experience with event-based vision is preferred but not necessary.

Name: Medical technology innovation
Description: design and development: a methodological perspective
Faculty supervisor: Canadian society; like most Western societies; is facing a significant population ageing. The resulting increase in the proportion of elderly people will have major repercussions on healthcare systems; which are already facing numerous challenges such as labor shortage. A number of hospitals are counting on the deployment of new technologies to address some of these issues. In parallel; this has been mirrored by major developments in medical technologies (medtech). However; the development of innovative medtech is complex. First; from a technical and organizational perspective; the medtechs of interest in this project are multidisciplinary products integrating mechanics; electronics; electricity; software and connectivity. On top of this; regulatory aspects must be taken into account; particularly for medical products/devices requiring approval from Health Canada; or the Food and Drug Administration in the United States. The business environment is also highly competitive; with "aggressive" intellectual property strategies. Legal aspects can also be raised in relation to data collection and recently adopted laws. The research project focuses on the development of innovative and intelligent medtech from a methodological perspective (approaches; processes; methods and tools). Indeed; there seems to be limited scientific literature on the development of "intelligent" medtech. The aim of the project is therefore to conduct a literature review on the development of innovative medical technologies; in order to identify the main approaches; processes; methods and tools discussed by the scientific community.
Student academic background: Students with a genuine interest in innovation and the application of technology to healthcare. Ideally; students should have some knowledge of product development/design; and a keen interest in the question of "how to develop healthcare innovation efficiently?". The question will be approached from a theoretical angle. The student is expected to be autonomous (weekly meetings); to be able to conduct a literature review and to have excellent synthesis skills.

Name: Adapting data from diverse robotic embodiments for fast robot learning
Description: Massive datasets (such as the combined text of most internet websites) have enabled impressive breakthroughs in approaches such as language modeling in the last year. In robotics; however; obtaining data is often expensive and slow; and existing data is tied to specific robotic hardware (often called the embodiment). In this project; we want to solve this problem by understanding how data gathered from different robotic embodiments can be used to speed up learning for a new robot in a new environment. The core goal (and challenge) is to learn dynamics models or imitation policies from existing data and transferring those to a brand new situation. Data from other embodiments can take many forms; so the concrete challenges involved in each instance can be diverse. For example; one robot might have a fully articulated hand; while another robot might only have a pincer gripper; but both are mounted to the same arm. In this case; some of the important aspects of motion; such as how to approach an object for manipulation; are shared; others; like what kind of grasp to attempt; are very different. Automatically detecting these differences in embodiment and deciding what aspect of the data to transfer to a new embodiment are the two core challenges in the project. In this project; students have the opportunity to work on one of the most challenging and exciting problems in robot learning. We expect that a successful project can be submitted to a top venue in machine learning or robotics such as ICRA; RSS; or CORL. Students will also become familiar with important tools of robot learning; such as common simulators.
Skills: Required: - Strong programming skills in Python - Close familiarity with software engineering tools such as IDEs; remote ssh; and Git - Familiarity with machine learning such as can be obtained from introductory courses in the field Bonus/nice to have - Familiarity with reinforcement and imitation learning - Familiarity with robotics and especially simulators such as mujoco or pybullet

Name: Creating an online and collaborative database for the representation of processes
Description: methods and tools for product development
Faculty supervisor: The growth of digital and connectivity technologies within the industrial landscape; and their integration within products; has led to the emergence of "multidisciplinary" products that combine mechanical; electrical; electronic; software and; more broadly; information and communication technologies. These multidisciplinary products are more complex; from both a technical and an organizational perspective. For companies wishing to evolve their "traditional" product ranges towards multidisciplinary products; it can represent a major challenge. To support companies in this evolution; previous research has investigated the evolution of product development practices from a methodological standpoint. In particular; this work has led to the creation of "cartographies"; graphically organizing approaches; processes; methods and tools; and their links for multidisciplinary product development. Although these cartographies can be seen as a preliminary database; their main limitation is that they are a snapshot of the scientific literature. Given this static aspect; it is not possible; for example; to perform queries on these cartographies; to display certain branches; or to easily manipulate these data to generate other results. This research project addresses an important limitation identified in previous work. The idea of this project is therefore to explore different types of representation (ontology; graph-oriented database; other); in order to determine the most appropriate representation for the project and apply it by setting up a demonstrator (VOWL/Protected; GraphQL/Neo4J; etc.).
Student academic background: The ideal candidate is a student in software engineering/computer science wishing to apply his/her database skills to set up a demonstrator to dynamically represent research data (cartographies) in a web environment. Knowledge of databases and/or ontologies is required; as well as programming skills. The student is expected to be autonomous (weekly meetings); to be able to conduct a literature review (in order to justify his/her choices) and to have excellent synthesizing skills.
column11: Computer Science; Engg-Computer; Engg-Software; Engg-Systems and Technology; Engineering

Name: Using photons to study fundamental issues in Quantum Physics
Description: The study of Quantum Information has reinvigorated the effort to understand the fundamental concepts of Quantum Theory; such as measurement; the wavefunction; and entanglement. Photons are the ideal quantum particle with which to explore these concepts because we can manipulate them easily; with high precision; and at room temperature. We are exploring the use of generalized measurements (e.g. weak measurement) as practical tools in metrology; optics; and Quantum Information. This project will perform experiments and theory investigating how quickly we can extract information about the quantum wavefunction from an ensemble of identical particles.
Skills: The student should have taken an officially course in quantum physics for credit at their university. In particular; they should be familiar with how to do calculations using the Dirac's Bra and Ket formalism (i.e. ). Additionally; some familiarity with optics; programming; and laboratory experience would be beneficial but are not necessary.

Name: Development of a Mechatronic System for Microrobotic Swarm Position Control
Description: The capability to directly interrogate intracellular structures inside a single cell for measurement and manipulation is important for understanding subcellular and sub-organelle activities; diagnosing diseases; and developing new therapeutic approaches. However; the measurements for intracellular structures are under-explored due to the lack of measurement instruments. Magnetic nanoparticles; especially a swarm of nanoparticles; can be controlled by magnetic force and to access small spaces for measurement. To achieve intracellular physical measurement using nanoparticles; this project aims to develop a mechatronic system for controlling the position of a magnetic nanoparticle swarm. The system will include visual servo control to achieve sub-micrometer position control accuracy and incorporate a magnetic force model to achieve pico-newton force control. With the developed system; the magnetic nanoparticles will be controlled three-dimensionally to form a swarm and positioned in the cell for performing the mechanical measurement. The ultimate goal of my research is to deploy the robotic technologies in clinical settings to expand treatment options for patients with tumors. My research program will involve topics including microrobotics; medical imaging; computer vision; instrumentation; nanotechnology; and tumor mechanobiology.
Skills: The ideal candidate for this position should have a background in mechatronic system design; as candidates with such experience will be given preference. The student will be collaborating closely with graduate students within the lab; so strong teamwork and communication skills are essential. In terms of technical proficiency; experience with CAD tools; C programming; and circuit design would be advantageous. At the commencement of the research project; on-site safety training and software tutorials will be provided to ensure a smooth start.

Name: Experimental study of mass timber connections
Description: Mass timber has been recognized as a sustainable and efficient building solution; and it is the driving force behind the fast growth of timber industry globally. One key component in a mass timber building system is the connection between timber elements or between timber and other elements. The connection design is complicated by the heterogeneity of wood and different layouts in various engineered wood products. The energy dissipation capacity of the building under earthquakes is largely depended upon connections. The connection design also impacts the building cost and the aesthetic expression of wood; both of which are critical concerns for architects. The Timber Engineering Group at UBC has been working on modern timber building systems for decades; and this short-term experimental project is part of our ongoing research and innovation in this field. The project will focus on low-yield-steel based energy dissipating connections for mass timber. Mass timber elements often have high in-plane rigidity thus little internal energy dissipating capacity. We have conducted some studies on the low yield steel energy dissipaters for CLT walls/modules. In this project; the student will work with our researchers to find ways to optimize the design; and then investigate the performance of the new design through experiments. The results will be analyzed and compared with existing models. This project offers the student opportunities to develop critical skills in research and engineering application; as well as to interact with colleagues from various disciplines and cultural backgrounds. In the long term; the outcome of this project will help engineers to develop innovative and reliable building solutions.
Skills: The student is expected to have good background in structural engineering; mechanics; or wood science. Basic skills in computer data analysis is required. The student will work in a team environment and therefore ability to communicate in English is needed. Interests and strengths in experiments are assets.

Name: Pipeflow Manipulation for Emissions Reduction
Description: This project focuses on pipeflow dynamics and manipulation towards lowering drag and heat losses in the flow. Energy of the fluid in turbulent flows is concentrated in particular coherent structures that belong to specific Fourier modes. This enables flow manipulation to retain energy in specific structures and dissipate it in others; which leads to lower drag and higher efficiency in heat and fluid transport.This constitutes an intrusive mechanism to lower greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions in transportation of energy products; including liquids; gases and multiphase fluids.
Skills: No skills available

Name: Visualizing and understanding biosynthetic enzymes
Description: Nonribosomal peptide synthetases (NRPSs) are megaenzymes that resemble molecular assembly lines. There are hundreds of thousands of NRPSs found in nature; many producing compounds that are currently-used therapeutics; and many others producing uncharacterized compounds that could be next-generation therapeutics. Furthermore; characterized NRPSs could be bioengineered to make novel therapeutics. For the past two decades; bioengineering efforts have mostly resulted in failures or drastically reduced yields. One major reason for this failure is that naïve bioengineering likely disrupts the many transient domain-domain interactions and dramatic three-dimensional flexibility NRPSs display during their synthetic cycle. Each NRPS consists of multiple so-called modules; made of a set of domains that together are responsible for the incorporation of a single building block into the nascent peptide chain. During this catalytic process; many distinct conformational states are necessary; and therefore not surprising that any bioengineering change made to the NRPS assembly line guided by genetic or biochemical information alone is very likely to perturb the spatial interactions necessary for catalysis. Consequently; high-resolution structural data for the different catalytic conformations is necessary to potentiate bioengineering. Structure-guided approaches could allow us to develop a biosynthetic toolbox of designed NRPS assembly lines with modifications such as insertion of tailoring domains; domain swaps; and active site surgeries that could make it possible to synthesize high-value compounds or generate new-to-nature compounds by rational design or genetic library screens. In this MITACS project; the student will work with a senior Schmeing lab member in a multi-disciplinary approach to purify; characterize; visualize and bioengineer NRPS megaenzymes.
Skills: Basic molecular biology skills Experience in working with proteins or structural biology is a plus

Name: Nanobubbles: Generation and characterization
Description: A major limitation that has restricted the use of nanobubbles to this point has been challenges with their efficient generation; e.g. high-energy costs; modest concentrations and lack of scalability. This research project will build upon a recently published revolutionary technology where electric fields are used to catalyze nanobubble generation. This novel approach requires ~1000-fold less energy compared to current methods; thereby overcoming the crucial limitation that has thus far restricted the potential impacts and widespread application of nanobubbles. A principal goal of this project is to identify key factors that affect the performance characteristics of the generator and the scalability of the design; and to characterize the nanobubble solutions produced (e.g. nanobubble size and concentration).
Skills: This project requires two highly enthusiastic and self-motivated students with background in 1) engineering and familiar with prototyping and design and 2) chemistry/material science that has taken analytical chemistry courses; has wet laboratory experience (prepare solutions; analytical balance; pH meter); and familiar with a range of instruments. Students must be proficient in English; and Microsoft Office software including Excel and Word. Both students ideally would have taken courses in electromagnetism; electrochemistry; and physical chemistry. A student with background in engineering that has knowledge in reactor design and transport phenomena is a plus.
Student academic background: Biochemistry; Chemistry; Earth Science; Engg-Biological; Engg-Chemical; Engg-Civil; Engg-Enviromental; Engg-Geological; Environmental Studies; Geology; Geography; Engg-Electrical; Engg-Materials; Engg-Mechanical; Engg-Mineral; Engg-Mining; Engineering

Name: Water reuse: formation of disinfection byproducts from recycled waters
Description: Water disinfection; one of the most important human health developments of the 20th century; is used in water treatment to protect against waterborne diseases such as cholera and typhoid. However; chemical (e.g.; chlorine) and ultraviolet (UV) light disinfection processes react with natural organic matter; present in rivers and lakes; to unintentionally form disinfection by-products (DBPs) that may cause adverse health effects by long-term exposure. Population growth; climate change; and increasing water demands by economic activities are jeopardizing the quality of water supplies leading to the use of waters with higher anthropogenic inputs (i.e. organic nitrogen; industrial solvents) in developed and undeveloped countries. The ability to continue to provide safe water under this constant change becomes challenging; because of the increased complexity of source waters and the multiple reactions and compounds that are produced from disinfection. Typically; wastewater effluents are treated through various physical-chemical processes including microfiltration; reverse osmosis; or advanced oxidation processes (i.e.; UV/hydrogen peroxide) to remove contaminants and inactivate microbial pathogens for potable reuse. Wastewater effluents contain high levels of ammonia and organic ammonia that are not well removed from these processes and can react with disinfectants to produce toxic DBPs. This study evaluates the formation of halogenated organic amines by reacting model organic compounds with disinfectants and identify intermediate and products using advanced mass spectrometry instrumentation (liquid and gas chromatography tandem mass spectrometry). Ultimately we want to evaluate the role that halogenated organic amines haves on the formation of toxic DBPs.
Skills: This research requires a highly enthusiastic and self-motivated student with background in analytical chemistry; water chemistry; organic chemistry; and/or engineering. Student must be proficient in English; and Microsoft Office software including Excel and Word. The prospective student should have good laboratory and analytical skills. The student should be detail-oriented and well-organized. Wet laboratory experience is required for this project (i.e.; prepare solutions; use analytical balance and pH meter). Student with knowledge and/or experience on gas chromatography mass spectrometry is highly desirable.

Name: From control theory to physics and back again
Description: My projects are for a physics student seeking to learn about control and information and thermodynamics or for engineering students with an introduction to control theory who want to learn more. The project will be original research – publishable if it works out well enough – that touches on the interplay between physics and control. This project will focus on the continuing development of both hardware and control algorithms for the classic “cart-pendulum” system (try to swing up and then balance upside down a pendulum attached to a cart by pushing it back and forth along a rail). This classic problem requires solving many hard control problems; including nonlinearity; and is a good way to evaluate novel control algorithms. We have been exploring new algorithms to increase the robustness of the control. How can a system recover from big perturbations; even when its dynamics are poorly known? Although the cart-pendulum is a “toy” system; it plays a role analogous to the harmonic oscillator in standard physics courses. Master it and so many other things become understandable (or controllable!). I have posted two positions; with the idea that one person can focus on hardware and the other on software / implementation and testing of new algorithms. Previous students have made some progress on these; but there is much to do. We would like to simplify existing hardware designs and also increase the sophistication of the software; including exploring ways to parallelize calculations (e.g.; with GPUs). So whether you like building things or playing with theory and whether you come from Engineering or from Physics; there is a place for you!
Skills: A perfect background would include courses in control theory; linear systems theory; statistical physics; and a bit of machine learning. You should also have good programming skills in some language (Matlab; LabVIEW; Mathematica; C; Python; or something similar). Some basic lab skills (elementary circuits; data acquisition using DAQs) would also be desirable. No one knows all this! So I will be looking for people with some of the background and – most important – who are enthusiastic and can learn quickly. You should want to know WHY and not be content to just “use formulas.”

Name: First-principles nuclear theory for neutrino and dark-matter physics (Supervision will primarily be provided by Dr. Jason D. Holt
Description: and the work is planned to take place on-site at TRIUMF
Host Province: which is located at the south end of the UBC-Vancouver campus)
Host Institution: What is the mass of the neutrino? What are the limits of matter? How and where are the heavy elements created? How do stars die? Can we detect dark matter? As science probes ever more extreme facets of the universe; the role of nuclear theory in confronting such fundamental questions in nature continues to deepen. Long considered a phenomenological discipline; advances in many-body methods together with our understanding and treatment of nuclear forces are transforming nuclear theory into a true first-principles pursuit. And with this shift; we are now in a position to provide reliable predictions to address the questions above and connect observations made in the laboratory to the underlying strong interactions governing the properties of nuclei. This project will focus on the development and application of powerful theoretical methods to explore fundamental questions on the structure of exotic nuclei; or more far-reaching connections to neutrino or dark-matter physics; neutron star physics; or searches for symmetry violation in nature. The student will first gain familiarity and build confidence working with the basic ingredients of such calculations: nuclear forces and their connection to the underlying theory of strong interactions (quantum chromodynamics); and nuclear many-body methods to predict properties of medium-mass nuclei. Depending on particular interests; the student will have the exciting opportunity either to design and implement an extension to the existing computational infrastructure; work on computationally optimizing existing codes; or perform a series of calculations which will confront directly with experiments being performed at TRIUMF or other prominent experimental facilities across the world.
Skills: University of British Columbia
column12: With the latest advances in high-performance computing and optimization algorithms at her/his disposal; the student will gain experience with parallel-computing techniques such as OpenMP or MPI and work on some of the world’s largest supercomputers. The ideal applicant will have mastered material encountered in introductory quantum mechanics courses and be familiar with concepts such as eigenvalues; wavefunctions; operators; unitary transformations; and angular-momentum algebra. Furthermore; some computing experience is required; with competency in Python and some experience with C++ would be helpful.

Name: Searching for the nearest transiting Earth-like exoplanets
Description: The Transit Exoplanet Survey Satellite (TESS); is addressing Kepler's shortcoming by observing the entire sky; albeit only the brighter stars. TESS-discovered exoplanets are around brighter and nearer host stars; and so offer more in-depth information on the diversity of exoplanets. However; TESS' limited sensitivity to faint stars means that what may be the most common type of stellar type hosting a rocky planetary system; the M dwarfs; are under-represented in TESS discoveries. At the same time; M-planetary systems may offer the best opportunity for characterizing any Earth-like rocky planets. The habitable zones of M dwarfs are much narrower; corresponding to orbital periods of months or less. And the planet-to-star contrast is very favourable for a direct detection of any exoplanetary atmosphere through transit or eclipse spectroscopy. Prof. Metchev's team at Western University if involved in the planning for a space telescope mission that will be in part dedicated to discovering rocky planets around M-type or cooler dwarf stars. The Photometric Observations of Extrasolar Transits (POET) is a mission proposed to the Canadian Space Agency that will spend up to a year on a survey of the nearest and coolest candidate rocky planet hosts. Any discoveries from POET will be prime targets for atmospheric spectroscopy with JWST; possibly even in search for atmospheric biosignature gasses. In preparation for POET; Prof. Metchev's team is assembling a catalogue of the nearest M-type or cooler (L or T types) stars; analyzing their properties from TESS observations or with ground-based telescopes; and prioritizing them for the POET target sample. Potential follow-up observations are also possible with an array of three 50 cm robotic telescopes in use by Prof. Metchev's group.
Skills: The successful applicant will have strong computing skills; including knowledge of the Linux operating system and of a scripting/programming language (python; C). Basic astronomy knowledge; familiarity with astronomical images; telescope use; or knowledge of parallel computing or machine learning are all preferred; but not required.

Name: 3D Scene Manipulation
Description: Neural Radiance Fields (NeRFs) have been shown to be effective in 3D reconstruction with 2D supervision. Having enough data (2D images of a scene with ground truth camera poses); NeRFs are able to generate high-quality novel views of the scene. Although a whole line of research is dedicated to making NeRFs faster; less data-hungry; and more performant; scene manipulation in NeRFs is still an important and much less explored problem. In this project; we will explore how NeRFs can be trained in a way that allows modifying a scene such as for moving objects; changing their appearance; or inpainting new / removing existing objects in a NeRF.
Skills: 1. Familiarity with general machine learning and deep learning concepts 2. Familiarity with PyTorch 3. Experience with implementing algorithms for computer vision tasks 4. Familiarity with general concepts in linear algebra 5. General understanding of 3D transformation; camera matrices; etc

Name: Ferrofluidic Platform for Mechanical Measurement in Tissue
Description: From magnetic tweezers to robotic magnetic-field generation systems; the development of magnetic micromanipulation systems; using electromagnets or permanent magnets; has enabled a multitude of applications for cellular and intracellular measurement and stimulation. Controlled by different configurations of magnetic-field generation systems; magnetic particles have been actuated by an external magnetic field to exert forces/torques and perform mechanical measurements on the cell membrane; cytoplasm; cytoskeleton; nucleus; intracellular motors; etc. The particles have also been controlled to generate aggregations to trigger cell signaling pathways and produce heat to cause cancer cell apoptosis for tumor hyperthermia treatment. Magnetic micromanipulation has become an important tool in the repertoire of toolsets for cell measurement and stimulation and will continue to be used widely for further explorations of cellular/intracellular structures and their functions. In this project; a ferrofluid magnetic system will be developed to perform measurements inside healthy tissue and brain tumor tissue. The mechanical measurement results will help better understand the mechanical stimulations within the brain tumor and how these mechanical stimulations affect brain tumor development. This research project will involve topics including microrobotics; computer vision; instrumentation; nanotechnology; and basic tumor mechanobiology.
Skills: The ideal candidate for this position should have a background in mechatronic system design; as candidates with such experience will be given preference. The student will be collaborating closely with graduate students within the lab; so strong teamwork and communication skills are essential. In terms of technical proficiency; experience with finite element analysis; and knowledge of basic cell biology would be advantageous. At the commencement of the research project; on-site safety training and software tutorials will be provided to ensure a smooth start.
Student academic background: Engg-Biomedical; Engg-Mechanical; Biological Sciences; Electronic Systems

Name: Fast 3D object recognition
Description: Ce projet de recherche est conçu pour conduire à l’amélioration d’un des critères de performance les plus importants pour les bras robotiques collaboratifs : l’évitement d’obstacles. Ce critère est important; tant pour des applications d’automatisation classiques que pour des applications collaboratives où un robot est appelé à interagir physiquement avec une personne. En particulier; le projet vise à explorer et à évaluer des méthodes de détection d’objets dans une scène à l’aide de trois caméras à haute fréquence. Les caméras utilisées sont conçues pour capter la posture humaine en temps réel à l’aide de marqueurs placés sur les membres des participants. L’objectif de ce projet est de débuter la mise en œuvre d’algorithmes de vision numérique qui permettent de faire la détection d’objets simples dans un environnement 3D sans l’utilisation de marqueurs. Certains outils; comme OpenCV; existent pour faire le traitement d’images. Cependant; une étude approfondie du placement des caméras dans la scène est nécessaire pour faire l’exploitation des outils pour la reconnaissance d’objets dans un espace 3D. En outre; il est nécessaire de faire l’extraction des données de la caméra; en temps réel; pour utiliser les outils de traitement d’images. Pour ce faire; une étude de faisabilité devra d’abord être faite. Ce projet a pour objectif l’étude préliminaire de la possibilité d’utiliser les trois caméras pour faire la reconnaissance d’objets simples.
Skills: Les candidat-e-s doivent être des étudiant-e-s en fin de programme de premier cycle en génie logiciel; en informatique; en génie électrique ou d’un programme équivalent. La candidate ou le candidat retenu-e devra avoir des compétences et un intérêt pour la programmation en C++ ou en Python. Pour ce projet; la personne retenue devra également avoir une expérience des librairies et techniques d'apprentissage automatique; et/ou d'outils; tels que OpenCV. La connaissance des caméras numériques et de la science de la perspective sera considérée comme un atout.
Student academic background: Engg-Computer; Engg-Software; Engg-Mechanical; Engg-Manufacturing; Engg-Electrical; Computer Science

Name: DEVELOPMENTAL EPIGENETICS
Description: Epigenetic modifications are small chemical tags that can be added directly to DNA; or on histones that package DNA within chromosomes. These various modifications provide means by which a genetic sequence may be functionally active or inactive at a specific time during cell development; without altering the DNA sequence. During early development; embryonic cells divide and grow according to a program of their own; driven by a major overhaul of epigenetic modifications. We believe that any interference occurring during the establishment of this embryonic epigenetic program may increase the vulnerability to deploy various developmental disorders.
