The project aims to identify the interdependence that exists between epigenetic modifications that regulate gene expression; as well as their susceptibilities to permanent disruption following errors in the embryonic program. We use an innovative embryonic stem cell model in which the expression of an epigenetic enzyme responsible for DNA methylation can be controlled. We will define at high resolution the chronology and evolution of epigenetic disruption in embryonic cells. Beyond standard techniques in molecular biology; sequencing approaches (Methyl-Seq; ChIP-Seq) coupled with bioinformatic analyzes will be exploited to establish detailed signatures for the DNA methylation and histone modifications. Under the guidance of a senior Postdoc; the student will participate in various aspects (experiments; analyses) of this project. By finely dissecting the epigenetic dysregulation mechanisms in embryonic stem cells; we aim to identify which epigenetic modifications are likely to be dysregulated in early embryos and how this could lead to adverse development. In this project; we also aim to uncover the molecular mechanisms implicated in the dysregulation of epigenetic patterns during early embryo development and during neural cell lineage specification resulting from the dysfunction of specific epigenetic modifying enzymes.
Skills: Our team is looking for students with a self-driven personality who are eager to learn! Candidates should have a collaborative approach to research; work productively in a team and contribute to a good social environment in the lab. Basic knowledge in cell culture; molecular biology or bioinformatics would be assets but are not essential.

Name: Identification et caractérisation de microorganismes responsables de produits laitiers atypiques ou non conformes
Description: The presence of spoilage bacteria and pathogens is a potential issue in the dairy industry; especially when these microorganisms modify the products by making them atypical or non-compliant. The source of these microorganisms is often unknown; for example milk; equipment; workers; or the presence of biofilm. Dairy biofilms are a complex microbial ecosystem that can include spoilage microorganisms or pathogens. As part of this internship project; samples will be purchased from local grocery stores to challenge them with different quality maintenance tests. IT management will be necessary to orchestrate everything. Subsequently; the potential microorganism in question will be identified by various conventional microbiological methods and by using sequencing or mass spectrometry methods. After its isolation; the microorganism will be characterized (Gram; antibiotic resistance; etc.). In addition; its ability to form biofilms will also be evaluated; and various chemical formulations will be tested in order to better control this microorganism. The antimicrobial effect will be assessed by various analytical methods (e.g.; absorbance measurement; bacterial counting on selective agars; and electron and/or confocal microscopy). The results obtained during this internship will be decisive since they will make it possible to expand the collection of microorganisms responsible for atypical or non-compliant products. Ultimately; this collection will speed up the identification process if a similar problem arises in industry.
Skills: The successful candidate must have a BSc degree in microbiology; molecular biology; food science or other related disciplines. He or she will have practical skills in the microbiology and/or cell biology fields. The student should also have a special interest for research in food sciences and microbiology. He or she should also have to be independent; organized and have the ability to work with a team. Mastering French (written and spoken) will be considered a particular advantage.

Name: Editing the Epigenome
Description: Epigenetic modifications are small chemical tags which can be added directly on DNA; or on histones that package DNA within chromosomes. These various modifications provide means by which a genetic sequence may be functionally active or inactive at a specific time during cell development; without altering the DNA sequence. During early development; embryonic cells divide and grow according to a program of their own; driven by a major overhaul of epigenetic modifications. We believe that any interference occurring during the establishment of this embryonic epigenetic program may increase the vulnerability to deploy various developmental disorders. Through unknown mechanisms; parent-of-origin-specific methylation marks on one allele of imprinted genes are able to escape the embryonic reprogramming wave occurring during the first week of development and retain their profiles via DNA methylation maintenance activity. Failing to maintain proper genomic imprinting patterns during the embryonic reprogramming leads to various abnormal developmental delay. What remains to be elucidated is whether we can permanently re-establish normal profiles of DNA methylation and subsequent gene expression of imprinted (allele-specific) sequences following the loss of their DNA methylation imprinting status. To set the foundation for a clear understanding of the mechanisms behind re-establishing the loss of inherited methylation profiles; we hypothesize that we can re-establish specifically and permanently the lost DNA methylation imprints at specific loci by targeted epigenome editing in embryonic cells. Under the guidance of a senior PhD student; the MITACS intern will use a CRISPR epigenome editing system to add or remove site specific DNA methylation marks on imprinted regions in a model of embryonic stem cells; and define if we can properly re-establish DNA methylation imprints and associated gene expression following their dysregulation.
Skills: Our team is looking for students with a self-driven personality who are eager to learn! Candidates should have a collaborative approach to research; working productively in a team and contributing to a good social environment in the lab. Basic knowledge in cell culture; molecular biology or bioinformatics would be assets; but are not essential.
Student academic background: Biochemistry; Biology; Computer Science; Genetics; Molecular Biology

Name: Mathematical Programming Methods for solving Multiple-Pickers Order Picking Problems
Description: The project aims to develop new mathematical models for solving Order Picking Problems with a polynomial number of constraints and binary variables. The literature is full of models using an exponential number of constraints or a polynomial number of constraints and integer or continuous variables. A model using only binary variables is flexible and can be applied to many variants of Order Picking Problems easier than traditional models. After developing and testing; a specialized variant of the new model to solve many routes simultaneously will be tested in a real warehouse’s data instances as an online optimization problem. The results will be tested statistically over efficiency measures of time to check whether the proposed model has a significant reduction.
Skills: Basic mathematical background: Optimization; Linear Algebra; and Probability. Basic programming skills in Python programming. The project will run with intense use of the libraries: pandas; numpy; scipy; matplotlib; scikit-learn; and pulp.
Student academic background: Engineering; Computer Science; Engg-Systems and Technology; Engg-Software; Engg-Industrial; Management Information Systems; Mathematics

Name: Improving Product Allocation in Warehouses through Content-Based Filtering
Description: This research project aims to investigate the application of the machine learning technique content-based filtering in warehouse management to solve a Storage Location Assignment Problem (SLAP). The goal is to identify the best storage location for each product based on its properties to minimize order picking time. This research project is divided into three main stages: (1) Conduct a literature review to understand the current state of the application of recommendation algorithms in warehouse management; (2) Identify relevant product characteristics influencing products’ allocation; such as size; weight; category; and expiration date; (3) Develop a content-based filtering model based on these characteristics to recommend the best location for each product within the warehouse. The proposed model will be implemented in a simulated storage environment; using accurate product data and considering available space restrictions. Experiments will be conducted to evaluate the model's effectiveness in terms of operational efficiency; search time and recommendation accuracy. Results will be compared to traditional methods of product allocation in warehouses; such as the rule-based approach. Statistical analysis will be carried out to verify the improvement achieved using content-based filtering. The model developed in this project is hoped to be applied in a real-scale proof-of-concept case to reduce operational time and cost in a warehouse.
Skills: The student should be comfortable with data science and machine learning. Good mathematical and programming skills are required. The programming language used for this project is Python. Experience with simulation modeling tools (e.g.; AnyLogic) is an asset.
Student academic background: Engg-Computer; Engg-Electrical; Engg-Industrial; Engg-Manufacturing; Engg-Software; Engg-Systems and Technology; Engineering; Mathematics; Management Information Systems; Computer Science

Name: AM process sustainability prediction using machine learning
Description: The increasing pressure of resource reservation has forced the rethinking of sustainable development in manufacturing. Additive manufacturing (AM) has been believed to be a green process because of its high material efficiency; shortened supply chain; and decentralized production. To further improve the process for elevated sustainability; there is a strong need to quantitatively model the AM process regarding its sustainable performance. In my research group; we have developed a lifecycle assessment (LCA) model to evaluate the sustainable performance of plastic AM process. However; this process requires strong background of LCA modeling and it creates barriers for designers without such a background to examine the environmental impacts in product design stage. In this regard; a machine learning model has been proposed to automate the process. The proposed project aims to further optimize the machine learning model for better accuracy and experimental validation as well as developing an optimization model for process parameter recommendation for AM process. The proposed project aims to develop a novel computational design method that is able to use “in-the-wild” images taken by mobile phones (with two or more cameras) as the input for custom-fit modeling. An “in-the-wild” image means that a photo is taken under no environmental constraints in terms of lighting; backgrounds; etc. This approach will largely relax the need for expensive 3D capturing devices. Once the digital product model is computationally generated; optimization of the digital model for better performance and printability for AM will also be investigated. Potential custom-fit products to be examined could be earphones; footwear; and wearable devices for medical treatment.
Skills: The ideal student would be having a background on product design; manufacturing; lifecycle assessment; math; or similar fields. Students who have some experience on CAD software; additive manufacturing; or programming will be preferred. The student will be trained on the skills listed or 3D printing depending on the qualifications. The proposed research includes both hands-on and theoretical study. The student must be hardworking; motivated and able to work in teams proficiently. Students must also be comfortable explaining their findings to peers in reports and presentations.

Name: Quality prediction of additive manufactured parts using computer vision and machine learning
Description: In the current era; industry 4.0 is the new paradigm which is taking industrialization to the next level with technologies involved are Additive Manufacturing; Digital Twin; IOT; Big Data; AI; Cyber- Physical System. These technologies will drive the future manufacturing paradigm. Digital twin technology will be implemented on the Fused deposition Modeling (FDM) 3D printer to improve the quality of the printed parts. A digital twin is basically the real-time virtual model and simulation of the physical entity. Collecting real-time data from the 3D printer through sensors and sending it to the virtual model of 3D printer will require to deal with different kinds of sensors; raspberry pi; and data acquisition systems. After that; real-time data will be collected; a machine learning algorithm needs to be developed to train the virtual model to predict the surface quality. The main tasks include: 1) Get familiar with 3d printer operations; 2) Learn about the API of the 3d printer firmware and reads data from the printer using programming; 3) Set up sensors and do calibration; 4) Develop an interface for data management. Preferred qualifications: Experience with C++/C#/python; CAD; sensors; raspberry pi; or robots is preferred
Skills: The ideal student would be having a background in mechatronic/control engineering; mechanical engineering; or similar fields. Students who have some experience in additive manufacturing; machine learning; and computer vision are preferred. The student will be trained on the skills listed or 3D printing depending on the qualifications. The proposed research includes both hands-on and theoretical studies. The student must be hardworking; motivated and able to work in teams proficiently. Students must also be comfortable explaining their findings to peers in reports and presentations.

Name: ILIVE : Development of immersive virtual environments for inclusive leisure activities
Description: Leisure activities are less accessible for people with autism and their families; resulting in reduced community presence and social participation. This observation led our research team; drawn from engineering (ÉTS); educational sciences (UQAM) and the community; to develop new innovative immersive and inclusive activities for people with autism. The CAVE system has been chosen to develop virtual reality leisure activities that will help foster social participation and improve social skills. This will promote better interaction between autistic and non-autistic people and encourage participation in different settings and communities across Quebec. With this in mind; a new prototype of a multi-purpose CAVE (adaptable and transportable) is being developed in the laboratory. This development also involves defining the leisure activities that will be relevant in meeting the challenges of inclusion and immersion; as well as the virtual environments that will be designed. This interdisciplinary project will focus on three axes: 1) updating the literature and collaborating on identifying the technological elements that make up the CAVE; 2) collaborating on drawing up the specifications and applying them to the design of the virtual environment that can be adapted to any CAVE surface; 3) collaborating on developing immersive and interactive scenario(s). This project will culminate in integrating the three components and testing this environment in the context of immersive leisure activities in the community.
Skills: This interdisciplinary project requires diverse and complementary skills in the field of immersive reality application design and in a social science context (education and psychology). To participate in the various aspects of the project; several profiles are needed: 1) a candidate with experience in hardware design; 2) a candidate with experience in application design and implementation; 3) a candidate with experience in developing social skills intervention activities with children. Experience in developing virtual environments (Unity engine for example); an interest in immersive technologies or 360° imaging (OpenCV library) is an asset.

Name: Predicting Apartment Prices in Winnipeg
Description: Over the past few years; there has been a significant surge in apartment prices; primarily driven by a disparity between the supply and demand for apartments. This trend has persisted; with a continuous decline in available apartments on the market and prices continuing to rise. The uncertainty surrounding the apartment market's performance in the next six to twelve months has sparked curiosity; particularly among those seeking apartments. Therefore; the objective of this research project is to develop a methodology that can provide informed and precise predictions about the future of the apartment market in Winnipeg. Our proposed methodology will rely on apartment characteristics and location data to forecast listing prices accurately. Additionally; it will identify areas in Winnipeg where apartments are projected to have the lowest prices. Constructing a realistic model for precise apartment price prediction has proven to be a challenging yet promising area for future research.
Skills: No skills available

Name: Language-Agnostic Grammar-Guided Testing of Compilers
Description: Interpreters and Debuggers
Faculty supervisor: System software is the foundation of computers by bridging hardware and application software. Its reliability is critical to our society; and any bug in system software; e.g.; operating systems; compilers; and device drivers can cause widely catastrophic damages. This project aims to improve the reliability of one big category of system software—system language tools; such as compilers; interpreters and debuggers which take as input programs. Specifically; this project aims to design and develop an intelligent software testing technique to automatically generate random; diverse; and expressive programs to thoroughly validate the correctness of various system language tools. Compared to the state of the art; the deliverable of this project will have the following research contributions; First; the technique will be language-agnostic. Namely; the technique can generate programs in different languages. For example; the technique should be able to generate Java; C; C++; and Rust programs. Note that we will not be writing a random program generator for each language; but strive to design a general technique which is able to support multiple languages automatically. Second; our technique will leverage the grammar/syntax of different languages to guide the generation of random programs. The technique takes as input a grammar written in Antlr (https://www.antlr.org); analyzes the grammar; and uses the grammar to automatically generate programs. This project also includes continuous evaluation of the developed tool on real-world system language tools. We have been using a powerful server to find hundreds of bugs in GCC; LLVM; Rust; and Solidity for over a year.
Student academic background: The student is expected to self-motivated and have solid understanding of fundamental concepts of computer science. The student should be interested in programming languages and software engineering. Specifically; First; the student should have taken a course on compilers; and know basic concepts of compiler internals; e.g.; lexing; parsing; abstract syntax tree; control-flow graph; compiler optimizations. Second; due to the nature of this project to validate language tools; the student should be good at programming; and is expected to be proficient with one prevalent programming language; for example; Kotlin; Java; C; C++; Rust.
column11: Computer Science

Name: Using AI to find and categorize bugs in data science software
Description: This research project aim at the development of new methods and models for more secure and reliable data science. First; we will extract a large dataset of bugs and security issues from open-source data science repositories to improve our understanding of data science bugs. We will then analyze the data to quantify the security and reliability problems quantitatively and qualitatively. This knowledge mobilization will help us understand and categorize the bugs and vulnerabilities found in data science software. Then; we will propose new data science testing methods that specifically detect bugs that appear in data science. We will develop a research prototype by training AI classifiers; such as transformer models; to automatically detect these defects. We will evaluate our research prototype on previously known bugs in data science software. Finally; we will also run the prototype on the latest version of the most popular open-source data science software to find previously unknown bugs and vulnerabilities.
Skills: Required: Python; git Desired: Linux; AI; Command line Useful but not required (R; Matlab)

Name: Big Data Acceleration on FPGAs
Description: Evidenced by Microsoft’s FPGA deployment in its Bing search engine and Azure cloud; Intel’s USD $16.7B acquisition of Altera; AMD’s USD $50B acquisition of Xilinx; and the announcement of its public cloud access by Amazon and Alibaba; integrating FPGAs into datacenters is considered one of the most promising approaches to sustain the ever-increasing performance and energy-efficiency demand of today’s and tomorrow’s big data applications. In this project; we will accelerate big data applications—with a major focus on big data queries and sparse matrix based computations—on datacenter FPGAs; to achieve better performance and energy-efficiency. This will be based on our strong record in accelerating big data applications such as computational genomics (e.g.; MEMSYS 2017 best paper and ISPASS 2018 best paper nominee) and machine learning (TCAD 2019 Donald O. Pederson Best Paper Award). In addition; our team developed the first open-source compiler SQL2FPGA (FCCM 2023) that compiles Apache Spark SQL queries (state-of-the-art big data computing system) onto the FPGA accelerators. Specifically; in the summer 2024 project; students will choose (or be assigned) one of the big data query operators or sparse matrix based computations (e.g.; query sorting; data filtering; table joining; SpMV; SpMM; etc.) and accelerate it on the datacenter FPGA with the AMD/Xilinx high-level synthesis. The goal is to significantly improve the performance and energy-efficiency of the chosen application. Based on our past experience; this usually means 10x-100x speedup for the offloaded kernel and 2x-3x system-level speedup. Finally; we expect the student will participate in a paper submission to a top conference or journal. Some examples of our research can be found here: http://www.sfu.ca/~zhenman/projects.html
Skills: Below is a list of requirements for the students. a. A high score (A-/A/A+; or 85% above) in computer architecture; or computer organization; or digital design course is required b. Strong general coding skill is required (e.g.; C/C++; Java; Scala) c. FPGA hardware design experience is required (e.g.; Verilog/VHDL; HLS C/C++/OpenCL) d. Knowledge of database queries is a plus (e.g.; MySQL; Presto SQL) e. Knowledge of sparse matrix based computations is a plus (e.g.; SpMV; SpMM) f. Prior research experience is a plus g. Good English and communication skills with other lab members is required

Name: Spin manipulation and imaging for ultra-cold gas dynamics
Description: This project will create novel potentials in which to study the dynamics of ultra-cold atoms. Complicated optical patterns will be created by manipulating laser light with spatial light modulators. The key idea is that electromagnetic fields of a laser can alter the energy and polarization in atoms. These perturbations affect interactions between atoms; through electromagnetic forces and quantum mechanical exchange symmetries. By tuning the frequency; intensity; polarization; and; most importantly; spatial distribution of laser light; a host of interesting new dynamical behaviors can be observed in ultra-cold gases; including spin waves; magnetic instabilities; and long-range ordering in magnetic domains. The focus of this project will be working with a spatial light modulator to create novel spatial and time-dependent optical profiles for manipulating a quantum gas; and also to perform simulations and analysis of atomic dynamics. Both computational and experimental techniques will be used for this project. The project will involve computer control of devices for optical manipulation; installation of lasers and optical elements required for manipulating ultracold atoms; and testing of the system. Opportunities for computational numerical simulations may arise; as well as working with atom-imaging systems and image-processing algorithms too.
Skills: Students must be pursuing a degree in Physics or a closely related discipline. This project requires knowledge of some quantum mechanics; Maxwell's equations and experience with electromagnetic calculations. Experience working with experimental optical systems; python or Matlab; or other general experimental physics experience is advantageous; but is not required.

Name: Hardware/Software Codesign for Deep Learning Acceleration
Description: In the past decade; deep learning has achieved an amazing success. Various types of deep learning models; such as CNNs; transformers; and the recent vision transformers (ViTs) and ChatGPT; have been deployed for various industrial applications like image classification; speech recognition; natural language understanding; autonomous driving; and automated control. However; while the model accuracy keeps improving; their model size and computation complexity also keep increasing; making it challenging for real-time inference on resource-constrained edge devices. In this project; we will accelerate deep learning applications—with a major focus on low-bit CNNs and transformer-based models—on edge devices with hardware/software codesign techniques to achieve better performance and energy-efficiency. This will be based on our strong record in accelerating deep learning models such as CNNs (TCAD 2019 Donald O. Pederson Best Paper Award; FPGA 2022); SNNs (FPL 2021; TRETS 2022); and Vision Transformers (HPCA 2023). Specifically; in the summer 2024 project; students will choose (or be assigned) one of the deep learning models (e.g.; 4-bit CNN; BNN; Vision Transformer; etc.); analyze its computation and memory access patterns; apply hardware-friendly software optimizations such as model pruning and quantization; and design a hardware accelerator on the embedded FPGA with the AMD/Xilinx high-level synthesis. The goal is to significantly improve the performance and energy-efficiency of the chosen deep learning model over the embedded ARM CPU. Finally; we expect the student will participate in a paper submission to a top conference or journal. Some examples of our research can be found here: http://www.sfu.ca/~zhenman/projects.html
Skills: Below is a list of requirements for the students. a. A high score (A-/A/A+; or 85% above) in computer architecture; or computer organization; or digital design course is required b. Strong general coding skill is required (e.g.; Python; C/C++; Java) c. FPGA hardware design experience is required (e.g.; Verilog/VHDL; HLS C/C++/OpenCL) d. Knowledge of deep learning is required (e.g.; CNN; transformer; ViT) e. Prior research experience is a plus f. Good English and communication skills with other lab members is required
Student academic background: Computer Science; Engg-Computer; Engg-Electrical; Engg-Software; Electronic Systems

Name: Data Analytics for Clean Water Technologies
Description: The goal of this project is to work with existing platforms developed in the lab using PowerBi; ShinyApp and R and advance our understanding of data developed through the water lab. Students will work work collaboratively with PostDoctoral Fellows and PhD students in this area and will develop unique work package contributions. The research project will connect into the larger research program that is developing data analysis tools which are becoming critical for research partners connected to the research lab.
Skills: Students should have a strong teamwork skills as the student will work with researchers that are generating data in the field and those that are developing data analysis tools. Our lab has a diverse student population and excellent communication skills are essential. Finally students that have a strong passion for environmental science and engineering is critical - we are developing innovative ideas to transform the water industry and aim to recruit students with this goal.

Name: Advancing Water Treatment in Response to Climate Change
Description: The overall objective of this research program is to advance the community’s understanding of climate change processes in drinking water treatment. Dr. Gagnon's team conducts their research in a pilot plant; full-scale facilities and under controlled laboraotry experiments. Through this research Dr. Gagnon’s team will utilize research tools to characterize water quality in response to climate change. The team will develop a better understanding of treatment technologies including new technologies to balance water quality goals with climate change pressures. In addition; Dr. Gagnon's students use advance tools too quantify water quality such as qPCR for algal detection; ICP/MS for metals analysis and LC/MS for monitoring organic matter. These tools are used to help address research projects that are developed in partnership with industry collaborators with the lab. Industry partners include water utilities; engineering consulting firms and technolgy monitoring companies. Global link students will be assigned a well-defined project so that they can advance their knowledge in drinking water treatment and contribute to the overall research initiative of biological treatment in drinking water.
Skills: Students with backgrounds in civil and/or environmental engineering; chemistry; microbiology and environmental science are encouraged to apply. Our lab has a diverse student population and excellent communication skills are essential. Students that have a strong passion for environmental science and engineering is critical - we are developing innovative ideas to transform the water industry and aim to recruit students with this goal.

Name: Nanoparticles in Blue Phase Liquid Crystals
Description: Liquid crystal displays (LCDs) are an omnipresent in our lives but new LC based devices are constantly being developed; such as smart windows or miniature lenses for endoscopes. Combining inorganic nanoparticles (NPs) with LCs can both enhance the LC response to external stimuli and allow for reversible variation of the NP spatial distributions and their associated optical; electronic or magnetic properties. Blue Phase liquid crystals (BPLCs) are fascinating materials both on a fundamental level and for applications. They are unique liquid crystals due to their cubic structures and very fast response times to electrical fields. Ultrafast BPLC displays have been developed but BPLCs also have applications in the field of photonics. BPLCs; with lattice parameters on order of visible light wavelengths; are natural photonic crystals with optical bandgaps; analogous to electronic bandgap materials (semiconductors) but control the flow of light (photons) rather than electrons. BPLC can also template NPs into ordered; dynamic assemblies. We showed that gold NPs in BPLC spontaneously and reversibly form giant 3D cubic crystals (Gharbi; ACS nano; 2016 10; p3410) but fundamental questions remain regarding the mechanism. The effect of other types of nanoparticles will be explored in this project; specifically ferroelectric and magnetic NPs. Small angle X-ray scattering (SAXS) will be applied to study the effect of the particle size; composition and shape on the NP spatial distribution and the thermal stability of the BPLC matrix. To do this project; it is not necessary to have a background in liquid crystals or nanoparticles and students will gain experience in a wide range of characterization methods.
Skills: The student should have basic laboratory skills as normally acquired from undergraduate organic; analytical and physical chemistry laboratory courses. Colloidal chemistry and surface characterization methods will be acquired as part of the research project. A general interest in polymer properties and nanoparticles is desirable.

Name: Contrôle des virus d’origine alimentaire par le développement de méthodes d’inactivation
Description: Foodborne illnesses due to the presence of viral pathogens are of major interest for the public health. It is important to inactivate viruses found on food in order to prevent potential outbreaks. Our laboratory is a Canadian reference in food virology and is specialized in developing innovative methods to detect; concentrate or inactivate foodborne viruses. This project will be part of a new Research Chair dedicated to the control of foodborne viruses. The main goal of this summer project will be to develop a new viral inactivation method based on a chemical or physical treatment. In order to easily progress through the project; the trainee will be paired with a Master; PhD or postdoctoral student. To do so; at risk produces (strawberries; raspberries; oysters) or surfaces (stainless steel) will be artificially contaminated with key foodborne viruses or viral surrogates. The newly developed inactivation method will be tested with these contaminated food or surfaces. Molecular biology or cell culture methods could be used to assess the efficiency of the method to inactivate the virus. Data generated during this summer project will be used to establish groundbreaking methods to better control foodborne viruses.
Skills: The successful candidate must have a BSc degree (or about to obtain) in microbiology; molecular biology; or other related disciplines. He or she should have practical skills in the microbiology and/or cell biology fields. The student should also have a special interest for research in food sciences and microbiology. He or she should also have to be independent; organized and can work with a team. Mastering French (written and spoken) will be considered an advantage.

Name: Deep Learning Techniques for Mining Customers' Sequential Purchase Patterns for E-Commerce Product Recommendation
Description: Recurrent neural networks (RNNs) belong to a class of neural network that are designed to process sequential and time series data. Common RNN's architectures include long short-term memory (LSTM) and gated recurrent units (GRUs). Such models considers historical information to predict the future outcome (e.g.; for example; analyzing words in a sentence and numbers in a series; customers' historical purchase records etc). The project requires developing a recommendation system using RNNs; such as LSTM or GRU; to mine sequential patterns from customers' historical records (user-product interaction data). The model is then trained to capture dependencies and extract sequential patterns in customers' behavior thereby enabling personalized recommendations based on users' past interactions.
Skills: 1. The student must be passionate in learning new skills and techniques to implement state of the art methods. 2. Experience with programming languages (e.g.; Python) to manipulate data and draw insights from large data sets. Experience with libraries such as scikit learn and Keras will be a plus. 3. Knowledge of a variety of machine learning techniques (clustering; classification decision tree learning; artificial neural networks; deep learning etc.) and their real-world advantages/drawbacks will be an asset.

Name: Number-theoretic structure of the Clifford hierarchy
Description: This project is centered around the Clifford hierarchy; a nested family of subsets of the unitary group. The Clifford hierarchy arises naturally in the context of fault-tolerant quantum computation and has been intensely studied over teh past two decades. Despite this sustained scrutiny; the structure of the Clifford hierarchy remains mysterious. The goal of this project is to apply to the study of the Clifford hierarchy newly developed number-theoretic techniques that have proven useful in the study of quantum circuits.
Skills: The student taking part in this research project is expected to have a good understanding of basic tools and techniques from linear algebra; abstract algebra; and number theory. Some experience programming is also required. Knowledge of quantum computing is an asset but is not necessary as the relevant concepts can be acquired throughout the internship.

Name: Restriction Monads
Description: It is well known that monads in the bicategory Span(Set) correspond exactly to (small) categories. A restriction monad in a bicategory B to be a monad in B on an object A together with other 1-dimensional data on A and several linking 2-dimensional data that encode the notion of partiality in a way reminiscent of a restriction category. We know that the correspondence between small categories and monads in Span(Set) generalizes to a correspondence between small restriction categories and restriction monads in Span(Set). Similarly; small restriction categories correspond to so-called restriction monads in Set-Mat; a restriction module is a right action of a restriction category X on a set M so that each element m ∈ M is assigned an endomorphism m in X. Specific questions for this project are: 1) A restriction monad in Span(Set) is a small restriction category. This leads immediately to questioning how similar structures are related: Is an ordinary monad in rCat a restriction monad? Is an ordinary monad in Span(rCat) a restriction category? 2) The work of Cockett and Cruttwell introduces the data of a restriction tangent bundle; which gives a categorical model of differentiation in a suitable abstract setting. A tangent bundle is a restriction endofunctor equipped with some structure reminiscent of a structured comonad (in the appropriate setting). How much of the restriction structure can be moved into the comonad? 3) Partially invertible computation has been modeled recently by Giles using Cartesian inverse categories. What is the role that the Cartesian structure (or; more generally; a monoidal structure) plays in computation; and how does this model compare to a restriction monad on an inverse category?
Skills: Ideally; a student should be actively studying mathematics or computer science; but all students with interest in these topics are welcome. There are some skills required for this project: Required: Knowledge of set theory and mathematical proof. Useful: Knowledge of abstract algebra (groups; rings; fields). Comfort with technical writing. Very useful: Knowledge of category theory; modules; and type theory.

Name: Maximizing recovery of silver from recycling of anode slime from copper electrolysis cell
Description: Silver (Ag) is used as an antibacterial agent in disinfecting medical devices; home appliances; and water treatment; as well as in dental alloys; solder and brazing alloys; electrical contacts; and batteries. Silver bullion is produced from the treatment of anode slime from the copper (Cu) electrolysis cell in two steps reduction smelting and oxidation converting; which will be further treated in downstream processes. The chemistry of the converting cycle can be simplified into the system Te-Pb-Cu-Se-Ag-O. The knowledge of the distribution behavior of Te; Pb; Cu; Se; and Ag between metal; slag; and gas is required under a set of process parameters (composition; temperature; and oxygen partial pressure) to minimize the Ag loss in slag and maximize its recovery in metal. However; there is a lack of systematic study on the thermodynamics of TeO2-PbO- Cu2O-SeO2-Ag2O slag in the literature. Experimentation based on trial and error is time-consuming and challenging. Alternatively; the thermodynamic behavior of this system can be studied with the aid of coupled modeling and key experiments. In the first step; phase diagrams and thermodynamic data (e.g.; enthalpy; entropy; heat capacity) related to the system and available in the literature are collected and critically assessed. Then; preliminary thermodynamic modeling will be conducted based on the collected data. Key phase diagram experiments will be performed when the data is missing or inadequate in the literature. At last; the final thermodynamic optimization will be performed based on the new experimental results. Optimization of unary oxides and binary systems is of utmost importance in thermodynamic modeling. The thermodynamic properties of the former can often be found in thermodynamic compilations. In this project; we focus on the optimization of the binary systems (X-PbO and X-Cu2O) where X is either TeO2; SeO2; or Ag2O.
Skills: Studying in the field of materials science and engineering; metallurgy; or geochemistry Knowledge of thermochemistry and thermodynamics of inorganic materials Knowledge of thermochemical software such as FactSage or Thermo-Calc is an asset Hardworking and motivated to complete a challenging capstone project with many important real-world applications Good time-management; planning; and organizational skills Good critical thinking; and problem-solving skills Good communication and teamwork skills

Name: 6- AI and Humans Interacting to Form one Explainable Energy Management System
Description: The integration of AI and human interaction in an energy management system can create a powerful and explainable solution that combines the strengths of both. In this project we will develop a platform that uses machine learning algorithms to identify patterns; correlations; and energy-saving opportunities. Based on the analyzed data; the AI component makes intelligent decisions and recommendations regarding energy usage; load scheduling; and system optimization. It can dynamically adjust parameters such as PV generation levels; and load prioritization. The platform will be developed to provide a user-friendly interface that allows users to interact with and influence the AI component. Users can set preferences; define energy-saving goals; and provide feedback on the system's recommendations. It will generate explainable reports and visualizations that highlight energy-saving achievements; cost savings; and environmental impact; allowing users to track their progress and make data-driven decisions.
Skills: Python programming; machine learning.

Name: 5- Enhancing Occupancy Prediction: Transforming Time-Series Data into 2D Images with Deep Learning
Description: Building occupancy prediction is a crucial task with numerous applications in areas such as energy management; security; and facility optimization. Traditional methods for occupancy prediction often rely on time-series data collected from various sensors within a building(i.e.; CO2 concentration; temperature; humidity;…). However; these approaches may struggle to capture complex spatial relationships that are vital for accurate predictions. In recent years; deep learning techniques have emerged as powerful tools for analyzing complex data. This project will explore the use of deep learning to transform time-series data into 2D images; and then develop a novel image processing techniques to improve building occupancy prediction.
Skills: Python programming; machine learning.

Name: 1- Integrating text analysis to improve load prediction by incorporating social media sentiment
Description: Textual sources of information; such as company reports; social media posts; news articles; and other unstructured texts; hold a wealth of valuable insights that can potentially enhance load forecasting. However; despite the potential relevance of this information; traditional load forecasting algorithms using machine and deep learning often overlook the inclusion of textual data. Load forecasting algorithms typically rely on historical load data; weather patterns; and other structured variables; neglecting the rich contextual information present in textual sources. In this project we will investigate both the innovative forecasting approaches using machine learning and deep learning; and the techniques in natural language processing (NLP); sentiment analysis; and feature extraction to transform it into meaningful inputs that can enhance the accuracy of load forecasting models.
Skills: python programming; machine learning

Name: Pertinence de la réalité virtuelle en réadaptation de l'aphasie
Description: Durant l'année académique 2023/2024; nous aurons mené un projet explorant avec des personnes ayant un trouble de communication acquis et des orthophonistes travaillant en réadaptation l'intérêt d'utiliser et de développer du matériel de réalité virtuelle dans la réadaptation de l'aphasie. Nous aurons des données d'entrevue semi-dirigées et des données de groupes de design thinking à analyser. Nous aurons aussi un article à écrire sur le sujet; et à rédiger un protocole d'une future étude visant cette fois à créer le matériel en question et le faire tester. L'étudiant·e intéressé·e par la thématique et intégrant le laboratoire à l'été 2024 pourrait être impliqué·e à différents stades de ce projet; selon son profil et le développement du projet au cours de l'année académique.
Skills: Ce projet s'adresse à des étudiant·es intéressé·es à l'orthophonie et/ou à l'aphasie. Cependant; les étudiant·es intéressé·es aux technologies innovantes dans la réadaptation pourraient tout aussi bien présenter un profil pertinent. Également; des étudiant·es ayant de l'expertise en sciences de l'informatique; dans la programmation d'environnements virtuels ou dans la réalité virtuelle pourraient tout à fait être intégré·es à l'équipe. N'hésitez pas à me contacter pour en savoir plus.
Student academic background: Neuroscience; Science and Technology; Rehabilitation Medicine; Medical Sciences; Computer Science

Name: Data-driven characterization and control of building systems
Description: This project will explore datasets from the building automation systems of the buildings of the University of Sherbrooke (mainly at the main campus); to identify key variables; develop and curate a well-documented database of high-resolution (i.e.; high sampling rate) operational data; and identify patterns such as total electric power use; weather; indoor temperatures; human occupancy and behaviour; lighting; and operation of central heating and cooling plants. The long-term objective is to create data-driven archetypical models. These models; while reflecting the specific case study; will also capable of being representative of similar buildings; so that effective control strategies may be easily replicated elsewhere.
Skills: The student should have basic familiarity with data analysis tools (e.g.; Python Pandas) and machine learning. Familiarity with building automation systems; HVAC equipment and electric metering is an asset. The candidate(s) should be patient; organized and methodical; but also resourceful; creative and inquisitive. Both students from a computer science or a mechanical engineering background are encouraged to apply.

Name: 2- Enhancing Short-Term Electric Vehicle Charging Load Forecasting in Low-Quality Data Environments using Machine and Deep Learning.
Description: Accurately predicting electric vehicle (EV) load is crucial for evaluating and optimizing the impact of EVs on the power grid. However; the scarcity of accumulated data from newly operated EV charging stations poses significant challenges in achieving accurate prediction results. Scarce datasets suffer from missing values and outliers; which greatly affect prediction accuracy. Furthermore; training a high-accuracy model with such limited datasets is not feasible. To overcome these challenges and obtain precise EV load predictions; a data generation method will be investigated in this project. This research project entails two main parts: studying recent approaches; particularly focusing on deep learning techniques; for EVs load forecasting; and implementing a novel technique that leverages the benefits of both deep learning and statistical inference.
Skills: python programming; machine learning.

Name: 1- Leveraging Weather Predictions for Electricity Price Forecasting using Deep Learning techniques.
Description: This study aims to improve the accuracy and reliability of electricity price forecasting models by integrating weather data as a significant predictor. The proposed approach involves training deep learning models using historical weather and electricity price data; enabling them to learn complex patterns and relationships between weather conditions and electricity prices. The model's ability to capture intricate nonlinearities and dependencies within the data enhances the accuracy of the forecasting process. The results of this research will provide valuable insights into the potential benefits of incorporating weather predictions through deep learning techniques in electricity price forecasting; ultimately aiding decision-making processes in the energy sector.

Name: Évaluation de la capacité structurale des ponts atteints de réaction alcalis granulat - Shear capacity of concrete bridges affected by alkali-aggregate reaction
Description: The Alkali Aggregate Reaction (AAR) is an expansion reaction that takes place within hardened concrete; resulting in a significant and damaging state of cracking. A large number of bridges in North America are affected by AAR. While some researchers have observed a reduction in the capacity of AAR affected reinforced concrete structures; many others have observed significantly greater shear capacity. This apparent contradiction is difficult to interpret because of the difference between the in situ conditions of an existing bridge and the laboratory conditions used in research (concrete confinement; prestressing; non-uniformity of cracking; other pathologies) and their effects on shear strength mechanisms. The question therefore asked by a structural engineer is: what are the effects of AAR on the structural capacity of the bridge I have to assess? The current state of knowledge does not allow us to answer this question; and the economic; ecological and social repercussions associated to the reconstruction of a bridge are major. In a context of sustainable development; climate emergency and limited availability of public funds; it is imperative to better understand the mechanisms involved in the shear strength of concrete structures affected by AAR. The aim of this project is therefore to better understand the effect of AAR on the shear resistance mechanisms; in order to propose a model to assess shear capacity of concrete bridges. The project is multi-faceted (prototyping; laboratory testing; computer modeling and analysis; structural design and verification) and can be tailored to suit the interests and skills of the applicants.
Skills: - Initiative; - Self-starter; - Creative; - Rigorous; - Basic knowledge of reinforced concrete structures; - Basic knowledge of structural analysis; design and modeling an asset.

Name: The impact of big data analytics on corporate social responsibility: Evidence from family firms
Description: As the main form of business organization in the world; the family business is an important part of any economy. Technological innovation in family firms has become a topic of increasing interest in management research in recent years. However; there is still a lack of research on big data technology innovation (BDTI) in the family business. This research focuses on big data technology innovation and family business. It will try to study the relationship between technological innovation and financial and social performance in family firms based on socioemotional wealth theory(SEW). Based on the FIBER model; this study will identify different variables that relate BDTI and SEW and proposes a conceptual model and the formulation of hypothesis for exploring the moderating effect of five SEW dimensions (e.g.; family control and influence; family identity; binding social ties; emotional attachment; and renewal of family bonds through dynastic succession) on the relationship between the technological innovation and the corporate social responsability in the context of family firms. This study contributes to the family business literature by offering a conceptual framework of the SEW–BDTI relationship and new research avenues that will provide a better comprehension for scholars and specialists for future investigations in the field.
Skills: The students should be enrolled in business adminstration; managment or finance. The students should be familiar with finance concepts. The students should be able to explore database to gather and organize data. The students should be able to conduct a litterature review of academic publications.

Name: Cross-Chain Connect: Advancing Blockchain Interoperability for Seamless Data Transfer
Description: The project focuses on advancing blockchain interoperability to enable seamless data transfer between different blockchain platforms. The project aims to tackle the challenges associated with the siloed nature of blockchains by developing innovative solutions that promote effective communication and data exchange. The project seeks to identify key interoperability concepts; explore existing protocols; and propose solutions to enhance cross-chain connectivity. The project will involve studying various blockchain platforms; analyzing their interoperability mechanisms; and conducting experiments to evaluate the performance; efficiency and security of proposed solutions.
Skills: Solid understanding of blockchain basics; DLTs; system interoperability and computer networking protocols. Proficiency in programming languages used in blockchain development; such as Golang; Nodejs; or Java Familiarity with blockchain platforms; such as Hyperledger Fabric; Hyperledger Cacti; Hyperledger Indy and Aries; or Ethereum.

Name: Synthesis of flexible fluorescent oligomers for use in chemical sensing applications
Description: Flexible fluorescent oligomers are shorter polymeric systems in which fluorescent polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) are connected to one another by flexible short chains. Flexibility gives the materials improvised processability and solubility; which improves their usefulness.
Skills: Students with basic laboratory skills; like those obtained in an undergraduate laboratory course; are required. Previous experience in a synthetic research lab would be an asset but is not required. Students should have a background in chemistry in general and would preferably have completed introductory organic chemistry courses at the undergraduate level.

Name: Synthesis of indole cyclophanes through bridge contraction
Description: The student will be involved in a larger product that aims to use the powerful new synthetic methodology of C-H activation to construct a new type of cylcophane containing an aromatic indole. Cyclophanes are a privileged class of compounds where an aromatic system is bridged between two non-adjacent positions. As the length of the bridge is shortened; the aromatic system can be bent from planarity; altering its properties through the introduction of strain. These compounds are of interest to researchers since they allow us to probe the nature of aromaticity and push the limits of chemical possibilities.
Skills: Students with basic laboratory skills; like those obtained in an undergraduate laboratory course; are required. Previous experience in a synthetic research lab would be an asset but is not required. Students should have a background in chemistry in general and would preferably have completed introductory organic chemistry courses at the undergraduate level.

Name: Synthesis of twisted polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons through ortho-allylation
Description: This project will utilize chemistry developed in our lab for the allylation of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs). This chemistry can be performed regioselectively to give well-defined products that will be further transformed into larger PAHs through metal-catalyzed cross-coupling cyclization reactions. The nature of the allylation products means that the cyclization reaction will give new compounds that contain five or seven-membered rings. The fusion of six-membered benzenoid rings; like in the PAHs naphthalene and pyrene; gives planar systems; but when five or seven-membered rings are incorporated into the molecular scaffold; non-planarity can be induced. There are numerous advantages to non-planarity; including improved solubility; unique photophysical properties; and host-guest chemistry.
Skills: Students with basic laboratory skills; like those obtained in an undergraduate laboratory course; are required. Previous experience in a synthetic research lab would be an asset but is not required. Students should have a background in chemistry in general and would preferably have completed introductory organic chemistry courses at the undergraduate level.

Name: Bioinspiration in engineering future energy systems
Description: We use fish swimming (schooling) habits and bird flight aerodynamics to develop more efficient; fast and stealth energy systems. This requires first a clear understanding of the flow physics associated with these biological processes; and then an innovative approach to replicate and/or surpass the limits of natures using an engineered (man-made) system. Finally; we will utilize these bio-inspired design to develop better technologies for energy harvesting. Thus; this process involves combining fundamental research for knowledge acquisition; tool development; and technology development.
Skills: The student needs to have a good understanding of fluid mechanics; structural mechanics and fluid-structure-interactions with familiarity in SolidWorks; Matlab and ANSYS. The right candidate will need to complete literature review; post-process results and complete simulations on oscillating foils representing fish tail fins. Knowledge and familiarity with OpenFOAM and Tecplot are considered a plus.

Name: Circuit diameters of cubes
Description: The complexity of a linear program (LP) is closely related to the maximum distance between vertices of a polytope along edges; i.e.; its diameter. The now disproven Hirsch conjecture was a linear bound on this distance. Generalizing to allow an LP to take certain steps through the interior of the polytope leads to the still open “circuit” Hirsch conjecture. Evidence for this conjecture is promising and includes the fact that a key counterexample to classical Hirsch is not a counterexample in the circuit case. Unlike classical diameter; circuit diameter depends on the realization of a polytope. Yet it has not been studied in the context of realization spaces. Ideally; we would like to understand how circuit diameter changes across the realization space. This project will approach that study by looking at a single family of polytopes—d-dimensional cubes—for which the circuit diameter is only known for the regular realization. We will begin by exploring the circuit diameter of specific realizations of the cube in low dimensions. Then we will proceed to higher dimensional and more general realizations; focussing in particular on how small perturbations affect this diameter. Further avenues; depending on the progress of the project; would include studying other families of polytopes; and looking for an algebraic characterization of circuit diameter in terms of the realization space.
Skills: Student should have - a strong background in linear algebra and be familiar with mathematical proof techniques - some exposure to topics in discrete math (exposure to polytopes is particularly beneficial) - strong computer programming skills (any language in which they can work independently is fine; any math-specific software knowledge is also beneficial) - good communication skills - excellent attention to detail - strong work ethic It would be beneficial for the student to have seen linear programming; exposure to some abstract algebra would also be an asset.

Name: Data security in smart buildings using federated learning
Description: Modern smart buildings have several IoT sensors; i.e.; temperature; CO2; motion detection; IP camera; HVAC control; etc.. These sensors generate large scale data that can be used in several applications related to smart buildings (e.g. occupancy detection and estimation; activities recognition and prediction; end users services) for energy management systems. Most deployed IoT devices and sensors in smart buildings lack or have extremely weak built-in security which makes them vulnerable to malicious activities and security threats that are harder to detect. The first goal of this project is to detect potential security threats (i.e. intrusion detection) using advanced machine learning techniques (e.g. deep learning). The second part of this project is related to preserving data privacy using federated learning. Federated learning enables edge devices to learn a machine learning models by keeping all of the data on the device itself. The models will be trained locally instead of moving the data to the cloud; and only the estimated parameters of the model are shared across the network. Using federated learning gives the following advantages: more accurate and low latency models and privacy-preserving because the data remains on the device; and energy-efficiency because the workload on the device is drastically reduced; leading to lower power consumption and longer device life. The project will be based on real data gathered from four smart houses equipped with different types of sensors. The intern will be involved in pre-processing and analyzing the collected data and building the machine learning models.
Skills: The student needs to have good programming skills in Python and good knowledge related to machine learning and data mining.

Name: Energy Disaggregation Using Deep Learning
Description: Many studies have shown that 20-40% of the overall consumption of a country in terms of energy is determined by the domestic household consumption. Thus; improving the energy awareness at household level is a crucial issue in current energy research. Nowadays; smart meters are a key factor to support that research. Non-intrusive load monitoring (NILM) allows to identify appliances according to their power characteristics in the total power consumption of a household measures by a smart meter. The main goal is to show the consumers not only when and what quantity of energy is consumed; but also which appliance is consuming what amount of power at what time (generally referred to as energy disaggregation). Different NILM techniques; based mainly on machine learning algorithms; have been proposed in the past. Unfortunately; until now no approach could solve the disaggregation in all its complexity. The problem is still open and needs a lot of research efforts. The first part of this project will be dedicated to study recent approaches that have been proposed for energy disaggregation with a focus on deep learning techniques. The second part will be devoted to implementing a novel techniques that takes advantage of both deep learning and statistical inference.
Skills: computer science; engineering; good programming skills (Python)
Student academic background: Computer Science; Engg-Computer; Engg-Electrical; Engineering; Engg-Systems and Technology

Name: Multivariate Time Series Analysis
Description: Modeling and Applications:
Faculty supervisor: Time series is very ubiquitous in industrial environments. Capturing the time dependency is very useful for time series analysis in several real-life applications. Several univariate time series approaches have been proposed in the past. These approaches cannot effectively handle multivariate time series. Univariate time series can be viewed as zero-order tensor time series while multivariate time series can be considered as one- or higher order tensor time series where each variable depends simultaneously on its past values and on the other variables. The goal of this project is to study recent state of the art multivariate time series analysis and modeling approaches with a focus on smart cities related applications.
Student academic background: computer science; engineering; good programming skills (Python)
column11: Computer Science; Engg-Electrical; Engg-Computer

Name: An online tool to refactor the safety assurance cases of autonomous driving systems
Description: Ensuring the progress of autonomous driving technology used by autonomous vehicles can save lives; prevent injuries; reduce the traffic; the financial burden with car accidents; and the environmental damages caused by vehicles. Developing industry-wide safety standards and making sure producers of autonomous driving systems (ADSs) comply with them is crucial to foster consumer acceptance. Producers of ADSs can rely on assurance cases to demonstrate to regulatory authorities how they have complied with such standards. Assurance cases are mainly used in safety-critical areas (e.g.; automotive; railways; avionics) to deal with high-risk concerns and show to stakeholders that such systems are safe according to domain-specific criteria. Assurance cases are structured as a hierarchy of claims; with lower-level claims drawing on concrete evidence; and also serving as evidence to justify claims higher in the hierarchy. The top claim is a statement such as a system supports non-obvious requirements. The most-used graphical notation to represent assurance cases is the goal structuring notation (GSN). In an assurance case; the nature of the support of each child’s claim to its parent claim can be specified in the GSN using three support patterns. Still; several assurance cases do not yet rely on such support patterns; which makes them poorly structured and not able to properly demonstrate they are sufficiently assuring a given requirement (e.g.; safety). We will therefore develop a web-based tool that will help represent and then refactor assurance cases represented in the GSN by applying support patterns. This will increase the correctness of assurance cases by making sure the inferential links between each parent claim and its supporting children (i.e.; child claims) are properly represented/structured. A novel confidence measure based on Evidential Reasoning will be developed and used to assess the assurance case before and after the refactoring.
Skills: Good oral and written skills in English; web-based development skills (e.g. good knowledge of JavaScript/REACT framework; Java Spring framework; AWS; Google FireBase or MERN stack); and familiarity with git (e.g. GitHub).

Name: 3- Graph Neural Networks for Multi-Site PV Power Forecasting
Description: Multi-site PV power forecasting refers to the process of predicting the power generation from multiple photovoltaic (PV) sites simultaneously. It is essential for efficient grid management; energy trading; and renewable energy integration. This task presents unique challenges due to the complex and interconnected nature of PV systems across different locations. To tackle these challenges; researchers and practitioners have developed various forecasting techniques. These approaches leverage historical PV power generation data; weather conditions; geographic features; and other relevant factors to build predictive models. Machine learning and statistical methods are commonly employed; including time series analysis; regression models; and artificial neural networks. In this project we will develop Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) which have emerged as a promising approach for multi-site PV power forecasting; addressing the complex interconnectedness of PV systems across different locations. GNNs leverage graph structures to capture spatial relationships and dependencies between PV sites; improving the accuracy of power generation predictions; and incorporate various data sources
Skills: machine learning; data mining; python

Name: 7- Tackling Activity Recognition Challenges Through Model Adaptation for Scarcity of Labeled Data
Description: Activity recognition in smart buildings involves using sensors; data analysis; and machine learning techniques to automatically identify and understand human activities within a building environment. The scarcity of labeled data is a common challenge in activity recognition problems. Collecting and annotating large amounts of labeled data can be time-consuming; expensive; and sometimes impractical. In this project we will tackle the problem of activity recognition using model adaptation techniques; that refer to the process of adapting a pre-trained activity recognition model to perform effectively in a new or different domain. This adaptation is necessary when the target domain has different characteristics; such as different sensor types; environmental conditions; which can affect the performance of the pre-trained model.
Skills: Machine learning; data mining; Python

Name: Tracing the Origins of Municipal Equity
Description: Diversity
Host Province: The landscape of equity in Canadian municipal governance is shifting rapidly. There has been an uptick in the adoption of Equity; Diversity; and Inclusion (EDI) initiatives (these may also include a focus on justice and decolonization). In many cities; local NGOs - often; women-focused organizations - have been at the centre of this work; both assisting and pushing municipal governments to advance their work on equity. In Ottawa; the City for All Women Initiative (CAWI) is a key example of an organization that has worked since the early 2000s both inside and outside municipal government to shape the development and adoption of equity tools for municipal practitioners. CAWI’s Advancing Equity and Inclusion Guide for Municipalities; first developed in 2005 as a tool to improve attention to women and gender equity; has been in use in Ottawa since 2018 and serves as the foundation for much of the internally-facing equity work that has been developed in Canadian municipalities. However; little has been documented about the way this current EDI work transformed from a focus on women's equity to a focus on equity more broadly. Moreover; many of the key players who were involved in early iterations of women's equity strategies are now retired from their professional and activist roles and; in some cases; have passed on. This project seeks to a) create an archive of stories about women's municipal-focused activism by capturing the voices of those who are still with us; and b) document the development and early iterations of what we know today to be municipal equity strategies.
Skills: English
column11: In terms of focus areas; the student should be: knowledgeable about and interested in women in cities; gender equity; intersectional and trans-inclusive analysis; and interested in policy and planning at the municipal scale. In terms of skills; the student should be: -comfortable conducting academic literature reviews; -comfortable reading and analyzing policy documents and grey literature; -interested in undertaking online and in-person archival research to find and gather policy documents; -comfortable writing reports in English; -willing to conduct detailed notetaking of recorded municipal council meetings; -interested in supporting and conducting in-depth interviews; -interested in supporting and conducting qualitative data analysis.

Name: Mathematical modeling and analysis for oncolytic virotherapy (OV) in cancer immunology
Description: In the OV; the oncolytic viruses were injected into the patients to infect cancer cells. Once the tumor cell is infected; the viruses replicate themselves inside the cancer cell and will be released into the tumor microenvironment to attract more cytotoxic T cells and macrophages to kill cancer cells resulting in tumor eradication. Therefore; the higher population of the viruses is; the better treatment efficacy of OV is. However; the population of the viruses is reduced; if the infected cancer cells are attacked by macrophages before the viruses were released. Thus; the immune checkpoints expressed on macrophages (such as CD200) reduce the functions of macrophages and hence reduce the killing rate of infected cancer cells by macrophages resulting in a higher population of viruses and a better treatment efficacy of OV. Additionally; immune checkpoint inhibitors for T cells (such as anti-PD-1) enhance the killing rate of tumor cells by T cells and hence improve the treatment efficacy of OV. Therefore; combination of overexpression of the immune checkpoint on macrophages and immune checkpoint inhibitors for T cells could obtain the optimal treatment efficacy of OV. In this project; we will work on developing mathematical (ODE) model to capture the immune responses in the combination of overexpression of the immune checkpoint on macrophages and immune checkpoint inhibitors for T cells in the OVs. This ODEs model includes the variables: uninfected tumor cells; virus-infected tumor cells; virus particles; M1 and M2 macrophages; CD8+ T cells; CD200- CD200R; and PD-1-PD-L1 to investigate the optimal treatment efficacy of OV by using numerical simulation; sensitivity analysis; and numerical bifurcation diagram.
Skills: 1. Programming skills for Matlab 2. Modeling skills for ODE and PDE models 3. Know how to generate numerical solutions for ODE and PDE model by using Matlab 4. Willing to learn some biological data / background 5. Analysis skills for ODE model; including existence; uniqueness; and boundedness of solution; positively invariant set; local stability of equilibria 6. Use Latex for manuscript editing

Name: Mathematical analysis and modeling for the opposite functions of immune checkpoint inhibitors in cancer treatment
Description: In most of my previous works related to immune checkpoint inhibitors; we used modeling and simulation tools to investigate how the balance between the pro-inflammatory and anti-inflammatory reactions from different types of treatments affects the tumor growth/treatment outcome. The model structures or the parameter setting could be different due to different treatment targets or cancer types; but the idea is the same: the balance between pro-inflammatory and anti-inflammatory reactions. Thus; in this project; we will generate a general mathematical model incorporating general functions f and g for the pro-inflammatory and anti-inflammatory reactions that can be used for most immune checkpoint inhibitors. Next; we will use mathematical analysis or simulation to derive conditions of the model for tumor reduction/promotion based on the function properties of f and g.
Skills: 1. Programming skills for Matlab 2. Modeling skills for ODE and PDE models 3. Know how to generate numerical solutions for ODE and PDE model by using Matlab 4. Willing to learn some biological data / background 5. Analysis skills for ODE model; including existence; uniqueness; and boundedness of solution; positive invariant set; local stability of equilibria; bifurcation analysis 6. Use Latex for manuscript editing

Name: CAR-T cell treatment in acute and chronic B cell leukemias and then extend this model to CAR-T cell treatment in cancer treatment
Description: The chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T cell therapy uses the engineering patients’ immune cells to attack the target cells. The treatment efficacy of CAR-T cell treatment in acute and chronic B cell leukemias is excellent; because the biomarkers of malignant B cells on CAR-T cell can accurate target the abnormal B cells and avoid to damage the normal and healthy cells. Recently; researchers started to apply the CAR-T cell therapy to cancers. However; the treatment outcome is not good as expected. The reason is that the biomarkers are not specific to cancer cells; such that the CAR-T cells also attack other normal cells and then cause serious side-effect of the patients. In this project; we will create a mathematical model to capture the mechanism of how the CAR-T cell works in B cell leukemias and the interaction between the biomarkers and B cells. Next; we will modify this model to capture the interaction between CAR-T cells and tumor microenvironment to investigate the potential methods for improving the treatment outcome of CAR-T cell in cancer.
Skills: 1. Programming skills for Matlab 2. Modeling skills for ODE and PDE models 3. Know how to generate numerical solutions for ODE and PDE model by using Matlab 4. Willing to learn some biological data / background 5. Analysis skills for ODE model; including existence; uniqueness; and boundedness of solution; positive invariant set; local stability of equilibria 6. Use Latex for manuscript editing

Name: Assessing self-paced open degree programs with a mathematical model
Description: An important aspect to consider by a distance education institution when working towards fostering lifelong learning is to ensure that its degree programs are regularly and properly assessed. Based on such assessments; which commonly have both qualitative and quantitative components; the strengths; weaknesses and needs of the programs are identified. This provides a useful ground to initiate and execute the necessary changes in the programs to help guarantee their sustainability. In this project; we aim at using a mathematical tool; given by a system of ordinary differential equations; for assessing the student population dynamics within self-paced open degree programs. The model will be used to quantify the temporal dynamics of various programs through the estimation of various parameters such as the overall enrollment; engagement; withdrawal; and graduation rates; assess their historical performance; and predict the future performance of the programs under consideration. We will also assess the impact that the different model parameters have on the outcome of the programs in terms of number of graduates.
Skills: The following areas of mathematics are required: Calculus; Linear Algebra; and Ordinary Differential Equations. Also; it is required that the student is familiar and skillful in computer programming; specifically with Python.

Name: Application of deconvolution methods for resolution enhancement and better interpretation of seismic data
Description: Geophysicists image the underground of Earth to explore renewable and non-renewable resources. To do so; they use seismic sources to propagate seismic waves in the subsurface. Then; they record the reflected seismic energy from the layer interfaces using the recording devices (e.g.; hydrophone or geophone) near the surface or in the wells. The reflected seismic energy is modeled by the convolution of the source signature with the reflectivity series of rock layer interfaces. The reflectivity series shows the changes in the rock properties (Impedance) in different layers in the subsurface. Hence; geophysicists are interested in extracting the reflectivity series information from seismic data. However; seismic data is always noisy. Also; the band-limited nature of the source signature reduces the resolution of the data. Noisy and low resolution nature of seismic data hinders its successful interpretation.
