Deconvolution is an important technique that can remove the effect of the source signature from the seismic data without boosting the noise. Deconvolution has extensive applications in different fields of study; such as astronomical imaging; medical imaging; digital angiographic images; optics; photography; and geophysics. Deconvolution is a long-lasting and challenging problem to solve. For more than a century; researchers used different constraints or assumptions to develop deconvolution algorithms. However; for real-world applications; some of the assumptions are not valid; resulting in poor performances of the algorithms. In this project; the student will work on developing and testing deconvolution algorithms based on realistic assumptions. To be specific; the student will work on developing deconvolution algorithms based on sparsity assumptions on the reflectivity series and no assumptions on the phase of the source signature and compare the result with well-known deconvolution methods. To deliver this project; familiarity with seismic data is an advantage; however; students with computational and signal processing backgrounds are more than welcome to apply.
Skills: To deliver the project; the student should be familiar with MATLAB or Python programming and basic signal processing concepts. Geoscience background and familiarity with seismic data is an advantage; however; students with computational and signal processing background are encouraged to apply for this position.

Name: CO2 Utilization for the production of Urea
Description: The objective of this project is to develop; validate; optimize and design a conceptual commercial scale process for the CO2 utilization for the production of urea. The work will include a techno economic study and sensitivity analysis based on comprehensive and parametric process simulation.
Skills: - Chemical Engineering Background - Process Simulation Skills

Name: CO2 Utilization for the production of Formic Acid
Description: The objective of this project is to develop; validate; optimize and design a conceptual commercial scale process for the CO2 Utilization for the production of Formic Acid. The work will include a techno economic study and sensitivity analysis based on comprehensive and parametric process simulation.
Skills: - Chemical Engineering Background - Process Simulation Skills

Name: Biomass to Synthesis Gas: Process Modeling and Simulation
Description: The numerical simulation will be performed to optimize the design condition for an entrain flow gasifier. This will allow the design of an entrain flow gasifier with optimal efficiency. The low fidelity simulation will be based on thermodynamic equilibrium analysis using the equilibrium constant approach and Gibbs energy minimization approach. These simulations will help to quickly perform the parametric study of varying oxidizer/moderator ratio with the effect of change in temperature; CO2 production and syngas composition. Also; a simulation of completed power cycle will be model using ASPEN PLUS software to calculate the overall efficiency of the power plant including the energy penalty due to CO2 capture. A high fidelity simulation with comprehensive three dimensional simulation model will be developed for an entrain flow gasifier that incorporates fluid dynamics; reaction kinetics and the effect of heat and mass transfer. This high fidelity simulation in conjunction with low fidelity simulation will help to design the reactor geometry and as well as the optimal operating parameters to achieve higher efficiency.
Skills: - Strong Chemical Engineering Background - Knowledge of process simulation software such as ASPEN

Name: Greenhouse Gas Emissions Accounting
Description: This project develops and demonstrates a system of engineering accounting for clearly and comprehensively quantifying emissions savings realized by industrial GHG abatement projects; in alignment with ISO and industry standards and Canadian regulations. This system will be demonstrated for the grey-to-blue conversion of a conceptual ammonia producer in Weyburn; Saskatchewan; providing guidance concerning end-product CO2 intensity; emissions by species and scope through time; key emissions sources and options for mitigation; and allowances made for operational performance and downtime. Design Components Key design components of this project include: • Process simulation considering both the base ammonia plant as well as CO2 capture; compression; dehydration; and transmission. Ammonia is high-level; CO2 is detailed. • Equipment design: CO2 absorber; regenerator; reboiler; heat exchangers; pumps & compressors; CO2 dehydration; piping and pipeline hydraulics. • Site design: location and arrangement of equipment; site access and egress routes; routing of piping; pipe rack; conduit; etc.; separation distances & containment areas. • Project economics: AACE Class 5 factored estimating methodologies; operating cost estimation; revenue forecasting; and net present value calculation. Objectives Students will achieve the following objectives: • Simulation of a conventional ammonia production plant to provide a baseline case. • Completion of a 95% CO2 capture design delivering supercritical pipeline-grade CO2 to an injection well located 50km from the plant. Students will conceptualize the entire process; from stack to well; simulate it; size and specify equipment; assess cost and emissions reduction; and prepare the required engineering and project deliverables. • Development and demonstration of a “Basis of Emissions” clearly identifying emissions saved over the mitigation project’s life. • Assessment of project economics based on mitigation of greenhouse gas emissions and avoidance of carbon price charges.
Skills: Students must have the following competencies: • Strong understanding of chemistry; heat/mass balances; and thermodynamics. • Understanding of energy uses within an industrial facility. Heat integration methods. • Understanding of industrial equipment (e.g.; compression; furnaces; boilers; reactors; absorption towers; heat exchangers; pumps; etc.) • Understanding of power consumption estimation for rotating machinery. • Understanding of engineering economics. • Awareness of greenhouse gas emissions regulations in Canada.

Name: Chemical ecology and biochemistry of poplar
Description: Poplars contain a large variety active phenolic secondary metabolites; including tannins and phenolic glycosides. These chemicals allow poplar species to thrive in diverse but often stressful environments. Condensed tannins can act as general defense compounds; antimicrobials and antioxidants; while the salicinoid phenolic glycosides protect poplar against insect herbivores. Our aim is to understand the regulation and biosynthesis of these phenolic secondary metabolites; and to test their importance using transgenic plants. For example; poplar trees with reduced phenolic glycoside concentrations have been produced in our laboratory using CRISPR technology. These have demonstrated an essential step in phenolic glycoside biosynthesis; and also provide a unique research opportunity for poplar chemical ecology. Additional CRISPR-mutants are being created; and these will be characterized by the student. The project's aims is to characterize novel genome-edited poplar lines. We will grow plants under controlled conditions and study the changes in phenolic chemicals due to the mutations in these plants. In parallel; we will conduct bioassays to what effects the change in phenolics has resistance to leaf-eating insects. Poplar trees will be grown in the Centre for Forest Biology's Glover Greenhouse. Phytochemical concentrations in poplar extracts will be assayed by high performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) of methanol leaf extracts using standard procedures. For bioassays; insect bioassays will established using leaves from transgenic and control plants. Leaf area consumed and larval weight gain is a function of plant resistance. All these experiments help to contribute to our understanding of the biosynthesis and role of poplar phenolic secondary metabolites.
Skills: Applicants should have a strong background in biology or biochemistry with interests in botany; ecology; or entomology; and should have good quantitative skills. They should also have a keen interest in understanding plant adaptation and ecological interactions at a molecular level. Students with laboratory experience in chemistry; biochemistry; or molecular biology are preferred. Basic computer skills and familiarity with MS Excel and PowerPoint are considered an asset; as is experience with basic statistical tests. Strong applicants will also be self-motivated and have good communication skills and an ability to work independently.

Name: Enhanced Mixed Matrix Membranes for Water and Wastewater Treatment
Description: Membrane technologies are currently the most effective and sustainable methods utilized in diversified water filtration; wastewater treatment; and industrial and sustainable energy applications. The major drawback of membrane technologies is fouling phenomenon; which causes a decline in permeation flux; change in selectivity; increase in energy consumption; higher operating costs; and reduced membrane lifetimes. Mixed matrix membranes (MMMs) have gained serious importance in microfiltration; UF; nanofiltration (NF); forward osmosis (FO); and reverse osmosis (RO) applications. Inserting hydrophilic NFs such as nanoparticles (NPs); functional multi wall carbon nanotubes (MWNT); graphene oxides (GO); or zeolites is an effective method of controlling hydrophilicity and morphology of MMMs. Despite their advantageous features; MMMs face multiple drawbacks when it comes to the identification of compatible NFs; as well as the lack of NFs dispersion mechanisms that in turn cause low physical; thermal; chemical; and mechanical stabilities during filtration; chemical cleaning; or backwash processes. This project aims to provide an in-depth assessment and enhancement MMM membrane performance. A novel MMM membrane will be developed and synthesized by the research group and several fouling remediation techniques will be created. For the virtual experience; all the virtual trainings and detailed plan will be provided.
Skills: This project requires a background in Organic Chemistry and chemical engineering; as well as a background in experimental design; and basics of modeling experience.

Name: Enhanced Forward Osmosis Membranes for Water and Wastewater Treatment
Description: Continuously escalating global water demands place a substantial burden on the available water and energy resources. Forward osmosis (FO) is an evolving membrane desalination technology that has recently raised interest as a promising low energy process. FO is a unique method since it utilizes natural osmosis as the driving force; and hence; ensures that the energy consumption is significantly reduced; in comparison to other pressure driven membrane processes that are constrained by their excessive energy consumption and unsustainable cost. The resurging interest in the FO membrane process can help it become a sustainable alternative to the conventional membrane processes as well as a new industry standard. Despite the method’s numerous benefits; FO fouling has hindered a more widespread FO application in real-world water purification projects. As a result; the growing interest in FO from various disciplines and industrial sectors calls for a better understanding of the FO process and further advances in the FO technology management. This project aims to provide an in-depth assessment and enhancement of the water transport phenomenon in FO membranes. A novel FO membrane will be developed and synthesized by the research group and several fouling remediation techniques will be created. For the virtual experience; we will integrate all the virtual experience and training needed.
Skills: This project requires a background in Organic Chemistry and chemical engineering; as well as a background in experimental design; and modeling experience.

Name: High Efficiency Biomimetic and Bioinspired Hemodialysis Membranes
Description: According to the National Kidney Foundation; the chronic kidney disease (CKD) affects 10% of the worldwide population. Hemodialysis is a life-sustaining procedure that can help deal with CKD; however; it is also associated with acute side effects that may involve life-threatening and chronic side-effects that diminish the patient’s quality of life. According to the Kidney Foundation of Canada 2017; more than 3 million Canadians have chronic kidney disease; a number that increases at a rate of 5-7% per year; or specifically around 1 in 10 Canadians has kidney disease and millions more are currently at risk. Therefore; Hemodialysis is an essential treatment for severe kidney failure (renal failure or end stage renal disease; ESRD); when the kidneys are no longer working effectively and waste products and fluids are building up in the blood. Unfortunately; this membrane-based hemodialysis therapy is still an incomplete renal replacement; as the mortality and morbidity rated for these patients remain unacceptably high. Hemodialysis Membrane performance; as determined by the effectiveness of solute clearance and biocompatibility; is of the utmost concern when choosing a dialyzer. As a result; technological advances in membrane designs and their chemical compositions are essential; especially since they are critical for enhanced hemodialysis performance and versatility that will reduce morbidity rates and prolong patient survival. The goal of the present study is to control the membrane’s morphology with Medium Molecular Weight Cut-Off membrane MWCO membranes; and to promote the removal of protein-bound uremic toxins and middle to large molecular-weight solutes.
Skills: This project requires a background in Chemistry and Chemical Engineering; as well as a background experimental design; and modeling experience. Students will be provided with the necessary safety training for handling of nanomaterials and biosafety.

Name: Molecular Dynamics Simulations of Membranes with Enhanced Hydrophilicity and Biocompatibility
Description: Membrane technology is a rapidly developing research area; with key growth in large-scale industrial applications; including biotechnology; biomedical applications; food industry; and water and wastewater treatment. Unfortunately; membranes are prone to the fouling phenomenon; which leads to high operational costs; increased power consumption; and reduced membrane lifetime. The goal of the proposed membrane design is to make its particular process highly efficient; cost effective; easily applicable; and sustainable. In order to obtain these key improvements; advances in membrane materials are necessary for the membrane technologies; and a revolutionary progress of membrane materials is needed for properly tackling the water and energy sustainability. Although there have been a number of attempts to improve this type of membrane technology; the understanding of membrane fouling and its consequent permeate flux decline still remain a challenge. The major goal of the present study is to enhance the membranes’ hydrophilicity and biocompatibility for a variety of critical applications. In this study; molecular dynamic simulation will be used so as to design new filtration membranes; as well as comprehensively understand water transport; organic solute rejection in polymeric membranes; and membrane properties at the molecular scale.
Skills: This project requires a background in Organic Chemistry; basic knowledge about molecular simulations capabilities; and an interest in learning Molecular Dynamics Simulations.

Name: Investigating the effectiveness of argument mapping in post-secondary classrooms
Description: Many existing instructional approaches aim to promote a student’s reasoning ability through computer-assisted argumentation. An example of computer-assisted argumentation would be web-based argument mapping. The proposed research aims to conduct a meta-analysis to examine the effectiveness of web-based argument mapping tools in promoting reasoning skills in post-secondary education. Argument mapping is an instructional approach that helps students to see inferential connections between claims and evidence; and assess them in terms of argument structure validity and soundness of premises. Students use diagrams to show the relationships between claims and evidence presented in an argument. Research has revealed a positive gain of using online argument mapping tools in various instructional settings with different populations; but there has been a lack of understanding of the parameters leading to such gain. The proposed study will thus synthesize past and current research on argument mapping tools through a meta-analysis. The investigation is important to inform instructional practices; assisting post-secondary instructors in integrating argument mapping into their teaching.
Skills: - Familiarity with research methods; including conducting literature reviews and data extraction. - Strong analytical skills and experience with statistical analysis software (e.g.; SPSS). - Excellent organizational skills and attention to detail. - Proficient in academic writing and communication. - Previous experience with meta-analyses or systematic reviews is desirable but not required. - Ability to work independently and meet deadlines.

Name: Aging of high-performance fabrics used in firefighter protective clothing
Description: Several families of high-performance fibers have been developed over the last 50 years with exceptional properties in terms of mechanical and chemical resistance; inherent flame resistance; and thermal stability. This includes aramids (e.g.; Kevlar®; Nomex®; Kermel®); poly (melamine-formaldehyde) (Basofil®); polybenzoxazole (PBO; Zylon®); and polybenzimidazole (PBI). However; the various conditions these fibers are exposed to during the lifetime of the protective clothing reduce their performance over time. The damaging conditions a firefighter protective clothing can be exposed to during service include: 1. High heat from the fire; between 60 and 300°C inside a burning room or a small burning building; and around 1000°C in the case of flash fire; 2. UV radiation from direct sunlight during outdoor operations; fluorescent lamps during indoor activities and storage; and fire; 3. Moisture from the extinguishing medium; weather conditions; matter’s burning process; the clothing wearer's perspiration; and the clothing laundering. Through this research; fabrics used in manufacturing firefighter-protective clothing are subjected to different aging conditions to evaluate their physical and chemical alteration. The aging conditions are defined to simulate the actual service conditions of the fire protective garments. The objectives of the research are: 1. Understand the kinetic and mechanisms of the cumulative and individual impact of aging agents on the common material used in fire protective garments; 2. Define the acceleration aging conditions that can be achieved within a lab environment simulating actual service conditions; aligning with different working conditions and firefighter categories; 3. Produce an accelerated aging model to predict the aging behavior of fire protective garments during the main categories of service conditions.
Skills: An understanding of polymer science is important for the project. In addition to being curious and rigorous; the student should be able to work independently while displaying a good ability for teamwork. Oral and written communication skills are important as well. Prior lab work experience and an understanding of textiles are an asset.

Name: Design and Analysis of Geothermal Energy Systems in Western Canada
Description: Western Canada lies along the ring of fire; the technically active margin of the Pacific Ocean; and has a strong potential to exploit geothermal energy. Yet; counter to many of the countries along this ring of fire; Canada only installed the first commercial geothermal power generator in 2023. This project aims to evaluate conceptual or planned geothermal energy systems; for heat and/or power; based on the geology and thermal gradients present near population centers in Alberta and British Columbia. During the design process; stakeholders from the local community chosen - either a small to medium-sized city or a remote community; the drilling contractor and operators and regulators will be continuously engaged. Existing contacts between Dr. Shor and the stakeholders are in place and appropriate partners will be identified prior to the start of the project. The conceptual energy system design will evaluate existing well designs used for geothermal; including open-loop and closed-loop systems; consider the geology and thermal reservoir properties through the use of reservoir modeling; and will size the surface facility for the required capacity and utilization factors. During this design process; an economic analysis will be conducted and will help steer design decisions with the goal of developing a system that is cost-competitive with alternatives and with the local grid. Finally; social and environmental concerns will be evaluated and addressed.
Skills: Students should have at least three of the following skills or experience: (1) reservoir engineering; including fluid flow in porous media; (2) thermodynamics; including heat transfer; phase transitions and heat capacity; (3) fluid dynamics; including multiphase flow; (4) drilling engineering; including well construction and horizontal drilling; (5) geologic characterization of energy systems; (6) geothermal systems; (7) economic analysis of energy systems and (8) district energy systems. Students are also expected to have strong communication and interpersonal skills; as there will be significant interfacing with external partners.
Student academic background: Earth Science; Engg-Chemical; Engg-Enviromental; Engg-Petroleum; Engineering; Geology; Economics; Engg-Civil; Engg-Mechanical; Industrial Design and Technology; Engg-Geological; Engg-Systems and Technology

Name: Effects of acidity on lichens on trees at forest edges in Nova Scotia
Description: Canada
Faculty supervisor: This research project is part of a larger study examining the effects of proximity to clearcut edges; acidification and slug herbivory on epiphytic lichens (that live on tree trunks). This research is of concern to conservation and the forestry industry because some of these lichens are important species at risk in Nova Scotia; Canada. The proposed project focuses on the effects of acidity on lichens. Next year we will be resampling plots that were treated with lime in 2019 to lower acidity and control plots. Lichens and understorey vegetation will be sampled at different distances from clearcut forest edges. In addition to helping with resampling and other field work; this project will include data analysis comparing results to the data collected before liming to evaluate the effects of acidity on epiphytic lichens. Results from this study will help address the overall goal of determining which factors may be causing the decline of some lichen species at risk in Nova Scotia; Canada.
Student academic background: I am looking for a student with a strong background (coursework) in ecology. Outdoor field work experience is an asset and an ability to work and camp outdoors for extended periods of time is required. Plant identification skills; ability to use GPS; GIS skills and data analysis (statistics) experience would be useful but are not essential. Written and oral scientific communication skills would also be beneficial.

Name: UX of layouts in XR
Description: In our research; we focus on the design aspects of placing user interface (UI) elements in room-scale user interfaces and the layout of multiple views in Extended Reality (XR) applications. We aim to understand how users interact with spatial representations and explore effective strategies for UI placement and interaction preferences with three-dimensional data. The visiting student will collaborate with our team to identify a specific experiment of interest and develop a system prototype using the Unity game engine on head-mounted displays like the MS HoloLens 2; Oculus Quest; HTC Vive and Varjo. If time permits; the student will also collect and analyze data; contributing to the development of empirical-based design guidelines in this area.
Skills: The student needs to have good software development skills. Some experience with the Unity game engine is preferred; but this could also be acquired as part of the project. A curiosity for new XR technologies and software development is key.

Name: Patterns of vegetation structure and biodiversity across heterogeneous forested landscapes in Nova Scotia
Description: Canada
Faculty supervisor: A major consequence of forest fragmentation is edge influence on vegetation in which forest structure and composition differs at harvested or agricultural edges compared to interior forest. Vegetation responses to forest edges are variable and depend on edge type; forest type; geographic location and other stand characteristics. However; it is difficult to make comparisons because of the extensive time involved for field studies. With the advent of remote sensing; especially LIDAR; an understanding of the extent of edge effects on forest ecosystems can be made using quantitative; accurate and repeatable techniques that measure the intensity of the effects on the vegetation structure of forest edges. The project will use LIDAR imagery to retrieve detailed inventory parameters of forest ecosystems and incorporate remote sensing to assess patterns of vegetation structure at forest edges. Details on locations; edge types and forest types are still being determined; but the project will likely focus on forest edges within Nova Scotia; Canada. However; a possible sub-project for the intern could be analysing LIDAR imagery from their own country. The project will likely consist of two components: widely available LIDAR imagery to examine broad-scale patterns and LIDAR imagery collected using a drone next summer. Although the original intent of the project was to investigate harvested edges; fire edges may be added. At the time of this writing; there are unprecedented fires burning in Nova Scotia; highlighting the relevance of fire disturbance with respect to climate change; therefore understanding the structure of fire edges is becoming more important. LIDAR imagery will be used to determine the distance of edge influence or edge width on vegetation structure and structural diversity. Comparisons will be made between edge types and forest types.
Student academic background: I am looking for a student with a keen interest and a strong background (coursework) in geography or ecology. Some experience or courses in GIS; remote sensing; drone imagery or similar field of study is required. Outdoor field work experience or experience being outdoors for extended periods of time is an asset. Data analysis (statistics) experience is useful. Written and oral scientific communication skills would also be beneficial.
column11: Ecology

Name: UX for cross-reality applications
Description: Our application enhances the understanding of presented information; leading to more effective and efficient problem-solving by utilizing transitions between or concurrent usage of multiple systems along the RVC. For example; we enable users to transition 3D data visualizations from computer monitor to AR so that users can gain more depth cues and interact with the data using more intuitive ways such as hand gestures and body movements. We are investigating a broad spectrum of design questions; such as how users would prefer to transition virtual objects between points along the RVC; how users would prefer to transition between real; augmented; and virtual spaces; and what interactions are most effective for triggering those transitions. The visiting student will work with my graduate students and me to identify a specific controlled experiment of interest to them and us. The student will then develop a system prototype to run the experiment (We use the Unity game engine to develop spatial-temporal representations of complex and large data running on head-mounted displays like the Varjo XR3 and Microsoft HoloLens 2). If time permits; the student will collect and analyze data; resulting in an empirical-based design guideline.
Skills: The student needs to have good software development skills. Some experience with the Unity game engine is preferred; but this could also be acquired as part of the project. A curiosity for new CR technologies and software development is key.

Name: Essais expérimentaux de combustion par micromélange pour turbine à gaz récupérée
Description: Le groupe de recherche CREATEK a développé une nouvelle architecture de turbine; nommée Inside-out Ceramic Turbine (ICT); qui utilise un anneau structurel en fibre de carbone pour retenir les pales en compression. Cette approche permet l'utilisation fiable de céramique dans un rotor; et donc d'opérer à des températures d'entrées de turbine (TIT) élevées; augmentant ainsi l'efficacité et la densité de puissance de turbines à gaz récupérées. Par contre; l'augmentation du TIT mène également à l'augmentation de la température d'entrée de la chambre à combustion (CIT); causant des problèmes tels que des émissions polluantes élevées et des instabilités de combustion. Pour résoudre ces problèmes; une nouvelle approche de combustion par micromélange a été développée; et les résultats préliminaires ont démontrés des émissions polluantes faibles mais une combustion pouvant être instable; surtout avec des carburants moins réactifs ou a basse température. Le projet de recherche vise donc à continuer le développement de cette approche en améliorant la stabilité de combustion et démontrer l'approche avec des carburants alternatifs tels que l'hydrogène et les biocarburants.
Skills: Le stagiaire devra répondre aux exigences suivantes. - Bonne compréhension des principes fondamentaux du génie. - Dynamisme et créativité pour répondre de manière appropriée aux nombreux défis rencontrés en recherche appliqué. - Mentalité entrepreneuriale; capacité à réaliser rapidement des prototypes; autonomie; débrouillardise. - Intérêt et expérience en conception mécanique et/ou en thermodynamique et/ou en combustion. - Expérience pratique en mesure expérimentale.

Name: Social Impacts of Misinformation Generated in Social Media
Description: In today’s world; misinformation and post-truth; have become common. As misinformation can generate misperceptions; it can negatively affect policies and potentially impact society in various domains; including but not limited to; economy; health; climate change; and foreign policy. The World Economic Forum listed digital misinformation as a key challenge to modern societies in 2013 report. Indeed; misinformation has become a common part of our digital media environments; and is compromising the ability of individuals to create informed decisions and policies. In 2016; ‘post-truth’ was chosen by the Oxford Dictionary as word of the year; after achieving a 2000% increase “in the context of the EU referendum in the United Kingdom. Also; more recently all the debates around the presidential election in the United States; COVID-19; and Twitter shows the importance of the impact of misinformation and conspiracies. A 2016 survey by the Reuters Institute for the Study of Journalism found that 51% of people use social media as their source of news; with Facebook being the top used social media platform for finding; reading; and sharing news. This demonstrates the high and constantly growing impact of online media on perceptions of current affairs and policies. Misinformation is a new challenge in modern life. We are constantly dealing with new information without knowing the real truth. Most of the information disseminated by means of social media; electronic media; and in some cases; through print media. According to the media jargon; terms such as misinformation; fake news; disinformation; and propaganda are all used interchangeably. The question is how we can incorporate social science theory to handle misinformation in social media. What types of social impacts could this spread of misinformation have in our life? State-of-the-art machine learning techniques could provide a platform to address the issue; together with incorporation of communication theory.
Skills: The student is required to be familiar with Machine learning techniques. In addition; programming skill in Python is required. Experience working with numeric data; data visualization; and optimization is desirable but not required. Students in Computer Science; Computer engineering; statistics; or a related field are encouraged to apply.

Name: Long term trend of air quality in Canada
Description: In most Canadian cites; air quality has been gradually improving during the last 20 years. However; there have been a few examinations of the relationship with the emission reduction that has occurred during the same time period. By investigating the air quality and emission trends for particulate matter; volatile organic compounds; ozone and mercury in southern Ontario and other Canadian cities in the past 20 years; this study will provide useful methodology that could be used in other places to evaluate the effectiveness of emission control measures. Such assessment will aid development of future emission reduction policy.
Skills: The project requires students from science or engineering programs; such as environmental sciences; environmental engineering; civil engineering; agricultural engineering; resources engineering; biosystems engineering; and mechanical engineering. Students are required to have good communication skills in both oral and written English.
Student academic background: Atmospheric Science; Engg-Aeronautical; Engg-Biological; Engg-Biomedical; Engg-Chemical; Engg-Civil; Engg-Enviromental; Engg-Enviromental; Engg-Geological; Engg-Industrial; Engg-Manufacturing; Engg-Manufacturing; Engg-Materials; Engg-Mechanical; Engg-Mineral; Engg-Mining; Engg-Petroleum; Engineering; Environmental Studies

Name: Predicting online learning performance using Machine Learning techniques
Description: Our research questions are: • How to predict students’ academic performance based on different sources of data; including online behavior and interactions with the Learning Management System (LMS)? • How early can a prediction model predict students’ academic performance that can adequately balance the required timing of intervention with the quality of the prediction? • Which prediction methods work best to predict student performance? In this study; we will be using different factors including student academic performance; drop-out; and engagement. We will investigate the effectiveness of several ML techniques to present comparative experimental results.
Skills: The student is required to be familiar with Machine learning. In addition; programming skill in Python is required. Students in Computer Science; Computer engineering; or a related field are encouraged to apply.

Name: Introducing a Scalable object detection algorithm to achieve higher accuracy and computational efficiency in Breast Cancer Images
Description: Mass detection and diagnosis in mammograms is still a challenging problem. Considering recent studies in the field of AI for the early detection of breast cancer using CNN; several limitations can be observed including use of non-representative imaging data for model training; limited validation in external datasets; potential bias in training data; and few comparative data for AI versus radiologists’ interpretation of mammography screening. Previous studies have been mostly small retrospective studies based on highly selected image datasets that contained a high proportion of cancers (median BC proportion in datasets: 26.5%). There is potential for bias due to the use of unbalanced imaging data (that does not represent the spectrum in real-world screening) to train and test models; hence; algorithms may not perform well in actual screening practice. Therefore; a unique AI solution tailored specifically for a large real-world dataset in mammography is drastically required. In this project; based on the extensive literature review; a scalable object detection algorithm will be introduced with the aim of achieving higher accuracy and computational efficiency.
Skills: The student is required to be familiar with Machine learning. In addition; programming skill in Python is required. Experience working with imaging data; medical image processing; and optimization is desirable but not required. Students in Computer Science; Computer engineering; or a related field are encouraged to apply.

Name: Radio and optical budget links
Description: Structure radio and optical link budgets as well as cellular dimensionning in one site. Based on existing programs and the books BENSOUSSAN; D.; LE MOUROUX; A.; Réseaux mobiles et satellitaires - Du 1G au 5G - Principes; calculs et simulations; Presses de l’Université du Québec; BENSOUSSAN; David; "Introduction à la communication par fibre optique"; ISBN TK5103.59B46; Édition de l'ÉTS; 2000; 191 p.; Réédité en 2003.
Skills: Matlab programming

Name: Systematic literature reviews on computational thinking
Description: This project involves learning how to conduct literature searches and extracting information about the records retrieved.
Skills: It would be helpful if the student is familiar with educational psychology; learning theories; and/or computational thinking.

Name: Computational thinking
Description: I am interested in analyzing and developing assessments of computational thinking concepts; practices; and perspectives. For instance; I help develop instruments to measure computational thinking; including games.
Skills: Thus; students from education; psychology; or computer science-related fields are welcome. Knowledge of programming is a plus but not absolutely necessary (e.g.; education and psychology students can learn R and Python during the internship; if they choose this).

Name: Bio-conjugate therapeutics for Alzheimer's disease.
Description: The objective of this project is to develop a therapeutic bio-conjugate that will reduce the amount of glutamate in the brain to a `normal' level; over a period of 1 -3 weeks after a single administration. Re-administration of the bio-conjugate at regular intervals will contribute to maintaining `normal' levels of brain glutamate; which could stop or slow the progression of AD.
Skills: All associated techniques will be taught on-site. Background in chemistry; biochemistry; or biology are seen as most appropriate for capitalizing upon this learning experience.

Name: Bio-hybrid material chemistry.
Description: A certain number of key challenges exist for the rational design of bio-hybrids; which limit their innovative potential. More specifically: (1) bio-conjugation approaches for grafting synthetic molecules to proteins are limited and can be inefficient; (2) a poor physical-chemical understanding of how synthetic molecules can alter the bio-activity of proteins exists; and methods for controlling the function (3) and structure (4) of bio-hybrids are at a crude stage of development and thus limit their specificity and bio-activity compared to e.g.; proteins. Our research program aims to address these challenges and thus design new functional bio-hybrid materials for applications in biotechnology.
Skills: Formation en chimie ou biochimie Une expérience en chimie analytique et/ou organique est un plus Compétences en communication (écrite/orale) en anglais

Name: Polymer nanoparticles for stopping the progression of Alzheimer's disease.
Description: The objective of this project is to develop therapeutic polymer nanoparticles that will reduce the amount of glutamate in the brain to a `normal' level; over a period of 1 -3 weeks after a single administration. Re-administration of the nanoparticles at regular intervals will contribute to maintaining `normal' levels of brain glutamate; which could stop or slow the progression of AD.
Skills: All associated techniques will be taught on-site. Background in chemistry; biochemistry; or biology are seen as most appropriate for capitalizing upon this learning experience.

Name: Drug metabolizing enzymes in zebrafish
Description: We use zebrafish as a model organism to examine the evolution and function of cytochrome P450 enzymes. Zebrafish are an excellent model organism for environmental; pharmacology; toxicology and biomedical research. Our interests are in anthropogenic chemicals that are common in the aquatic environment; including human pharmaceuticals and we study the toxicity of a variety of environmentally relevant chemicals. Cytochrome P450 enzymes are of interest because they play a major role in chemical defence; as the major enzyme family involved in oxidative metabolism (Phase I) of xenobiotics. These enzymes are also critical for the generation of important biological signalling molecules like steroids. We have expressed multiple cytochrome P450 enzymes from zebrafish; using a bacterial expression system. This has allowed us to develop a high throughput screening assay to determine what compounds are substrates for these enzymes. We are screening environmentally relevant chemicals in this assay to determine which zebrafish enzymes are likely to contribute to chemical defence in zebrafish. We have a colony of zebrafish that we use to study the effects of environmental chemicals on embryonic; juvenile and adult fish. The intern will be involved in our chemical screening experiments; using biochemical assays for enzyme function; reactive oxygen species generation; and to determine enzyme kinetics for the likely compounds. This will give them experience in a high throughput screening lab. Alternatively; the intern may be involved in chemical exposures to zebrafish; to assess potential substrates for CYP mediated metabolism in vivo. The intern will also be involved in the culture and maintenance of our zebrafish colony and will have the opportunity to be involved in exposure experiments with adult or embryonic fish.
Skills: Students should have a strong background in biological sciences; biochemistry; or pharmacology. Previous work with enzyme or protein based assays is considered an advantage. Some technical skills related to spectroscopy; bacterial culture; and basic molecular biology techniques would be helpful. As this research focuses on enzymes; interns should have completed an undergraduate biochemistry course and be familiar with basic enzyme kinetics. Trainees will be required to take a number of health and safety courses prior to working in the lab. For all assays; we provide in lab training and training sets

Name: Étude de l'effet de l'usure des outils sur la qualité de soudures produites par friction malaxage
Description: Le soudage par friction malaxage est utilisé dans l'industrie du transport et permet de souder des matériaux métalliques de haute résistance. En raison des grands efforts appliqués sur l’outil durant le soudage; celui-ci se dégrade/s’use; ce qui engendre des coûts de remplacement et aussi des défauts dans les matériaux soudés.L'usure est un phénomène complexe à étudier en raison de la multitude de ses origines notamment physico-chimiques (affinités entre certains matériaux) ou thermomécaniques (abrasion; diffusion; adhésion; etc.). Toute modification de l’état général d’un outil de soudage par friction-malaxage est considérée comme de l’usure. Elle peut résulter d’une perte de matière ou encore d’une déformation permanente modifiant l’état de surface ou le volume de l’outil. L'usure a un impact considérable sur le déroulement du procédé : augmentation des efforts; des vibrations et de la température; ce qui entraine une détérioration de la qualité du soudage. Il est donc évident que la géométrie de l'outil; la pression et la rotation sont des paramètres critiques. La dégradation rapide des outils et les coûts qui y sont reliés étant un frein à l’utilisation de ce type de soudage pour la production de masse; une meilleure compréhension du mécanisme d'usure des outils pendant le procédé de soudage permettrait de sélectionner de meilleurs matériaux/géométries d'outils et d'améliorer les propriétés de soudure. Dans ce contexte; ce projet a pour but d’étudier l'effet de la dégradation des outils sur les soudures afin d'obtenir des données précises qui permettront d'élaborer un modèle de soudage par éléments finis; sous le code de calcul ABAQUS; permettant de simuler l’usure des outils.
Skills: L'étudiant recherché devrait être familier avec les essais mécaniques et avoir certaines connaissances en métallurgie; notamment dans la préparation d'échantillons pour les analyses en microscopie. Une expérience ou des connaissances dans l'analyse de microstructures serait un atout. Aucune connaissance précise du soudage par friction malaxage n'est toutefois requise.

Name: Thermal Impacts on fish development
Description: Anthropogenic activities such as industrial thermal effluent and climate change can impact the temperature of our lakes and rivers. Temperature is a key factor in the biology of fish species because they don’t thermoregulate. Fish have a range of temperatures that they can tolerate wit optimal temperatures where they perform best. Development is highly temperature dependent; not only in the rate of development and timing of hatching but in growth and survival. Our project focuses on the effect of increased incubation temperature on fish development; using Canadian native species that are commercially; ecologically and culturally important or zebrafish as a model species. We have demonstrated that elevated temperatures in development can lead to specific phenotypes at hatching; fish are smaller; have a larger yolk sac and less developed jaws and fins. Our current projects focus on temperature alone or in combination with chemical exposures and examine the impacts during embryogenesis and post-hatching. Our experiments determine the morphology and growth and a range of morphological features (eye; jaw and fin development). These assessments require the intern to learn fish development and manipulate both embryos and hatchling fish that have been fixed. Samples are imaged under light microscopy for developmental staging and to determine the morphological characters. Our experiments also determine cardio-metabolic impacts (heart rate; oxygen consumption; vascularization) and behavioural assessments of hatchlings and juvenile fish reared at different temperatures. We have assessed a range of behaviour in hatchlings such as feeding responses; light:dark responses; general activity levels; startle responses; thigmotaxis (open field test); chemoresponses and thermal preferences. Behaviours are assessed in appropriate arenas with video capture and are scored manually; or where possible; with automated behavioural software.
Skills: Students should have a strong background in biological or environmental sciences. Previous work with vertebrates or in aquatic sciences is considered an advantage. For an intern working on morphology; previous training in vertebrate development and experience with light microscopy would be an advantage. For an intern working on the behavioural assays; previous training in animal behaviour would be an advantage. Trainees will be required to take a number of health and safety and animal care courses prior to working in the lab. For all assays; we provide training sets to ensure the data collection is comparable to prior research.

Name: Nano-Satellite Drones: Conceptual Design
Description: This project focuses on completing the conceptual design of a nano-satellite drone for very low earth orbit flight. Using a combination of existing knowledge in literature and new out-of-the-box ideas from within our group that are tested with simulations; this project aims to develop the next generation of the conceptual design of the Nano-Sat drone. The first generation was explored last year in a separate Masters' thesis. This project is to build on the basis of the exiting UofA Satellite currently in orbit (AlbertaSat Cube Sats).
Skills: The student needs to have a good understanding of fluid mechanics; aeronautics and aircraft design with familiarity in SolidWorks and ANSYS. The right candidate will need to complete literature review; develop conceptual designs; and CAD models based on design principles in literature.

Name: Using Big Data to Assess the Performance of Public Transit Systems
Description: Sustainable transportation modes such as public transit and active transport play a major role in addressing climate change and achieving Vision Zero objectives; as well as providing equity and fairness through the provision of mobility and accessibility that could not be otherwise met for the lower-income population. There are both short-term and expected long-term travel behavioural changes given disruptions such as health pandemics; the emergence of autonomous vehicles; teleworking; and the sharing economy. This research investigates how public data can be employed to study travel behaviour and the modal; temporal; and spatial travel focusing on sustainable transportation modes. The data comes from various sources: General Transit Feed Specification (GTFS); Google Transit API; and other relevant data sources will be employed to understand service supply and demand changes during a certain period of time. Spatial and temporal data from social media (such as Twitter) and the Transit app will be also be employed for tracking passengers' travel behaviour during the same period. Combining these data sources; there is an opportunity to perform data fusion and time series analysis and investigate travel pattern changes; modal shifts; and transit demand key performance indicators (KPI) over time. Geographical Information Systems in Transportation will also be used to integrate and fuse many of these data. The finding from this analysis will be useful for decision-makers and the research community to determine the adequacy of the use of open data sources for tracking travel behaviour and modal shifts and whether some of these emerging data sources can be used as an alternative to the higher cost methods (e.g. manual surveys) or closed data.This project will be part of the large scale research program on "Urban Transport System Diagnosis; Monitoring; and Management using Mobility Sensing Data".
Skills: Programming; data analysis; data visualization; and familiarity with Machine Learning are requied for this project. Education and experience in transportation engineering and public transit operations and modeling is an asset. Familiarity with General Transit Feed Specification (GTFS) will be also a great asset.

Name: Manipulating Regulatory Genes to Modulate Biopolymer Production
Description: Acetic acid bacteria (AAB) are important for many biotechnological applications including synthesis of nanocellulose; consisting of an ultra-fine network of nanofibres. The unique nanomorphology of bacterial cellulose contributes to its tensile strength and highly crystalline structure. Extracellular cellulose is a crucial component of the biofilm structure of many bacteria facilitating attachment and providing protection. This project will use targeted mutational analysis to investigate regulatory control points involved in cellulose biosynthesis.
Skills: Students should have a working knowledge of aseptic technique. A background in microbiology and/or molecular biology is highly beneficial. Students should be able to perform laboratory calculations (e.g. molarity; dilutions; etc.) and have exceptional note-taking/documentation skills.

Name: Unraveling neurophysiological mechanisms of somatosensory and motor interactions
Description: Somatosensory afferents contribute to the planning and adaptation of movements and postures according to the ongoing state of the body and the environment. They play a key role in motor learning by providing information about errors in the motor command and; when altered; can have a drastic impact on motor control. Although the link between sensory and motor systems is undisputable; the underlying mechanisms by which somatosensory inputs shape motor control remain unclear. The advent of non­invasive neurostimulation opened up new opportunities to study human neurophysiology and sensorimotor control. The combined use of peripheral stimulation; causing an experimentally controlled sensory inflow; with transcranial stimulation of the motor cortex highlighted complex interactions between sensory and motor networks. The repeated application of sensory stimuli can also lead to sustained plastic changes through mechanisms similar to those observed during motor learning. However; evidence from this emerging field of research remain scarce and heterogenous. The widespread use of electrical nerve stimulation; depolarizing a mixed population of motor and sensory fibers (skin; muscle; joint; tendon); might in part account for the high variability of results across studies. Being able to isolate different sub­types of sensory afferents would lead to significant advancements in our comprehension of modality­ specific interactions between sensory and motor networks. The goal of the present research is to elucidate the neurophysiological underpinnings of somatosensory and motor interactions. We will verify how different somatosensory inputs activated by peripheral electrical; magnetic and vibration interact with motor cortical excitability and neural plasticity. Renown experimental paradigms (paired­-pulse; paired­associative; repeated stimulation) will be applied using technologies and procedures complying with the highest standards in the fields of human neurophysiology and sensorimotor control.
Skills: 1. Interested in OR having previous training in human mouvement sciences. 2. Have or will have an University degree (any level) 3. Basic skills with a computer 4. Work well with others (teammates and research participants)

Name: Exploring Haskap (Lonicera caerulea) traits throughout the course of pre and post-harvest stages : Insight into ethylene production
Description: quality changes
Host Institution: There is evidence that Haskap is a climacteric fruit; but this has not been proven physiologically; nor the possible links between the production of ethylene; respiration; and alternative oxidase (AOX) activity; which can alter the overall metabolism of the fruit. Thus; it is intended to establish the ripening profile of two Haskaps cultivars (i.e.; Aurora and Boreal Blizzard) based on their respiration rates; ethylene production; enzymatic activity; including AOX; CAT; APX; and the production of hydrogen peroxide (H2O2); and other reactive oxygen species (ROS). A Ph.D. student will perform the physiological profiling on both cultivars; the enzymatic activities of AOX; CAT and APX; and ROS quantification after treatments. The intendent B.Sc.1 will support him by determining the content H2O2 during the development of the fruit. Physiological measurements will be carried out during fruit development after anthesis. The total ROS determination (primarily Н2О2; but also О2•−; and ОН•) will be done by fumigating the fluorescent probe 2';7'-dichlorodihydrofluorescein diacetate (H2DCFDA) on plant material; and the related produced image will be acquired using a bioluminescence system. The possible modification of AOX and its retrograde modification by ROS represent a new frontline in the regulation of ripening.
Skills: Université Laval
column12: Students should preferably have a background in food science; biochemistry; biochemical engineering; chemistry; horticulture or agriculture. It is also desirable that he/she has carried out practical laboratory work and has an interest in plant products (vegetables and fruit). In addition; it is recommended that the candidate be able to perform basic Excel functions; such as constructing graphs and using formulas. Experience in post-harvest technologies would be an added advantage.
column13: Agriculture; Biological Sciences; Biochemistry; Biology; Engg-Biological; Engg-Chemical; Food Science; Science and Technology

Name: High throughput functional proteomics for surface proteins on stem-cell derived cells
Description: Proteomics is a high throughput analysis of the structure and function of proteins in biological systems. Our comprehensive proteomic analyses employs liquid chromatography (LC) as a separation tool and the mass spectrometry (MS) as a detection tool to identify and quantify cell surface proteins and their posttranslational modifications; such as glycosylation. In a typical analysis; proteins will be extracted from biological samples; digested into peptides enzymatically. Peptides of interest will be chemically enriched; selectively analyzed through LC-MS. Thousands of peptide MS spectra can be acquired in a short duration and processed by bioinformatics tools to infer hundreds of proteins' structure and function simultaneously. This project will focus on improving the sensitivity of the method that we have developed previously (Adams; et al.; Int. J. Mol. Sci.; 2022). Our lab has extensive experiences with mammalian cells including mouse and human stem cells. The new knowledge gained from these high throughput analyses will help us draw novel insights into cell biology and physiology. Executing these projects will help students gain hands on experiences on all aspects of proteomics technology; including protein chemistry; liquid chromatography separation techniques; tandem mass spectrometry; and data-analysis skills. Our lab also harbors various molecular and cellular techniques; such as mammalian cell culture and assays besides LC-MS bioanalyses; which can be acquired during training. Successfully trained students will have opportunity to continue the project as MS or PhD students.
Skills: Students with good analytical skills; including hands on experience with HPLC and MS. Basic statistic and bioinformatic skills; and solid training in biochemistry such as protein extraction; protein purification; and chemical modification are highly recommended. Self-learning and team work are both encouraged in the lab. Highly motivated individuals with good ethics; integrity; and an eager to enroll in proteomics field will be further considered.

Name: Prédiction de l’évolution du taux de rendement global (TRG ou OEE) des machines de production par intelligence artificielle
Description: Ce projet consiste à exploiter et consolider le flux de données disponibles par les outils Industrie 4.0 pour définir et entrainer des modèles prédictifs (ex. classificateur supervisée SVM ou un réseau neuronal convolutif). Le modèle retenu sera entrainé à reconnaître des situations conduisant à une détérioration du rendement ou; au contraire; des situations permettant une utilisation et un fonctionnement optimaux des moyens de production. Le modèle obtenu pourra aussi être utilisé pour prédire l’évolution des performances (ex. disponibilité des équipements; niveau de qualité; niveaux de productivité; etc.). Cette capacité du système à anticiper des situations anormales pourra être utilisée à des fins tels le raffinement de l’estimation de l’heure de fin des opérations et des ordres de fabrication mettant en place une planification dynamique et rétroactive. Le récent développement des techniques d'IA et plus spécifiquement de l’Apprentissage Machine supervisé (AMS) offre des opportunités qui peuvent se résumer en : (1) Développer des outils de diagnostic; (2) Développer des outils pour établir des modèles prédictifs. Le but in fine serait de : (i) développer un outil pour consolider les données disponibles et s’assurer de leurs cohérence; qualité et ergodicité temporelle; (ii) développer un outil avec une fonction « diagnostic » pour identifier les corrélations significatives entre différents entrants et sortants des processus suivis; (iii) développer un outil pour intégrer un module IA pour la construction et la validation de modèle prédictif offrant une capacité de pronostic pour établir des scénarios d’analyse et l'optimisation des procédés.
Skills: Bonne base en mathématiques et en statistiques Programmation (Python) Professionnalisme et bonne communication Capacité de travailler en équipe Algorithmes IA est un atout

Name: Power calculation in multivariate analysis
Description: Sample size calculation plays a crucial role in multivariate analysis. It is a critical step in the research process; ensuring that the sample adequately represents the population of interest. Multivariate analysis involves analyzing multiple variables simultaneously; aiming to identify relationships; patterns; or differences between variables. Determining an appropriate sample size is essential to ensure the statistical power; precision; and generalizability of the findings. A sample size that is too small may result in insufficient statistical power; leading to inconclusive or unreliable results. On the other hand; an excessively large sample size may be impractical; time-consuming; and expensive. The research proposal aims to develop power calculation approaches for multivariate analysis methods. The student will collaborate in the development of method; simulation analysis as well as programming in R to be integrated into an R package.
Skills: Required: Statistical methods and concepts Familiarity with multivariate analysis (e.g.; principal component analysis) Experience using R statistical programming language Time management skills Ability to work both independently and in a team environment Excellent communication skills in English or French (oral and written) Preferred but not necessary: Familiarity with simulation analysis in R

Name: Additive manufacturing of shape transforming structures
Description: Today’s reconfigurable structures are either: strong; adaptable; or lightweight. Reconfigurable aircraft structures require achieving all the three characteristics in a single material; which is the challenge we design engineers are facing for decades. Intelligent structures possessing the above characteristics mandate the use of smart materials – materials whose physical properties can be altered by external stimuli like stress; moisture; electric and magnetic fields; light; temperature; and chemical substances. As the airplanes; cars; wind turbine blades today are being manufactured from fiber reinforced polymer (FRP); integrating smart materials; for shape adaptation would result in considerable weight and space savings. Structural health monitoring with embedded sensors will result in efficient and timely repair and thus; enhanced product life cycle. Inspired from the nature’s growth and development; three-dimensional (3D) printing serves as the most pertinent fabrication tool for intelligent structures delivering organic and efficient complex geometries; which are a characteristic of an efficient bird flight; our inspiration from nature. But; the smart materials of today are inefficient and unreliable compared to their conventional mechanical rigid body alternatives and hence; do not satisfy the aircraft accreditation requirements for safety. This research project aims at developing these smart materials and improving their compatibility with the high strength materials. The know-how gained in this project can be directly applied to build intelligent planes; cars; wind turbine blades; and other structural and functional composite components; especially in customized equipment like prosthesis; rehabilitation-aid; exoskeletons; and sports equipment towards individuals.
Skills: The project is looking for undergraduate or graduate interns with backgrounds in materials science; mechanical; chemical; biomedical or electrical engineering to address multiple objectives of the project described in the next section. The students should have experience in at least one of the following: • Designing and hands on experience in building things; 3D printing • Wet-labs; materials or chemistry labs; mechanical characterization of materials • FEM softwares like Abaqus; or Comsol • Instrumentation; building circuits for amplifiers; data acquisition; signal processing; data analysis CAD softwares like CATIA; AUTOCAD and use of programming languages
Student academic background: Engg-Chemical; Engg-Electrical; Engg-Industrial; Engg-Manufacturing; Engg-Materials; Engg-Mechanical; Engineering; Engg-Biomedical; Engg-Systems and Technology; Industrial Design and Technology; Manufacturing; Medical Sciences; Psychology; Rehabilitation Medicine

Name: Characterization of the innate mucosal immunity of the upper airways in wild mammals
Description: Respiratory infections are a main cause of morbidity and mortality in many wild mammals including ungulates and carnivores. The innate immune response of the nasal cavity and other airways is crucial for the early control of respiratory pathogens in most animal species. However; the proteins and cells involved in this response are poorly characterized in wild animals; preventing further assessment of the role of innate mucosal immunity on the transmission of respiratory pathogens in these species. This project aims to characterize the leukocyte populations and innate immunity proteins in the nasal and pharyngeal mucosa of South American fur seals (Arctocephalus australis) and African buffalo (Syncerus caffer). For this project; nasal and nasopharyngeal biopsies were collected in 2022 from healthy wild African buffalo and South American fur seals. These biopsies will be processed for histological assessment and through immunohistochemistry the populations of T and B lymphocytes; macrophages; dendritic cells; plasma cells; neutrophils and eosinophils will be characterized. Additionally; we will identify the location and relative abundance of proteins involved in the control of respiratory pathogens such as immunoglobulin A (IgA); type I interferons (alpha and beta); cathelicidins and defensins using immunohistochemistry and proteomics. We expect to identify a significant number of T-lymphocytes associated to the respiratory mucosa as well as few neutrophils and macrophages. We expect to identify IgA producing plasma cells in the lamina propria and secretory IgA in the respiratory epithelium and cathelicidins and defensins in neutrophils; macrophages and epithelial cells. This project will be critical to characterize the innate immunity landscape of healthy long-living wild mammals; a critical step to later understand how this landscape changes in response to respiratory pathogens.
Skills: The most important motivation for students working in this program should be the pursuing of a career in science and a genuine interest in animal immunology and pathology. The students should have basic knowledge of laboratory bench work. This experience could have bene obtained doing ELISAs; immunohistochemistry or molecular work such as PCRs. Communication and inter-personnal skills are important to join an inclusive and collaborative lab environment. Willing to learn R statistical software and to explore statistical analyses such as linear regression and generalized linear mixed models is desired

Name: AGronomic Trait Improvement in canola
Description: This project aims to develop improved canola varieties through various molecular tools. The student will work closely with a research personnel to generate various gene editing constructs; perform mutational screens and generate transgenic canola lines. These lines will then be evaluated for various agronomic traits both in the greenhouse and in the field.
Skills: Basic molecular biology techniques; tissue culture experience

Name: Regulation of HUMANIN in response to maternal obesity
Description: Exposure to maternal obesity during prenatal and postnatal periods is a powerful early-life stress that can shape developmental and behavioral outcomes in offspring. In particular; exposure to maternal obesity lead to metabolic diseases (type II diabetes; high blood pressure); increase in body weight and adiposity; and altered neurodevelopmental outcomes (lower IQ and autism spectrum disorders) in children. The discovery of humanin (HN/MTRNR2) 20 years ago blazed a trail to characterizing small peptides with biological function; that originate solely from the mitochondria; the powerhouse of the cell. Humanin is associated with pro-survival; anti-inflammatory; and anti-oxidative properties and may play a role in reducing neurodegenerative and metabolic disease progression. This specific peptide was given the name “humanin” because of its ability to reverse and/or reduce the progression of Alzheimer’s disease. Humanin is present not only in humans but in several other mammals; amphibians; and reptiles and increase in expression and activity soon after an acute cellular insult and/or stress. However; the regulation of humanin in the offspring brain in response to maternal obesity exposure (a chronic stress) is yet to be investigated. The students will use a maternal obesity-centric rodent model to study the functional dynamics of humanin; in the brain (hippocampus; hypothalamus; and the frontal cortex); heart; liver; and kidneys during critical periods of early postnatal development. Students will obtain hands on experience in animal handling; diet regiments; animal dissections; animal behavior testing; and molecular biology techniques; including but not limited to DNA/RNA/Protein extractions; qPCR; protein immunoblotting; ELISAs; and bioinformatics tools for protein folding and identification methods. The findings may help develop humanin-based therapeutics to treat inflammatory and developmental disorders that result from chronic obesity exposure in children.
Skills: - Student should have a strong background in the biological sciences; including but not limited to molecular biology; biochemistry; and/or animal physiology. - Students are expected to have knowledge of statistical methods including but not limited to t-tests; parametric versus non-parametric modeling; ANOVAs; Generalized Linear Mixed Models; Linear Mixed Models; correlations; etc. - Workable knowledge of statistical software such as R; SPSS; or Prism. - Students will be trained in all animal care protocols. As such; comfort working with and handling rodents is mandatory.

Name: Countering online dis- and mis-information: A human centric approach
Description: This project builds capacity to counter disinformation by equipping participants with skills through workshops; podcasts; and online resources. The use of AI driven technology to identity misinformation allows for the democratization of disinformation tools; making it easier for Canadians to spot and combat disinformation quickly. Community engagement activities; such as workshops and podcasts; will equip citizens with long term media literacy skills. Skill sharing between experts and the community is a core asset of the project.
Skills: Cyber security; geo-politics; communication

Name: Feasibility of alternative low carbon retrofit solutions for existing buildings.
Description: Buildings are a leading source of emissions contributing to over 40% of the total energy use globally and resulting in about 39% of the total direct and indirect CO2 emissions. With commitments made by several nations to reach net zero emissions by 2050; efforts are needed to decarbonize building energy use. Canada's buildings currently account for about 12% of the total CO2 emissions. Constructing new net-zero buildings will not help us reach net-zero by 2050 if nothing is done to ensure that the existing buildings are retrofitted with low carbon energy systems. Working with local property developers and property managers; this project aims to identify; evaluate and analyze the feasibility of low carbon energy systems for space heating and cooling in Canada's cold climate. The project will identify all the possible alternatives to natural gas for space heating and evaluate the technical and economic feasibility of each. Working with building owners; building energy load profiles will be obtained; analyzed; and used in the proper design and sizing of any proposed retrofit solutions. Furthermore; using the obtained load profiles; the long-term performance of any proposed solution will be undertaken in detail.
Skills: The student is expected to have an excellent grasp of the fundamentals of heat transfer; thermodynamics; and fluid mechanics. An understanding of energy systems for buildings is an asset. This project also requires excellent technical; oral; written; and interpersonal skills. Students are also expected to have the ability to review and synthesize related literature; develop system configurations; and apply fundamental laws to develop mathematical models of the different configurations.

Name: Commercial Refrigeration Sensor Array: Detecting
Description: Analyzing
Host Province: The research project aims to develop a sensor array for commercial refrigeration units to prevent harmful leaks and monitor air quality. Leaking refrigerants; like hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs); have significant environmental consequences; contributing to global warming; climate change; and ozone depletion. The project focuses on designing a device with MQ gas sensors to detect various gases; including refrigerants; methane; propane; butane; alcohol; carbon monoxide; and air pollutants. The collected data will be logged and streamed to an analytics dashboard for real-time monitoring. Technicians can quickly identify high gas concentrations and detect leaks; enabling timely repairs to prevent further refrigerant loss and environmental harm. The sensor array will also monitor temperature and humidity; ensuring optimal efficiency and sustainability of refrigeration systems. Expected outcomes include improved leak detection; reduced refrigerant loss; and enhanced environmental sustainability. The device will facilitate responsible refrigerant disposal; reducing greenhouse gas emissions and protecting the ozone layer. Continuous air quality monitoring will create a healthier environment for employees and customers; ensuring product quality. This project addresses the need for effective monitoring systems in commercial refrigeration units; promoting operational efficiency and sustainability.
Skills: English
column11: The ideal student for this research project should have a strong background in quantitative analysis and general knowledge in the field of environmental science or engineering. Proficiency in Python and SQL would be advantageous as these skills are relevant for building and automating data tools. Additionally; the student should possess critical thinking skills; attention to detail; and the ability to work with sensor data. Strong analytical and problem-solving abilities are essential for effectively analyzing and interpreting the collected data.

Name: Contrôle de version pour un modèle ontologique fortement interconnecté
Description: La plateforme de support de système de santé apprenant développée par le GRIIS se base; entre autres; sur un modèle de données cliniques fondé sur des ontologies. Ce modèle consiste en un réseau d'ontologies ou de parties d'ontologies; qui sont soit importées; soit créées au sein de notre groupe; et qui sont fortement interdépendantes. Cette architecture apporte une grande flexibilité et nous permet d'ajouter des représentations de différents domaines selon les besoins. En revanche; elle est très sensible et tout changement dans ses parties nécessite de plus en plus d'efforts de maintenance au fur et à mesure que le modèle grandit et évolue; ce qui peut compromettre sa viabilité à long terme. Ainsi la gestion de l’évolution des ontologies devient un défi majeur. Quel est l’impact de la modification d’une ontologie sur les autres et sur le modèle au complet ? Ce projet consiste à : •. Apprendre les méthodes et outils existants déjà mis en place pour le développement et la maintenance du modèle clinique ontologique; à savoir : GitHub/GitLab; ROBOT; ODK •. Mettre en place des méthodes et des outils de contrôle de version et d'intégration continue adaptées aux ontologies. Cela impliquera l'utilisation de tests automatisés et de mécanismes d'assurance qualité pour garantir la stabilité et la cohérence du modèle. •. Évaluer ces méthodes avec un cas d’études
Skills: Les connaissances/compétences suivantes sont un atout : * Programmation : OWL; SPARQL; Python * Outils : Protégé; ODK; ROBOT; Git
Student academic background: Engg-Computer; Computer Science; Management Information Systems

Name: Population Determinants of a Satisfying Life
Description: Subjective well-being refers to the cognitive evaluation and affective feelings towards the quality of one’s life. It has gained significant attention as a policy indicator of population well-being (i.e.; subjective well-being measured at a population level). For instance; governments in the United Kingdom and France now track citizens’ subjective well-being; and annually; a World Happiness Report is published documenting key findings on well-being across the Globe. Therefore; more policymakers recognize that a flourishing society should cultivate a satisfying life among citizens. The overarching goal of the research project is to examine how major population events and societal changes are linked to citizens' well-being.
Skills: Students with background in psychology; public health; economics; statistics; or a related quantitative social science disciplines are encouraged to apply. Preference will be given to students with prior research experiences and students with strong programing (e.g.; R) and quantitative (e.g.; R; SPSS; Stata) skills.

Name: Population Consequences of Subjective Well-being
Description: Subjective well-being refers to the cognitive evaluation and affective feelings towards the quality of one’s life. It has gained significant attention as a policy indicator of population well-being (i.e.; subjective well-being measured at a population level). For instance; governments in the United Kingdom and France now track citizens’ subjective well-being; and annually; a World Happiness Report is published documenting key findings on well-being across the Globe. Therefore; more policymakers recognize that a flourishing society should cultivate a satisfying life among citizens. While subjective well-being has been linked to many desirable individual-level outcomes; how well-being is linked to population-level outcomes is less clear. Through this research project; we will extends this research area by focusing on population-level outcomes; such as election outcomes; collective actions; and population health. Understanding the consequences of population well-being will further motivate communities and stakeholder to invest in citizens' quality of life.
Skills: Students with background in psychology; public health; economics; statistics; or a related quantitative social science disciplines are encouraged to apply. Preference will be given to students with prior research experiences and students with strong programing (e.g.; R) and quantitative (e.g.; R; SPSS; Stata) skills.

Name: The Policy Relevance of Happiness
