Description: Subjective well-being refers to the cognitive evaluation and affective feelings towards the quality of one’s life. It has gained significant attention as a policy indicator of population well-being (i.e.; subjective well-being measured at a population level). For instance; governments in the United Kingdom and France now track citizens’ subjective well-being; and annually; a World Happiness Report is published documenting key findings on well-being across the Globe. Therefore; more policymakers recognize that a flourishing society should cultivate a satisfying life among citizens. The research project aims to examine the public opinion on subjective well-being as a policy indicator. Do citizens think happiness is a good social indicator? How does this opinion vary across age; gender; social groups; and political affiliations? What are the perceived promises and challenges in using happiness as a policy indicator?
Skills: Students with background in psychology; public policy; survey method; or a related quantitative social science disciplines are encouraged to apply. Preference will be given to students with prior research experiences and students with strong programing (e.g.; R) and quantitative (e.g.; R; SPSS; Stata) skills.

Name: The Long but Dissatisfying Life in Hong Kong
Description: Subjective well-being refers to the cognitive evaluation and affective feelings towards the quality of one’s life. It has gained significant attention as a policy indicator of population well-being (i.e.; subjective well-being measured at a population level). For instance; governments in the United Kingdom and France now track citizens’ subjective well-being; and annually; a World Happiness Report is published documenting key findings on well-being across the Globe. Therefore; more policymakers recognize that a flourishing society should cultivate a satisfying life among citizens. Hong Kong presents an interesting case study where objective and subjective indicators of societal progress diverge. Despite Hong Kong's high GDP and world-leading longevity; subjective well-being in Hong Kong is among the worst among similarly developed societies. Explicating why this is the case will advance our understanding of how public policies can be better aligned to promote citizen well-being.
Skills: Students with background in psychology; economics; public policy; survey method; or a related quantitative social science disciplines are encouraged to apply. Preference will be given to students with prior research experiences and students with strong programing (e.g.; R) and quantitative (e.g.; R; SPSS; Stata) skills.

Name: Effects of environmental pollutants in the Arctic using in vitro assays
Description: The Arctic is traditionally considered a pristine environment; but toxicological research over the past decades has revealed that environmental pollutants used and released in industrialized regions of the world reach the Arctic through long-range transportation processes. Once there; these chemicals accumulate in Arctic food webs and biomagnify to alarming levels in apex predators like polar bears; toothed whales; and seals. These species are exposed to hundreds of legacy chemicals as well as potentially hundreds of new chemicals; termed chemicals of emerging Arctic concern (CEACs). For many of these chemicals we have very little data or understanding of their bioaccumulation (uptake by organisms) and even less regarding their adverse effects (toxicity). Given the large and growing list of environmental chemicals; it is practically impossible to test them all using traditional animal exposure models. As such; we are turning to animal-free cell-based approaches to tackle the issues of chemical testing. In vitro laboratory assays can make use of various cell types; experimental designs; and analytical techniques to characterize the bioaccumulation and toxicity of priority chemicals. The focus of this project will be to develop; test; and apply in vitro assays to characterize the toxicology of CEACs. The student will design and carry-out cell culture experiments with difference cell lines and CEACs and measure bioaccumulation potential and several toxicity endpoints including cell viability; cell-specific function (e.g. immune function for immune cells); receptor binding; and gene expression.
Skills: The student should have basic laboratory skills and be comfortable in a molecular biology lab setting. Experience with cell culture and cellular assays is a major asset. Background in toxicology is useful; but not necessary.

Name: Respirateur liquidien
Description: Malgré des efforts constants pour optimiser les techniques de ventilation mécanique conventionnelle; la prise en charge respiratoire des nouveau-nés les plus prématurés; qui sont de plus en plus fréquents dans les unités de soins intensifs néonataux; demeure laborieuse et très dommageable pour le système respiratoire. Pour répondre à ce défi médical; le néonatologiste Étienne Fortin-Pellerin; veut offrir à ces prématurés un support ventilatoire prophylactique grâce au ventilateur liquidien Inolivent développé par le professeur Philippe Micheau. Cette technologie expérimentale; unique au monde et jamais déployée sur l’humain; permet une ventilation liquidienne totale en remplissant les poumons avec un liquide respirable et en assurant son renouvellement pour maintenir les échanges gazeux. L’objectif est de repousser les frontières de la technologie Inolivent afin de faciliter la transition vers la recherche clinique sur des prématurés extrêmes humains (500 -700 g). La réduction d’échelle d’un facteur 3; le changement d’espèces et l’allongement à plusieurs jours de la VLT constituent les défis majeurs de ce projet. Le stagiaire viendra en support de l'équipe de recherche en mécatronique qui porte sur la conception du respirateur (pousse-seringues; valves; chauffage; unité de traitement du PFOB; Arduino; Pi). La technologie avec les algorithmes sera validée in-vivo sur des modèles ovins; et testé sur un modèle animal de petit poids représentatif d’un extrême prématuré humain.
Skills: Le candidat devra avoir des connaissances en mécatronique. ¸Il nécessitera des compétences en programmation dans l’environnement Matlab/Simulink; C/C++; Qt. Il doit être capable de planifier; de réaliser et de documenter des plans de fabrication. La connaissance d’outils de conception 3D tel que COMSOL ou Solidworks sera un atout. Une bonne aptitude à communiquer et à travailler en équipe est essentielle.
Student academic background: Engineering; Engg-Mechanical; Engg-Systems and Technology; Engg-Electrical

Name: Customer Service Trends in Canada: A Social Network Analysis
Description: The research project aims to utilize Twitter data to study customer service trends in Canada through the application of social network analysis. Twitter has become a significant platform for individuals to express their opinions and experiences regarding customer service interactions with various businesses. By analyzing the vast amount of data available on Twitter; this research project seeks to uncover valuable insights into the customer service landscape in Canada. The project will collect and analyze tweets about customer service experiences in different industries; such as telecommunications; banking; e-commerce; and more. The data will be obtained using relevant keywords and hashtags associated with customer service interactions. By examining the content of the tweets; sentiment analysis techniques can be applied to determine the overall sentiment of customers towards specific businesses or industries. Social network analysis will be employed to explore the relationships and interactions between customers; businesses; and customer service representatives on Twitter. This analysis will identify key influencers; communities; and patterns of communication within the customer service network. By mapping out the network; researchers can gain insights into the dynamics of customer service interactions; including information flow; customer satisfaction levels; and potential issues faced by customers. The findings of this research project can have significant implications for businesses in Canada. By understanding customer service trends and identifying areas for improvement; companies can enhance their customer service strategies; address customer concerns proactively; and ultimately improve customer satisfaction and loyalty. Additionally; the research outcomes can provide valuable insights to policymakers and regulatory bodies; helping them make informed decisions to protect consumer interests and promote better customer service practices across industries. It is important to note that all data collected and analyzed in this research project will be anonymized and handled in compliance with ethical considerations and privacy regulations.
Skills: The student involved in this research project should possess strong skills in Python programming; as it will be the primary language used for data collection; analysis; and visualization. Proficiency in working with APIs (Application Programming Interfaces) is also beneficial; as it will enable the student to access and retrieve data from the Twitter platform. Additionally; familiarity with social network analysis concepts and techniques would be advantageous; although optional. This knowledge will aid in understanding and applying appropriate methods to analyze the relationships and interactions within the customer service network on Twitter.

Name: Design and development of tools to build in vitro 3D cancer models
Description: Precision medicine for oncology aims to predict the response of a cancer patient to a therapy. Currently; this is performed by screening the tumor for biomarkers that suggests a patient will respond positively to a therapy. However; there are relatively few treatments that target specific biomarkers. In addition; the tumor microenvironment (TME) can greatly influence how a patient responds to a specific treatment regiment. A method that shows promise to fill this gap is the use of 3D tumor models. We develop methods to build more complex 3D models that contain tumor stromal cells; immune cells; and patient-derived tumor cells to better replicate the TME than previous 3D tumor models and in turn; improve the ability to predict a patient response to a treatment. This would allow clinicians to provide more effective treatments and limit the toxicity to the patient of drugs that will not work. This project is to design and build new hardware to make these 3D tumor models. There are two parts to this project. The first is to improve the design of our current method of using guides to cut tubing containing the cells and hydrogel mix to form cylindrical constructs. The second part is to design a new high-throughput method of making the tumor models based on a plug flow method similar to what is used for microencapsulation.
Skills: The student needs both the theoretical and applied skills to design; model and build various pieces of unique hardware used to make the 3D tumor models used by the laboratory. They should know how to use fusion 360 CAD software; have a working knowledge of 3D printing and the use of various tools (drill press; band saw; etc.).
Student academic background: Engg-Biological; Engg-Biomedical; Engg-Chemical; Engineering; Industrial Design and Technology

Name: 3D geometric inspection and predictive monitoring of non-rigid parts
Description: Product and structure quality significantly affect manufacturing companies' sustainability by deploying non-destructive evaluation (NDE). NDE provides tools to inspect for flaws; imperfections; malfunctions; and anomalies without damaging parts. The 3D geometric inspection aims to verify the manufactured products' conformity and monitor structures' geometric condition. Computer-aided inspection (CAI) applies 3D optical and laser scanners to digitize the geometric surface of parts and compare it with reference models to detect defects and geometric anomalies. Geometric inspection of non-rigid parts/large-scale structures (N-RP/L-SS); e.g.; parts made of sheet metals in aircraft and vehicle fabrication and metallic infrastructures; is largely performed in the industrial context. Due to the flexibility of N-RP/L-SS; the inspection is typically performed on physical fixtures to immobilize and constrain components in the required inspection position. As a result; fixtures are robust and require low qualification; but they are dedicated to a single product inspection requiring modification and reconstruction for each change that imposes high costs. This project aims to reduce the use of inspection fixtures by developing smart real-time fixtureless CAI of N-RP/L-SS under large deformation. Using advanced nonlinear modeling/simulation; robotized 3D scanners; optimization; and artificial intelligence tools; the geometric state of equipment/structures is monitored in real-time to detect defects of products in each manufacturing process to avoid processing a faulty part and eliminate poor quality assemblies. Meanwhile; it enables predicting undesired deformation and geometric anomalies of infrastructures to associate geometric changes with potential failures or breakdowns and raise the alarm before they occur. The performance and robustness of CAI methods will also be evaluated and analyzed concerning the impact of measurement noise generated by 3D scanners. The project comprises fixtureless CAI of N-RP/L-SS under large deformation using robotized 3D scanners for geometric data; validation and verification of developed methods; smart and automatic defect detection in real-time; and geometric anomalies prediction.
Skills: The subjects require a knowledge of 3D geometric metrology and computer-aided inspection; finite element analysis (FEA); and strong interest; knowledge and skills in computer programming; numerical and data analysis.

Name: Development of in vitro 3D tumor models to study tumor microenvironment for drug development
Description: Precision medicine for oncology aims to predict the response of a cancer patient to a therapy. Currently; this is performed by screening the tumor for biomarkers that suggests a patient will respond positively to a therapy. However; there are relatively few treatments that target specific biomarkers. Also the tumor microenvironment (TME) can greatly influence how a patient responds to a treatment regiment. A method that shows promise to fill this gap is the use of 3D tumor models. This project aims to develop methods to build more complex 3D models that contain tumor stromal cells; immune cells; and patient-derived tumor cells to better replicate the TME than previous 3D tumor models and in turn; improve the ability to predict a patient response to a treatment. This would allow clinicians to provide more effective treatments and limit the toxicity to the patient of drugs that will not work.
Skills: The student will require basic wet laboratory skills; such as pipetting and basic microscopy; for areas such as cell biology; molecular biology and biochemistry and an understanding of techniques; such as Western blots. It is not required but useful skills would be tissue culture techniques. It would be also useful to have a knowledge of cancer signalling and tumor microenvironment.

Name: Design
Description: Development and Evaluation of a Portable Microwave Breast Cancer Detection Device
Faculty supervisor: Access to early breast cancer screening is limited in rural populations and developing countries; resulting in increased mortality rates for women in these disadvantaged communities. Microwave based breast cancer detection has shown promise as a safer and less costly approach to early breast cancer detection. The goal of this research project is to build on our decade long experience in bed-based microwave radar-based breast imaging research to develop and test a portable microwave breast cancer detection device suitable for use in these communities. The system will incorporate an array of patch antennas; and a source of microwave radiation (generated by a collection of nano-VNA’s) operating in the 0.8-3.5 GHz range that can be swept across the breast to create a tomographic data set. The battery-powered system will be controlled using an advanced NVIDIA Jetson supercomputer and is designed to be operated by the patient herself; using an easy to understand graphical user interface; and will use Machine Learning to enable an immediate response as to the presence (or absence) of a significant breast abnormality. Previous simulations have shown that such approaches can achieve similar sensitivity and specificity to x-ray mammography. The machine learning approach will compare data from both breasts to enable reliable results for a range of breast sizes and densities and will be validated using an array of 3D printed breast phantoms of varied size and breast densities derived from MRI data. A robust breast microwave imaging system will provide a safe; comfortable; and affordable breast cancer screening; increasing access and reducing mortality for women in remote and low-income communities.
Student academic background: The student is required to be an independent learner with strong communication skills and a background in; Applied Physics; Electrical or Computer Engineering; or Computer Science. The successful student will have a good understanding of microwave electronics and electromagnetism and will be comfortable using and programming microprocessors. Experience with Machine Learning and Matlab/Python will be an advantage. The student will be expected to be creative and innovative; capable of working well in a diverse team and will have demonstrated undergraduate research experience that includes 3-D printing; electronics; programming; data collection and analysis; ideally in the medical field.
column11: Engg-Electrical; Engg-Computer; Physics; Computer Science

Name: NUTRITION & CANCER
Description: Le cancer du sein est le type de cancer le plus fréquemment diagnostiqué chez la femme et le deuxième plus meurtrier chez les Canadiennes. Si l'incidence de ce cancer continue d’augmenter; la mortalité qui lui est attribuable diminue; ce qui souligne l'importance du dépistage et des traitements. L’identification des facteurs de risque modifiables demeure donc grandement pertinente; non seulement pour la prévention de nouveaux cas; mais également pour augmenter les chances de survie. Jusqu'à présent; les études ont principalement porté sur l'évaluation de la contribution des facteurs individuels au risque de cancer du sein et tiennent rarement compte de l'alimentation dans sa globalité et de sa contribution à la capacité antioxydante totale. Plusieurs preuves épidémiologiques et expérimentales indiquent qu’une consommation excessive (mal équilibrée) de lipides alimentaires est un facteur de risque important dans l'étiologie du cancer du sein; probablement par le biais de l’augmentation du niveau de stress oxydatif. Mais les études prospectives réalisées n'ont pas toutes démontré une association entre les graisses alimentaires et le risque de cancer du sein. Ces résultats en apparence contradictoires peuvent être dus à plusieurs facteurs; dont certaines imprécisions dans les questionnaires de fréquence alimentaire et la possibilité que les effets observés dépendent du type d’acides gras contribuant à l'apport total en lipides et aussi aux apports en substances antioxydantes. Notre projet permettra la détermination des substrats à l’origine de la synthèse des radicaux libres et des molécules capables de s’opposer à ces effets lors du processus de la carcinogenèse mammaire.
Skills: Connaissances minimales au sujet de la relation entre le statut oxydants/antioxydants et les maladies chroniques

Name: Text Summarization and Question Generation
Description: Natural language processing (NLP) is one of the most important technologies of the information age. Understanding complex language utterances is also a crucial part of artificial intelligence. Applications of NLP are everywhere because people communicate almost everything in language: web searches; news; advertisements; emails; customer services; language translations; radiology reports; social media; virtual assistants; conversational systems (chatbots); blogs; product comments; etc. I am interested in developing techniques for delivering information that is appropriate and relevant to the user; avoiding information overload and assisting informed decision making. This will lead to build up systems that on the one hand gist; synthesize and abstract information content from documents; and on the other hand capture user needs; intents; and preferences and generate customized; personalized documents. Text summarization and question generation are research directions for solving the information overload and the information fatigue problem. This will result in theories; technologies; and tools to help users obtain the information they need in a clear and useful way; leading to rich information use and efficient decision-making. Text summarization is a process of analyzing one or more documents; extracting the important information; compressing and condensing it; and presenting it in a concise; coherent and readable short text; according to the users' requests and needs. Users can grasp necessary information by reading the short summary generated; hence saving the reading time. Text summarization can be extractive or abstractive. The former is to select important sentences without changing the components of the original sentences; while the latter is to generate new sentences based on understanding; synthesizing; and abstracting the content of the documents. Question generation is a process of generating valid and fluent questions from a given text or passage. Question generation can be used in several scenarios; including reading comprehension; tutoring systems; search engine query suggestions; virtual assistants;
Skills: Natural Language Processing (NLP) is concerned with concepts; models and algorithms to interpret; generate and learn natural languages; as well as applications of NLP. The goal for the students is to be familiar with basic concepts in NLP; understand the algorithms and methods for NLP and acquire the skills for developing NLP tools/systems. I am interested in students with a very good computer science; algorithms; and programming background.

Name: Exploring AI Adoption in Canadian Businesses: A Survey-based Study
Description: This research project aims to investigate the willingness of Canadian businesses to adopt artificial intelligence (AI) technologies. Through a comprehensive survey; we will assess the perceptions; attitudes; and barriers related to AI adoption among businesses across various sectors and sizes. The survey will cover topics such as awareness of AI; perceived benefits and risks; current usage; implementation challenges; and future intentions. The collected data will be analyzed to gain insights into the factors influencing AI adoption and to identify potential strategies for promoting its widespread integration in Canadian businesses. The findings will contribute to a better understanding of the AI landscape in Canada and provide valuable insights for policymakers; industry practitioners; and researchers interested in fostering AI-driven innovation and economic growth.
Skills: The ideal student for this project should possess strong interpersonal skills and be outgoing; as they will be responsible for engaging with business representatives to administer the survey and gather qualitative data. While experience with qualitative data gathering and analysis is desirable; it is not mandatory as training and guidance will be provided. However; the student should demonstrate a willingness to learn and adapt to new research methodologies. Proficiency in communication; organization; and attention to detail are essential for effectively conducting the survey and documenting the responses accurately.

Name: Mobile mapping and place recognition using miniature robots and AI-based cameras
Description: The aim of this research project is to propose a global; real-time geo-referencing solution for miniature autonomous vehicles (bots) within a customizable urban environment made up of roads; road signs and buildings. The solution will also enable the bots to recognize certain locations (e.g. house facades). The bots are equipped with a front-facing camera with a 160-degree fisheye lens capable of broadcasting images with a reliable resolution of 30 frames per second; front-facing time-of-flight sensors (i.e. LiDAR); IMUs and wheel encoders on the motors. All calculations are carried out on board the bots (Raspberry Pi computer or Jetson Nano). The project also involves the use of cameras incorporating artificial intelligence processors. These will be used in both static and dynamic modes; offering complementary views of the environment to those of the bots. The aim here is to carry out research into 3D representation and perception; in a context that exposes users to real-world conditions (noise; variability; partial information; etc.) while preserving control over the environment.
Skills: Good knowledge and skills in image processing or computer vision Knowledge of machine learning Very good knowledge and skills in Python programming Knowledge in the following areas would be an asset: deep learning; deep neural networks; geomatics; robotics; Linux environment Resourcefulness; ability to solve technical problem and creativity Good communication skills to technical and non-technical communities; both verbal and writing Ability to work both individually and as a team member
Student academic background: Engineering; Engg-Computer; Engg-Software; Engg-Electrical; Geomatics; Computer Science

Name: Quantum Sensing using Electron Paramagnetic Resonance
Description: The novel field of Quantum Sensing exploits both the quantum mechanical behavior of atoms; molecules; and nanostructures ; and their exquisite sensitivity to external influences (such as external electric and magnetic fields). The components of a quantum sensor include the quantum system (such as a diamond NV center; or a quantum dot); the control (such as an external electric; magnetic; R.F.; or optical field); and the readout (such as a microwave resonator or other cavity). There are many sensor platforms being developed throughout the world; and each have their unique advantages and disadvantages. In this project; the intern will carry out an environmental scan of quantum sensing technologies that use the principle of electron paramagnetic resonance (or electron spin resonance). The purpose of this environmental scan is to identify the state of the art; the limits of sensing capabilities; and any gaps in the literature. Activities will include a search of databases with research articles; patents; and/or industry documentation. Some small calculations and modelling will be involved to get a feel for the parameters of candidate systems. The intern will also write a report that could form the nucleus of a conference presentation.
Skills: Basic familiarity with quantum mechanics (quantum states; two and three-level systems; Rabi oscillations; measurement) Ability to independently carry out a literature review by accessing data bases Writing a report; and oral communication skills Ethical and professional behaviour; time management skills

Name: Enhancing Business Education through Simulation: Exploring the Feasibility and Potential of Simulation-Based Learning in Business Courses
Description: The project aims to explore the use of business simulation in delivering business courses at the university level. The research involves investigating different technologies and their applicability to simulation-based teaching methods. While simulation-based practice is already prevalent in fields like nursing; this study focuses on conducting a survey of faculty and administration at business schools across Canada. The objective is to determine the level of interest in developing simulation-based business scenarios for enhancing business education. The research aims to provide insights into the feasibility and effectiveness of incorporating simulation-based approaches in business curricula by assessing the interest and potential benefits.
Skills: The student should have a strong background in research methodology and survey design. They should be proficient in conducting literature reviews; collecting and analyzing data; and interpreting survey results. Familiarity with statistical analysis tools and techniques would be beneficial. Additionally; the student should possess excellent communication skills to effectively communicate with faculty and administration at various business schools in Canada. Attention to detail; critical thinking; and the ability to work independently are also important skills for this role.
Student academic background: Sociology; Business; International Business; International Business and Trade

Name: Unlocking Quantum Secrets: Exploring the Convergence of Quantum Computing and Data Privacy Regulations
Description: The research project focuses on investigating the relationship between quantum computing and data privacy regulations; particularly the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) in the European Union. It aims to examine the potential impact of quantum computing technologies on data privacy and security requirements for businesses. The project involves analyzing the implications and challenges faced by businesses in the field of business analytics as they strive to comply with these data privacy regulations in the era of quantum computing. By exploring this intersection; the project aims to provide insights into the evolving landscape of data privacy and security in the context of quantum computing advancements.
Skills: The student participating in this research project should possess a strong background in business analytics; as well as a good understanding of data privacy regulations; particularly the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR). Knowledge of quantum computing concepts and technologies would be advantageous but not mandatory. Additionally; the student should have excellent research skills; including the ability to collect and analyze data; and interpret research findings. Strong critical thinking; problem-solving; and communication skills are essential for effectively exploring the complex relationship between quantum computing and data privacy regulations.
Student academic background: Computer Science; Engg-Computer; Engg-Software; Studies Science and Technology; Science and Technology; Engg-Systems and Technology

Name: Quantum control of molecular qutrits
Description: The novel field of Quantum Sensing exploits both the quantum mechanical behavior of atoms; molecules; and nanostructures ; and their exquisite sensitivity to external influences (such as external electric and magnetic fields). There are recent proposals for using high-spin magnetic molecules as candidates for quantum information processing because of the possibility of qutrit or qudit quantum computing. While qubits are based on two quantum states (or spin-1/2); qutrits are based on three quantum states (or spin-1). As opposed to N-qubits which allow for 2^N numbers; N-qutrits will allow 3^N numbers. In this project; the intern will be able to explore the differences between qubit and qutrit quantum control. Are there a set of universal quantum gates for qutrit quantum computing? How are qutrit computing protocols different from qubit protocols? What are the initialization requirements? There are many open questions to explore.
Skills: Basic familiarity with quantum gates; algorithms; measurement Ability to independently review literature Numerically solve differential equations Some familiarity with Qiskit is an asset Report writing; oral communication Ethical and professional behaviour; time management skills
Student academic background: Computer Science; Engg-Computer; Engg-Electrical; Chemistry; Mathematics; Physics

Name: Financial Planning and Portfolio Optimization with Data Analytics and Artificial Intelligence
Description: The recent global financial crisis has made risk analytics and financial stability a foremost concern of investors and corporations worldwide. Given the rapidly expanding scope and complexity of risk-aware management and finance; mathematical and software innovation is central to the field. Monte Carlo simulation techniques and numerical optimization; which computes portfolio risks and automates the construction of portfolios that best meet specified requirements; is finding novel uses in the field of finance; investments and risk management. Monte Carlo simulation techniques allow modeling future uncertainty of portfolio value and computing financial risks under different scenarios of future events; and optimization techniques can serve as one of the tools for individual investors; wealth managers and companies to find better solutions and improve decision-making. While portfolio optimization algorithms are often applied to solve portfolio construction problems for wealth management and pension planning; translating individual preferences of investors expressed in natural language into optimization problem objective functions and constrains remain a challenge. Based on available data; individual goals and personalized use cases we plan to develop an artificial intelligence software tool that helps formulating optimization problems and guiding users through portfolio selection process. Combining visualizations; natural language processing; machine learning and quantitative algorithms the tool would interactively guide user throughout their portfolio selection journey allowing them to compare portfolios until they arrive at their "ideal" portfolio choice. It is planned that developed software tool would be deployed on a cloud.
Skills: Student background would preferably be in a quantitative field such as data science; information technology; computer science; engineering; mathematics; statistics; economics or finance; but students with other backgrounds that have basic knowledge of data analytics are welcome to apply as well. Required skills are basic mathematics and statistics; understanding of optimization and algorithms; and ability to program in Python; R or Matlab (Python preferred). Familiarity with visualization tools and basic knowledge of finance would be an asset; but are not strictly required.
Student academic background: Actuarial Science; Business; Computer Science; Econometrics; Engg-Computer; Engg-Industrial; Engg-Software; Engg-Systems and Technology; Engineering; Finance; Management Information Systems; Mathematics; Science and Technology; Statistics; Studies Science and Technology; Sociology; Quantitative Surveying; Banking; Economics; Information Studies

Name: Single Photon Avalanche Diode characterization and modelling
Description: Single Photon Avalanche Diode are capable of detecting individual photons providing information about their arrival time and position. Our group is developing SPAD for application in astro-particle physics and various climate change related application. This project will support the development of new SPAD solutions. Our strategy is detail characterization of various processes taking place in SPAD: 1) the onset of the avalanche process; 2) light production during the avalanche process; 3) thermal production of carriers in the presence of high electric field. This project will specifically investigate the process of charge carrier transport within SPAD using a new technique for charge injection called "Two Photon Absorption" (TPA). TPA relies on an infrared laser for producing charge carrier within silicon. This technique has never been used for SPAD characterization and it will be implemented for the first time at TRIUMF in 2024. It will be used to probe the SPAD response uniformity in 3 dimension. The long term aim is to improve SPAD performances and tailoring them for specific applications. One key application is for the search of dark matter interactions in silicon bulk.
Skills: Experience in data analysis and experience in programming either in C/C++ or Python. Experience in work in a laboratory environment. Desirable experience in silicon sensor or devices.

Name: Robotized 3D Geometric Inspection: Enhancing Accuracy and Efficiency in Industrial Quality Control
Description: The project aims to develop a robotized 3D geometric inspection system to improve accuracy and efficiency in industrial quality control. By integrating robotics; computer vision; and metrology; the proposed system will enable real-time and high-precision inspection of complex geometric components. This project seeks to overcome the limitations of manual inspection methods; reducing human errors and enhancing overall production quality. This project focuses on advancing quality control processes in industries using robotized 3D geometric inspection. Manual inspection methods are time-consuming; subjective; and prone to errors. By leveraging robotics and advanced technologies; this project aims to develop a system that offers accurate and efficient inspections of complex geometric components. A comprehensive review of existing research and technologies will be conducted to explore methodologies; algorithms; and tools utilized in the field; with an emphasis on advancements in robotics; computer vision; and metrology applied to industrial quality control. The methodology involves developing a robotized inspection system that combines robotic manipulators; computer vision algorithms; and metrology techniques. This system will be designed to handle complex components and perform real-time inspections with high precision. The methodology includes selecting and customizing a suitable robotic manipulator; developing computer vision algorithms for 3D reconstruction and feature extraction; integrating metrology techniques for calibration and error compensation; and implementing a user-friendly interface for system control and data visualization. An experimental setup will be established to validate the proposed system. This setup will include selecting test components; performing calibration procedures; and collecting data. The collected data will be used to evaluate the system's accuracy; efficiency; and reliability in comparison to manual inspection methods. The obtained experimental results will be presented and analyzed; focusing on metrics such as measurement errors; repeatability; and inspection time. A comparison with manual inspection methods will be provided to highlight the advantages of the proposed system.
Skills: The student undertaking this research project on robotized 3D geometric inspection would benefit from a strong foundation in robotics; computer vision; and metrology. Proficiency in programming languages such as Python or C++ is crucial for developing and implementing computer vision algorithms. A solid understanding of robotics principles and experience with robotic manipulators is essential for integrating the inspection system. Familiarity with metrology techniques and calibration procedures is necessary to ensure accurate measurements. Additionally; knowledge of industrial quality control processes and a proactive approach to problem-solving would be advantageous for the successful completion of this project.
Student academic background: Engg-Computer; Engg-Electrical; Engg-Industrial; Engg-Manufacturing; Engg-Mechanical; Engg-Software; Engineering

Name: Improving Personalized Learning with Data Analytics and Artificial Intelligence
Description: Recent advances in automation and machine learning would significantly reduce demand for many professions. As a result; most professions in the future would require constant learning and improving skills. With the tsunami of information that we have difficulties to process; understand and analyze; interactive courses that can automatically adapt to each person learning patterns and can deliver personalized content would be in high demand. That especially applies to online and distance learning courses; where it is extremely difficult to motivate students and professionals to focus. Advances in mathematics of learning; data science and artificial intelligence can help to design algorithms that would decide what course materials and in what order should be presented to each student. Based on available data; individual goals and personalized use cases we plan to develop an artificial intelligence software tool that helps delivering interactive online courses and guides students and professionals through their learning process. It is planned that this software tool would automatically re-arrange slides and learning materials; decide whether to add quizzes and additional interactive materials to improve learning of an individual taking an online course and motivate people to study. Combining visualizations; natural language processing; machine learning and quantitative algorithms the tool would automatically guide user throughout their course learning journey allowing them to learn faster and more efficiently. It is planned that the developed software tool would be deployed on a cloud.
Skills: Student background would preferably be in a quantitative field such as data science; information technology; computer science; engineering; mathematics; statistics; economics or education sciences; but students with other backgrounds that have basic knowledge of data analytics are welcome to apply as well. Required skills are basic mathematics and statistics; understanding of algorithms and learning process; and ability to program in Python; R or Matlab. Familiarity with visualization tools such as D3 and Java Script would be an asset.

Name: Soft Wearable Haptic Devices using Magnetic Actuation
Description: Advances in materials science; chemistry; mechanical engineering; and robotics engineering have brought soft actuators to interactive devices. A wide range of working principles have been used for developing soft actuators: pneumatics; hydraulics; electroactive polymers; acoustofluidics; electrorheological and magnetorheological fluids. However; current soft actuators possess several limitations which include: slow response; low/no force output; difficulty in precisely controlling them; or require high operating voltages with bulky control setups. Pneumatic actuators are commonly used in soft robotics because of their ability to generate large forces but they need high pressure; have low efficiency; are slow in response; and need noisy actuation valves. On the other hand; electrostatic actuators (e.g. dielectric elastomers) provide a high-frequency response but require thousands of volts with bulky control setups. This prohibits the use of these actuation principles in soft wearable settings. Recently electromagnetic actuation has been receiving a lot of attention because of its fast response; lower actuation voltage; and highly programmable and well-controlled movements. However; their deployment in interactive applications is not fully explored. Current state-of-the-art soft magnetic actuators in HCI are limited to low-resolution and enable only subtle vibration feedback. This project aims to develop high-resolution soft magnetic actuators that can deliver high force output and a variety of haptic sensations. By studying; simulating; and investigating novel device architectures; we aim to develop soft actuators that can be precisely controlled and programmed to open up new possibilities in AR/VR; Accessible computing; sports; and rehabilitation.
Skills: This project requires 1-2 students with a background in any one of the disciplines: Computer Science; Electronics and Electrical Engineering; Chemistry; Materials Engineering; or Mechatronics. The following skills are desirable for students from non-CS disciplines: designing PCBs; designing/working with printed electronics; signal processing techniques; knowledge/experience of simulation engines such as COMSOL/Ansys/FEMM; etc. For Students with a CS background; the following skills are desired: strong implementation skills in one or more of the following: Python; Unity; JAVA/C#.Net; Android; and ML tools (Pytorch/TensorFlow). Highly motivated students with a desire and aptitude to learn new technologies quickly are also encouraged to apply.

Name: Study of the physical and mechanical properties of black spruce and sugar maple wood treated with co-products of the dairy industry.
Description: Wood is an abundant material on earth and has the ability to sequester carbon. In addition; wood is a biodegradable material. These properties make wood a material to be favoured over fossil fuels in the face of global warming. One of the major problems limiting the use of wood as a substitute for fossil-based materials is its ability to absorb and desorb moisture in relation to the relative humidity of the air around it. The absorption and desorption of moisture by wood causes variations in its dimensions; which can lead to cracks; and the presence of moisture in wood provides a living and reproduction environment for the micro-organisms that degrade it. To overcome this problem; reduce wood's capacity to absorb and desorb moisture in order to increase its dimensional stability and strengthen its resistance to micro-organisms; we have developed a new biobased technology that involves impregnating wood with a solution containing a biobased acid and whey ultrafiltration permeate and then heating the mixture to form polyesters (macromolecules) in the wood. These macromolecules formed in the wood will block the main moisture absorption sites in the wood. Measurements of dimensional stability; density; mechanical properties (hardness; modulus of elasticity; bending strength) and resistance to micro-organisms will be carried out to validate this new technology. We are interested in black spruce; sugar maple; trembling aspen and white pine; which are among the species that are abundant in Quebec; chosen for their economic importance; for outdoor and indoor uses; in order to extrapolate this new technology to all other species.
Skills: The student must have a scientific background; such as chemistry; materials engineering; chemical engineering; or any other related field. The student must have a desire to learn new methods and techniques. The student must be motivated and detail-oriented.

Name: Design and Fabrication of Multi-Modal Wearable Health Sensing Devices
Description: Physiological sensors are recently receiving increasing attention in the broad field of computing. While long used in areas related to health and rehabilitation; we are now witnessing an impressive array of new applications in interactive computing. For instance; continuous monitoring of electrocardiogram (ECG) signals informs athletes about their performance; monitoring of electrodermal activity (EDA) enhances computer-mediated emotional communication; and surface electromyography (sEMG) allows for gestural input. Despite these advances; designers seeking to develop new applications are confronted with serious restrictions at the level of the computer-body interface: commercial gel-based electrodes are non-conformal; problematic at body locations that deform; and neither ergonomic nor aesthetic to wear during everyday activities. Secondly; the current state-of-the-art physiological sensing devices can capture only a limited set of signals; typically restricted to electrophysiological signals (e.g. EMG; ECG; or other electrical signals). However; monitoring the electrolyte and metabolite concentration by measuring electrochemical activities in the body will present us with a higher level of granularity in determining the state of health. Sensing electrochemical signals can help in determining various vital signals such as blood glucose levels; blood-oxygen levels; characterization of sweat; etc. In this project; we will be developing novel wearable multi-modal health sensing devices that can not only capture the electrophysiological signals but also electrochemical signals. By leveraging state-of-the-art machine learning and optimization techniques; this project aims to create highly optimized wearable health sensing devices. Another anticipated scientific contribution is the development of novel; widely-accessible; and low-cost fabrication techniques for creating these devices. Taken together; the scientific contributions stemming from this project will have a broad and lasting impact as we envision the techniques to be replicated by other researchers; hobbyists; and industry to easily fabricate custom multi-modal wearable health monitoring devices.
Skills: This project requires 1-2 students with a background in any one of the disciplines: Computer Science; Electronics and Electrical Engineering; Chemistry; Materials Engineering; or Mechatronics. The following skills are desirable for students from non-CS disciplines: designing PCBs; designing/working with printed electronics; signal processing techniques; knowledge/experience of simulation engines such as COMSOL/Ansys; etc. For Students with a CS background; the following skills are desired: strong implementation skills in one or more of the following: Python; Unity; JAVA/C#.Net; Android; and ML tools (Pytorch/TensorFlow). Highly motivated students with a desire and aptitude to learn new technologies quickly are also encouraged to apply.
Student academic background: Chemistry; Computer Science; Engg-Materials; Engg-Electrical; Engg-Computer; Engg-Biomedical

Name: Single Photon Air Analyser
Description: The probability of forest fire impacting urban center is increasing rapidly with the advent of climate change. We are developing a system for early forest fire detection based on sensor concept called "Single Photon Air Analyser" (SPAA). Air is analysed by detecting photon scattered by particulate (smoke) or reemitted due to the fluoresence process. Our design is meant to provide a high sensitivity solution that is cost effective and capable of operating without servicing for a complete season. We are collaborating with the company Sensenet that is developing the complete solution. Our focus is on optimizing the air analyser sensor to enhance the reach of the solution maximizing the area of forest that can be covered by early fire warning sensors. In summer 2024; we are expecting to continue further development of our solution while recording and analysis data from pilot systems.
Skills: The student can be either an environmental science major or a physicist/engineer. In the former case; work would focus on assessing performances of new sensors for the early detection of forest fire to be operated during the 2023 and 2024 seasons. Data taking will be under responsibility of Sensenet with our group playing a major role in data analysis and the student leading the effort. The other side of the project is the development of the next generation sensor. This work will involve characterizing the peformances of the sensor in the lab in a controlled atmosphere.
Student academic background: Engg-Electrical; Engg-Systems and Technology; Environmental Studies; Physics

Name: Exploring the Landscape of Business Analytics and Data Science Degree Programs in North America
Description: This research project aims to investigate and analyze the scope of business analytics and data science degree programs across North America. The objective is to provide a comprehensive overview of the educational offerings in this field; including undergraduate and graduate programs; as well as their curriculum; focus areas; and specialized tracks. The study will involve gathering information from universities and colleges across North America through surveys and data collection. The collected data will be analyzed to identify trends; commonalities; and variations in program structures; course offerings; and industry partnerships. The findings will contribute to a deeper understanding of the current state of business analytics and data science education; helping inform academic institutions; prospective students; and industry stakeholders about the diverse opportunities and evolving trends in this rapidly growing field.
Skills: The required skills/background of the student for this research project include strong research skills; proficiency in data collection methods; and the ability to synthesize information effectively. Prior experience in analytics and data science is not mandatory but would be beneficial. The student should have a solid understanding of research methodologies; data gathering techniques; and the ability to critically analyze and interpret information. Proficiency in literature review; survey design; data collection; and data synthesis is crucial for successfully conducting this project. Additionally; strong communication skills and attention to detail are essential for presenting the findings in a clear and concise manner.

Name: Designing Open Educational Resources for Students to Engage as Biodiversity Scientists
Description: Advancing knowledge and generating solutions to our current biodiversity crisis requires widespread participation. Efforts to engage students and community/citizen-scientists have led to increasing species observations and growing numbers of high quality publicly-available data. When scientists explore this data; new species have been discovered; changes in biodiversity have been identified; and the community has been mobilized to conserve local biodiversity. In our own courses; students have contributed observations of local plants and insects; and their work has identified rare and endangered species that require protection in Calgary. To effectively collaborate and utilize these increasing data to conserve biodiversity; it is especially important for students to now develop skills in finding; critically evaluating; visualizing; and sharing biodiversity information to multiple audiences. To empower our students to become collaborators in this new age of biodiversity research; we aim to create open educational resources (OERs) for upper-level undergraduates and graduate students engaged in ecology and biodiversity sustainability studies. Students will develop skills in extracting information from the primary literature and biodiversity databases; attributing their sources; generating and comparing estimates of ecosystem health; and communicating how our understanding of natural systems changes with new information. Our online OERs will focus on finding; sharing; and disseminating the latest knowledge on plant-pollinator relationships in Calgary; and throughout Canada. Plant-pollinator biodiversity data spans subdisciplines in biology and will introduce students in multiple courses to this next generation of collaborative biodiversity research; monitoring; and conservation.
Skills: Students with some basic background in ecology and biodiversity would be ideal for this position. And interest in science communication and/or education would be an asset.

Name: All-solid-state Li ion batteries and Fuel Cells
Description: Thangadurai group designs and develops highly conductive solid state electrolytes (ionic conductors) and highly electrochemically active electrodes (mixed conductors) for solid oxide fuel cells (SOFCs) and Li ion batteries. The current project involves development of novel oxide ion electrolytes based on perovskite-type and fluorite-type metal oxides; and solid state Li ion electrolytes based on the perovskite; garnet-type; NASICON-type and LISICON-type structures.
Skills: Motivation and interests in materials science and chemistry.

Name: Electrochemical Detection of Antimicrobial Resistance
Description: Drug resistance is a growing problem that severely increases the number of deaths from bacterial infections and cancer. Cellular resistance mechanisms are at the root of drug resistance; which include cell membrane protein modifications; intracellular drug target alterations; and the over-expression of efflux pumps. This project will focus on the detection of resistance mechanisms in bacteria; yeast cells; and isolated mitochondria by electrochemistry. Electrochemical techniques are inexpensive; fast; sensitive; and can be applied to opaque samples. They are the basis of biosensors; which aim to detect diseases; such as bacterial infections. By monitoring the exchange of molecules between the cell and its environment; electrochemistry has the potential to distinguish between drug-susceptible and drug-resistant pathogens. This project will monitor the uptake; retention; and export of important antibiotic substances; such as tobramycin and chloramphenicol; by/from living bacteria by voltammetry and scanning electrochemical microscopy (SECM). SECM is an electroanalytical technique that employs micro or nano-electrodes and has the ability to measure the number of molecules consumed or expelled from a single cell per second. Results obtained through this project will be important in understanding infections and identifying effective treatment strategies for patients.
Skills: Applicants should have a strong understanding of chemistry or biochemistry. Students with experience in electrochemistry will be prioritized. Knowledge in microbiology (bacteria culture; handling of microorganisms) will be an advantage; but it is not expected. Interdisciplinary research students are welcome. Individuals identifying as part of a visible minority are especially encouraged to apply.

Name: Microwave Kirigami Based Strain Sensor
Description: Highly sensitive; and wireless flexible strain sensors would have widespread application across a number of different fields. Here; in this project we are aiming to develop a novel combination of two different metamaterials; one mechanical and one electronic; to demonstrate the potential of the new structures for sensing and communication applications. sensor. An array of split-ring resonators (SRRs) at various operation frequency bands will be designed and integrated to kirigami substrates to act as a mechanically adjustable frequency selective surface. The dimensions; elasticity and the size of the Kirigami substrates will be engineered to accommodate the microwave resonators and to be compatible with the microwave responses and properties of the resonators. Mechanical structure will be confirmed using finite element modeling prior to experiments and microwave structures will also be simulated prior to physical implementation to demonstrated the microwave performance and compatibility. The designed sensor system (Kirigami structure and the microwave) will be investigated in different environmental conditions such as high temperature and various humidity and very low temperatures (-20'C) and various humidity levels of (0 to 90 %). The performance of wireless communication will also be investigated against other microwave signal polluted environments such Bluetooth and WiFi existed environments to investigate the interaction between the sensors' response against those common interferences.
Skills: A student with microelectronics; microwave; mechanical engineering background is preferred. Familiarity with HFSS; COMSOL and other FEM simulators in this research field will be a bonus.

Name: Electrochemical Detection of Cancer and Chemoresistance
Description: Bioelectrochemistry is an emerging field in bioanalytical chemistry and recent applications of electrochemistry to biology include studies on tissue and cancer cells. Scanning electrochemical Microscopy (SECM) is an electroanalytical technique that enables the quantification of molecule exchange between living cells and their environment. This project aims to detect; quantify; and compare biomarkers related to cancer and chemoresistance; such as the production of reactive oxygen species (ROS) in cancer cells and healthy cell tissue. Electrochemical studies of living cells will be conducted using the techniques cyclic voltammetry; chronoamperometry; and SECM. By positioning a micro-electrode close to target cells; electrochemistry can quantify the efflux of molecules from cells in real-time. Living keratinocytes; ovarian cancer; and skin melanoma cells will be investigated for biomarkers; such as ROS; or glutathione. Because ROS are highly reactive molecules that diffuse and disappear quickly; a microscopic tool is needed that can be positioned close to the cell membrane. Ultramicroelectrodes can detect and compare the amounts of ROS naturally produced by different cell lines. Strategies will be explored to induce ROS production through chemical stimulation and UV irradiation. This project has the potential to identify new biomarkers for the rapid detection of cancer by electrochemistry.
Skills: Applicants should have a strong understanding of chemistry or biochemistry. Students with experience in electrochemistry will be prioritized. Knowledge of cell culture will be an advantage; but it is not expected. Interdisciplinary research students are welcome. Individuals identifying as part of a visible minority are especially encouraged to apply.

Name: Detection of damage in concrete members and steel pipes using ultrasonics
Description: Public agencies and society at-large face ongoing structural collapses of aging civil infrastructure because of lack of reliable nondestructive evaluation (NDE) and non-intrusive techniques for condition assessment. NDE methods are faster and more practical and economical than traditional destructive methods; they are essential for the effective condition assessment of infrastructure. Ontario has a pressing need for new inspection; maintenance; and remediation strategies for civil infrastructure demonstrated by recent tragic structural collapses. The goal of this research is to mitigate the collapse risk of civil infrastructure by developing novel and reliable NDE techniques to detect early damage; ensure operational safety; minimize maintenance costs; and inform rehabilitation and replacement efforts. A high-power ultrasonics system and ultra-high-sensitivity infrared camera are requested to advance civil engineering NDE methodologies that will allow simultaneous ultrasonic and infrared imaging analyses. This research will help reduce the economic impact and loss of human life caused by unsatisfactory maintenance and rehabilitation of civil infrastructure. The proposed work is timely and vital to Ontario's economy; it will allow local companies to become global leaders in structural assessment and train students in state-of-the-art practice. The early detection of damage induced by loading; corrosion; and environmental conditions could save lives. This proposed research aims to enable Ontario to optimize the allocation of resources for civil infrastructure repair; rehabilitation; and replacement operations.
Skills: non-destructive testing; signal processing; structural dynamics; vibrations; numerical simulations

Name: New regulators of the NLRP3 inflammasome
Description: Excessive or dysregulated inflammation contributes to the development and progression of numerous diseases including cancer; arthritis and atherosclerosis. If we can understand the fundamental signalling processes driving inflammation it may be possible to design new therapeutic strategies aimed at reducing inflammation and limiting disease progression. Recent work has indicated IRE1; a key mediator of the UPR; may also contribute to the formation of a protein complex called the NLRP3 inflammmasome. NLPR3 inflammasome assembly is a key pro-inflammatory event as it enables casaspe-1 activation; which in turn facilitates processing of pro-IL1b converting it from an inert pro-form to a highly potent bio-active cytokine. Active IL1b has been implicated in the progression of numerous diseases characterised by excessive inflammation. Therapeutic treatments; currently used; are targeted at blocking the effects of already activated IL1b however a better approach could be to limit caspase-1 activation by targeting the NLRP3 inflammasome. To determine the feasibility of such an approach we need to understand the signalling processes contributing to NLPR3 assembly and pro-caspase-1 processing. Recently; we have demonstrated that the endoplasmic reticulum anchored transmembrane receptor IRE1 contributes to structural assembly of the NLRP3 inflammasome formation. We found that reducing IRE1 protein expression; via siRNA; or blocking IRE1 RNase activity; through the use of a small molecule inhibitor; reduced inflammasome assembly; caspase-1 activation and processing of pro-IL1b. As yet we do not understand exactly how IRE1 signalling contributes to assembly of the NLRP3 inflammasome. In this project we will dissect the signalling mechanisms downstream of IRE1 RNase activity and assess how they contribute to NLRP3 inflammasome formation. This project while contributing to our fundamental knowledge of IRE1 signalling will also test whether targeting IRE1 could be a viable therapeutic target for the treatment of inflammation.
Skills: Preferably the student will have a background in cell or molecular biology. I am open to students from other backgrounds who have an interest in understanding signal transduction pathways and their impact on cellular function.
Student academic background: Biochemistry; Biological Sciences; Immunology; Medical Sciences; Pharmacology

Name: Les effets du climat froid sur le taux d'érosion côtière au Canada - The effects of cold climate on coastal erosion rate in Canada
Description: In Quebec (Canada); a freeze-thaw cycle occurs when air temperature drops low enough to freeze water (0 °C); then increases enough for it to thaw again. Freeze-thaw action is a common type of geomorphological processes eroding cliff faces in the temperate climate zone. In such conditions; the exposed frost-vulnerable silt and clay sediments exfoliate and eventually fall off; leading to successive exposure of next layers of sediments getting eroded by frost processes. Under the background of climate change; the freeze-thaw cycle is expected to increase. In this project; we aim to assess their impact of freeze-thaw cycle on the historical studied eroding cliff; based on the local climate conditions. The local climate conditions can be found from the public or private sectors. University of Quebec at Rimouski (UQAR) is part of the Université du Québec network; the largest university network in Canada; with over 100;000 students. Université du Québec à Rimouski (UQAR) is part of the Université du Québec network; the largest university network in Canada; with over 100;000 students. UQAR and the Ministry of Transports Quebec (Government of Quebec) are joining forces to create a research chair in coastal engineering dedicated to the design; construction and maintenance of coastal infrastructure. The Coastal Engineering Research Group will develop cutting-edge knowledge from which will emanate innovative and environmentally friendly solutions to reduce the vulnerability of populations and coastal infrastructure to environmental hazards. The candidates will work with professional researcher; PhD students and master`s students within Coastal Engineering Research Group. The candidates are also provided with an exciting opportunity to carry out research activities; in cooperation with Laboratory of Dynamics and Integrated Management of Coastal Zone (one of most leading group)
Skills: Civil Engineering- Coastal Engineering The students are expected to be highly motivated in research project; and willing to work in a team environment. Background in coastal engineering is an asset.

Name: Performance of riprap to preserve Quebec`s coastline
Description: Canada ( Performance des enrochements pour préserver le littoral québécois
Host Province: Quebec is the largest province of Canada. In recent years; it has become evident that Quebec is losing land and is expected to lose more land in the coming decades due to changes in coastal and riparian dynamics resulting from climate change. Several protection measures (such as riprap) have been constructed along Quebec`s coastline. This internship will mainly focus on the evaluation of rock protection measures in the long-term. This internship will mainly include literature review; data collection and analysis of coastal erosion with/without protections along Quebec`s coastline.
Skills: Either English or French

Name: Analysis of climate conditions in eastern Quebec
Description: Canada - Analyse des conditions climatiques dans l'est du Québec
Host Province: A freeze-thaw cycle occurs when air temperature drops low enough to freeze water (0°); then increases enough for it to thaw again. Freeze-thaw cycle is a critical factor inducing and accelerating coastal erosion in Quebec; Canada. The number of freeze-thaw cycle is largely determined by the seasonal change of air temperature. In this study; we aim to the calculate the freezing index and thawing index; based on the local climate conditions. A seasonal index is defined as the seasonally integrated temperature; which is approximately equal to the sum of daily mean temperatures for the duration of the season. The climate data should be found from the public or private sectors. This internship will mainly include data collection and analysis of freezing; thawing index along Quebec`s coastline; Canada Known as the 'students city' the University of Quebec at Rimouski (UQAR) is part of the Université du Québec network; the largest university network in Canada; with over 100;000 students. Name: 9- Privacy-Preserving Machine Learning for Smart Buildings: Investigating and Implementing Federated Learning Approach
Description: Smart buildings often involve the collection and analysis of large amounts of sensitive data; such as occupancy patterns; energy usage; and personal information. Privacy concerns arise when this data is shared with a central server or third-party entities; increasing the risk of unauthorized access or misuse. In this project; we will investigate; develop and implement machine learning approach named Federated learning; that can indeed be used to address privacy issues in smart building applications. It offers a decentralized approach to training machine learning models while keeping the data local to the devices or systems where it is generated. This study requires careful consideration of various factors; such as communication protocols; synchronization mechanisms; and security measures. It also requires the cooperation and participation of building owners; occupants; and other stakeholders to ensure the success of the federated learning approach.
Skills: machine learning; python programming

Name: Développement d'un modèle de régime thermique le long du littoral québécois
Description: Canada - Model development of thermal regime along the Quebec`s coastline
Host Province: A freeze-thaw cycle occurs when air temperature drops low enough to freeze water (0 °C); then increases enough for it to thaw again. The freeze-thaw cycle plays an important role in the rate of coastal erosion. The candidate will develop a thermal model to study the change of soil temperature along the coastline; in Quebec; Canada. The specific site conditions (such as air temperature; snow conditions; soil properties) will be collected from the study site and used as the input of the model developed. The model developed will be validated using the measured field data. The software GeoStudio will provide for this research project. At the end of project; the candidate is expected to gain the deep understanding and associated operation skills of GeoStudio; one of the popular software for geotechnical engineering. Name: Coastal roads vulnerability
Description: resilience
Host Province: résilience et capacité de récupération des routes côtières en cas de catastrophe
Host Institution: The St. Lawrence River; which links the Great Lakes to the Atlantic Ocean; and its main tributaries form the basin around which most of Quebec's population is concentrated. The Quebec’s coastline is highly populated. About 80% of Quebec's population currently lives on the banks of the St. Lawrence and its tributaries. More than a third of the population of Québec maritime alone lives within 500 m of the shores of the St. Lawrence and more than 90% within 5 km. The St. Lawrence riverbanks are eroding; and the rate of erosion is expected to increase as climate change raises the sea level and more extreme climate conditions (e.g.; flooding). These threats the national roads along the Quebec`s coastline. Coastal developments must therefore take hazards into account and promote an approach based on understanding; mitigating and protecting against these risks. Name: Investigating the impact of the unfolded protein response in triple negative breast cancer
Description: In healthy cells the UPR provides a mechanism by which to restore cellular balance and return to normal functioning. If this is not possible the UPR triggers cell removal by instigating cell death. However; recent research has shown that cancer cells are different. Cancer cells permanently activate the UPR and harness its power as a way to ensure their survival and progression. How cancer cells rewire to sustain chronic UPR activation is not understood nor do we fully understand the broader impact of sustained UPR activation in cancer cells. This project will explore the impact of UPR signaling on the ability of cells to communicate with their surrounding environment. In other words; this project will investigate how the UPR helps stressed cells to “talk”. Using cell biology techniques; such as siRNA; the student will interfere with various components of UPR signaling in cancer cells and assess the impact of this on the production of pro-tumorigenic cytokines and chemokines. This project will help us understand how UPR activation impacts on the ability of a breast cancer cells to interact with and shape their surrounding environment. Techniques used will include tissue culture; siRNA and ELISA’s.
Skills: Preferably the student will have a background in cell or molecular biology. I am open to students from other backgrounds who have an interest in understanding signal transduction pathways and their impact on cellular function.

Name: FPGA/GPU Based Numerical Solvers for Sustainable Energy System Simulation
Description: This project deals with numerical simulation of energy systems (power systems and power electronic converters) for sustainable and renewable energy resources. The research internship might involve any of the following components: mathematical system modeling; control design; numerical solution of differential equations; utilizing machine learning and artificial intelligence techniques; implementation of the solution or control algorithms on digital hardware such as FPGAs; MPSoCs; and GPUs. Good programming skills in C/C++ languages will be an asset. Knowledge of Matlab/Simulink is also expected.
Skills: The background of the intern could be from Electrical Engineering; Computer Engineering; or Computer Science. If the student has a background in power systems modeling and analysis; it is an asset; however; it is not a requirement. Students from other engineering disciplines may also be considered such as Nuclear; Mechanical; and Chemical engineering.

Name: Smart Habit Tracker System to Decrease Stroke Risk
Description: The project aim is to build a Smart Habit Tracker System / Health Coaching System that can track healthy habits and guide users (elders or users) by providing recommendations for habit changes on a continuous lifestyle basis to reduce stroke risk. Furthermore; early warning and response an imminent need for stroke risk management so there is a need to develop a Health-Coach system to track patients' habits; monitor stroke risk and alert clinicians if unhealthy habit can cause stroke risk levels to get high; thus decreasing first response time in stroke diagnosis. Methodology: stroke risk level is predicted by machine learning techniques; and then the XAI strategy is employed to get detailed insights into the factors that cause stroke in a patient. The Explainable Artificial Intelligence (XAI) health coach component of the system recommends the users' habits that they can endeavor in order to reduce their stroke risk levels. The users would then use the habit tracker system to track these habits on a continuous basis for a period. They would then get a detailed report on how their stroke risk has changed over a period; resultantly decreasing stroke risk levels in an individual. Lastly; the system would enable Remote Health Coaching (RHC) feature wherein patients can use Smartwatch with integrated medical sensors to continuously monitor their vitals in real-time and the machine learning model would simultaneously predict the stroke risk; if the stroke risk reaches concerning levels; the users and clinicians would be alerted to take the necessary course of action. Significance: This health-coaching framework can help patients in decreasing the risk for stroke and hence act as a stroke prevention approach for users. It can help guide users to inform them about their health condition and help them manage their stroke risk by tracking their habits and stroke
Skills: Basic background in Explainable AI. Basic knowledge in machine learning skills Strong programming skills (preferred python and R). Basic knowledge about health monitoring systems. Basic knowledge about source code management (like Git protocol).
Student academic background: Computer Science; Engg-Biomedical; Engg-Biological; Engg-Computer; Engg-Software; Molecular Biology; Statistics
